If you looking a good quality lunch, picking something for dinner, this new Hainan chicken joint is the place to come.  Clean, quick and very reasonably priced, and friendly service!
"Ordered: 
- Hainan Chicken (single order) with Chicken Rice $10.48 
- Beef Brisket Curry with Jasmine Rice $11.95

I have been searching for the best Hainan Chicken in Metro Vancouver and my expectation was high since this place was recommended by a friend.

Little to my surprise, the restaurant layout was more like a fast food restaurant, although bright and comfortable. There were only three main courses on the menu - sorry to those who don't eat beef or chicken. You would have to order at the cashier, take a number, and take your food at the counter.  They serve their food in disposable container (not very environmentally friendly).... 

Any way, let's move on to the food - 
Hainan Chicken - average - I've had better. Chicken rice - not very fragrant, didn't have much chicken escent. The sauces were okay.
Curry Beef Brisket - too salty! - not ""soft to the bite"" enough, small portion, not worth 11.95

Not sure if I would come back again...for a while."
Quick, flavourful chicken if you're craving Hainan chicken. Love that it's dark meat! The half chicken is better value for sharing for 2 people, and if you're really hungry, one person can finish it. For a family, definitely go for the full chicken. So happy to find this across the street from where I live!
"在溫哥華這樣一個移民城市裡，匯聚了世界各地的特色餐廳，星馬泰美食當然也必不可少。只可惜許多亞洲餐廳由於食材來源跟原創地有所差異而只能改良成為適應加拿大的風格。所以我每次吃到這種改良版的星馬菜，總覺得有點失落，就盼著哪天才能吃到原汁原味的當地特色。今天光顧這家海南廚房，顧名思義可以猜想到餐廳主打的是星馬美食，更以新加坡風味的海南雞為招牌菜。餐廳的餐點確實稱得上少而精，只有海南雞、咖哩雞、咖哩牛腩三款可供選擇，另外還有一些港式飲品提供。

餐廳的內部裝飾同樣是簡而清，配合落單方式和用完即棄的塑膠便當餐盤，感覺有如商場美食中心的格局。顧客先到櫃檯落單付款，等候取餐作堂食或外賣帶走，食完後將即棄餐盤及剩菜放到回收箱，全部自助形式進行，不要期待任何服務！"
"Self Serve set up. Small menu option. Essentially Hainese Chicken single order, half chicken or full chicken, curry beef brisket or curry chicken. And drinks. That's it. Seat yourself. My fav was the beef brisket. I expected more from the Hainese Chicken but found it ""ok"". I've had better. I found the meat to be tougher & drier - maybe I'm just use to soft, soggy, North American chicken?! Anyways overall I thought it was ok. Not sure it's worthy of being in the regular rotation."
"As the name says this is a specialty restaurant for Hainanese Chicken, recently opened, simple decor and its set up is like a food fair stall; you order and pay and pick up for either take out or eat in.
Tried their Chicken and Curry Beef, the Chicken is average. The Chili and Green Onion/Ginger sauce is not bad. Chicken is boneless, tender. The Chicken Rice pilaf was done just right; flavourful and not oily! 
The other dish is Curry but there is not a hint of curry spice in the dish! This is more like Beef Ragout/Stew, if that's what it really is then it's good, but it's supposed to be Curry Beef!?
Kitchen service is slow as there is only one staff, plus the cashier, as I was waiting for my order more and more customers arrive I can clearly see that the kitchen is overwhelmed! Hope they will have more staff so that they won't have customers waiting for too long, as the place is set up as a fast food joint!
Anyways, will be back to try out the Curry Chicken and see if that will have more Curry flavour!!"
The hainese style chicken tastes very good, sauces are flavourful as well. Only blemish for this place is that the lemon tea tastes terrible.
"Hai there Hainan Kitchen! I always love welcoming new restaurants with a different twist on classics. 

Their main dish is Hainanese Chicken but I have to say it's not like the typical super smooth, slippery marinated chicken I'm used to when I think of Hainanese chicken. Their chicken is still top-notch with it being tender but it's not a silky smooth texture - it's just tender chicken. Regardless, the flavours are there to create that harmonious and delicious Hainanese taste. Dipping the chicken that's already been bathing in the sweet soy sauce into the crisp spicy chili sauce and the savoury garlic/green onion sauce is a perfect combination! Then add in the not too oily rice that has been steamed in the chicken broth and it's protein and carb deliciousness!

The salad that came with it was crisp and the dressing was a sweet, tangy compliment. 

The seating area is clean and simple. The menu is straight-forward and not overwhelming - with other menu items like a beef curry and specialty drinks like HK Style drinks like milk tea and lemon tea. Free parking at the complex. Hainan Kitchen is next to Chatime.

Overall, a great new place to have a good meal and drink!"
"This restaurant has a very small menu which makes ordering fairly straight forward. I really like hainanese chicken so I made it a point to try this place when I was in Richmond. My date ordered the beef brisket curry. Food is served food court style. 

The chicken was good. The chicken rice was alright. I was expecting the rice to be more aromatic, oily and flavourful. The sauces were great. The salad was average. The lemon honey drink tasted as expected. I tried a bite of the beef brisket. The beef was tender and flavourful with a strong coconut milk undertone.

My main complaint is that they can be a bit more environmentally friendly by using less disposable items. Everything is geared towards take out style.

The restaurant accepts credit card which is a plus. There is ample plaza parking available. They should also try to clean their restrooms daily as I only used the restroom to wash my hands. I can tell by looking at the sink and toilet, it has not been cleaned in weeks. There was no paper towels to dry hands. It is probably a good idea to skip the restroom unless you desperately need to use it."
Everything was pretty straightforward; ordering was simple and quick. Food arrived shortly after ordering and the portion size was good. The chicken was tender and juicy and came with multiple sauces that blended in nicely with the rice.
"Atmosphere: Very bright and modern inside, lots of space for 2 - 4 people. 

Price: Market Value

Customer Service: Friendly customer service. 

Food: Hainanese chicken rice is what I came for on recommendation. The chicken is average but the portions were respectable."
Their food is yummy!!! They even take the chicken bones out for me. I love the rice flavors.
"Located in the busy Garden City Plaza. Parking could be hard to find depending on the time of the day. Small but clean restaurant. Seating was rather limited; however. 

We ordered a half-Hainanese chicken for take out @ $15.98. It came with sauce, salad, and rice.  The chicken wasn't bad and it was completely deboned. The texture of the meat was also good. I've had  Hainanese chicken where the meat was way too soft in a disgusting kind of way. Overall, the dish was ""ok"" - it was yummy but nothing about it screamed ""wow"" - exactly a 3 star in my mind. 

What I didn't like was that even when you dine in, they used those plastic bento box containers and utensils. The service was also extremely slow. It appeared that they were quite understaffed. The cashier was also not very friendly.  Essentially, it was basically higher-priced food served in food court style setting.

As you can see from my photo, the menu selection is rather small. I may come back for the beef brisket."
If you're looking for Hainanese chicken, this is the place to get it. The chicken is incredibly tender and the rice is full of flavor. But the best thing about it is the green sauce that comes with the chicken, 1000X better than the traditional ginger/scallion oil. I can't wait to be back in town to eat here again.

"Amazing Hainanese chicken. Deboned too, which is so convenient.

The chicken flavoured rice is soft, fluffy (not mushy), and so flavourful.

The condiments are the best part. There's the usual ginger onion sauce and sweet chili sauce, but they also make this green onion pesto like sauce that's so addictive. Tastes like everything is homemade.

Full chicken rice is only $30, which is huge value for the quality. You get a full deboned chicken, two boxes of rice (choice of regular or chicken rice), and the three condiments."

Portion size was pretty good, chicken was tender and the sauce was flavourful.  Only thing I didn't really like was their lemon tea so can probably skip that. "Great Hainan chicken at an affordable price.

I've had many Hainan chicken dishes in Richmond and I would put this in my top 3. This place serves only 2 dishes: Hainan chicken and Singaporean-style chicken/beef curry. I mainly come here for the Hainan chicken, however. Each serving of the Hainan chicken dish comes with your choice of plain white rice or flavourful yellow rice, salad, the usual dipping sauces, and either a quarter, half, or whole bird. They also serve half the chicken as white meat and the other half as dark meat. When I first tried the chicken, I expected the white meat to be dry, but to my surprise it was actually juicy. Normally, I would prefer dark meat because it is always tender and flavourful, but this restaurant makes white meat Hainan chicken extremely satisfying.

The restaurant is set up mainly as a fast food joint, so don't expect staff to serve you while you're seated. However, do expect to enjoy some great food dining-in or taking-out!"

"Visited for the first time today. Small store with limited seating. Decor is bright and simple. Newly renovated so the seating area seemed clean.

I have tried their Hainanese chicken & rice.  It tasted pretty good and I quite like their sauces.  It is a little pricy but It is a decent take out place for a fast & flavourful lunch.  I rather come here now than going to Master Hung across the street for lunch.
"They only serve 3 dishes - Hainanese chicken rice, beef brisket curry and chicken curry. 

I'm not really sure if it's Singapore Hainanese chicken rice they are trying to re-create. In any case, you will never find such yellow rice for Hainanese chicken rice in Singapore. It seemed common in Vancouver. I asked other restaurants about that yellow rice before and was told it was due to chicken fats. I don't buy that story since you can probably find more chicken rice stalls in Singapore per square feet than in any other places, and I have never seen that kind of rice. 

The chicken is not the traditional Hainanese style where the chicken is poached and then dipped in an ice bath to prevent over cooking. It will also create a cold chicken meat with slippery skin. Personally I do not like cold chicken so I am ok with warm chicken meat. I prefer the roast chicken version which cannot be found here. 

Chili sauce makes or breaks the dish in Singapore and this is not the best. Then again, all the sauces here are never similar to those in Singapore. 

For Vancouver, I think this is an average dish but definitely not worth driving out to Richmond for. 

Maybe that explained the empty restaurant when we were there. I was expecting it to be crowded from the reviews here."
Yum! I'm not usually a big fan of Hainanese Chicken but this place changed my mind. The chicken is nicely cooked and the sauces are the perfect addition. It's also a plus that I don't have to work at picking out chicken bones since it's deboned. I will definitely be back!
"Few weeks ago, I went to a newly opened Singaporean eatery, Shiok. During its soft-opening week, I heard some good things about it, and it is hard to find authentic Singaporean cuisine in Vancouver. So, I decided to pay a visit with Ethan. 

We arrived at 5:30 pm on a Saturday, and it started to get crowded around 6 pm. We grabbed our seat first, prior to ordering. This eatery is partially self-served. We need to order the food at the counter first. Then servers will bring over the food to the tables. 

The menu has limited items in each category, but they also have special items written on the blackboard that change in a rotational basis. 

We ordered Kopi-C and Teh. The owner said that the main difference between Singaporean coffee and others is that Singaporean coffee beans use butter in the roasting process, which gives a thicker and smoother texture. Kopi-C is Singaporean coffee with carnation milk, while Teh is a tea with condensed milk. Both are not bad, and they pair well with the meal. 

Kueh Pie Tee is one of the special items, and the dish comes with 5 pieces. Inside the crispy shells, there are carrots, shrimp, and peranakan spice of jicama. Though the appetizer has a crunchy texture, it is bland. I hope to have sauce or additional spice in each piece.

I ordered Laksa, which is an authentic Singaporean dish. It is a curry soup base, and you can choose between white or yellow noodles, or mixed. The bowl comes with bean curds, fish cakes, shrimps, and half of the hard boiled egg. The noodles are slightly over-cooked, but the soup is flavourful. The portion is perfect for me, but it is relatively smaller size than normal. 

He ordered another special item, Beef Rendang. It is a spicy curried coconut beef, serviced with rice. Though it is only $10, the portion is what you pay for. The taste is okay, but nothing stands out to make it special. 

 * Overall Impression *

I've heard a lot of good things about Shiok prior to our visit, but I think the dishes are hit and miss. The price on the menu is inexpensive, but the portion is relatively smaller. So for Ethan, he can easily eat two Beef Rendang in addition to the appetizer and drink. It is a family-owned restaurant, so everyone is friendly. As a restaurant in the soft-opening stage, its service is good, and there are no delays on orders.  

Taste : 3.5/5 * Service: 3.5/5 * Ambiance: 4/5 * Quality-Price: 3.5/5"
"The problem with high expectations is that it is seldom realized. This was Shiok for me. 
Let's highlight the positives.  About time we had a Singaporean restaurant in town. Simple set up, but clean and efficient.......if you help to clear your own dirty dishes. Prices are very reasonable. Flavours for beef Rendang and Chili Squid and Shrimp was good. Presentation is weak compared to Asian restaurants in town.  Laksa lacked flavour, even though it is the most nicely presented dish. Owners and family were very friendly and sincere. 
Negatives, unfortunately at the end of the day, would I come back? Not for a while I think, as the overall experience did not live up to expectations. 

At the end of the day, I wish them success and hope they keep improving. We need more restaurants like this in town."
"Months ago I saw this little place getting ready to open and knew I must give it a try as there are not many Singaporean restaurants in Vancouver. 

A few weeks ago, I went for lunch and had an opportunity to share a bunch of items with friends. All in all, I enjoyed the food & the service was great. For Saturday lunch, they opened at 11:30am but a line up already started forming at 11:15am. When the doors open, the place was packed in 10 mins. The restaurant is small and hold under 30 people.  The turn over is fast, like around 30ish minutes, as it's an eat and go place and people don't linger knowing there is a line up. 

You order the food at the counter, given a number to place at your table and the food is then delivered to your table. When finished, take your plates, utensils and cups to the dirty dish cart. This keeps the price down and I have no problem in helping this family run place. 

We had:
Chicken Wings: lightly touched with shrimp paste and crispy. It came to the table hot and crispy. 
Roti Prata: roti was light and crispy on the outside but soft inside. The gravy had a nice kick of heat.  Not creamy like curry. Don't know if this is how it should be or just water down that day. We saw many people ordering this and they enjoyed it. 
Boneless Chicken Rice: you can choose either white or dark meat and we selected dark. A lighter note than the traditional Hainanese chicken rice but they were not there to copy it. This is their version and it was good. The dip for the chicken was a dark and thick but sweet soy sauce. Again different from the classic green onion and ginger sauce. 
Laksa: choice of yellow or white noodles so we took the white rice noodles. This laksa smelled wonderful but the taste was on the light side. Not as creamy or flavourful as others I have tried. Should have taken the yellow noodles. 
Iced kopi coffee which is served with condense milk: strong, cold and sweet. 

I would come back to try other items on the menu."
I have been here at least 6-7 times the past few months since they had their soft opening. They truly do have authentic Singaporean style food here which is very pleasant. The food is absolutely delicious. It is a family ran business and they do a good job and being able to handle busy times in regards to how long the food takes to get served after you order and pay in advance. Great place to have lunch !
"Solid 4.5 stars for this humble indoor hawker eatery owned by a true blue Singaporean family. Reasonable prices and some really nostalgic homegrown dishes to enjoy here. Particularly loved their shrimp paste chicken, laksa and nasi lemak rice, achar, and chicken congee with that signature maggi powder taste. Also their sweet sambal chilli is the bomb I could eat that as a meal itself. For those that like spicy and strong flavours where u have steam out of ur ears, theirs is on the milder side but it suits me just fine :) think they can improve on their bak kut teh 
And maybe the chicken rice though! Expect a very casual self serve ambience. When I miss Singapore like crazy at least shiok keeps me relatively sane. Hope they survive through covid - support local businesses!"
Made a visit with some friends. The food was absolutely delicious!! We practically got everything on the menu except for the vegetarian dishes. The curry puff pastry was so soft and filled with delicious potato and boiled egg! My favourite was the chicken rice and laksa! It has a rich broth and delicious ginger rice for the CR. The only downfall was the otak otak (fish cakes). It was SO TINY and not worth it! Shiok's prices are similar to Hawker's Delight on Main but the food is WAY better here!!!
"Heard there was a new Singapore restaurant. My daughter & I checked it out. It is on Kingsway, if you are going westbound, it is passed Victoria Dr, street parking available but limited. Newly decorated with clean & simple decor. You have to order before you find a table. If you have a big group of people, I highly recommend you come early. You have to decide what you want first. You order & pay at the counter, they are friendly & patient. Self serve on your utensils & if you want cold water. Nice touch in adding lemon to the water urn. We ordered chicken rice with a mixed of dark & white meat (no extra charge) , they asked what you prefer- dark or white meat. Laksa with white & yellow noodles, the white noodle is your typical ""lai fun"" that comes with the laksa. The yellow noodles is the fresh egg noodles. We also ordered the chicken wings fried in prawn paste. We ordered curry puffs,mee rebus, pandan chiffon cake, longan jelly & pandan cassava cake for take out.
The chicken rice was flavourful & the chicken rice chilli was spot on. The laksa gravy was thick & good, they serve it in the typical ""rooster"" bowl, very nostalgic. The laksa is served with laksa leaves, sliced prawns, sliced fish cake & blanched bean sprouts- an enjoyable dish. The fried chicken was piping hot, you can smell a hint of the prawn paste, we enjoyed it very much, $5 got 6 pieces of drumstick & mid wing portion is reasonable. My daughter liked the longan jelly & the pandan chiffon cake was good, worth $3 a slice, light & airy with full of pandan smell & flavour. The pandan cassava cake taste like cassava- I would give it a miss.
My husband loved the mee rebus. All in all, a great new place for Singapore food! Will definitely come back again to try the rest of the mains on the menu. 
Please be kind & remove all your dirty dishes into their appropriate buckets for them. Then the next group of patrons can find a table quicker, the staff are quick to quickly clean the table after you clear up your own dirty dishes."
"Wow! It's been awhile since I've found a Singaporean or Malaysian cuisine restaurant that I've thoroughly enjoyed! I'm happy to report that Shiok Singapore Cuisine delightfully surprised me with it's authentic flavour! This is a family run place where you order at the counter and then seat yourself. It is similar to that of a canteen/cafeteria set up. Remember to put away your dishes when you're done eating! Oh, and they also have a points card! For every $10 you spend, you get a stamp. Collect 10 stamps to get any 1 item on the menu free. 

Here's what we ordered:
Mee Siam: 4/5 My dad enjoyed this noodle dish, but I didn't like its flavour profile. You can definitely taste the tamarind in it. I haven't seen this dish on many other SE Asian restaurant menus so I would try it out if you haven't before. 

Boneless chicken with rice: 4.5/5 My chicken rice craving was satisfied with this dish! Not only was it not greasy like some other places, but the flavour was perfect as well! I would have liked for a bit more chicken, but at $10 a plate with a bowl of soup, who can complain! I also like how they give you the option to choose white meat, dark meat, or both!

Laksa: 5/5 The flavour of this laksa broth was unreal! It was fresh, thick and legit! Many other places I've been to dilute the soup. Hands down one of the best laksa I've had in the Greater Vancouver area! They offer you the option of white rice noodles, yellow noodles or both. 

Teh Alia (ginger milk tea): 3.5/5 The ginger flavour was noticeable but not overpowering. For me, I like my ginger tea strong and spicy so that's why I'm giving it a 3.5.

Shiok Singapore Cuisine, I will definitely be back regularly!"
I had the chicken rice which was amazing. The roti prata was good as well. However, I felt like the curry was a little watery and felt more like soup. Although the food was very authentic, I felt like the portions were a little too small for the price. The tables were too close to each other and I found myself squeezing through to get to my seat. Otherwise, it was a good experience and I look forward to visit again.
"Shiok是一間家庭式經營的星洲菜小館，於2019年6月開業。店名「Shiok」是新加坡俚語用來形容食物""好味Yummy!""的意思。店家的特色是由落單、付款、找位坐、餐具飲水及將用過的餐具送到指定回收處都是自助形式，服務生只會將你點的餐送到桌上，這種安排也算是一種彼此互動吧！如果你想要熱水的話，可請員工代勞送來

餐廳的餐點選擇不多，四款小吃包括炸雞翼、印度手撕餅、沙爹和釀豆卜，主食六款有海南雞、叻沙、娘惹咖喱雞、泰式炒粉、乾咖喱牛肉及辣拌海鮮，都是星馬的知名美食。最後是幾款廚師推介小食、多士和咖啡。價錢方面主食全部劃一$10元，看似非常經濟抵食，但實質份量偏小，以我的食量起碼要兩份主食再加小吃才會夠飽啊！"

We especially loved the piping hot, crispy and flavourful prawn chicken, the flaky shredded chicken potato curry puffs, and tasty beef rendang. The laksa was good too with shrimp paste flavour. One of us really liked the tau pok. Nice, friendly Singaporean owner manned the till. He accepts credit cards. Approx $35. He came around to ask how we liked his food. "Amid the virus crisis, this place is only open for takeout or delivery now!
The door was barred when I arrived. The guy inside used a broom to push open the door and asked for my order name. He then put my order that was all packed up on the table separating us. I grabbed my order and the door closed behind me. You can tell they were being very careful handling orders and eliminating chances of the virus spreading. 

I ordered the Mee Siam, Hainanese chicken rice, fried wings, laksa with egg noodles and chap chai.
The Mee Siam and laksa were my favorite. Both were very flavourful and true to what I've had in Singapore. The hainan chicken was good too. Rice was very fragrant, the chicken was good but not super moist. if you've had amazing chicken rice in Singapore you know what I'm talking about! The wings were also crispy and juicy. I could've done without the chap chai. There's nothing extraordinary about this dish but I wanted some veggies to go along with my meal.

All in all, I would come back and try some of the other dishes or just to satisfy my mee siam craving!"
Excellent Chicken Curry, Prata and Rendang.  The chicken curry gravy and Rendang has authentic spices and flavor.  Very friendly owner.
"Great to have more Singapore/Malaysian food options.  

Newly opened. Friendly staff and clean.
You order at the cash till, pay, get a # and they bring the food to you. 

Their portions are similar to hawker style portions in Asia. So don't expect large North America sizes.

Roti - good size but a big soggy. My son enjoyed it
Satay sticks - small but tasty!!!
Laksa - chockfull of goodies and for me, it was plenty spicy
Haianese chicken:  chicken not much taste but the rice was delish!
Tau Pok - tofu stuffed with beansprouts. Too weird for me
Teh - Very smooth and would recommend!
Chicken wings: Tasty, crispy and yes, there is a prawn spiced taste! sort of like a shrimp chip coating. Love it!

You also get a customer stamp card.  Every $10 spent, get a stamp. 10 stamps get you a free item.  This can easily add up in 3 visits if you enjoy tasting everything. 

You put away the dirty dishes. Honestly, I don't mind at all. Just a little bit of mindfulness goes along way and helps keep prices down. 

I would go again, especially for the chicken wings and of course, try the other items."
"Shiok is a good Singaporean restaurant that has just recently opened. The food here is delicious. They make their dishes really well and what's even better is that it's priced pretty well too! Win win! The downside of the place is that it's small. Like really small. They can fit maybe 20 people? 

Maybe. 

Ambiance isn't anything special. The people who work there are friendly though and respectful. With regards to service. The staff brings the food out to your table. But when you're done eating. You'll need to bring your dishes to the dirty dish tray yourself. 

Overall. I'd give Shiok a 4/5 rating."
"Finally came here after driving by so many times.  You order at the counter, they give a number on a small stand and you find a seat. I'd recommend finding seats first though as it gets busy.   You also grab your utensils, water, etc at the counter. They'll bring the food and any drinks/extras you ordered.

We ordered the laksa, mee siam and some chicken wings.  The laksa was really good. I got the yellow noodles for it.  It has sliced shrimps, tofu, bean sprouts and I think some sliced fish tofu. It had a nice kick to it but not so much that you lose your taste buds. 

The mee siam was actually more sour than we thought but I probably should have taken the hint when the guy said ""It's sour, you still want?"".  The menu says its sweet, sour and spicy noodle so my mind thought of normal sweet and sour type. 

The wings were good too.  The outside was crispy, the inside was tender and overall, good flavor.  One thing was they are a little small.

All the mains were the same price so I wasn't expecting large portions but they are a decent size for the price.  The place looks small from the outside but can probably fit around 25 people or so."
"A friend recommended this place & Shiok did NOT disappoint. During these uncertain times, they have taken all the right steps to keep their customers & themselves safe. 

Easy to ordering through their website. Fast turn around time.  Straightforward pick up at the front door. Bonus points for their minimal takeout packaging.

Oh yeah, about their food:) I have ordered the Laksa, Roti, Wings, Beef pastry & Mushroom Vegetarian dish. All delicious. Very flavourful. 

I am a fan!"

Boasted with comfy seating, air conditioned environment, this half service restaurant is friendly and promises to bring back memories from Southeast Asia  Roti Prata, Laksa, and Mee Siam were ordered that night and we especially enjoyed the Laksa  Roti Prata was tougher than the ones we usually had. The Mee Siam was a delightful dish as not a lot of places offer it. Unique tangy flavours coming from the tamarind gravy really gives this dish a kick! Looking forward to trying their other dishes
"Family came here for a Saturday dinner. Walk in only. Last call is at 7:30pm. 

It feels like a food court style restaurant: order and pay first, find your seat and wait to be served. Kitchen starts preparing your order after you are seated. Remember, return your dishes and clear the table after meal.

I can take very spicy food. Therefore, I found the spicy dishes here were mild. Also, I do not prefer savoury dishes with a stand out sweet taste. As a result, the dishes here were on the sweet side for me. As someone enjoys strong tea, I found the Teh here lacked the flavour of the tea.

Overall, I think this place is better for take out with good value."
Food here is decent but it's either over or under seasoned. I had the Mee Siam, it had the sweet, sour, and spicy but it for overwhelming in the end because it was salty. I also ordered the fried chicken wing, and it was bland. I ended up dipping the chicken wing in the Mee Siam's sauce.
Enjoyed the wings, chicken satay, laksa and Chicken rice. All were delicious and good portions for lunch. Might need a dish more for dinner. The teh Tarik was great. Will be back for the wings. Yum!
I come from Malaysian/Singaporean descent so when I heard about this place, i was so excited to try it. The concept is that you order aT the till, find a seat, then the food comes to you. We ordered the chicken with rice (very small portion. Needed more flavour), mee siam (a little too sweet and watery), roti and kaya toast (both very delicious would order again), bak kuh teh - I know it's supposed to be peppery but this was overly pepperY and the long donut we ordered with it was rock hard. "Shiok is a newish Singaporean restaurant that opened up on Kingsway in mid-2019. I dropped by for some takeout in early October. The food's pretty good so I might wind up coming back to try their dine-in service.

First off, let me just say that their takeout packaging is a bit more unique than other places. Most of my items came wrapped up in butcher block paper. That might not be unusual if you're picking up a steak at the local butchery but I've never had a curry dish wrapped up in butcher block paper before. It does keep the packaging size down to a minimum (but your food winds up looking book-shaped).

A must at any Singaporean restaurant has to be the Roti Prata ($3) which is a flatbread served with chicken curry sauce. While flaky, I found it to be a bit denser than other versions I've had before but it's still pretty good.

The Boneless Chicken Rice ($10) is their Singaporean version of Hainanese chicken rice. To be honest, I found the rice to be a bit on the dry side. I was able to offset this a bit by using the leftover curry sauce from the roti.

I was really pleased with the Beef Rendang ($10) due to the meaty and flavourful beef. They slowly cook this until it's fork-tender and it has a nice spicy flavour to it.

The Chicken Wings ($5) were really unique and I've never had this kind of flavour in chicken wings before. The wings are deep-fried and coated with some type of prawn-spice which really imparts an umami flavour.

Last up was the tasty Chicken Satay ($5) served with a thick peanut sauce.

So, the food's pretty good but the take-out packaging leaves a bit to be desired - although I give them props for using compostable packaging (at least I think butcher block paper is compostable). Your best bet might be to dine-in but just note that it can be difficult to find street parking (especially if you visit when the no stopping on the street due to rush hour is being enforced)."
"Small Singaporean eatery

Shiok doesn't open late for dinner, so be sure to check the hours before heading over

The Roti was pretty tasty and the dip has a kick to it

The laksa was pretty flavorful and you can taste the coconut milk for sure. We chose the white and round rice noodles to go with the laksa

The Hainan chicken came with boneless chicken, rice and soup. Maybe it's because I came in 30min before closing and the rice tasted like it was scraped from the bottom of the pot, hard and dry

I would come back to try their other dishes"
Excellent Chicken Curry, Prata and Rendang.  The chicken curry gravy and Rendang has authentic spices and flavor.  Good quality curry puff too.   You can request for white or dark meat for the chicken rice.  Very friendly owner.
As a local in the neighbourhood I was super excited to see this restaurant open. I have been a few times including their soft opening and I have been pleasantly surprised at how great it is. Laksa is one of my go tos and they do a great job with it. The staff, the family aspect- amazing. They are all so sweet and welcoming! Everything is pretty spicy so keep that in mind if you're not a spice lover. Must try in the area!!
"After discovering this place, my family is in love. The food here is well priced and the portions aren't too bad, especially for lunch. For singaporean eats, it is not too oily but still very tasty. My family especially loves their beef rending puffs and chicken curry puffs. The filling inside is delicious and make for a perfect snack and accompaniment to their main dishes.

I love their chicken rice, as they allow you to choose white meat and the rice itself is soft and flavourful. The beef rendang and prawn noodle are also family favourites. Roti and satay are only okay but the food definitely  makes us coming back for more and more! 

The owner is also really friendly and being such a small little place, they need some support during this time. 

Overall, should've tried it sooner, so now YOU, just go."
It is a nice little self serve restaurant. Food is tasty and good size for a small eater. I like it.
"The restaurant is located in a fairly low traffic part of Kingsway, so parking on the side streets was easy to find. Decor in the restaurant has a rustic feel, with wooden accents and furniture used throughout. Like I expected from a Singaporean restaurant it was very tidy and clean, and would probably easily earn an A rank back home. 

Shiok is a self service restaurant, so customers are expected to place their orders with the cashier, grab a number, grab their cutlery/water, and then sit down at a table. For 2 or 3 people, this is fairly easy. But for larger groups of 6-7 people, it is much more problematic. Not that I expected a maitre'd to be available to seat us, but Shiok seemed unprepared to handle large groups, especially during busy dinner hours. Service was friendly, and generally very polite but still - unprepared.

Now onto the food.

Lots of great comments about the food. Roti prata comes in a healthy portion, and tastes fluffy and moist. Their chicken rice perfectly captures the traditional smell and flavor. Satay is well roasted, cooked correctly and goes fantastic with their homemade peanut dipping sauce.  The chili squid and shrimp had that wonderful kick to it that burned so good while retaining its sweetness. The laksa had a flavorful, rich broth and a good variety of toppings.

Some misses with the food. Beef rendang was way too sweet rather than salty, and had a very gamey texture. Tofu puffs lacked flavor and felt overcooked.  

Overall food-wise - Shiok hits the flavors dead on for a lot of the dishes, and tastes exactly like a Singaporean hawker stall. And that's hard to do well.

Price wise, Shiok feels like it's all over the place. For the most part the appetizers felt like a great deal, coming in a $3-5 dollars. Drinks are a fantastic deal at $2 - $2.50. But the entrees felt small and overpriced for $10. The portion size is in alignment with what you would get in Singapore - but in Singapore you'd pay almost half the price. It would feel more fair if they lowered their prices or increased their portion size, but as it stands I don't see that happening in the near future. 

For a final, parting comment:

I agree with some of the reviews here about the tipping. Not to be rude, but why am I tipping them when I am doing everything except for bringing the dish to my table? It's a self service restaurant, where you are required to get your own cutlery, cups, and water refills. And when your meal is finished, you are equally expected to return your dishes and seperate them into the appropriate containers. In some ways this is truly authentic, because it is exactly what you should do in Singapore, and exactly what you would do in the rest of Asia. But in true Singaporean fashion, there shouldn't be an expectation of a tip."
"A restaurant with a very limited opening hours for lunch and dinner, and closed twice a week means to me that they're not around to just make money. They're making their food with love and they want to share it. This is also where I have found my go-to for bak kut teh from now on. 

From the moment I walked in, I was warmly welcomed by the older gentleman behind the counter. He told us the specials on the board. The space looks a lot bigger inside than expected. It's a cafeteria type setting where you order & pay first, find seating and the food are served to your table. 

The gentleman was able to tweak my order of bak kut teh to be served with vermicelli instead of rice without extra charge. He kept saying it's not normally eaten with noodles but he accepted my request and exceeded my expectations! The noodles have some of the bone broth poured in so has a chance to absorb into the noodles. I was also surprised to see two large ribs in my soup. The meat just fell off the bone and so flavorful.  
My friend's laksa, which I took a sip from, has some heat to it but manageable. For those who can't take any heat, should ask if they're able to make it mild. 
We also ordered the roti prata. It comes with a side of curry sauce (not spicy). The roti is flat like a pancake but has a nice chewy texture and a little sweetness to it which brings out the sauce. I ordered the haianese chicken but only enjoyed one bite since I was so full. I had it packed up for next day's lunch and it still tasted really good. The rice was packed with flavor. The accompaniments were a spicy sauce and a blend of soy/oyster sauce. You're also able to choose white or dark meat. 
My friend really liked her ginger tea but found it could use more ginger. 

Overall, I had a great meal. We came early enough on a weeknight so seating wasn't an issue. Parking is bit of a hassle since Kingsway doesn't allow parking during rush hours. The gentleman came out to chat with us for a few minutes. It was all very pleasant. I would definitely be back to try other items. I noticed the curries didn't score very high points so guess I have to come back to see for myself!"
"TLDR: pretty authentic Singapore dishes. Worth a try. Run, don't walk, to get the limited quantity nonya bak Zhang (rice dumpling). Excellent! Like those in Singapore or even better. Prawn paste chicken is another dish like those in SG. 

--------
Finally! A restaurant serving Singapore dishes in Vancouver. This place just opened over the weekend. I was told it closed early on the first day so we decided to go for brunch on its second day of operation. Good thing as it was so overwhelmed by the crowd it closed by 1230pm. That was just 90 minutes after it opened the doors. Several people stopped by as they saw people inside and were turned away. They didn't see the ""closed"" sign? 

This is a 36 seater restaurant and I think the management needs to tweak their seating and ordering of food system. Currently it is order at the counter, then get a table or seat, and food will be brought to you. We were warned beforehand that if at full capacity, it will be a wait for food. 

Everyone was pretty congenial and understanding of the long wait while waiting. I think everybody was just excited to finally get to try real Singapore dishes made by Singaporeans here. 

I ordered my food first and it took about 30-40 minutes. My friends who came later waited 90 minutes for their food. 

Food wise, it was pretty much close to what you would get in Singapore. The menu is pretty limited but I always believe in sell what you are good at like those hawkers in Singapore selling just one or a few dishes. 

The prices are very fair and I hope it will remain this way. When appetizers and snacks are $5 and under, it's much more affordable to just add them to the main meal. Entrees are at $10. 

The dishes under the Comfort Food section  were not available that day so I could not try the Chee cheong fun (different style from the HK version), chicken congee and chicken and macaroni soup. 

What I tried: 
 Mee Siam - gravy seemed home made. Right amount of spice and tang in the gravy. Too little gravy and I actually went to ask for more. They were a bit reluctant as I think they didn't prepare enough for the crowd, but they did top up for me. 

 Prawn paste chicken aka har cheong kai - super yummy and very much like from the tze char restaurants in Singapore. So good! A winner at $5. I really hope they don't increase prices. I have yet to see this dish in Vancouver. 

 Curry puff - also pretty good. With potatoes, chicken curry and egg in it. The filling tasted home made too. 

 Cassava kueh - disappointing. Too sweet and the color! I was expecting the pale yellow beige soft wobbly cassava kueh. This was hard. $3 for 3 tiny pieces, not worth it. Lucky I got it for free as part of the opening promotion

Friends said chicken rice was good, with the correct dark soy sauce and home made chili. The Bandung drink did not taste strong enough. 

I will be back and hopefully the quality will remain the same.

P.S: I bought the nonya bak Zhang and they were da bomb! Even better than those in SG (non specialty stalls in cold storage or hawker centers, maybe closer to Kim Choo version or like your peranakan neighbors' versions). It's limited quantity for Duan Wu Jie."
We 2 arrived at 7, owners very friendly and helpful with the menu. Ordered the Roti, Laksa with yellow noodles, and the boneless chicken (dark meat). There were distinct flavors: the dipping sauce for the Roti, the noodle broth, and a soup on the side with the chicken. The jasmine rice was cooked in chicken broth. It was all delicious and for $23 very good value. Will return.
"Good price for good singaporean food in the area! After wanting to try this place out for months now, we dropped by for take out and were very happy with the delicious and authentic flavours.

The puff pastries were some of the stars being soft and flaky as well as filled with a delicious meat filling. The chicken wing flavour was also great though a little bit over fried in my opinion. It was flavourful, soft and fluffy with small grains. The beef rendang was also very flavourful and the laksa was adored by my spice loving brother. The prawn noodle was the unsuspected winner of the meal though with a delicious broth that was not too salty but filled with shrimp flavoured goodness. The amount of toppings is again, not too much but definitely enough to keep you satisfied and full. 

Overall, a great place to grab some food (that comes in paper packaging) with one of the nicest owners i've met. I called to ask about a peanut allergy and he had me go over my entire order to identify which one had peanuts. He was patient, kind and had a friendly smile amidst COVID 19."

"This place is much better than expected.  It's not a big place, but you don't feel cramped.  You order at the counter, grab water and utensils then find a place to sit.  They will then deliver the food to your table.  When you are done, put the plates in a bin located in front.

So on to the food....  Aside from the menu, they also have specials on the board.  I saw prawn mee and got this along with an order of chicken wings.  For the prawn mee, they asked if you want the yellow noodles, vermicelli or mix. I got the mix as I wanted to try both. It's just a preference plus I think the thicker yellow noodles is more suitable for this dish.  The wings were fried crisply.  I taste some saltiness which I guess is from the shrimp paste, although I can't really say there's anything special with this.

"Finally! a Singaporean restaurant in Vancouver worthy of taking the mantle of representing Singaporean food. You will first have to read this review with the lens of knowing that Singaporeans can be some of the pickiest eaters on the planet. It is often said that every Singaporean is a food critic.
 
 Enough preamble. Onto the food!
 
 The Chicken rice is very passable. Wish that the rice had more chicken oil. The accompanying condiments were on point. (7/10)
 
 Prata was very good. The gravy that came with it was as good as anything in Singapore. (8/10)
 
 Rendang was absolutely amazing.  By far the best in the city. You could serve this rendang in Singapore and still get accolades. I have only had better or equivalent rendang in Indonesia itself.(10/10) edit: some days they make it even better and would warrant an 11/10.
 
 Satay was weak. The peanut sauce was authentic but the meat on the skewers were slightly dry. (5/10)
 
 Mee Siam was authentic. My mom loves Mee Siam and she was happy with it.  (7/10)
 
 Laksa was of the Nyonya variant. It was good. I do like the version with more ""lemak"" flavour from added coconut cream. The addition of Persicaria odorata (Laksa leaves) chiffonade as garnishing was a great little touch that many restaurants outside of South East Asia lack. (7/10)
 
 Chicken Wings. Winner winner chicken dinner. These were very good and would get a good review even in Singapore. (9/10)
 
Mee Rebus was 100% authentic. As good as anything you could find in Singapore. Only improvement is maybe some calamansi lime. (10/10)

 The tea was very good. Could do with a bit more evaporated milk. The flavour profile was authentic. The owner imports the correct tea dust. The Teh Alia (Halia) was just right. They used ginger in the infusion instead of powdered stuff that some other places try to get away with. (8/10)
 
Bandung was sorta sweet (maybe it's my taste) but very authentic.
(8/10)

Curry Puffs were a bit on the mild side but the pastry was very good. On par with Old Chang Kee (8/10)

 The Chiffon Pandan was as good as anything you can get in Singapore. It could be a little more moist but that's just a personal preference.(7/10)
 
 Some of the dishes come out drier than what you might get in Singapore as the owner said that he wanted to present a more healthy version of the dish. Overall, this is a restaurant I could proudly take my friends to give them a taste of what food in Singapore is really like."
Great Singaporean Hawker style food on Kingsway. The interior is clean and organized. Not smelly at all. Their rotti is really good, and chicken rice was delicious too. Friendly customer service and very affordable prices. It's an absolute gem in the neighbourhood.

"This Yelp recommendation did not disappoint! Glad to have found another awesome Singaporean/Malay food spot in the city. This spot has done a really good job of making itself a casual self-serve joint, while still offering an awesome dining atmosphere. We went in for an early dinner on a week night. It was relatively quiet to start, but as we left they really filled up. 

I tried the laksa, roti, satay, then finished it off with kaya toast for dessert. All were delicious! I highly recommend getting the laksa with a mix of both white and yellow noodles for an interesting texture. There were very fragrant flavours on all the dishes and you definitely feel everything is prepared with care. Portion sizes were decent for my stomach, but I would say smaller than the average. Prices were very reasonable though. While kaya toast is pretty simple, I haven't seen it in restaurants before in Vancouver, so it's pretty neat that they have it. Just wish there was a thicker spread of kaya between the toast. I would love to try the chicken rice next time. Thought it was pretty awesome that they offer a choice between white meat and dark meat. 

This restaurant was largely self-serve. There is a cutlery and water station for you to grab what you need. Once you order up front, you get a number and then you can find a table. I love that there is a spacious seating area that allows you to feel like you are having a proper dine in meal. The tables are set up so that they can be joined, so coming in with a party of 6 or 7 is definitely something they can accommodate. The staff are very friendly and the restaurant seem to be run by very thoughtful owners. I love that while the menu is simple, there are many little tips and hints to help decide how to customize orders to your liking, as well as help those unfamiliar with the cuisine to navigate the menu. There is also a chalk board with their ""test kitchen"" items, sort of like a feature list. Lots of dishes that you don't often see. Great to see the restaurant experimenting and figuring out what works for them as a new business. Will definitely be back to try more of the menu."
Not bad. Works for quick fix if need to satisfy craving for Malaysian/ Singaporean food. Laksa soup is creamy but lacks in depth flavor, same goes for chicken wings, did not really taste shrimp paste.. beef rendang is difficult to fail so it's okay! Will return to give it another try!

Nice owners, food was good and price reasonable but portions were more a snack than lunch and we don't eat a lot. I don't think I'll be back but I truly wish them well. "We came here on a Saturday at 1145ish (they open at 1130) hoping the wait wouldn't be too long. Good thing, we only had about 2 groups in front of us so we didn't have to wait long. There were no more tables for 3 so we opted for the bar seats with the nice view of the kitchen and the beautiful sunny street. The restaurant itself, as most have said, is small. There were about 4-5 larger tables (4 seaters) and then 2 smaller tables (2 seaters) and a 5 seater bar near the door. Small space but because it is counter service I feel people didn't really linger. There is a place for you to put away dirty dishes as most people did so turnover was okay quick. 

Now for the food...We were a little ambitious for 3 people. We wanted to try everything. We ordered...

Kopi/ Teh C - we ordered one of each and was pleasantly surprised to see uncle doing the traditional pulling of the tea. Uncle was even nice enough to come and reconfirm with me before making my Kopi that it was preferred without sugar! Super grateful for that as I do not like sugar in my Kopi.

Kaya Toast - unfortunately this was a real let down. It was not authentic tasting. The coconut taste overpowered all other flavours. The delicious eggy flavour was lost which was dissapointing. Also it was bright green as apposed to the darker yellow-y colour that I'm used to. (If anyone knows where to get really good kaya PLEASE let me know!)

Shrimp Paste Chicken Wings - being a huge fan of shrimp paste I was hoping to love these but I didn't. There wasn't a whole lot of shrimp paste taste which may be good for those who are new to the flavour or who don't love it as much as I do. The wings themselves though were fried beautifully. Crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Saw there was an air fryer in the kitchen not sure if that's what they used but I'd be surprised if it was as it came out super crispy like deep fried crispy.

Roti Prata - not too bad but nothing to write home about. A little iffy on the freshness of the roti. It may have been frozen which would be a little disappointing. Though not a lot of places do fresh roti. Curry sauce was nice. My husband did manage to sneak in a question to the uncle who we believe is the owner to see whether or not a chance of egg roti will show up on the menu one day but uncle said no. If one day we go back and its a quiet day, uncle did say he may be able to make it happen.

Mee Siam - now I have been craving the homemade Mee Siam that we get everytime we go back to Singapore so I was SUPER excited to try it here seeing that it's a pretty popular dish to order. The flavours were all there. Tasted quite good and authentic. Loved the tofu puffs and even enjoyed the little shrimps. Although for my personal taste, I would've loved much more heat and a little less sweet. Even with that said I think it was real tasty.

Mee Rebus - this was on the specials menu and my husband had to try it! This was very tasty! Such a delicious curry gravy with the egg noodles! YUM! Like the other noodle dish, it was very tasty and pretty authentic to me.

Chicken Rice - our friend had ordered this and I only had a small taste but from the little bite that I had I thought the flavours were there. They had the right sauces (the thicker sweet sauce along with the spicy relish). We may have to order this one again and eat more to get a real good opinion on it.

TL;DR 
All in all I say this place has a lot of potential. The space is small but efficient and flavours so far has been pretty good. I think my rating is more 3.5 stars than 4 but there is still so much of the menu to try and since the specials menu seems to change periodically we may never eat the whole menu. The portion sizes are generous and the pricing is good. Being that it is counter services really helps look after my wallet. With that being said I think we will be back especially since this is the only Singaporean restaurant in Vancouver (if I'm wrong please let me know) we'll need to get our fix somewhere."
"I went to there around 1pm on Saturday. From entering door till served food, it might have taken about 40 min. Friendly cashier told me weekend is always like that. So I recommend you to come on weekdays. 

I had laksa and cassava kueh. 

Laksa with egg noodle is always my favorite. A little hard texture noodle too. But what I missed in here, shrimp paste or chicken. Their laksa was tasty but I prefer more strong flavor. 

Cassava kueh was delicious. It's close to Filipinos cassava cake but this one is more dry. I enjoyed very much. 

The point card seems useful. I'm sure I will be back soon."
Nice friendly owner, price is right, the place is new and clean, they are fast, food is not salty like most restaurants.
"Picked up the following items after my friend from South East Asia recommend Shiok.

Curry fish + mixed veg on rice (only available on weekend) - spicy, meaty fish and beautiful curry flavour

Roti Canai - nice sauce and denser texture as opposed to the drier flakier texture. I like both textures and didn't mind this at all.

Chicken Curry Puff - you get 2 pcs with each order - nice and flaky, not overly spicy and well flavour with chicken and chicken egg. Generous amount of filling

Chwee Kueh - comes with 2 pcs as well. Love the texture and the flavour of the topping. They added some sambal belacan on the side and it was out of this world. Like really really good! I can't wait to taste their nasi lemak next.

Currently, this restaurant is offering pick up and delivery."
"My wife and I stopped in here with our young son during their soft opening. It was a really great experience.

The atmosphere was simple but clean, and much nicer than many of those in the area. The food was very good as well. I had never had Singaporean food, but I was quite impressed. I'm not sure if prices were artificially low for the soft opening, but if not, it was incredibly affordable.

We also had a very good experience with the staff. Everyone was quite helpful and friendly. It was a sweet family restaurant; I would recommend it to anyone."
It's improved on some of its recipes.  I find it somewhat expensive relative to portion size.  Think authentic Singapore portion sizes (small) with average Canadian prices.
"Great authentic Hainanese Chicken Rice. They sell freshly daily made foods until sold out.  Great concept as most restaurants prepared in quantities and stored in the fridge.  We like this as it's fresh and made daily a small portion until sold out.  So be forewarned to see a "" Closed Sign"" at the entrance door.

We were there on their soft opening day Friday May 31, 2019 and came back next day again.
We tried also their Laksa, Mee Siam, Nonya Bak Chang, Roti Cani , and oh their real authentic and the best Kopi O ( thick black coffee without milk/cream )

A small well run restaurant run by a Singaporean family.  We love their concept of selling freshly made daily foods unlike other restaurants.  So definitely a wait time for your foods to be served in which you have trade-it for freshness.

Keep up the concept of making daily a small batch of foods until sold out!  We love this new way of selling fresh foods in restaurants."
"Was here sometime last month with a couple of my girl friends to catch up. I would have to say the food and service really remind me of Singapore when I went last year. 

When I walked in the staff or owners greeted be right away and directed me to order with a menu. We chose to sit down first to decide on what to eat. We ordered a about 4 - 5 dishes to share and a Milo each. I miss milo since going to Singapore so was very please to see it on the menu. While I went to order, I had to tell them my dietary restrictions and they were very accommodating to tell me what has sesame that I can't have. They even checked up on me to make sure everything was ok and that I didn't touch the haianese chicken that had sesame oil in it.  

I didn't give this place a 5 star rating because I think if they had a sit down and waiting service it would be a lot better. I understand that this order and then sit down is a very Singaporean thing but it's not common here considering the layout of the restaurant. The portions are a bit small for the price you are paying. Not very shareable in the end for us. 

Overall, there aren't many of these restaurants here in Vancouver. So, I do suggest you go try it and allow yourself to basically pay for the experience. Do keep in mind for dinner they do close a bit early in my perspective."
"Came here on a Thursday lunch,  it must be my lucky day again that arrived in a quiet eatery, only a few customers, but I preferred this, so I can enjoy the food, even better I can chat with the chef/owner?? about their food. 
I ordered a Laksa with rice noodle, did not take the egg noodle.  The Laksa looks pretty mouth watering, the soup actually pretty good (good smell and thick), great color, full of umami but for my taste just need a tad of fish sauce to enhance it, the shrimps was just nicely done but I felt the rice noodle was a bit stiff and brittle. I am sure when I come back next time it will be perfect as I raised my concerns to them. I will try other dishes next time."
"Ordered a bunch of items for takeout to try - I was really surprised by their packaging because it was all wrapped in paper. But don't let this fool you! They pack a lot of food. We ordered the laksa, chicken rice, duck rice (only available certain days), chicken wings, roti, curry puff pastry, and tofu puffs. 

My favourite was the laksa noodles - creamy and sweet but still savoury. The chicken rice was a little dry compared to the signature Hainanese chicken rice. Chicken wings were pretty average. I enjoyed the roti with the curry dip as a nice appetizer.

Read my full review on my blog: https://sincerelyloewe.com/shiok-singaporean-cuisine-singapore-takeout-in-burnaby/"
"Tasty Singaporean hawker style food on Kingsway.

Parking is available along Kingsway after 1800 on weekdays, as well as on the side streets. The place has some rather short business hours and I hear they simply close when they run out of food, so best to come as early as possible. Also the place was almost deserted at 1800 but was completely packed by 1900.

Inside is nice and new and modern. Not sure why there are an extra pair of French doors just inside the main entrance that don't exactly close off any area. Looks like leftovers from someone's renovation project. They are pretty though.

Staff are friendly. The staff I spoke with spoke Singlish. I also noticed that most of the other customers here also spoke Singlish. Looks like this place is legit.

The place is run somewhat similar to that of a food court, with the exception of them bringing the food out. Utensils and water are self serve. There is also a self serve garbage/disposal station.

The food portions are a wee bit small, but according to my friend the portions are actually large compared to a real deal Singaporean hawker. Food quality is definitely there. Noodles are nice nice and tasty.

Chicken wings - dusted with prawn powder. Could definitely use more prawn flavour. Tasty.

Mee rebus - noodles with potato gravy. Served with tofu puffs, hard boiled egg, and some green chili slices and dried baby shrimp. Quite tasty.

Tau pok - 6 tofu puffs with sweet rojak sauce. Sauce is nice and gooey. Contains crushed peanuts.

Tau suan - mung bean dessert with slices of Chinese donut on top. Not too sweet at all, which is really nice.

Definitely will be back to try more items here. Recommended."
We had the beef rendang, the laksa, roti, and Kopi ice coffee.  Food was good, although the beef rendang was surprisingly small portions IMO.  You order and find seat, and they deliver the food to your table. The restaurant was clean and tidy, and staff was friendly. I would come again, but for sure not the beef rendang.
"Been wanting to try this place out for awhile and I wish I had tried it sooner. I ordered online through their website for pickup. When I arrived, the door was closed and the person inside pushed the door open using a broom to maintain distance and had my order ready on the table for me to grab. I tried the beef rendang puffs. Flaky, tender pastry and plenty of flavourful filling. I would definitely order this again or try out the chicken version. For the chicken rice, it was a little disappointing. I found the portion of chicken to be kind of small for the price. Although the chicken was tender and tasty. The amount of rice was definitely enough though. However, I found the rice to bit a little mushy. It could have been because I ordered take out and the packaging. I liked the pickled vegetables that was served with the chicken rice, along with the sauce.

There are other things on the menu that I want to try, so I'd give this place another try."
"[Social distancing takeout review]
I'm sorry that my first time trying Shiok was takeout, but I'm happy I finally got to try! After going on vacation to Singapore last year, there have been many times I looked back at vacation pictures and craved the delicious food there. Shiok satisfied my craving 100%! We tried the laksa, chicken rice, and curry puffs. They came wrapped up in wax paper instead of takeout containers, which was a bit of a surprise but amusing. The laksa was delicious! I heated up a bit to get it back to piping hot and happily slurped away. The chicken rice was also very good; as comforting as the ones I tried in hawker centres in Singapore. The curry puffs were a bit too rich for me, very buttery pastry exterior, but filled with delicious curry. I'm excited to try more of the menu soon!"
"Shiok Singapore Cuisine is really the Shiok! place to be for Singaporean food! 

Having visited Singapore regularly when I was a kid, I love the country and the food there.  There is always this familiar element in Singaporean cuisine that attracts me.  It is never easy to find a place that makes good/as-close-to-original-flavour Singaporean food, and I'm quite happy to have visited Shiok. The food was good and it reminds me of the hawker centers back in Singapore.  

Indulgence took over and I couldn't resist but to order several items (again) on the menu.  I think we ordered almost half of the entire menu.  The menu is adequately refined so you're not overwhelmed with choices, and they also have seasonal specials on the chalkboard.  

The specials this time were Beef Rendang and Chicken Jook (congee/porridge), and Kueh Pie Tee.  Here are what we ordered:  Satay, Roti Prata, Kueh Pie Tee, Chicken Jook, Laksa, and Mee Siam, and Teh Alia (Ginger Milk Tea).  Not too much for two person right? Right! 

(1) Satay - we got half chicken half beef, moist and juicy, good sweetness level. The satay sauce was nutty and sweet.  I think they have their own take on the sauce so it was different.
(2) Roti Prata with chicken curry gravy - you can taste the chicken flavour in the curry gravy (didn't expect that).  A good dipping amount of heat.  Although the roti was on the stiffer side for me, my tastebud says it was homemade.  
(3) Kueh Pie Tee - one bite snack! a little crispy cup filled with diced turnips and prawns.  Mr. Owner recommended a touch of hot sauce to finish it in one bite. I had four. 
(4) Chicken Jook - this stole the spotlight for us because it was overwhelmed with chicken flavour.  We got congee because my friend was a bit sick.  You can tell they stew this congee for a long time with lots of chicken bits and bones, otherwise you can't get this level of flavour, and the congee was smooth and thick.  The comfort food you want on a gloomy day.  
(5) Laksa - finally a place that uses the right rice noodle! (or close enough) With tofu, fish ball slice, a few big prawns, and half an egg, this was really good.  Star is the broth, which is somewhat like a curry soup with coconut.  Each place has its own take on the flavour but it's within a range.  Although I do find it a bit too watery for my preference, the flavour is decent - not overwhelmingly creamy or spicy, it is definitely toned down for local's taste. 
(6) Mee Siam - thin egg noodle tossed in tamarind sauce/broth. You'll love this if you enjoy tamarind, the sweet and sour fruit flavour.  This was a good balance to my laksa.  
(7) Teh Alia - ginger milk tea was a nice pair to my meal.  A bit spicy, a bit creamy, just enough to warm you up and make you happy.  You can compare it to Chai tea.  

Are there more things I want to try? Yup. Among the other half of the menu, hainan chicken rice! I chose Mee Siam this time since that's rare to find (very tempted to add the chicken rice too in the end... very).  

The joint is medium in size. You order in the front, go get seats, and they bring the food to you. When you're finished, please help bring the dishes to the tray. It feels like half a hawker centre.  Oh you also get a stamp card.  We were glad we came right when they opened because the crowd filled it up pretty fast.  I'll be coming here again, hopefully soon."
Technically speaking, I may stalk these guys whenever they are in South Austin, but it's worth it.  I am addicted to The Scholar; their Golden Nuggets are pretty awesome too.  I have been known to eat here days in a row or order 2-3 Scholars just so I can have some saved at home; I'll admit it is not as amazing reheated, but still ssssoooo delicious.

The food is usually my measuring stick when considering places to eat, and I only expect average when it comes to service so it's not something I typically even notice, but my recent experiences make me question whether I'll be back any time soon.

"I went here last Sunday (Aug 3rd) and their food really blew my mind. We walked in at first thinking if this place was a food court. My sister and I prepaid for our food and there was no water fountain at all. Everyone had either iced tea or canned coconut water.

Once you try this traditional Singaporean restaurant, you will immediately felt in love with their food. Their dishes reminded me of the time when I was in Singapore. Nothing is overly powerful, your taste buds will be able to sense each spicy and sweetness within the dishes. The sizzling sound of the deep fry spring rolls is music to my ears, the freshness brings the dining experience to a greater level.

"My sister had posted pics on Facebook from Singapore Hawker and they looked so good that fiance and I went the next day!

We ordered the Roti Canai as our appetizer - as we always do at any Singaporean or Malaysian restaurant we go to. It was really good. Warm and flaky, just how we like it!

For our first entree, we got the Hainanese Chicken on Rice. The chicken was yummy: moist, juicy, perfect tenderness. The rice was so good that I finished it all (normally I don't eat what's left after the chicken is gone).

Our second entree was the Malaysian Laksa. This was delicious. Super tasty and packed with flavour. Noodles were the perfect texture. But one thing about this laksa was that we could not taste any spice in it whatsoever. The soup base had too much flavour that it drowned out the spice. Going to have to ask to get it super spicy next time.

At the time we went, it was fairly busy. There were no available tables so we sat on the high chair seats to the right side of the cashier. The restaurant itself has high ceilings with a clean and modern look. 

Overall, it was a great visit. Definitely coming back when we're in the area."

"I found this restaurant on Yelp and made my way here for lunch today. The restaurant is set up like a cafeteria. You place your order at the cashier section and pick up your food afterwards. The staff call out your order number off the intercom and you go up to the kitchen counter area to pick up your food. 

The chicken satay skewers were nicely grilled. The peanut sauce was good. It was not watered down. It has been a long time since I have eaten Hainanese chicken and this restaurant did not disappoint. Chicken was tender and juicy. The rice could have been more flavourful. The clear soup helped washed down the meal. The portion size was good for the price. I also ordered a fresh young coconut. You have to get staff to crack it open after you purchase it.

Covid precautions were in place. Most staff wore face masks. There was hand sanitizer located at the front of the cashier. Plexiglass was at the cashier section. There was sign in sheet for contact tracing purposes. Staff were disinfecting tables and chairs between customers. There is paid street parking in front of the restaurant and some two hour free parking one block away."
Food is authentic, very similar to the actual Singapore taste! Take my words for it because I'm a Singaporean!

The restaurant was just opened for businesses two days ago. It was packed when I got there for lunch. Because of the soft opening, you can either get 10% off your bill or get a free drink from the fridge. The restaurant is more like a fast food style. You order at the cashier, find a seat, and pick up your food when you see your ordering number on the screen. I ordered the laksa and my friend got the curry beef. Laksa was good. The broth wasn't too spicy and it had a great coconut flavor. However, my laksa was missing an egg and they gave me the wrong kind of noodles. I ordered the laksa with vermicelli (Singapore Laksa) but they gave me the egg noodles laksa (Malaysian). I let them know and they gave me a new bowl. My friend liked the curry but she said the beef brisket wasn't hot at all. It was warm and a little bit cold in the center. She thinks the beef was just heated up from microwave and added curry sauce to it afterwards. Overall it was a bit of a disappointing and lots of room for improvement.
"炒粿條 (Char Kuey Teow) $11.50
新加坡特色叻沙 (Singapore Laksa) $11.95
Review: I finally got to go on a date with my best friend hehe :)) She went here with her family and it looked like it really slapped so we decided to come here together! She got the singapore laksa and I got the char keuy teow. We ended up sharing because we wanted to try each other's  I'll start off with mine- it's kind of like Cantonese 干炒牛河. It's basically wok fried rice noodles with shrimp, fish cake, squid, bean sprouts, eggs and chives. Although this dish is only $11.50, there are a lot of ingredients, they're pretty generous with the shrimp, squid and fish cake! I'm not quite sure why but mine was so spicy... it doesn't look spicy but it was a lot spicier than the laksa which is red I believe they may have used a lot of chilli paste and sweet soy sauce to season it! I packed it up since I couldn't finish it so I wouldn't waste and when I ate it at home it wasn't THAT bad... Nevertheless, I don't think I'll ever order this again since it's so spicy. If you like spicy then this will be perfect for you! Now onto the laksa- the laksa slapped pretty hard to be honest  the flavours were well balanced and although it LOOKS red and spicy, looks deceive and it's really not! The soup is a seafood coconut soup and I believe they added some chilli paste to add a slight kick to it. The laksa is basically vermicelli noodles with tofu puffs, prawns, egg, fish cake, bean sprouts and fish balls in the laksa soup! They were also really generous with ingredients for this meal too. Maybe because the toppings for both meals are mainly processed foods (fish cake and fish balls) which are cheap but they're really generous compared to other restaurants! The ambience of this restaurant is exactly like the name- ""hawker"" which is self serve  you do everything yourself and there are no waiters. Overall, I will definitely come here again and I would recommend people to come here  I want to try the laksa again and other dishes they have here :)
Rating: 8.5/10"

"The Rendang is soooo good!! Very authentic food and really clean.
