"We used to go to Tropika all the time in Edmonton. The food there was great. We were pleased to discover that there were two Tropika's in Vanouver, and we decided to go to this one on Cambie. Our overall experience here was OKAY.

Iced coffee- I had a Matay Dark Iced Coffee. I had two because hubster did not want his. Both drinks were sweet-ish but watered down. Nothing special.

Satay- Good. Came with peanut sauce

Roti- It was okay. The sauce that came with it was watery.

Tom Ka Gai- Soup was good but not worth $19.95. I'll never pay for overpriced soup again.

Indonesian Spring Rolls- Decent but not as good as the ones I've eaten at other Tropikas.

Kari Kambing- the flavors and sauce were on point. This is Tropika's lamb curry dish but the meat was chunky and tasted more like beef pot roast.

Coconut Rice- I asked for coconut rice to go  with the currry dish. The rice had NO FLAVOR. It was plain regular rice.  I asked for a side of coconut rice to go. When I got into the ride I tasted it to make sure it was coconut rice and it wasn't. The rice had a strong chicken stock flavor. NO COCONUT.

Dessert- Only thing that was good. We had the Panda (black sesame gelato with vanilla icecream in the center) and the Pear (hazelnut icecream shaped as a pear and dipped in chocolate).

Customer Service- 4/5

As I said, it was just OKAY here. Nothing exceptional. We might come back one day just to try the K. L. Krab dish."
"*3.5 stars*

Great family restaurant.  Large enough to accommodate big groups and the more people to share with means more variety!

Always start with some roti canai.  These savoury flaky Malaysian bread are puffy and served with a thin curry sauce and should not be missed. One order comes with 1 so make sure you order enough! I like to have a whole one to myself.

Also tried the Char Kway Teow which is the fried flat rice noodles with some egg, fish cake and bean sprouts.  Love the flavours in here...some soy sauce, shrimp paste and chili for some spice.  

They also have different drink specials every day for those who are always thirsty."
"Reservations are definitely recommended for weekend (evening) dinner plans. Service was good, they work efficiently in taking orders, changing plates that are full, re-assuring that your water glasses are always full and that the food is in good quality. The food usually tastes great. It can be slightly overpriced for some of their portions (not all). 

They didn't get 5 stars for this visit due to having found hair in my daughters drinking glass. They also ""politely"" rushed us out by constantly asking if we were ""done yet"" - probably due to having others waiting at the door; which I found rude. We made proper reservations for 9 people and deserve to eat comfortably without feeling rushed."
"Decent place for the price but the food is not authentic Malaysian. We ordered the satay to start, sambal clams, kangkung and deep fried pomphret fish.

The satay itself was tasty but peanut sauce was lacking flavour and spice. Most disappointing dish was the sambal clams which had NO sambal in it at all more like a plain stir fry. Not a single hint of heat in it. Maybe you guys should rename the dish and not deceive your customers? 

The kangkung was great up until the point we found a strand of hair in it. Fish was okay and the serving was plentiful. 

Overall its not bad but not great either. Their service was on point and everyone there was helpful and friendly. But still not enough to make me go back especially when there are more authenthic Malaysian restaurants out there."
"This place used to be packed all the time, but now it can't even fill half the restaurant during lunch or dinner. I think that speaks volumes.

The food is priced well and the portions match about the size of what you'd expect for what you're paying which is nice.  Now to the actual food part of the review:

- Tom Yum Goong (or however they spell it there) is delicious but it's not as good as some authentic Thai restaurants. But overall it's really good.

- Hai nan chicken is not as good as it used to be so that was really disappointing.

- Pad thai was pathetic. I've had pad thai in a lot of places and this is probably one of the worst ones Vancouver has to offer. I wouldn't get it again.

- Deep fried shrimp cakes were tasty. I could eat it all day long.

- Nasi goreng is something that I personally think is difficult to muck up, so it's no surprise it was decent here. Their chicken and salted fish fried rice is the best though, but not for those who can't tolerate ""fishy"" tastes if that makes sense. 

The service was decent but not outstanding, but I don't come here for the service so I don't think it's something worth complaining about."
"Again Malaysian food, but I actually enjoy ordering their ""skewers"", ""jumbo prawns"" & ROTI :)"
"We decided to go here on a Friday evening to try, as we hadn't really spent a lot of time in the Cambie Village area.  Upon arriving we had a brief, but expected wait for a table and then were seated. The place is nice, has a pretty good atmosphere that is comfortable enough that you can relax and enjoy your meal.

Their fancy (non alchoholic) drinks are pricey $4-6 but well crafted and worth enjoying at least one of to complement your meal. The menu is large but not too large to be confusing, and there is something on the menu for just about everyone. Being Vegetarians we naturally stuck to those options, but the carnivore food we saw coming out looked equally as appealing. 

We ordered the Gado Gado (large) $8.50  which when it arrived we remarked we could have easily shared the salad with some roti and called it a meal. Generous portions, spot on flavours and great presentation - WIN.  Roti was hot, soft and just the right amount of sweetness in the aftertaste.

Next was the pad thai - we were already almost too full from the gadogado, but tucked in and enjoyed the flavours, a little different than other pad thai dishes we've had, kind of almost tomatoey. Different but good nonetheless. We had so much food left over we had enough for a meal the following day. 

The service also was excellent with the staff very friendly and operating as a team ensuring orders and plates got out to the tables quickly, and the food came quickly each course.  

If you are in the mood for Malaysian/Thai food and are in the Cambie corridor area, its totally worth checking out. Prices are reasonable and the food is well made."
"I'm not sure how authentic this place is but the food was pretty tasty.  We tried the sambal bunchies, which was delicious but I have never had asian green beans, that were not.  The Roti Canai was amazing.  Worth going back for that alone.  I could have made my whole meal out if this.  Reminds me of the buss up shut trinidadian style roti, but sweeter.  Delicious.

We also tried the seafood hot pot, pad thai, some kind of beef stew, and the fried hokkien mee.  The noodles and beef stew were really good, pad thai alright, but I didn't really like the sauce on the hot pot.  Almost tasted like an indian curry, which I do like, but maybe didn't like this one, as I was expecting something different?  

Overall, the food was pretty good.  

The service was extremely good, which was a nice bonus."
"I have been to Tropika many times; however, it has been a very long time since my last visit. One of the reasons I stopped going was because I found the waiters very curt. I don't mind higher prices food if it is good quality and the ambience, which includes the service, matches.

This time, we had a much better time. The food was very good. We had the green beans, the lamb curry, and the lemon chicken. We also had it with the famous coconut rice. For dessert, we had deep friend banana with vanilla ice cream. Everything was very good. The food came out quickly and the waiters were nice. They filled our water many times and made sure to top off our beer when it looked low. 

What brought me back into the restaurant is that Tropika has become a Lyoness member, so I get cash back with my purchase. I can't really pass up a deal, so I decided to give the restaurant another chance, and I'm very glad I did. 

I will definitely be back!"
"I have an Asian wife, therefore I've been granted expert status on Asian cooking, or so at least I tell people. Tropika is as good as any place in Vancouver for Southeast Asian cooking. It's not Thai, it's not Chinese, it's really more Malay (but not Peranakan). Anyway enough of the whitey education lesson. Tropika is great food, good service and reasonable prices.  Plus it's generally filled with Asians, so you know the foods going to be good. 

Get the Bunchies (Sambal Green Beans), it's the best thing on the menu. Roti is tops, as is the satay and any noodle dish (obviously). Coconut rice served in a coconut is fantastic too. I argued with the rest of the group as to the quality of the chicken red curry. I said it was a little substandard, I'm also a white male, whereas they are not.  Therefore my opinion on the matter was acknowledged and dismissed.

Great place, i can't decide which is better here or Banana Leaf."
Like the food over here especially the crab dishes. We find Roti and pineapple fried rice quite average but everything else is good. The place is normally busy and service could be slow. P.S. Parking can be hard to find.
"Let me start off by saying...boy, was I impressed with the crab I had here - it was flavorful, a bit spicy for my taste buds, but overall just a unique and tasty preparation with crunchy bits that leave a garlicky and savory after taste.  My honey seems to disagree with me a bit in that he feels the flavor was only ok, and overall it was not very satisfying.  He thinks the Chinese salt & pepper crab we had at xxx (can't remember name of restaurant inside Aberdeen Center) was much better.  

I was disappointed with the pineapple fried rice and the satay was lackluster.  I liked the Roti, but not everyone enjoyed it. The accompanying sauce was so watery, it didn't seem to go together at first, then the flavors came together in my mouth.

I loved the stir-fried veggies we ordered. It was just simple Asian veggies but the sauce was delicious.  I would usually think it is a bit too salty but for some reason, I just kept eating and eating and eating it.  

I come here each time I visit Vancouver because my cousins seem to really enjoy the food here.  For me, it's alright, nothing spectacular, but not terrible that I would discourage my cousins from taking me."

Brisket was tender, flavourful, and good cuts instead of being fatty or full of tendon. I'm not a roti expert but.... This roti canai here though was pretty high up there for me, I thought it was flakey and light and chewy, and not overly greasy. Pricing was good too and I left happy!

We then had the home-style chicken which was yummy and the rendang lembu which I could not get enough of!

"The food here is more Indonesian rather than Malaysian.  The service area is pretty big and can take quite a few guests at a time.  Parking is a bit of an issue as there is only street parking.  We ordered the Gado Gado, chicken satay, Kari Ayam, curry puff, and Roti.  The Gado Gado was very fresh and the chicken satay sauce quite authentic.  The Kari Ayam was very spicy (pedas)!

In the end we had enough left overs to make a killer curry fried rice the next day!  In all, the food is ok relative to the many Malaysian food restaurants in Vancouver.  Not over the top great but not bad either."
"I came here on a Friday night and it was PACKED...hence i had big expectations.   The fact that it was so packed didn't bother me because this restaurant does have a nice flow.  

We ordered:

-Crab: RECOMMENDED!-  but should be remembered that it takes skill to get the meat out (Saying that because I look like a complete viking doing this)  This item not recommended for a hot date.   

-Green Beans: Nothing special.  Too greasy for my taste.

-Nasi Goreng:  I have never been to Indonesia so I don't really know what authentic nasi goreng is .....but it didn't have the usual egg and satay...also it was REALLY greasy and salty which killed it.

Oh well.  The server was VERY attentive, friendly and had GOOOD attitude...even came often to refill our water- man this guy should win an award.  

it was $100 for four people which was reasonable.

"Came here for a late lunch with a party of two the atmosphere here is comfortable and fits in with the Malaysian theme we ordered the roti canai to start followed with the lamb curry and the Assam chicken 

The roti canai was great flacky crispy roti served with a flavorful curry sauce for dipping 
*this appetizer is a must get*

The lamb curry was also great it's basically potatoes and lamb that was so soft you could cut it with a spoon all swimming in a thick rich curry flavored with coconut milk 

The Assam chicken was good but probably the weakest dish we had chicken and tomatoes swimming in sauce flavored with tamarind and lemon grass garnished with cilantro and carrots on the menu it also states star anise but I didn't pick that up to me it sort of had a sweet and sour flavor although unique and worth a try I definitely prefer the lamb 

All in all it has great food good service and an atmosphere that fit the theme I would definitely return"
Though the prices are a little steep, I continue to return for the spicy green beans and the MP tofu.  I'm no vegetarian, but I can't get enough of the flavors and textures in these particular dishes.
"Went here for dinner. When we made reservations, they let us know that we had a time limit at the restaurant. When we got there, half of our party was on its way, but the server seemed incredibly rushed when he asked us if the rest of our party was coming or not after a couple of minutes.

The food was pretty good. For appetizers, we ordered a large Gado Gado to split amongst 6 people, as well as Roti Canai ( Malay Bread ). I enjoyed the tasty peanut sauce that came with the Gado Gado. We ordered 3 pieces of the Roti Canai which they cut in half for us. The curry sauce that came with it was enjoyable.

Afterward, we ordered plates of meat and veggies to go along with a couple bowls of Coconut-flavoured rice. We had the Indonesian Style BBQ Pork Ribs, Thai Style Green Curry Chicken, Broccoli with Sliced Beef. I've forgotten what the other veggie platter was unfortunately, however all of the dishes were good! My personal favourite would be either the Green Curry Chicken or the BBQ Pork Ribs. The curry wasn't too hot and the coconut taste wasn't too overpowering either.

Finally, for dessert we had a hot Bubur Cha Cha and Cendol. I really enjoyed both of the desserts. 

I enjoyed the food, however the service wasn't exactly amazing. They weren't exactly the most friendly people."
"returning a year later to use up the entertainment book coupon, i gotta say my review for the FOOD itself is better with larger dishes, a little less oil slick (maybe because i've experienced much worse elsewhere) and authentic tastes, but the service is some of rudest around. We got a a lot of food tonight since we are a family that loves leftovers for the next day. The first dish was the jumbo prawns with vermicelli which was flavourful although the prawns were not a large portion (huge shells though). The roti and satay were as expected ALTHOUGH the pork satay was really really red...dont know if it was fully cooked. We got a char kweo teow and it was the oiliest of the bunch but an appropriate amount of noodle to goods portion. For meat, we got the half hainenese chicken, fried chicken and the beef rendang. The prices are quite high here but the meats were all very well received, each tasty and a large portion! the beef rendang was my dad's favourite with fatty pieces of brisket and a coconutty sauce to go with their chicken oil rice. Finally, we got a tung choy stir fried with sambal was delicious and spicy but not as oily as I expected! It was a huge portion of greens and satisfied our need for a veggie.

Overall, I must say i was impressed with the portions size as it justified the higher prices but the service is curt and unkind. The food came out a little slowly but was hot when eaten which is mostly appreciated. Continues to be a go to for malaysian eats."
"It's been a while since I've been here but it was still a nice dining experience. Great for our large group and kid friendly too. This is not a free colouring book type of ""kid friendly"" but they did have a stack of high chairs and a slightly whiny child won't be noticed because of the buzz in the restaurant.
Side note:  We didn't order or see the final total so I can't comment on the value but was overall a good experience. Since we had such a big order they even gave us a few complementary coupons for free roti and satay for next time! They know how to rope you back!

My highlights were:
- the fluffy roti (though the curry is on the runny/watery side!)
- nice crisp and juicy sambal beans =not soggy!!
- delicious eggplant dish, lightly browned on the outside and tender on the inside ...yummm! It just melts so you can even enjoy the inside of this without teeth! 
- the deep fried tofu with a sweet soya sauce dip was amazing! The tofu was so fresh, plump and soft on the inside and and crisp on the outside. 
Who ever was working their fryer tonight was on fire, seriously. No pun intended...kinda. :)

The pineapple chicken dish was nicely cooked through and the chicken was not tough and over cooked. The pineapple fried rice was fine and was the best for the kids who couldn't handle any spice. I don't usually order dishes in pineapple boats but the group enjoyed them. Most dishes have a bit of spice so best to ask if you're unsure. The squid was tender and flavourful...and was fine. 

Lowlight: I was underwhelmed with the clams, they were a bit mushy and drowned in a thick sauce. Our table ordered two of these dishes and the other side of the table loved them. So your gamble! 

Dessert time! 
- The warm Bubur chacha was amazing! Taro tapioca!
- The Goreng Pisang (deep fried banana with ice cream and whip) was nice but seemed to be a bit soggy. I'd ask for a knife and fork next time. But wasn't the best I've had. 
- The kids had the ice cream balls on the tabletop specials menu, coconut with mango centre's, but those are the decorated pre-made ice cream balls. A sure hit for the kids but nothing unique to this restaurant. 
- If you want a challenge and an interesting taste of Malaysia. Try the Ice Kachang. It's unique. I've added a pic. When I was in Malaysia on the Borneo side, we were offered this (by our hosts) as a Summer treat and all the local children gathered as well. What you don't see under the colourful shaved ice are the red beans, firm jelly, and corn! Yes that's right, corn. I ordered it for the nostalgia of it, but to be honest after the first bite you wonder...was this a mistake?...then you try again...and again ... think about...and it starts to grow on you. As weird as that may seem. I may not say it's my favorite ...but it's interesting! 

I'll be back and next time will try their: Laksa, beef rendang and mee goreng as those are our usual SEA restaurant staples. 

p.s. We parked a block away down 14th between Ash and Heather and was totally fine on a Friday evening. Don't let the parking scare you off. :)"
Food is good but a tad pricey when compared to its neighbours.  There are lots of asian restaurants in the area that serve fantastic food for a better price and with better service.  Good girly beverages, also a little on the pricey side.

"I've been going to Tropika for years, mainly because my family members like this place.
Personally, I find that it's a very adequate restaurant. It's got good service, and food quality is alright, if you ignore how much your meal costs.

They make some pretty good curries, however their Pad Thai is somewhat dissatisfactory. My expectation of Pad Thais are simple. They need to be sweet/sour, and the noodles chewy. While Tropika has a good sauce, it's rather lacking in the noodle department. The noodles are hard and somewhat brittle.

They also make good beef briskets, which are definitely worth trying."

"Went here for lunch and I was pleasantly surprised at the quality and the price.

They have a few selections for lunch specials so I'm sure there's something for you. My guy and I ended up getting the Assam seafood hot pot and the goat curry with Malay bread. We also got 6 skewers (the minimum amount) of satay lamb, beef, and chicken

The peanut sauce for the skewers were very nutty and delicious! The skewers were fresh and moist, although the size for this could have been a bit bigger.

The Assam seafood hotpot was huge! A lot of seafood (shrimps, mussels, fish, calamari, clams) as well as tofu and veggies. It was very flavourful anda came with rice.

My favourite was the lamb curry with Malay bread. The bread was something I've never tried - crispy on the outside yet soft and rich/buttery. The curry was excellent with big chunks of lamb.

I would definitely revisit again during lunch hours!"

"Omg finally... finally, finally, finally.... I've been saying I'm going to eat here for 8 months now, and I just got it done. It's just been one of those restaurants I kept seeing on Yelp, but I just never got around to it. 

However, what a mistake that was. This place is in some apartment complexish area on Riverside. Bold move to open an Asian fusion restaurant in 888's hood, but... thank goodness this isn't the Highlander. There can apparently be 2 totally bomb places. 

So, lemme start by saying: idk what constitutes the word ""fusion"", this wasn't like any Asian fusion i've had before. A lot of times that means it's got an American/or other culinary twist on Asian food. Also, I'm not going to pretend like I know what authentic Asian food should be... probably just rice. WHAT MY THEORY IS THOUGH... they call themselves Asian fusion because they sell different dishes from different countries...?

Anyway, I got appetizer sampler, and I'm just gonna say -- best egg rolls I've ever had. When I go back I'll just get egg rolls. They were super tight. Nice fried look, crispy, flavorful. 

Main course I did the crispy pad Thai. Ugh... so good. Comes on a bed of veggies, and all of it was done masterfully. My girl thinks this place is the bomb too. We really did have a great experience there."

All the hosts and servers were *so* friendly and accommodating, making sure they got the spice level perfect. Great ambiance--they even had smooth live piano music playing. The owner or manager came out personally at one point to thank us for coming. We would *highly* recommend. Great for a date night especially. Also: parking was easy, around back.

"Wow! I don't even know where to begin. Everything here is so great, from the food, cocktails, service to the atmosphere. The staff is incredibly friendly. The grilled octopus is definitely a must try. The grilled lamb chop was very soft and flavorful, you can't even taste the usual lamb aroma. "Everybody gives this place five stars.

Your mom and dad give this place five stars.

The entire Yelp Elite Squad gives this place five stars - and so do their dogs and cats.

I give this place five stars.

That means its good.

* * *

The place has its quirks.

They have beautiful arc-ed wooden slats on the ceiling that are like a boat hull or the Saint Louis arch.

Lovely to look at. 

I wonder how hard those are going to be to dust.

They had a folk singer trying to sing to 1618's huge cavernous hall.

Good luck with that, folk singer.

She made pleasant random noise that was semi-drowned out in the general din.

One of the featured drinks is a Chocotini. I ordered it. It was lovely. 

Chocotini and Asian food are not exactly a classic pairing. But then Asian food and folk singing are not exactly a classic pairing either.

Thank you 1618 for making these pairings so other restaurants can learn from this and won't have to in the future.

* * *

So with this level of snark, 

Why I am giving this place five stars?

a) The food

Also,

b) The food.

* * *

We had about five dishes at our table nearly all of which were sensational.

As good as everything was, I will mention just one dish. It is an absolute best of in its class. If you eat this dish anywhere in the world, you probably want to eat it at 1618 Asian Fusion in Austin, Texas.

That dish is fried whole fish.

This is a Southeast Asian staple. 

You take a fish in its entirety. You cut out the guts but leave head, and tail intact. You deep fat fry the whole thing, generally in a simple batter.

You serve it sitting on its belly vertically, looking like it would swim down the river if it wasn't fried.

You pull pieces off the fish with your chopsticks and eat it.

If you like, they have lettuce and noodles to wrap it in, and fish sauce to dip your wrap in.

In most places, what you have is just plain good fried fish. 

You use the lettuce etc to add some flavors, but it is often fine just the way it is.

What does 1618 Asian Fusion do to kick this dish into the next dimension?

They brine the fish in tamarind.

This is not ""putting sauce on the fish"".

The tamarind is completely incorporated into the flesh and the skin of the fish. You now have a bona fide tamarind fish.

The fish is dry and crispy on the outside, the way fried fish is supposed to be.

The fish is tender on the inside the way fried fish is supposed to be.

But now the taste instead of being 100% fish and crusty coating is 80% fish and crusty coating and 20% tamarind.

Which makes all the difference imaginable..

Note that this is an expensive treat.

My wife's magnificent coconut curried salmon was less than 1/3 of the price of the fried redfish.

The other plates on the table were also reasonably priced and magnificent for what they were

The only item on the menu that is more expensive than the fried fish is their lobster.

But that redfish at fifty eight dollars was worth every penny.

I am willing to pay a premium for ""best in the world"".

Best whole fried fish in the world is a big deal.

* * *

And what was the best part of the redfish experience?

I was so engaged with the redfish, I forgot about the dust on the wood waves, the folk singer struggling in the background, and the absurdity of my chocotini.

I also forgot about the other magnificent dishes at the table.

All that mattered was the redfish.

It was like looking at a woman with the bluest eyes in the world.

It didn't matter if she was speaking profound wisdom.

It didn't matter if she was chattering inanely.

It didn't matter if she had a figure that was a glamour photographer's dream.

All I saw that night was those eyes, those eyes, those eyes."
This restaurant was so much more than expected! We celebrated my best friends birthday here and they made it the most special evening! A handwritten letter from the restaurant, a free dessert, the best asian food, and a wonderful ambiance created the perfect evening! Thank you 1618 for such a memorable experience!!
"This food is absolutely delicious!!! 

By far the best Chinese takeout I've ever had. 

I had the orange chicken. My mouth is watering just thinking about it"
This place is phenomenal. The red curry with roasted duck was absolutely incredible, it was the taste of happiness, truly an experience. The ambiance was wonderful, the staff were amazing. Oh and the drinks  the tropical Asian is soooo good. Probably the best dinning experience of my life. We will be back, many times!

I wouldn't say the food blew me away but it was better than I expected for fusion food. It's probably because the common denominator is fish sauce and lemongrass. I liked everything we ordered. The char on the baby octopus was yum! I felt the duck skewer was well seasoned and didn't need the extra dipping sauce. Crispy pad thai is a take on the Vietnamese ""ap chao"" crispy pan fried flat rice noodles. Good take!

The restaurant is big! Has a stage for perhaps live music or it reminds me of a Vietnamese style restaurant for wedding receptions.

"Hubby and I went in for lunch and had Brian as our server. He was extremely friendly and attentive. We order the grilled octopus, the lemongrass lamb-chops, as well as the dragon mule cocktail and Hanoi coffee. 

Everything was superb! The grilled octopus was perfectly cooked and held its firmness and the flavor was an amazing balance of sweet and salty. Skip the sauce that comes on the side. It's delicious all by itself. 

The lemongrass lamb-chops came with a refreshingly spicy sauce that paired extremely well. I have never seen this on the menu before so it was a wonderful option to have.

We loved this place so much, we went here the following day for dinner. The pineapple fried rice was just as delicious as everything else and our server, R-Jon was super cool! Thank you!"

Also shoutout to Maggie Moo's we got our cake from them which ended up tasting good as we expected from their ice cream cakes. The big moment of walking in their doors arrived. The restaurant looked upscale from the location and appearance so wearing decent clothes might be a good choice. I became a bit nervous about what my grandparents would think of it because of all the action and stuff which. I was into it though. Eventually we were able to sit at our table when they were done preparing it. Most of the employees are dressed up in traditional Asian clothes which is a nice touch. Everyone sat down and started reading the menu. It was a bit expensive but that's not really an issue. All of us chose our food with an appetizer of spring rolls. When the spring rolls came I knew I chose the right place. It looked like food from a 5 star Asian restaurant, and it's because it was! My only complaint about the place is the music being played at the time. Loud country music. It's more of a gripe than a complaint though because it's opinion based. Most of the surrounding tables cheered for us. I also got a card from them which had my name on it and was hand made inside. I think it proved how they were grateful we are there that day. I certainly was. Definitely would recommend. I am curious of what their whole pecking duck would be like though."
"My husband and I definitely debated between 4 and 5 stars, but after getting into the mindset reminder that this was Asian Fusion, the uniqueness of the dishes here definitely excelled.

There was a lot of hype that this was better than 888, but I have to say 1618 has a higher class feel to it. Parking was great for being towards downtown as their is a parking garage across the street and the ambiance is modern yet intimate with a classic Austin side feel.

The duck skewers were my favorite. The moistness of the duck and with how much meat was actually on each skewer, it was melt in your mouth delicious.

The crispy Pad Thai sounded good, but it wasn't my favorite. The clumps were crunchy and good in terms of flavoring, but the thickness and stickiness of the sauce made it hard to eat too much in one setting as it would get stuck in our teeth. The filet mignon was amazing. I'm not a huge fan of curry, but I was surprised at how the flavors came together in that dish. I would definitely want to go back to try some other dishes and obviously order some more duck.

The price was a little higher, but for the quality and uniqueness, it's not crazy expensive. More like average for new Austin restaurants now a days. Overall a great new addition to Austin's food realm."

"A-OK is the rating I am giving.  I can only describe the food I had as sweet and clean eating ( i.e. no fat when I am expecting a little).  My biggest disappointment was that there is no heat in the dishes that I have ordered.  I can only taste the sweetness but not the five common elements in Asian food.  I had request Thai chili, satay, and even jalapeno to supplement the heat factor but weirdly all the request condiments were flat and not spicy or had any heat.

Vietnamese cuisine has a mix of sweet, sour, bitter, spicy and salty in the dishes. However, sweet was the dominate element in these two dishes I order. I know Peking Duck is not Vietnamese - Its Chinese.

Given that the two dishes I order are on the pricey side, I expect it to be pretty good but it was ok.  I wasn't interested in paying double the price for noodle soup that I can have at other Pho place.  So I went for the good stuff...or so I thought.

I had the Imperial Crispy Redfish which come with rice paper, vermicelli and fresh vegetable ( julienne carrots, thinly quarter slice daikon, and thai basil) - basically to make your fish spring roll.  The preparation looks nice but first off, I was disappointed with the little special sauce that was poured over the fish.  It should be more sauce and the aromatics are non existence when it came to our table.  The green onion and peanut, are to enhance the smell but I didn't get the sweet aromatic smell.  Second, you need to pickle the carrot and daikon so that you can get the sour element into the dish.  I created my roll and was shocked how sweet and flat the taste was.  I could no longer bring myself to make additional rolls after the second one and ate the dish as is.  Just fish without the sides that came with it...the daikon and carrots was soaked in sugar water it seem. If the sides were good, I was going to mention that you should increase the portion for the price you are demanding but I think the point is moot if I don't even want the side.  Last but not least, why do we not have some heat in the fish sauce?  The fish sauce for dipping  was diluted fish sauce with sugar, where is the sour and heat?  This was why I asked for the heat, waiter didn't have chili garlic and so he brought Thai chili but it didn't have any heat, seriously.  Regular Pho place would have a little chili garlic in the dipping sauce to bring a little heat...I am surprise!

How many leg does a duck have? Two right? Dish came with four drumstick...isn't that funny?  Skin was crispy, but the duck is very lean which to me strip away the tastiness of the duck.  Ever wonder why people cook with duck fat? Such a clean dish, its not enjoyable to eat anymore.  I think they are halfway there with this dish but I feel like its missing something...

Service was good, Bryan our waiter was patience as I asked questions on the menu.  Fusion is suppose to be a cross in culture, but the menu just showed that they took the most notable dish from each country.  So jack of all trade and master of none."

It was a cold, rainy night and my friend and I really wanted Ramen. All the Ramen spots had crazy long lines so we found something random that was close by and came here. Sooo happy I did! First off, the restaurant is a huge, open, clean and inviting space. The service was AMAZING. Everyone was so incredibly courteous and attentive! My friend got the Pho and I got noodle soup (which to be honest tasted exactly like Pho, I could not tell the difference at all) but it was some of the best Pho I've had in my life.. and I'm from Houston (the Asian food capital of North America). Definitely going back!
"Stopped here for lunch on our last day in Austin and are so glad we did! We started with the sampler appetizer tray which consisted of 
2 egg rolls, 1 fresh spring roll, 4 fried wontons, 2 chicken satays, and 2 seared pork belly buns... we thoroughly enjoyed it and the 4 sauces that accompanied it. I also had the crispy pad Thai, which was slightly oversauced, but was still very, very good. My wife had the hu tieu
(Vietnamese pork thick broth with shrimp, pork belly, fried shallots, and egg noodle) and it was great as well. I doubt I'll ever return to Austin but if I do, I'll be back!"
"There's a cool somewhat new Asian fusion restaurant in town and 1618 Asian Fusion did not disappoint. 

Free garage parking? Check. What more can we ask for in town where most of the hottest new restaurants are located in places with lack of parking spots such as E 6th or downtown?

Decor? Modern and nice. Definitely going for a fancier vibe: 

Stopped by for lunch and tried out their roasted duck red curry. Definitely an interesting combination! See it in my attached picture. First thing I did was try the flowers to see if it was edible, they're not for consumption, bitter. Warning please. 

My overall thoughts are that the curry somewhat makes the taste of the duck itself underwhelming so I'm not confident in saying it's the best combo. What I can say is that it's an enjoyable combo because I like both duck and curry. The red curry gives a more sweet than spicy taste, good choice for those that can't handle the spice. Excited to try the curry filet mignon.

Also had a taste of my friend's general tsao's chicken, a classic Chinese American dish. My thoughts are... not bad. It's good for those who just want pure meat. Quite a bit of breading and the crunch didn't last under the power of the sauce. 

Overall, I'm down to come again and try more dishes. Till next time."
"I went here tonight based on the awesome reviews!

I was really stunned by the decor of this place. Like everyone else has said, this place is huge! Such a nice break from the cramped restaurants that are everywhere in Austin. They have incense in the bathroom and the whole place is super clean!

Onto the food - I LOVED the calamari, it was probably one of the best calamaris I've had. There was a lemon sauce that came with it that was -heavenly- and the squid had the perfect flavor. I definitely recommend it, even if you haven't had squid before! I shared the dishes with the two other people I was with and we all agreed that the pineapple fried rice was the winner. The orange chicken and seasame chicken both kind of tasted the same, and to be honest they kind of tasted like slightly better quality Panda Express. Both of the chicken dishes did come with rice though, which was nice.

I'm definitely coming back here to try the pho and the octopus skewers! I don't think I would order the chicken again, but based on how good the other dishes were I think it makes up for it!"
While many Austin restaurants claim to be upscale Asian, most of them are just expensive. This one delivers. The food was outstanding. I ordered the spicy tamarind lobster and the salt and pepper shrimp. Both were crispy, delicious, and had amazing sauces. The staff was friendly and attentive and made great recommendations. I loved the decor and the whole place has a relaxing atmosphere. I will definitely be back.

Myself and a group of friends decided to try this place.  Overall, everyone was happy with their food.  Standouts were salmon in banana leaf, Tom Yum soup, spring rolls and a few standard Chinese dishes (sesame chicken).  In order to make the dining experience more pleasurable, I strongly recommend they get a shade to block the blaring sun from customer's eyes (and screens to print flies from getting in), and make sure the music is not too loud.  Nothing is more frustrating than trying to talk to people at your table, and music is so loud that you have to yell.  This place has potential, and I will gladly return after they tweak a few things.

"We were really excited about 1618 Asian Fusion.  We had to wait about 30 min for a table and that made us even more excited.  It HAD to be good.  The live music was also a nice touch.  The band was playing songs from the 80s up to present and that really got our appetite whet.  Finally got a seat and we knew exactly what to order since we browsed the menu while waiting.  Ordered the Pho with meatball and brisket, grilled lemongrass duck skew, and pineapple fried rice.  The Pho broth was 100% legit, not too salty, clear, and satisfying.  The duck skewer wasn't was we expected.  We expected just duck meat and a metal skewer...nope!  The ""skewer"" is lemongrass with the duck meat wrapped around it.  How clever!  Beautiful presentation and the grilled taste really made you crave for more.  The pineapple fried rice was spicy, sweet, salty, all served in a pineapple bowl.  All in all, A+ for presentation and taste.

The issues.  The ""brisket"" in my Pho was really disappointing.  I didn't care for the brisket and really preferred the thinly sliced raw beef but they don't have this option.  The ""brisket"" really looks like spare pieces of brisket just thrown in.  I had to complain about this unfortunately.  

The other issue is the table who sat down next to us ""party of 14"" sat down later, ordered later, and got their food first.  I know for certain that Pho and fried rice doesn't take 20 minutes to make and we were getting really agitated.  Then it made sense, the party apparently are friends of the manager/owner because he came to greet that table a total of 5 times.  Fine, understandable, friends of restaurant owners get perks but it's a little unacceptable when your other customers are waiting 20 minutes.  But the food was good enough for us to not make a stink about it.  If it wasn't for this mishap, I would've rated this place 5 stars."

"Best table service I've ever had in Austin. Period.

Chris (aka Ton) was hands down the best server I've come across in this city. His recommendations were unique and incredibly helpful - made me feel like I was eating in a 5-star restaurant. From appetizer suggestions to pairing spicy oil recommendations for our entrees, Chris was attentive, knowledgeable and fast. When we return, we will make a reservation and ask to have him serve us.

The food is excellent and the atmosphere is an absolute delight. The live music was great and the acoustics in the restaurant make it possible to hear great sound without having your dinner conversation drowned out. Bathroom was sparkling clean, dining room lighting was marvelous and the visit we got from management at the end of our meal really delivered that the owners are very hands-on/invested in delivering a good experience.

The only constructive (and still very minor) criticism I can come up with is that the Cherry Soda cocktail was a bit too sweet - likely from the cherry and vanilla flavoring used. I'd also like to see an expanded craft beer list, but they had St. Arnold selections behind the bar, so I definitely found some things that paired well with dinner.

Overall, I can't recommend this place enough. I will certainly be returning again and again."

"I'm a bit skeptical when I visit a restaurant that has the word ""fusion"" in it and serves ""every"" Asian cuisine. 1618 seems to be the exception to that rule. I went on Chinese New Years with some friends. We didn't make a reservation and it was packed so we had to wait ~30 minutes - but no worries, we got some drinks! I loveddd my 1618 secretini which is a lychee martini - it was fruity, boozy, and not too sweet! 

Once we were seated, we started with the Five Sampler. I wish we had purchased 2 of these since it was a bit hard to share it between 5 people. Everything was super delicious. I loved the pork bun the best.

- Red curry: yummy typical red curry

- Papaya salad: refreshing

"Wow! This place is fancy. The Vietnamese owner of 888 restaurant sold 888 and opened 1618 Asian Fusion. Those who jumped ship with him, were a Filipino manager and five Filipino servers. 1618 is an elevated Thai and Vietnamese restaurant. The chef is Vietnamese. The ambience and service are on par with Soto South Lamar but without the exorbitant prices. A live band performs at 6 PM every weekend and parking is ample. 

They are currently in their soft opening. Their grand opening is this coming Friday. I really enjoyed the dragonfruit rose refresher drink. There are tons of items on the menu that are labeled gluten free as they only use gluten free soy sauce!  They are still in the process of switching ingredients to gluten free, so some of the items on the menu haven't been updated yet, like the deep fried egg rolls and pineapple fried rice. This is my new favorite gluten free restaurant. I haven't had deep fried egg rolls since I went gluten free eight years ago. The tum yum kha soup was spicy and sweet with the coconut milk. The pineapple fried rice was too spicy for me, but I would definitely come back again and try a different dish. They are still in the process of creating a dessert menu. Temporarily, they are serving mango and sticky rice not on the menu. The rice was a little hard and the mango wasn't sweet.  Dominic said it probably won't make the final cut to their menu at the grand opening."
This is now my absolute favorite take out for covid times!! I highly recommend the Octopus, the duck curry, and the Tom yum fried rice! Such great food!

"With a recent soft open, I'm leaving a 3 star review not because the experience itself is bad, but because it has some ways to go in terms of really differentiating itself from its sister restaurant (888) before standing out as its own type of destination.

To start - the venue is beautiful. They've renovated the old Draft Pick location that was here and transformed the typical dive-y sports bar locale into a real clean and modern setup. The staff and service is attentive as hell; seems like a lot of familiar faces from the wait staff at 888 which also operates at impeccable efficiency and speed.

The current menu is a rotational experiment, a good way to solicit feedback from early guests. Although there is no issues with being limited, there is a sort of disappointment in looking at a menu that looks almost identical to the items offered at 888, albeit with a 30 - 50% markup.

And this is ultimately where 1618 fails to meet the mark: not because the food is not good (888 is a personal 5-star and weekly favorite), but because it is nearly identical to everything at 888. Outside of having nicer plates and silverware and a nice venue, the menu items look and feel the same as its more affordable sister restaurant just 7 minutes away. Based on my understanding of what the owners are going for in terms of delivering a slightly tiered up experience, this is where the food lacks real differentiation or creativity. 

Given our endless loyalty to 888 (delicious, affordable, efficient), we're hopeful that 1618 will soon find its own niche of a slightly more up-scaled (yet equally delicious, relatively affordable, and efficient) pan-asian restaurant. We'll certainly be back for a round 2 in a few months to see if that's the case."

"Unique, with amazing decor and ambience that is modern and elegant.  Even the dishware was  I stopped by here while traveling for work, and I'm very glad I did.

Everything about this restaurant is authentic and phenomenally delicious, and I mean that very sincerely.

I had a ""Saigon"" dried noodles dish that is unique to here as far as I've ever had, and it was one of the most refreshing and unique dishes I've ever had, with savory flavors that complement one another perfectly.

Their authentic Vietnamese style egg rolls were also very delicious and I would highly recommend then whether on your own or with a group.

For dessert, with their menu being relatively new, they had a Mango sticky rice in a coconut cream that was a new experience for me as well and incredible."

Being new to the area, I've been keen on supporting local east side eateries. 1618 is basically down the street from me and had a promising menu, although priced just $1-2 higher than the typical Viet meals I seek out. Upon receiving my order of salt and pepper calamari, pho w/ brisket and filet mignon, and filet mignon and onion stir fry, I can totally appreciate the price range for the quality of each dish!!! Compliments to the seasoning and batter on the calamari. It had a great sauce accompaniment that offered a tangy counterbalance to the salt and pepper. My pho came with a healthy portion of meat and sides. The broth is adequately oily with a nice balance of fat, spices, and onion permeating the broth. The meat in both main dishes was so tender and flavorful!! They don't skimp on anything here. 1618 is definitely worth a try. I'm excited to be in the same neighborhood and look forward to trying out more dishes!

"I was so surprised to walk into an only week-old restaurant that had over 200 5-star Yelp reviews already. Definitely set off high expectations!
When you walk in, the waiting area consists of comfy modern couches and a modern fireplace. To the left is the front desk which has modern (and beautiful) Vietnamese clothing displayed. Many of the servers were also wearing beautiful traditional Vietnamese clothing and they looked great. The restaurant is huge. There are lots of different seating arrangements. We (my family of 4) were seated at a half booth table. There is green everywhere (plants) and it really makes for a fresh vibe. There is also a stage and I was told they have live music on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. We had a cute older couple that came on at 7 that played some classics. The server mentioned they wanted to take advantage of great local music. Our server was super sweet, helpful, and accommodating. We were also approached by one of the managers and he was a hoot to talk to.
Now onto the food. I ordered the Crispy Pad Thai which I shared (luckily because the quantity is HUGE here!). I would definitely order next time I come. The Won Ton soup was great and the General Tso's Chicken was good but not a plate that really stands out (the rice was really yummy and sticky though!)
I will definitely come here again when they have live music playing!"

"My husband planned a surprise date night at 1618 and it was extremely wonderful!  

It is one of those menu's where you want to try everything.  This is how they get you, with quality food and service!

They also take presentation very seriously here.  The pineapple fried rice is served...in a pineapple, and the coconut fried rice, you got it...served in a coconut.  Sometimes I am wary of this because it often means style over substance, but I was pleasantly surprised that the food is as good as the presentation.  

We also had the orange chicken which was so unbelievably delicious.  

My absolute favorite experience though was the Hanoi coffee.  I've never had this style of coffee before, but it is Vietnamese coffee poured over a sweetened egg cream.  The pour over is done at the table and is just lovely to watch.  

They have a green Thai tea which I was not a fan of because it tastes like Jasmine (but looks like matcha).  I am just not a fan of jasmine tea, but my husband loved it, so if you like jasmine, you'll probably love this tea.  

We went on a Saturday evening and there was a great musician performing.  I appreciated that the music was not so loud to make it hard to have a conversation. 

Lastly the service was top notch.  We did have a reservation but arrived a little early and they were kind enough to seat us earlier than our reservation."

Our family was craving Asian food and settled on this place due to the stellar yelp reviews. As a Bay Area native, I get to eat a lot of Asian food but the food here definitely stood out. We ordered beef pho, filet mignon, the red curry with duck, coconut rice, and crab rice. The beef pho was very rich and flavorful; the curry was spicy and very authentic, and the filet mignon was wonderfully succulent. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone!

We had the duck skewers as an appetizer and they were incredibly moist and full of flavor.  We had the crispy pad thai and the filet mignon green curry.  The crispy pad thai was unique; basically the noodles were deep-fried.  While the crispy noodles were nice and the taste was good but a bit sweet, I think I would have preferred regular noodles with crispy noodles as an addition.  The green curry had deep flavor with a nice subtle spice.  The beef was a little tough, but the dish was great.  The lemongrass refresher drink was a nice pairing with a sweet and sour taste.  Overall, great food options and great service.

"We're new to Austin and the misses really likes Asian Fusion. 1618 popped up as one of the best spots in the city with a 5 star rating. Done. Parking is in the rear of the building because the restaurant is located under a mid rise apartment complex right off of Riverside. No biggie, there is a free parking garage for retail business right across from the entrance. We started with the sampler platter pictured here.  It has a little mix of goodies such as pork buns, fried egg rolls, satay chicken, wonton and shrimp spring rolls. It also comes with 4 different sauces to do some dip action and all were the truth. The wife had the Crispy Pad Thai which had crispy fried flat noodles mixed in with tender pieces of chicken. Tons of flavor and the ""crispy"" version is a hit. I opted for the Yellow Curry Chicken which had some kick to it, potatoes, onion, mushroom and of course chicken all in a yellow curry sauce. Tons of flavor and just the perfect amount of spice. The service was top notch as well which rounded out a great experience at 1618 Asian Fusion. I highly recommend it as a ""must try"" when in the ATX."

"One of my new favorite restaurants, and I'm unhappy with myself for not ordering sooner. I had seen the good reviews but it took me until Coronavirus lockdown to order from them. Even though I used UberEats, I didn't get charged for the delivery as 1618 does their own delivery. Sweet!

My lamb chops were everything I had hoped for, and the appetizer sampler didn't have a bad item on it. My only disappointment was the extra spring rolls I ordered were accidentally replaced with a different appetizer. When I called the restaurant, they were quick to apologize for their error and offered for me to call in on my next order and they'd add it no charge. Worked for me.

Ordered for a second time yesterday and they remembered me about a week later. I was able to customize the spring rolls to be vegetarian so my girlfriend could have them, and we each had a new dish we hadn't tried. She loved hers and I did as well. I tried the general tso's chicken and they were nice big portions of quality chicken meat. I would have liked a bit spicier, but the flavor was on point.

Considering you save the ~$4 delivery fee vs. other restaurants, I plan to order from 1618 more in the coming weeks. Can't wait until I can one day dine-in here."

"I've been here three times in two weeks and it just opened. I'm in love.

PLUS, you can buy a cocktail for $6, a glass of the house wine or a chilled mug of beer for $5.

This space can seat 200 people and the acoustics are so good that your conversation will remain private and you won't have to shout, either. 

I recommend the filet mignon pepper steak. Tender, flavorful and juicy, and combined with an appetizer, there's enough for two with a moderate appetite. I've had better pho.

On warm days, they open the windows way up, there's outdoor seating, and dogs are welcome. 

Parking is FREE (praise the heavens)."

"Updated with photo of Vietnamese Bowl! Sooo good!!!!

As a Korean, I have very high standards for Asian food and rarely care for Asian fusion food. Decided to give this place a try after seeing it on A Taste of Koko's Instagram. 

The interior immediately had me skeptical. It's not your typical hole-in-the-wall place. It's actually very beautifully designed with wood paneling, earth tones, and wall planters. It feels modern but in an Austin-y sort of way. There's even a stage that I hear hosts karaoke night / live music sometimes. 

The food. Oh. My. Goodness. This little place has got to be the best Asian restaurant in Austin! We had the Duck Red Curry and the Filet Mignon Stir Fry with Onion. The curry was phenomenal. Spice level was just right, the duck was fork tender, and the coconut notes were spot on. The filet was cooked perfectly (medium rare is the only way to eat filet!) and the seasoning was amazing, not too salty. After the first bite, it had my mouth watering for more. We ended with mango sticky rice, which was the perfect way to end our post-Valentine's meal on a sweet note. 

Everything was plated beautifully and the service was fast & friendly! Can't ask for anything more from this new favorite restaurant of mine in ATX"
"Took my mom here for lunch, and we each ordered a noodle soup. The soups were generally tasty enough, but you could tell the dumplings in mine had been frozen. They weren't fresh. I did like that they deboned the duck which most Asian restaurants don't. This is during COVID, so we're fine with giving restaurants some latitude that they may not have the same level of quality as they may otherwise have.

The service was perfectly nice. They didn't have the outside patio set-up for the day, so we asked if they could put up a covered table for us. The waiter seemed less than thrilled to do it, but he did it anyway. It was lunch time. Three other tables ended up setting up outside too."

That paired with the ambiance of the jazz band made for an awesome dining experience. I can't wait to come back!

"I visited 1618 Asian Fusion with my family for their soft opening and was greatly impressed with all areas of what makes a restaurant great...

The ENVIRONMENT:
An ambient contemporary and modern color setting with options for full stage performances. This is a new restaurant so everything was kept very clean and well organized. We truly enjoyed the wavy wood design ceiling leaving one feeling peaceful and creative at the same time. Their stage was not yet operational but the potential for fun entertainment is definitely there in the future and we can't wait to check it out later! We already saw people holding birthday parties here which said a lot about comfort and ease for big gatherings.

The SERVICES:
The service staff waiters and waitresses were exceptionally friendly and happily recommended to us what they felt as good food options to try on our first visit. They visited our table often enough thereafter to refill our water and check up on our needs while never once being pressuring for us to leave. They also smile often even while standing on the side waiting to service, a rare sight indeed!

The FOOD:
We ordered appetizers Grilled Octopus and Papaya Salad and they did not disappoint. They served 6 octopi on skewer sticks nicely grilled and very well seasoned. The papaya salad was super delicious seasoned perfectly and almost taste like authentic Vietnamese papaya salad, making me homesick! For our main course we ordered their signature dish Imperial Crispy Redsnapper and Pho Brisket/Filet Mignon for our little daughter. The crispy redsnapper was one of the tastiest fish dish I've ever had since moving to Austin. It is nicely seasoned and slightly sweeten to the taste and super crispy to eat! Highly recommended! Our daughter loved her Pho, we tried some as well and truly enjoyed how tender and juicy the filet mignon were! All the food we ordered from appetizers to main courses were beautifully presented making this feel like fancy dining, yet, everything were reasonably priced and served in sizable portions with decent waiting times!

Overall, we would give 1618 Asian Fusion 5+++ stars if we could since they've met and exceeded in all areas that make us feel like true fine dining without breaking the bank. We highly recommend this restaurant for all family and friends gathering and party goers as well (they also served alcohol) and we can't wait to return again to check out their full menu once they officially open!"

Let me start this by saying, I LOVE PHO, but I'm a bit picky with it.  1618's pho was one of my favorites.  The broth was dark, delicious, and complex - it was so good. "Just had an amazing meal here, courtesy of Eric and the team at 1618. It was my first time dining in, and they absolutely knocked it out of the park.

The service here is, I think, exceptional. I'm a pretty low maintenance guy, but I really appreciate the white glove treatment I received. Eric was extremely friendly and accommodating, and really took charge and owned our experience. The interior ambiance of the restaurant is also very nice, definitely not what you would expect, being in a mixed use development and all.

I ordered the chicken skewers, which I loved last time, and they did not disappoint. Super tender & smokey, very satisfying and I will need to try the duck skewers next time. I also sampled the tom yum kha which was light and refreshing, with a touch of heat. 

As for the entrees, my wife ordered the red curry, and she was delighted. It really made her afternoon. I initially wanted the oxtail pho, but Eric let me know that I would want the beef rib variant instead, and he was completely right. The pho here is has a lighter & fresher broth than some of the other pho places I've frequented on the North side. The noodles aren't vermicelli noodles, I don't think. They are a bit wider and more translucent. I could be wrong. The broth was poured over the noodles tableside, out of a kettle, and the pho was also served with a raw egg. Never had pho with raw egg - it proved to be a great addition. The star of the show was the heaping portion of beef rib, resembling two prehistoric tusks, jutting out of the bowl with a presence. The smoked flavor absolutely killed it. And the sizable portion is going to suit me well later tonight. 

The best part is that our meal, 2 drinks, 3 appetizers and 3 entrees came out to a tidy $60. I think this place is a steal for the service and quality of food. I am very excited to come back again and delve further into the menu!"

No worries, the tofu vermicelli bowls are satisfying and flavorful as well as the vegan pho! Grab some egg rolls for apps and wonderful cocktails (real dragonfruit?! Yes!) and you'll be set for the night.

We ordered family style. EVERYTHING was delicious. The duck skewers and lamb chops were super tender. We got the appetizer sampler to share and cleaned the plate. Thai pineapple fried rice had just the right amount of flavor and spiciness to it. My friend ordered a whole fried red snapper, and we made our own spring rolls. You can order the rice paper and other ingredients on the side of the fried fish even though it's not on the menu. The restaurant itself is big and inviting with plenty of natural lighting. "There's a reason this place has all 5-star reviews: it's GOOD.

Since the pandemic, I've never had the chance to dine-in at this spot, but I'm extremely lucky to live within their free in-house delivery radius. You can also order on UberEats, but if you live within 3 miles, they will also delivery directly from 1618I for no fee! I've ordered from here about 4-5 times and every time it's great! Here's a few menu items my husband and I have tried... if you want to save some time reading and prefer to just know if you should order your food from here already, I can summarize: EVERYTHING on the menu is good, and yes, order away. 

- Appetizers: we've tried the egg rolls (shrimp + pork, and the veggie ones) , they are AWESOME and come with this badass sweet and sour dipping sauce that's a tiny bit spicy. They're never greasy but they're crispy on the outside in the best possible way! We've also had the fried dumplings, spring rolls, appetizer platter (that's my husbands favorite) and tom kha soup. You can't go wrong, but if you're looking for munchies to snack on while you binge Netflix, def recommend the appetizer platter so you can try the egg rolls, satay, buns, and fried wontons.

- Entrees: I keep ordering the Vegan Vermicelli bowl, because it's delicious and healthy, so you feel good after you eat it too. I like the one with tofu and veggie egg rolls, but have also had the one with avocado and grilled tofu, and they are both delicious. It's basically a spring roll in a bowl! My husband is a Sesame Chicken enthusiast, and he LOVES the Sesame Chicken from 1618. Good quality chicken, the sauce flavor and the fact that it's not greasy, it's just saucy but somehow the chicken still stays crispy under all the sauce. Our two year old also approves. Apparently good Sesame Chicken is an art- who knew? I've also had the Chicken Pad Thai and it was solid. 

On my To-Try List: the Tom Kha Coconut Fried Rice and the Pineapple Fried Rice, and the Green Curry with filet mignon!

Drinks: The Thai Iced Tea is particularly awesome at 1618. Not sure what they do differently to make it so special, but I can't order from here without getting it."

The only downside were the drinks. The old fashioned was really strong and the Red Snap was just ok. Overall I loved it and will be back!

There were only two customers in the entire restaurant, yet I had to wait to be seated and it took forever for the dishes I ordered. I had two different waiters, the first ended up disappearing and then another one took over who was very good. I'm not quite sure what all the other staff was doing.  The owner was there, but made no attempt to interact with the customers.  I think I will continue to look elsewhere for Asian fusion.
"In Austin for work and stumbled on to this restaurant during thier soft opening. WOW, this please is setting the standard for service. Friendly, caring and yes even Charming these words describe the female server that helped me. Also, to a lerfer degree the entire staff.
The setting is residential and mixed use. The dining area is welcoming and spacious, upscale use of natural materials and a very  large open window filled the room with a sense of being comfortable in the outdoors.
The food was delicious, the spring rolls, tso's chicken and octopus skewers are solid. The Vietnamese bowl was the star of the show.
Drink selection was limited for the opening and a full bar is being opened this week. The lychee martini balanced and not too sweet, the second was even better."

"An amazing new spot for Asian food in Atx brought to you by the owners of 888. This is a classier and hipper version. They take southeast Asian food and give it a little spin to it. They got live music here and It's a cute date place!

I really enjoyed it but my parents and grandparents thought everything was too greasy and sweet for them. In my opinion it is not fully authentic however it is the best fusion that's closest to authenticity. If that makes sense. It's like 98% authentic. They definitely cater the taste to the American tastebud = more sweet/fats

My favorite dish was the calamari, thai crispy red snapper in tamarind sauce, Saigon grilled lamb chops, Saigon chicken wings,and the crispy pad thai.
I don't recommend the Thai tum yum fresh coconut fried rice. It was hard to get the rice out of the coconut. It was aesthetic though.

In all I really enjoyed the food here! Would definitely come back!

"1618 is aesthetically beautiful with its natural decor of wood and plants surrounding the restaurant. The hostess could use some work, but other than that our service was great. As its name states, 1618 is an Asian Fusion restaurant. If you are expecting traditional nationalistic items, 1618 ain't it. Instead, think of it as Asian Food with an added touch of pizazz.

We ordered the Crispy Pad Thai, Vietnamese Styled Chicken Wings, and our favorite, the Filet Mignon Pepper Steak. The Crispy Pad Thai is a breaded version of the the normal Pad Thai. It's a bit too fried for me, which steers me to order the regular Pad Thai the next time I'm in. The Vietnamese Styled Chicken Wings can also come across as a bit too much, as it is overdosed with sauce. However, if you save it for the next day, you can actually taste the better flavors such as the lemongrass that enhances these wings. Our all-time favorite which takes the cake is the Filet Mignon Pepper Steak. It was so good, I was contemplating on ordering another one to-go for dinner the next day! Logically, I didn't. But, oh my, you will not regret it! The Filet Mignon we ordered was medium rare per our request, and was SO SO SO SO tender, seasoned well, not salty, and pure perfection. 

They've only been open since January, so come out & support your local businesses during these trying times!"
Alright so this place is pretty interesting. First off, this place is a little too fancy for me personally. For those who want a fancy date night or a more upscale place, this is it. I prefer a more casual setting but it all really boils down to the food. Growing up and traveling to Vietnam many times throughout my 25 years of life I can honestly say their Mi roast duck is actually soooo good. I've had many Mi dishes all over Austin/Houston/Cali and I can seriously say this one is the bomb. In Saigon there's a mi place owned by a family that I think is the best in the world and I can say the one here at 1618 is a very close second. And to me that is IMPRESSIVE. Go try it!

There were quality fans that kept the air circulated, so you wouldn't feel the summer heat. The manager, John, also personally came to us and he was very pleasant. My friends and I were celebrating our graduation and he surprised us with a coconut type of cake and we ALL loved the cake. It was such a beautiful gesture. The food was so phenomenal. It's literally feels like fine dining but the best part is the prices for meals, so affordable and the portion sizes were very filling! The food was like a symphony in our mouths.

"Hey Austin! There's a new Asian restaurant in town. 1618 Asian Fusion is casual, inviting and most importantly, has excellent food! They're not ""fusion"" per se, because all the dishes are quite authentic but they serve dishes from various Asian countries very, very well. We had the sampler appetizer and it was beautifully presented in a wicker platter with fresh spring rolls, fried spring rolls, a couple of pork belly buns, fried wontons and chicken satay. It came with 4 different sauces which were all freshly made. They definitely did not come from a bottle. They even garnished with edible little flowers! We also ordered pad Thai which rivaled my own except I don't have to slave for hours to make it. The orange chicken was excellent and I don't normally eat this because they're usually so sickly sweet and covered in tons of dough. Not at 1618 Asian Fusion. Theirs was lightly breaded and the sauce was tangy and not syrupy. I would also do this restaurant a complete injustice if I didn't mention that they have the most ""whole fish"" menu items I've ever seen. Some Asian restaurants will have one and it's seasonal and on special. They have about 5 different whole fish in different preparations from their fish tank in the back! You read that right. They have a fish tank. You can't get fresher than that without getting a fishing pole and catching it yourself. I chose the striped bass and it came fried to perfection. Super crispy outside but tender and juicy inside. It was easy to pull it apart with chopsticks and dipped in the citrusy chili sauce that it came with. There was also a mango slaw that was the perfect accompaniment to the fried fish.
1618 Asian Fusion is so new they haven't had their grand opening yet. They have live music on Friday nights and Saturday nights which I'm definitely going to check out. It's located at the Amli Southshore on Riverside so there's plenty of parking in the garage. If you love Asian food, do yourselves a favor and eat here!!! You're welcome."
"My new favorite Asian restaurant!!!

Cool, modern decor. Very attentive and friendly service but best of all is the food!!! As it should be!

We started with the grilled Octopus appetizer. They were 3 skewers of two little octopus. Tender and well seasoned. The highlight was the pineapple purée that came with it. Mmmmmm. 

Next was the Tom Yum Kha soup. It was very good! Chicken, mushrooms, grape tomatoes all in a spicy coconut broth. A great version. 

For the entrees, the Orange Filet Mignon was more than what I even hoped for. I was afraid it might be too sweet and wondered about the tenderness of the beef. It said it was spicy, so I was in. It was perfectly tender, not too sweet and a hint of spice. Personally, I wish it had more spice. It was in a deep brown savory sauce with a side of rice of your choice. We also had the Spicy Pineapple Fried Rice. It had shredded duck and shrimp along with pineapple, basil, red pepper, onions and egg. It was served in a pineapple shell. It was just the right amount of spicy!

There is a free parking garage onsite too. It is a bit more pricey than other places but this is quality. All in all, it was a perfect lunch!"

"During shelter in place, totally craving Thai food and find Austin to be challenged with solid distinctions among varieties of Asian culinary specialties - everything is fusion (nope).

1. 1618 egg rolls w/pork - just okay.  Flavors were there and generous meat filled, however the outside crispy was off.  Perhaps the to-go container did not have a steam release which made the outside soggy.

"As a Korean, I have very high standards for Asian food and rarely care for Asian fusion food. Decided to give this place a try after seeing it on A Taste of Koko's Instagram. 

The interior immediately had me skeptical. It's not your typical hole-in-the-wall place. It's actually very beautifully designed with wood paneling, earth tones, and wall planters. It feels modern but in an Austin-y sort of way. There's even a stage that I hear hosts karaoke night / live music sometimes. 

The food. Oh. My. Goodness. This little place has got to be the best Asian restaurant in Austin! We had the Duck Red Curry and the Filet Mignon Stir Fry with Onion. The curry was phenomenal. Spice level was just right, the duck was fork tender, and the coconut notes were spot on. The filet was cooked perfectly (medium rare is the only way to eat filet!) and the seasoning was amazing, not too salty. After the first bite, it had my mouth watering for more. We ended with mango sticky rice, which was the perfect way to end our post-Valentine's meal on a sweet note. 

Everything was plated beautifully and the service was fast & friendly! Can't ask for anything more from this new favorite restaurant of mine in ATX!"

Think of this spot as a classier and more high end 888. The type of restaurant you can have a business dinner at or host a large group for a birthday dinner. Very modern and chic aesthetic. Bamboo and wood structures lined the restaurants ceilings. There's plenty of light and green in the room. The food is fusion for sure but it doesn't compromise the authentic Asian flavors. They've definitely adjusted it to fit the American  palette but they've stayed true to their Vietnamese roots. I'll be back to try more dishes soon!
"I will start by saying this was a very enjoyable dining experience. Arrived a little before 6 on a Sunday night and the place was still a little quiet, but it was filled up by the time we left around 7. Service was impeccable, we enjoyed all the interactions with everyone we met there. The menu was Thai + Vietnamese + Chinese, nothing too out of the ordinary and not too many dishes, which I appreciate, because you can't possibly do that many things well. Prices were surprisingly reasonable since the place actually looked quite upscale compared to most Asian restaurants.

We loved the appetizers, the grilled octopus was delightful in presentation and flavor, tasty with or without the sweet and tangy sauce. Tom yum was just the right amount of flavor, which is surprisingly difficult to find. We weren't sure what the crispy Pad Thai was (even though the server did try to explain), and it turned out to be these deep fried thick and wide noodle pieces that sort of reminded me of the pan fried Vietnamese noodle dish ap chao. Unfortunately we did not like the noodles since the texture was more chewy than crispy. The other entree pineapple fried rice had really good flavor, but I was not a fan of the texture of the rice. 

They are still working on their dessert menu (only mango sticky rice for now) so we decided to go somewhere else for that instead. As we were leaving a singer was prepping on stage, apparently they have live music every weekend. I would have loved to write a five star review given the wonderful service, nice but not pretentious atmosphere, and the great appetizers, but I just didn't find the entrees to be amazing. Still, definitely a place I would come back to for date night or just dinner with friends!"

"Came here for my birthday as a group dinner and was very impressed with everything.

Drinks:
Tropical Asian - I enjoyed this drink, solid not spectacular.
Some Frozen Blue Drink with Lychee - they comped this drink for me, I wasn't a huge fan mainly because I don't like my drinks frozen. The lychee was nice, though.

Food: 
Grilled Octopus - I felt a little guilty eating these baby octopi, but they were grilled perfectly and everyone really enjoyed them.

Banana Leaf Spicy Steam Salmon - Tasted like a salmon curry, but the salmon didn't overpower the great flavor of the sauce. The salmon was cooked well and the sauce had a slight kick to it, but not too much.

Green Beans - Just well-cooked green beans, 'nuff said.

Also tried:
Pad Thai and Crispy Pad Thai - Solid Pad Thai, the crispy Pad Thai was all crispy, which was too much for some (mix them together for balance).


Other than that, the service was great all around. They had a few mix-ups with getting orders to the right table, but they were very quick to correct any mistakes. Additionally, the manager came around to say thanks and comped my entree as well as a thanks for celebrating my birthday there. I would love to come here again, and try some of the more expensive fish dishes (it looked like a really large portion meant to be shared when we saw someone else order it)."

"My cousin & I went here for dim sum brunch on a Saturday brunch. I was surprised there was no line because we were seated almost immediately. All the staff wore masks and were attentive to all of our needs. The restaurant has a very relaxing ambiance and medium noise level. 

I am giving a 3* due to the dishes being either hit or miss. For example, the bánh tráng Đà Nẵng was too sweet and nowhere similar to the bánh tráng street food in Vietnam. We tried it because there were no current photos on Yelp and our server (who was great) said it was his favorite new dish. The sauce on top was too overpowering and it was not crunchy so the resulting dish was extremely messy to eat. 

Additionally, the pan fried dumplings looked great in picture but, in actuality, were oily and the wrapping was too thick and chewy. 

Xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and har gao (shrimp dumplings) were delicious! They were fresh and steaming when we were served. The dumplings here were a lot better than those at New Fortune that I had on New Year's day. 

Mango sticky rice and thai tea affogato was nicely presented and also good, with the mango sticky rice on par with many in Thai restaurants. 

My cousin enjoyed her matcha latte and I really enjoyed the Hanoi egg coffee because of the presentation and the taste. I left it in the refrigerator and it was still delicious hours later! 

Overall, I would say the ambiance is great and you can tell a lot of thought went into the presentation of the food.  Furthermore, the service was! This is definitely a once-in-awhile stop (great for monthly lunch?) the but it did not leave a lasting impression based on the taste and price (our meal came out to about ~$100)."

"Stopped by this place last night expecting to get a simple Vietnamese snack on our last night in Austin.
