"This place is fairly new. I don't believe they even have their grand opening yet. However these are the dishes I recommend:


1: EGG COFFEE. One of the traditional coffee from North Vietnam. This place made the egg coffee extremely rich, smooth, soft, and fluffy. You just HAVE to try.

2: matcha thai tea: just enough sweet and not too much sugar.

3: grilled duck skewer with lemongrass: because they use duck meat over other kind, you have the natural  moist and juicy flavor from the duck fat grilled into the meat

4: Hu tieu Nam Vang: the broth is just amazing

5: Peking/roasted duck. The menu said it's roasted, trust me it's peking. Tho sometimes they serve with different type of sauce. Ask for the traditional peking sauce and get the buns with it."
"An Austin GEM and a MUST visit!! Great venue for a hang out with friends or family. OUTSTANDING services, DELICIOUS foods, BEAUTIFUL venue, and FAIR price for an upscale restaurant and HIGH QUALITY food.

I visited 1618 Asian Fusion 3 times during their soft opening on October 4, October 13, and October 26. The menu changes each time with new items for each visit and every dish was GREAT.

I don't provide review much so this is a rarity. I've confirmed this one is worth writing about with the multiple visits and trying lots of items on their menu.

Dishes I've ordered:
Bar and Cocktails
1. Tropical Asian
2. Pink Coco
3. House Wine

The drinks were okay and tasty. You don't taste strong alcohol so heavy drinkers might not like it. Those who like fruity drinks will likely enjoy these drinks. The best part here is the price!! Can't beat it so keep those orders coming....

Appetizer
1. Papaya Salad
2. Grilled Octopus
3. Grilled Lemongrass Duck Skewer
4. Wonton Soup
5. Tum Yum Soup

All the appetizers were good and I would order them again. The Duck Skewer and Wonton Soup were awesome! The meat on the Duck just falls off the bone like a good ribs and super moist. The Wonton Soup were an absolute delight. My daughter couldn't have enough and kept asking for more.

Entree
1. Pho Brisket and Filet Mignon
2. Hu Tieu Saigon
3. Whole Roast Duck
4. Filet Mignon Pepper Steak
5. Imperial Crispy Redfish

I recommend all the entree dishes above and you can't go wrong with any of them. The Filet Mignon in the Pho and the sweet broth (no MSG) is what separate this dish apart from the other pho places.

The Hu Tieu is a safe and fulfilling dish. It's quite good for an everyday food item. 

1618 Asian Fusion did a very nice thing with the roast duck where there's no bone except for the legs. That's so convenient and make it that much more enjoyable. I did used the sauce for more flavor  and wouldn't mind the skin being more crispy and crunchy (understanding there is a balance to prevent burnt). This dish was served with white rice and serve 2.

One of my favorites is the crispy redfish. As you can see from the pictures other uploaded, the dish was beautifully presented. There is so much good flavor packed into this dish, you don't need to use any of the side fish sauce that came with it. You'll need 3-4 people to finish up this fish or can take the leftover to go.

Overall, I like the atmosphere and it's modern. On a night when there's no band (Oct 4) multi genre music is played in the background and provide a soothing environment. I experienced two nights with music entertainment, the Southsiders on Oct 13 and Kate Metz (7 yrs old sensation) on Oct 26. That's nice to support the local artists. I was also able to talk to the owners and they are very kind and would go the extra mile to take care of their customers."
Awesome! Awesome! Awesome! This is the best Asian Restaurant I've been to in the Austin area. The food, the atmosphere, the service--all amazing. The manager, Jon, came over to our table after our meal to find out what we thought and how our experience was. He was so sweet. Everyone was responsive. The live music was wonderful. Get there ASAP!

And now the food - holy crap, it was great. I've had my fair amount of Pho in my life and this was near the top. Bursting with flavor, plenty of noodles and meat and the chili oil only enhanced it.
I would bring any friends or family members here and trust that we'd leave having had a super fun (and filling) time.
Come here. It's more than worth it."
"The management and staff were extremely helpful on helping us decide which items on the menu complimented our taste buds. Terrific service and terrific food. My girlfriend says the Green Curry is the best she's ever had. 
Stop by and give this place a shot."
Been a big fan of this place for dinner since they opened. Just tried it for dim sum brunch and it is absolutely a must go. Best dim sum brunch in Austin. Every dish was a delight. The service is also always wonderful. They have things nicely spaced out for COVID safety, with big open windows and patio space. They also offered sanitizer to us at our table after we paid. Get the Hanoi Coffee. You won't regret it.
Ended up going here because Dee Dee was closed, but I was pleasantly surprised! The skewers, especially the grilled octopus, and the papaya salad were right on point! Chicken skewer was a bit too bland but other than that everything was great. Glad to find that there is other good Thai place other than Dee Dee.

"Um, Y'ALL!!!

This place is fantastic. I've had a lot of Asian food in my life, and I was really impressed with this restaurant. To start, this place has a great ambiance. A lot of great wood pieces, tile, and lighting throughout the restaurant.

Our server Shane was excellent, he was literally waiting on every table at lunch and doing a great job. He was very helpful at explaining different dishes and navigating the cocktail list. 

The cocktails: YUM! We ordered all together four cocktails. The old fashion (which was quite the presentation), the tropical Asian (which was heavenly), a cucumber watermelon cooler, and a berries and sake cocktail. They were literally all fantastic. We also got an expresso. They also had both regular and matcha Thai tea which looked very good.

The food: DOUBLE YUM! We got the appetizer tray, the pineapple shrimp and duck fried rice, filet mignon green curry, chicken pad Thai, and garlic bok choy. We asked for everything extra spicy, which they honored. I loved the presentation of the dishes, they all came in fun shaped bowls topped with flowers. Everything was so flavorful and delicious.

The final touch-we got some items boxed to go and they labeled each box and drew cute faces on the boxes.

This is a great restaurant and WE WILL BE BACK!!!"
"Tried the crispy pad thai, the octopus appetizer, and the duck rice noodles. Loved the first two, wouldn't get the duck again because it didn't taste like duck, more like meatballs.  I'm still thinking of that pad thai though! Very well thought of fusion food, we both loved it! Great texture, flavor, and quantity. Very pleased with the ambiance and live music as well.

For the yelpers: You might like this local tip: 
We asked for a traditional vietnamese dipping sauce that is commonly used to dip in meat in Vietnamese home cooked meals. It's called ""Muoi Tieu Chanh"". The waitress knew what I was talking about and brought a dish over. It was 1618's own version of my favorite sauce! Great job! Ask the staff to try their salt and pepper lemon sauce if you like a special tart kick to your grilled octopus. It's great!"

"I was craving Asian food and we saw that 1618 head patio dining and decided to try them again during this Covid crisis. We made a reservation online for 5 PM on the patio and arrived at about 10 till five. They had us wait while they prepared the table and took us out to the patio where the combination of large umbrellas and a misting fan kept the area relatively cool. 

Bottled water with ice in glasses was left for us along with the menus. It was a little breezy, and the paper menus tended to fly away, but we were able to hold onto them long enough to find food we wanted. From the happy hour menu, I ordered a Saigon summer which was coconut rum with pineapple and was delicious. My husband ordered the yellow curry with chicken and white rice while I ordered the grilled tofu avocado vermicelli bowl.

The drink came out right away followed very quickly by the food. Since my dish was vegetarian, they provided a vegan ""fish sauce"" which was extraordinary. The grilled tofu was better than any I had ever had in the whole bowl was a delightful mix of flavors and textures. My husband very much enjoyed his yellow curry which was very rich and a little spicy. 

Our waitress, Catherine, was attentive and kept an eye on us, clearing unused plates and ensuring that we had everything we needed. Although the temperature outside was in the high 90s and the sun was setting, causing our table to partly be in the sunshine, we were comfortable and very much enjoyed our meal. I look forward to dining inside when Covid is a memory!"

"To put it frankly, I was blown away by this place! Here's why:

Word on the street is that the original owners of 888 sold the place and opened up 1618 on riverside. Smart move. The restaurant is portrayed as a fusion restaurant with a lot of influence from Vietnam, Singapore, China, and other Asian cultures.

The food is AMAZING. At least what I tried. Definitely recommend the Lemongrass Duck Skewers. Super flavorful and tender. The fried whole fish was absolutely delicious. It comes with a side of papaya salad which is a great palette cleanser. It's not as spicy as traditional Thai style, but still really yummy. The star of the meal is the lobster. Whatever is in that sauce, flavor bomb in the mouth! It's supposed to be a little more sweeter and slightly spicier, but it's a fusion restaurant and they're catering to the area.

Downside is that the food is pretty pricey here. You can tell as soon as you walk in that it's a little bit on the boujee side, but hey, you get what you pay for. 

Definitely a good place for a nice date night or a place to take a group of about 4-8 so you can try a lot of food and split the bill!"

The space is beautiful, and it's clear that the staff truly appreciate their customers."

I got the chance to visit 1618 Asian Fusion twice. As a Vietnamese who grew up in Vietnam, I'd have to say that 1618 Viet food is not Vietnamese 100% authentic. If you are looking for true authentic Viet food, then 1618 is not that place (which the name of the restaurant has explained, fusion Viet). Now, being a fusion restaurant, I'd have to say that their dishes do fairly represent the Asian taste with great twists. The dishes are seasoned and cooked to perfection. However, a bit too mild for me as I do prefer flavorful dishes. For me, the item that I'm most impressed with is their egg coffee and I think is their must try! Overall, I had great experience at the restaurant, with enjoyable atmosphere and customer service. If you like Asian food but are not comfortable with exotic taste, then 1618 is definitely your perfect choice! But if you would like authentic Viet food, come to Houston and hit me up ;)

"Been here twice and soo impressed with their food each time. I LOVE their egg rolls. They use taro fillings in their egg rolls and it makes it taste soo amazing. I wish they would sell these in frozen packages. 

I got the Vietnamese Bowl with pork and egg rolls. They are very generous with their portions. It came with like 4 mini egg rolls along with the pork. My only complaint was that their pork slices were burnt and I had to pick out every burnt part. (Not sure if that's their style of cooking or not to give it a smokey taste) But the second time I was there I told them to not burn the pork and they fixed it! 

Beware - most of their Thai dishes are on the spicer end and you can't modify the spicy level. The Tom yum soup, Pad Thai, and pineapple fried rice were all very spicy. (For reference at Thai restaurants I usually order spice level 2 out of 5) I came with people who love spicy food so it was perfect for them. 

The Pad Thai was a bit too sweet for my taste. I prefer my pad Thai to be more savory than sweet.

"This place felt like home. I'm Cambodian American and Southeast Asian food can sometimes be difficult to come across when traveling. I was extremely pleased with what they have here. 
I ordered banana leaf salmon... which is known as Drey Amok in Khmer. Often, this dish is a red curry fish soufflé, usually served inside a banana leaf that is constructed into a bowl. It hit all of the high notes with the flavors but the soufflé was the only component that was missing.
My wife had pineapple fried rice and she thought it was great. 
My friends had green curry (lemmongrass) and stir friend filet minon dipped in a salt, pepper, lemon sauce. In my culture, this is called lok lak. Both were also fantastic.
We also had lemongrass duck on skewers, appetizer platter and salt, pepper calamari, and satay (chicken skewers) all were amazing.
Additionally, the service was impeccable. The cocktail drinks were reveled by everyone who had one. 
The decor was elegant and design was fresh. The menu was disguised to appeal to Americans for sure."
First time eating here with my family for lunch and we had a good amount of portion for what we paid.Service was amazing and Phat our server did an amazing job!He was so kind and accommodating and even offered us hand sanitizer before we left!They definitely practice the safety of others during the pandemic and we can't wait to eat here again.Thank you Phat for giving us an amazing first time experience and serving us really good food.Was so good we forgot to take food pictures
"I really wanted to like this place. I ordered shrimp pho, shrimp and pork egg rolls and Tom yum soup. 
1) pho: they didn't devein the shrimp and it was super undercooked, like raw in the middle. I even boiled the broth before adding it to the bowl, but it still didn't cook the shrimp through. After the first bite of raw poop string shrimp, I tossed the rest. 
2) Tom yum: it didn't taste like your typical Thai restaurant, it was really sweet and not tangy/spicy like I'm used to. 
3) egg rolls with fish sauce and lettuce were excellent, I'd order these over and over again. 
I'll give this place another shot, and try something else and order more egg rolls."

"My Date made a reservation and brought me here on a Tuesday night saying he wanted to take me to the best restaurant in Austin, and honestly everything was AMAZING! Starting with the hostess, very welcoming and we were sat promptly at our nicely ""reserved"" booth. Next, we were greeted by our server Sonia with water, and while pouring for us gave a brief explanation of the drink specials. They all sounded SO AMAZING! We decided the 30% off bottle of wine special which was too great to pass up as we both love wine! Next Sonia came to the table and presented the wine and poured for us in these beautiful wine glasses they use, so far all the service felt very classy, and that is something I really look for in a place, and rarely experience. We started with the Calamari, and though I don't eat the tentacle part, there were plenty of rings, and my Date was more than happy to eat the rest! Best Calamari I've ever had, and the sauce was just perfectly flavorful and really set it off! We then ordered the ""Banh Trang Nuong"" which was explained as a Vietnamese street food, and wow, so interesting how it came with these beautiful little scissors to cut it up and it was fun. Honestly the flavor was so uniquely delightful. Just the right amount of spicy elements to it as well, and I'm a little fearful of spice. We then had the 1618 Egg Rolls, which were perfectly hot, light in flavor, and crispy because it seems they use rice paper instead of thicker dough to wrap and fry them in, and the veggies and fish sauce complimented it nicely. Lastly, we ordered the Lemongrass Duck Skewers, and woah...this was by far my favorite as I had never tried Duck before, and OMG the flavor was incredible. Definitely a must try! For dessert we got the new Cheesecake Dessert and the presentation and flavor were just a perfect finish to the date! They bring it to you with a side of ice cream, and the fun begins...our server Sonia lit a glass of some type of alcohol and once turning the glass to allow it to thicken a little as it was flickering a blue flame she poured it over the cheesecake and with the little blue flame engulfing the cheesecake she ""dashed"" cinnamon on it to make it have a beautiful and fiery finish, and then topped it with the ice cream....wow...quite the presentation and I have never tasted a dessert so perfectly smooth and sweet! By this point we were in Heaven! Sonia was such an amazing server, she was always there with a happy demeanor when we needed her, and she always kept our water and wine glasses topped off. She had a super sweet and perky demeanor as a server, and a vibe about her service that really made us both feel like royalty! The manager John came by the table to greet us and he also had such a wonderful and welcoming personality it makes perfect sense why this place is the best! Keep it up 1618 Asian Fusion, we will 100% be back and talking about you to everyone we know!"
"As an Asian person I find myself cringing at the word 'fusion' a lot, especially coupled with anything asian. No I would not like a pho taco, you get that nonsense away from me! I want carnitas taco and pho in a bowl please. I am well aware that asian restaurants dont necessarily come with the best service either. This restaurant is a step up from the owners of 888. And they brought the best! 

Service was phenomenal we had a group of 20 and 1 server. Multiple drinks, snacks, entrees, oh my goodness my water was always filled too. This man deserves an award! It was my friend's birthday and he got the live music to sing happy birthday TWICE! It was such a smooth experience, I was blown away. I was definitely dredding the asian restaurant bill/food mix up fiasco.

"Okay, any place that names itself 'Asian fusion' is always going to get some degree of healthy skepticism. 

That being said, I was pleasantly surprised with all of our food here. As a picky eater - especially with Asian food, I loved all the things we ordered. 

My partner and I ordered the salt and pepper calamari (my fave), the Tom yum soup, the Vietnamese bowl and crispy pad Thai. 

For the most part, the Vietnamese dishes tasted like something I'd get at a good viet restaurant, but with a little bit of pizazz and fancy presentation.  

Also, the part where I'll give 1618 a lot more credit is that there were small things in the food that really showed their care and creativity. My calamari had these beautiful wild flowers laid on it. 

And, I even got nostalgic eating their eggs rolls. The style of Vietnamese egg rolls that I rarely ever see is those made with rice paper (as oppose to egg wrappers). The moment I bit into the egg rolls it reminded me of what my grandmother use to make with the crunchy skin and layers of layers of chewy rice paper. 

1618, thanks for the nostalgia and for bringing fusion forward. 

Yes - I'd go back, and I'd bring a friend!"

"Reprising my role as a dedicated Yelper (I've been busy, yo) to sing the praises of this Hot and New estab. 

1618 is named after its address, but the lack of creativity stops there. The interior is a gorgeous, modernist representation of traditional Asian architecture. Raw wood is the star, here. Bent strips create spectacular movement from the ceiling to the walls. It's breathtaking. 

But ok, let's talk about the food. Holy crap, this food is a far cry from the sports bar that used to fill the kitchen. The menu is Asian. There's not a geographical location that gets the bulk of real estate on it, but everything is chosen carefully and the food we had was absolutely phenomenal. 

We tried the pad Thai and the fried rice and I know that is super basic, but these dishes are anything but basic. The pad Thai had a hint of heat that left the chili's lingering, but didn't overpower the other flavors. The fried rice had the most tender filet mignon in it that could've stood by itself. I'm in internal conflict trying to decide which dish was better. I highly recommend both. 

Lastly the service is a dream. Our server (Kai?)(I'm sorry, I'm in a good daze!) was amazing. He was attentive and answered all our questions and just made us feel welcome overall. 

I don't venture to riverside often, but you can guarantee I'll be headed this way over and over again. Spread the word, they're new and ready to please."

"Had a really great dinner at 1618 this evening. Loved the atmosphere and relaxed ambience. The excellent, attentive service provided by Audrey, manager and staff was on par with a fine dining room. Given the restaurant was pretty busy for a Monday night, I was surprised by the attentive service. 

The food is - per its namesake - a fusion of Southeast asian & Chinese dishes. 5 items sampler appetizer was tasty, both visually and flavorful, with all the different colors, textures, and sauces. It's like 30+ different combinations  of sauces & apps. The duck skewers were juicy and the lemongrass stalks they were grilled with provided a nice flavor profile. The tom yum kha was delicious and packed full of ingredients in a hot (not very spicy) & sour broth. The pineapple fried rice was a mouthwatering dish made with giant sized prawns, fresh (not canned) pineapples, basil, chunks of duck, and egg - highly recommended dish. 

This place has been soft opened for ~4 months with an official opening for 01/31/2020. Amazing food, great service, comfortable setting - a fusion for great success. You won't regret stopping in."

"The main thing I want to highlight about my first visit to 1618 is the stellar service. My server (I believe her name was Shaira) did a phenomenal job of thoughroughly explaining the menu, specials, popular dishes, and upcoming events. I wish this was a common occurrence at other restaurants.

"This is without question, one of the best all around dining experiences in the greater Austin area. You will not find better bang for your buck anywhere, period. Great food and exceptional service! Highly recommend! Indoor/outdoor vibe is great for date night, girls night and even solo dining after a long day at work (aka zoom fatigue). Can't speak more highly of this place, been multiple times. Vegetarian and vegan friendly!!!
This is the 3rd time we've been at 1618 and I'm finally writing a review. They are very consistent with a superior experience each time!  The appetizers are delicious, as well as the entrées. We have been too full each time to try the desserts.  Tonight we got the chicken satay appetizer which was delightful. My boyfriend got the combo fried rice which he really enjoyed!  I got the Vietnamese bowl with pineapple sauce instead of fish sauce per my request & I loved it!  It even has egg rolls right on it & they were amazing too!   All of the wait staff and management were very professional, friendly, and attentive - perfect!  Cathy (or Catherine) was our waitress tonight & she was excellent!  The restaurant is beautiful inside. We will be back again soon!
Final prep of the filet mignon & rib pho was done table side and the flavors were delicious. It included two brontosaurus ribs that were fall off the bone tender. Highly recommend but come hungry. Large portions!
"1618 Asian Fusion is worth a visit. The food is consistently delicious. We had the P2. Pho Brisket and Filet which has a decadent clear beef broth that has the essence of a traditional Vietnamese broth. The P7 which is their most expensive Pho. It was worth every penny! They bring the dish out fresh sans broth with a side of egg yolk. They pour their 16 hour broth right there which allows the raw filet mignon to cook to the perfect temperature before adding broth to the egg yolk. The rib that is included has been grilled to perfection allowing the char flavor to really enhance the overall flavor profile. I also highly recommend pouring in the yolk to create a smooth creaminess that makes the dish super decadent. The L3. Filet Mignon Pepper Steak (medium). These juicy nuggets of meaty deliciousness have achieved gold status with my family, we order it at every visit. Finally, dessert...the tiramisu although not made in house is very well balanced (portion is a little small). My favorite way to end my visit is with the mango sticky rice! The texture of the rice with a slight saltiness pairs perfectly with the balanced sweetness of the sauce, top that with a sweet ripe mango and you get one of the best things to ever grace your palate. 

The only thing that could use a slight improvement is the speed of service. They do a heavy volume of to go orders which seems to impact the in house dining experience. Don't get me wrong though, it's worth the wait!"
Hands down best pho I've tasted in Austin. Love both the food and the service and atmosphere. I would be a regular here for sure if I lived here. Even compared to nyc I gotta say this is super legit. 6 stars if possible!
"But FIRST dessert AND while in Austin....OMG my first here and I am beyond HAPPY! I ordered waaaay too much food for one person but how else are you going to really experience a place? Right? My heart is happy, my pansa full! 

Not only is the food AMAZING, the hospitality is phenomenal! My server Bryan was excellent! They really care about their guests! So next time you're in Austin be sure to stop by!! 

They have a great Happy Hour too! M-Thursday from 5pm-7pm. $5 cocktails*$5 Apps*$4"

Waverly was amazingggg! I never leave reviews but this girl explained the whole menu to me and gave me the best customer service I've ever had!! Love 1618 and the bartender, Waverly.
"Food: 5; Drink: 4; Design: 5.

It is rare to find a Vietnamese fusion restaurant and most of them are not great. 1618 is one of the few that is different from other Viet fusion restaurants. The food here is not authentic Vietnamese food, but if I wanted authentic food, I wouldn't go here in the first place. It's Vietnamese fusion and it's surprisingly good. We got baby octopus, lemon grass duck skewers, crispy chilean salmon, chicken sui mai, lamb chop, and fried onion filet mignon. They were all great. Different but great! Some of these dishes like the filet mignon can be related to Vietnamese popular dishes but the food was made and presented with a very unique taste that did not lose the traditional flavour, yet offered something very different.

Their drinks were also very enjoyable. I tried the emperor, tokyotini, doers dragon, and Saigon rum punch. All of them were interesting and very floral. The emperor was the least floral and aslo what I like most. The Saigon rum punch can be a bit a difficult to appreciate since it doesn't have a standout flavour. However for those who have been to Saigon and know that place well, this cocktail can bring you a feeling of nostalgia about Saigon, a place that's humid, hot and hustling, yet charming and dynamic."
This restaurant is deserving of its five star status. Only opened a year ago but should be here for a long time. The food is delicious. The ambience is dreamy. The service is wonderful. If you like Asian food, Don't pass this place up. Catherine was an excellent server, Who is very friendly and helpful. We had the Drunken Devil which is a special containing shrimp wrapped in beef in a Panang curry sauce and even comes with a glass of wine. The Crispy pad Thai was the best ever. We had the pineapple fried rice along with the fillet mignon in green curry. We had the happy hour between 5 to 7 PM which included the Tokyotini, a sweet and delicious melon martini for five bucks. We will be heading back to California soon but definitely would be returning if we lived in Austin.

The happy hour menu comes highly recommended for several good reasons.  Each dish was prepared with care and hosted its own homemade sauce - which is made fresh and in-house, by the way - they don't buy any of their sauces.  And we were offered 30% off bottles of wine (including local Austin wine) - yes, please & thank you!

Catherine was a BLAST and top-notch server - talk about the best service ever, she explained all the dishes and wines (and paired them beautifully), dropped by with this fabulous drink cart of delish dinner shots, and continued to ensure our entire dinner experience was nothing short of the best.  Thank you, Catherine!

I'll be back for more great food and great service (and will always ask for Catherine's section), and I can't wait to share the newly announced Saturday & Sunday DIM SUM BRUNCH with the rest of my circle ... and come back for the Pho with my lunch group ... and feel safe about setting up physically-distanced happy hours.

I'm happy to support this local business!  Make your reservations through Yelp."

"Well damn, when did this place happen? Stunning interior, cloth napkins, free & easy parking - all on East Riverside? They could rename this place Pearl of the Quarter. 

It appears what you're getting here is their spin on the most popular Thai, Viet, & Chinese dishes, with IG presentation and impeccable service. On the random Thursday afternoon I was there, Shane & Zayn working the front were pretty perfect. 

I did think the baby octopus was a little chewier than I like, but that's subjective. The Bún Thit was solid, and the duck on lemongrass skewers was surprisingly great. The seasoned fish sauce was a nice touch. I also left here thinking I played my order way too safe, but I can only eat so much on my own. Next visit I'll just let Shane or Zayn pick all of it.  

They're still in soft open, I'm curious what the final tweaks will be, and if 1618 AF were downtown or on East 6th, the hipsters would be lining up for days. Maybe there is some kind of renaissance happening on East Riverside. That'd be cool."

"Please let me start off with stating that I like to be very straight forward and honest with my experiences so that people can really know what to expect and not just be wowed by the aesthetics of a place.

Living in south Austin, I feel that my options for Asian food are pretty limited. Therefore, I pretty much try any new Asian place I can find in hopes it'll be my new go to!

Firstly, any place that has Fusion in its name will receive some skepticism because people will most likely associate it with fast casual dining that's usually not anything close to traditional, which it is just that IMO. It just doesn't fit the vibe/atmosphere of this restaurant because it's beautiful inside and feels upscale. However, they had the front door open in the middle of summer, in Austin, TX, so it was muggy and there was a fly going around us while we ate. Maybe that's to add to the south East Asian dining experience? 

Ultimately the food is what really matters.
We were the first diners of the day and I feel that the food was a little slow to come out given no one else was dining atm. But I'll give them the benefit of the doubt assuming the wait time is due to them making everything fresh? 
My fiancé ordered the duck noodle soup and I ordered the dry noodle bowl with egg noodles. After a while our food comes and my order came with rice noodles due to waiter mix up which caused it to be sent back to the kitchen and remade, adding even more time. Normally I wouldn't really mind but I was SO hungry this morning haha which is why I didn't even bother to take pictures before eating. Although the presentation wasn't anything special either. Then again, taste is what really matters for me. Our waiter was apologetic and very kind about the mistake. My dish came with a side of soup as well and it was a little too sweet for my taste. It lacked depth that one would get from a bone broth, but perhaps it wasn't a bone broth to begin with in which case I would understand. However it tasted the same as the broth in my fiancé's duck noodle soup. He prefers the sweeter side of things so it didn't bother him. I know that depending on where in Vietnam you visit, they have different palates. These dishes remind me of the Hue region as a lot of their food is on the sweeter side. ‍ 
Lastly, the dry noodle entree itself was good but my dish was not hot, more like lukewarm which is disappointing. The sauce is savory and sweet as well and good on its own. However, when sipping on the side soup along with my dish, the two together are way too sweet and ruin the dish all together. 

All in all, I'd rate this place based solely on what we ordered, a 6.5/10 on taste and for the value of what you pay, at 5/10. My fiancé was so much more impressed than I so we'll probably give it another shot in the future and hopefully I can bump this place from a 3 star to a 5 star if the food and experience are better.

It's worth a shot b/c it's a cute spot for date night and if you're not a critic like me then you might enjoy it."
We went here on a whim a few months ago and it is to die for!! I ordered the lamb and it was so good. We will definitely be back soon.
"Found this restaurant on Uber Eats with as part oF their no delivery fee for local restaurants which is great BTW and DoorDash and Grubhub need to step up. But I digress, their menu looked good, pictures were appetizing and prices were reasonable. 

I am so glad we gAve it a chance! We had the General Tso's chicken, crab Rangoon and the Titanic Roll. 

Order arrived ahead of  promised time, packaged perfectly, hot and fresh! The Titanic Roll was crab, shrimp and creeks cheese deep fried with spicy mayo and eel sauce. Divine. Crab Rangoon was perfectly cooked and both dishes were still  crispy which is a feat as we all know  for carry out and delivery. My fiancé loved the General Tso's and it smelled heavenly. 
They followed all my notes in my order which is such a bonus. 

Another good place that  I will continue to support and you should too!"
Let's be clear, Sakura is certainly not Sakana on Broad. Having two restaurants with similar names in the marketplace can make things a tad confusing. It also explains why everything ordered was different than expected, and not necessarily in a good way. The spring rolls and egg rolls were fine, but my wife's fried chicken rice was extremely garlicky. I had the teriyaki chicken, and while the portion size was impressive, everything was extremely salty that came with the meal. The soup was highly unusual in flavor on top of the salt. Delivery was amazingly quick, but I do wonder if we would have had a different experience in restaurant. It feels a bit like they are trying to be someone else, and need to find their own place in the market, something to help them stand out. I am certain I will have to try them again to see if we just ordered poorly.

"This used to be our go-to place for Malaysican/Singaporean cuisine.  However, it appears that the chefs have changed and the quality of the food isn't as good as we remembered.  For example, the roti, which used to consist of many thin layers of yumminess, that is crispy on the outside and soft and tender inside, turned out to be a disappointment in recent visits.  Instead of many thin layers, the roti was a clump of thick dough, which was difficult to chew and not at all what it supposed to be.

Assorted Assam Seafood Hotpot, another one of our favorites, was less than expected.  Soup was still delicious, but there was hardly anything in it.  Not good value for the price.

Sambal Bunchies, which we always order, was also disappointing.  The green beans tasted overcooked. And instead of large prawns, smaller shrimps were used.  Hmm...

What is worth ordering is the KL crab - so good and flavorful!  And of course, the service is very good there."
"Compared to all the other locations this one is probably the least touched location in terms of decorations and atmosphere.

However being as large as it is, it has been great for throwing large dinner parties with a big group of people.

The more people you have the more food you can try and everything on this menu has been tasty and delicious."
"I have ate at a lot of the other Tropika locations, but this was my first time to the Cambie location. We ordered many dishes and everything was really good, much better than I remember from the other locations. I hear that the Cambie location is the original, and that is probably why.  

I've been to Malaysia a few times and I would say that the food was quite comparable to what I had there, although of course there is less selection than Malaysia."
"Tropika's food is not ""authentic"" (it has been ""Hongerized""), but the chain is one of my favourite.  There are very few dishes here that they can't pull off.  Cambie is actually my favourite location, even though Robson is quite nice too.  With that said, parking isn't the best here, but there is usually a spot or two just W of the restaurant.

All of their sauces/curries are pure crack.  Mmm..

Malay Roti - quite bubbly and fresh.  Sauce (some type of curry?) is awesome.

Rendang Lembu - beef was cut nicely into bite-sized chunks. More beautiful sauce.

Chili prawns - the prawns are all large.  Sauce is good, but there was a bit too much of it.

Pineapple fried rice.  Tasty, but volume is a bit small.  They hollow out half a pineapple (bisected lengthwise), but the hollow is not that deep.  So there isn't *that* much rice inside.  Cleaning out the pineapple with a spoon is awesome though.

It's just a *little* bit pricey, but the food is freaking good. Recommended."

I always have a good experience at tropika either with my friends or family. My family used to celebrate Christmas eve here before going to midnight mass. I love the deep fried tofu, the fish, the curries, the vegies, the shrimp cakes, and the pastry bread they have.
"Your Southeast-Asian food utopia...

You can't go wrong coming here if you're looking for delicious Malay/Indo/Singaporean grub.  I don't think I've ever been disappointed with any dish that's left their kitchen.

Start with a Gado-gado salad.  It has their highly addictive peanut sauce and freshly fried tofu and potatoes.  I've yet to find a Gado-gado this tasty anywhere else, even in Indonesia.

Their satay skewers, although small are super flavorful, and somehow work with their canned pineapple pieces (which I normally despise) & their peanut sauce.

I'm a big fan of their curry beef brisket here.  It's Malay style, so it tastes more like a mildly spicy beef stew. My tip is always to pair it with their 'coconut rice' to maximize your flavor smorgasbord!

Their Singaporean fried rice noodles is always on point too... mildly dusted with curry, so you get a little heat.  
 
Roti is crispy, greasy but delicious here, and they give you ample curry sauce to dunk or douse it with.

I'd suggest coming here in groups of at least 4-6+, so you can just order more dishes and sample."
"it was also  my first time at this location.
i thought the service was meh.  we ordered quite a bit for 10 people and we had to double some of the dishes.  so while we were going down the menu to order, the waiter kept rolling his eyes at me, i totally did not know what his problem was. and when we were done ordering, he walked away shaking his head.  i dont know what i said or done wrong but isnt the customer always right? though i did not try to argue anything and just ordered off the menu.

the food was delicious! we ordered
- hainanese chicken
- roti
- beef and chicken skewers
- pad thai
- coconut fried rice
- pineapple  fried rice 
- mussels
- seasonal ""tong choi""
- hot and sour soup
- the beans and prawns
there was probably a few more dishes but i dont remember the names of it

the soup came first and the server, oh my goodness, he literally took 10mins to serve 9 bowls. my mom was soooo impatient with him we just told him to leave it and we'll take care of it ourselves.  i know he was probably a newbie but c'mon, how hard is it to scoop the soup in the bowls?

there was way to much food but we managed to just take the pad thai home because it was getting cold and nobody ate it.

overall, the food was delicious but the waiter that took the order ruined the experience.  i should of complained about him but it was my birthday and i didnt want to cause a scene so i left it at that."

I can't remember the names of most of the menu items, but that's OK. Tropika on Cambie's staff that will help you along so you can free up your table for the next diner waiting. 

I'll be back."
"The oldest location of the chain now, nicely located on Cambie Street, once you enter here, there is a nice little waiting area with a ton of polaroid shots attached to the wall of old patrons who have been here. Sure the colors from the photos are turning a bit yellow, but if you live in Vancouver, you may recognize some friends in the shots.

The place is roomy, with some nice big round tables, for parties of 10 plus. The menu is the same as the other Tropika's that you may have visited, which is always a good thing! The last time here, I ended up eating there fried chicken wings, spicy rice wraps, pineapple fried rice, and beef curry. 

The service was real good, as always when I come here. The food comes to the table piping hot, what you would expect from a restaurant of this quality. They also have fresh seafood at market price, and a good drink menu, which includes fresh cut coconut. 

The one advantage of this location, is the parking, as you can park along Cambie, a block down, just watch the sign of the times you are allowed to park. When your thinking of Malaysian food in Vancouver, this is one of those places that comes to mind."

It was savory and well seasoned without overdoing the spices one bit. I had a fresh lime soda to wash it down and dessert was deep fried bananas and ice cream ...YUM!  Service was friendly, prompt, and attentive. I will be back!

This is a nice little place located on Cambie. We called in for dinner one evening. We got there about 5:30pm for an early dinner. There were barely anyone in there but around 6pm, there were quite a bit of people. The staff were really friendly and the place was clean. We ordered three dishes for two of us: spicy and sour soup, lamb curry and beef curry. We also ordered a small bowl of rice. The soup was quite delicious; the vinegar was very pronounced - I like it just like that. The bowl of soup is perhaps good for 3-4 people. Since it was a cold evening and we really wanted soup, we finished the entire bowl so by the time we were having our main dishes, we were half full. Both the curries were delicious - I loved the aroma of the lemongrass. The portions were very generous for $19 per bowl of curry. We ordered a small bowl of soup for about $11. We thought we had ordered too much food and we actually did. We took the rest home and had it for lunch and dinner the following day; so $60 for 3 meals for two sounded pretty good to us!
"Initially I was recommended to Tropika's Laksa so I headed on over there for dinner. But low & behold, they stop serving laksa after lunchtime, so keep that in mind ! 

Nevertheless, my friend and I decided to order the pineapple fried rice (served in half of a pineapple) and the daun pisang rendang fish. The fish dish was very flavourful but also super oily and salty. After the first few bites, the oiliness becomes quite off putting, so I recommend sharing it with 1-2 other people ! The Pineapple fried rice was a bit underwhelming and the pineapple fruit was still hard and sour."
"Food was 4 stars. Service, first 4 stars and later it turned 3 stars. 

All of sudden, it turned chilly day here. Yes, it's time for Laksa!  They have two types laksa : Singaporean or Curry. Also you can choose noodle type. Today's my order Singaporean with egg yellow noodle. For dessert, warm Bubur Cha Cha. 

I was bit surprised they have real seafood on top not like fish cake even the price was reasonable. Mussels, prawns and squids were big enough. Prawns were lack of flavor but squids were prepared very well. Coconut milk/broth ratio was just right. I'm very satisfied. 

About dessert, I don't know if the warm Bubur Cha Cha is not common but our server came back to our table to confirm and even we finished noodle, we had waited about 10 min to receive it. So I checked if they forgot our order. 

Anyway the dessert was so gentle and delicious. Sweetness and texture were perfect.

I will be back here again."
"One-line review: Mostly average, but better if you stick with the curries.

We had roti on the brain and went in search of a nearby restaurant, only to discover that it was closed during the day. We ended up at Tropika for the sake of convenience and well, roti.

We had:

Indonesian fried rice, which was one of the specials of the day. It was... alright but not special in any way. I violated one of my sacrosanct rules of eating out: NEVER order fried rice. The chicken satay skewers that came with the plate were decent; they came with a chili peanut sauce -- not really spicy, but tasty.

Lamb curry with Malay bread. This was a very plain option -- just curry and bread -- but it was the star of the table. The curry (which we ordered spicy) was mild to our taste -- and that's not a compliment. Nevertheless, it was hearty and flavourful, and we were glad to have ordered it.

The Mango salad, also a special. This was HORRID -- sicky sweet and drowning in some kind of dressing/sauce, this dish of thinly sliced mangos over a fairly standard diner iceberg lettuce/tomato/cucumber salad was virtually inedible. My wife stopped eating after the first couple of bites; I stuck with it and nearly finished it, just because I couldn't bear to leave a $12 plate mostly untouched. But in retrospect, I should have complained and tried to send it back. DO NOT ORDER. You've been warned.

I might give this place 4 stars if we had simply ordered two curry dishes (maybe one with rice, the other with bread) and left it at that. But given the quality of the other food, I'll rate it average.

Our server was not helpful; I asked a question (about what he'd recommend) and he basically didn't answer it. They did keep our water filled. Parking was free on the street, though I think there were meters around as well.

Bottom line: I'd come back here and stick strictly to the curry lunches. But even at that, I'm not anxious to get back here anytime soon."
"Came here on the weekend during lunch hours and tried their lunch specials. The prices are pretty reasonable during lunch so I can't speak to the main menu.

I overheard the table next to us asking questions about the menu and it seemed the sever was struggling to explain the dish to them or make alternative suggestions. I felt they were pretty generous with their seafood (got a good amount of shrimp in mine) but the flavour didn't have the punch I expect in Malaysian cuisine. Overall this place left a neutral feeling of ok food, ok prices, and ok service. Nothing stood out but also no real complaints. I might suggest this place for big groups if you're in the area but not really worth the commute otherwise."

On my hunt for vegan laksa, I tried Tropika and asked if they could prefer a vegan version of their curry laksa. They agreed after I peppered them with questions regarding what would be in it. The food came out in less than 5 minutes and was a huge bowl -- delicious noodles, with lots of different veggies, and tofu, with a tremendously spicy broth. This restaurant is generally on the more expensive side, but their laksa is well-priced at $11.50 plus tax. Service wasn't particularly friendly, but I appreciate the effort they made to alter the laksa to my standards. Recommended for vegans if you don't mind asking a dozen questions to customize your order. Delicious food.
"It has literally been years since the last time we dined at Tropika. Many years ago, this was one of the first Malaysian restaurants that we tried and we fell in love with the spices associated with SE Asian cooking such as Malaysian and Thai cuisine.

First up was some drinks to accompany our order of Roti Canai. Tropika makes a nice version of this with light and crispy yet chewy layers served with a curry dipping sauce.

The Fish Cakes that we ordered were tender and plump while the Pad Thai that we ordered turned out to be a spicier version than we're usually accustomed to.

We rounded out our meal with an assortment of Chicken, Beef, and Pork Skewers accompanied by a thick peanut dipping sauce.

We returned for a revisit 3 months later (before the coronapocaplyse shut down all dine-in options) and ordered a bunch of stuff... including Roti, Chicken and Beef Skewers, Pan-Fried Hokkien Mee ($17.95), and Pan-Fried Pomfret with Sweet and Sour Sauce ($20.95).

Skewers and roti here are always good and I like how meaty the beef skewers are. They expertly de-bone the fried pomfret at the table in front of you and that's always a fun thing to watch.

Fairly solid SE Asian eats at this long-standing establishment."
"Came by in a group of 11 for dinner on a Saturday night.  We do frequent another Malaysian establishment (BL) and it had been a while since I was last in Tropika.  The room is quite open and good for accommodating groups.  

We ordered several dishes which were hit and miss.  The highlights of the meal were the Roti Canai, the Chicken Satay and the Homestyle Chicken...the Lemon Chicken was not great (overly breaded which became soggy with the sauce) and the Sambal Kang Kong (one of my fav dishes) was overly cooked and it lost its flavour and colour.

The service was good and we were happy to find free street parking a block away...that is always good.

Gave it three stars as they accommodated our large group, the service was good and a few of the dishes were enjoyed by all."

"Tropika has been around for a long time if i remember correctly. They used to have many locations, but I think they closed some of them over the years.

I always order their chicken satay, prawn cakes, pompano fish, pine apple fried rice and pork chops. I think those are my go to dishes.

Their roti is also not bad, but personally not my taste.

The restaurant used to get very busy and loud before covid-19. Service is very typical Asian restaurant, ie you have to flag down servers to get things. But food comes out fairly quickly and servers responds very promptly.

I hope they don't close more locations as it'll be a shame to lose this restaurant from this city's dining scene."

"(In the interest of full transparency, this review is based on a delivered order via SkipTheDishes.)

"the Festival takes place on the best of the longer weekend in spring time in a relaxed atmosphere awashed by the great nature scenery that is of the superbly manicured Franklin Conservatory Park. The people are gentle, friendly, not drunk like people in other festivals in town, there are also a lot of Caucasian visitors coming from Europe, England, France, Germany, Spain, Israel, Russia, Alaska and elswhere...they are probably here in town visiting their family and friends but made good choice to attend; so the Festival had gone global in a sense and not just confine to one or two countries but at least 50+ countries involved.. I lost count.
The food is ofcourse excellent nothing can be compared, I've been  ripped off at the ribs-fest(rip-fest) with their boiled ribs and dogs covered with thick gooey sauce before and never again, I'd prefer getting ripped off by the variety of tasteful asian food any time of the days, weeks and years :); the entry is free(not charging you $10-$15 like other festivals)so you can afford to bring family and friends, the food very cheap and the park is so huge with multi spots with activities for you and your pet to to freely roam and play, it'll be a great Memorable weekend and always had been."
"First time attending.. It was a fun event.The food was delicious. There was a Healthy Gourmet Vegetable spot that had Bamboo rice that was to die for. Lots of vegan/vegetarian noodles, pad thai, lo mein! If you are vegan you want to ask if they put animal products in because some vegetarian looking dishes had ground beef/chicken that you can't see. The bubble tea was made with non-diary creamer so that was good. 

I only watched the evening performances and the finale by the Punjab people was such an amazing close to the eventful weekend. Can't wait to go next year! 

Some negatives: some people think it is cool to smoke in a family friendly event.... NO! Also, unfortunately there were some youngster disturbing the peace by starting  fights. But that's okay, the police handled it with finesse."
"A celebration of all things Asian takes place over Memorial Day weekend on the beautiful grounds of the Franklin Park Conservatory . More than 15 different countries and cultures are represented, including Bengalis, Burmese, Cambodian, Chinese, Indian, Indonesian, Japanese, Korean, Lao, Malays, Singaporean, Pakistan, Filipino, Thais and Vietnamese. 

The Marketplace is a little underwhelming with vendors selling chatzkes that you can find at any Pier One Imports or bargain store, though some stalls do offer original services or information about different Asian groups and organizations.  

The entertainment schedule is impressive. It's loaded with dancers, actors, singers, drummers, choruses and martial arts groups performing on a few different stages and an outdoor amphiteater throughout the day and evening.  I was mesmerized by the costumes and really enjoyed seeing traditional dances from Cambodia, Burma and Japan, and particularly enjoyed the Bhuddist chanting.    

The ""food court"" area offers the whole gamut of Asian food- which, in and of itself, makes attending the festival totally worth while!  Local Asian resturants set up stalls and serve up some of their best sellers. Tables are strewn around the stages & park, but most folks just plop down in the grass and enjoy their food picnic style.

Across the board, I enjoyed the Asian Festival but was partially annoyed with the effort it took to get there in terms of parking and shuttling.  Other than that, it was worth the effort.  Especially since it is a free festival and family-friendly.  It's a great experience to be exposed to other, perhaps unfamiliar cultures. 

I will definitely go again, but with slightly different expectations."
"Anything that celebrates culture and diversity is a plus in my book - just wish everyone could be on board with culture and diversity.

We've been to the Asian festival every year for the past few years - this year we brought the little guy with us - our five month old was FASCINATED by everything he saw  (Probably would have been fascinated without the festival, but hey...  who knows?) and we all had a good time.  Enjoyed some Filipino food and Indonesian sports and some wooden board breaking.  :-)  It's well organized, just wish the lines for food weren't so long, but hey, which festival doesn't have long food lines?"
"This was our first time visiting the Asian Festival, and overall it was OK.

The website was hard to navigate, but eventually you could find some useful information (especially about parking).  They had several lots available to park in at no charge with shuttles to take you to and from the festival.  There was a bit of a wait for the shuttle on the return, though, but not too bad.

The festival overall had a somewhat haphazard, disorganized ambiance. There was a pretty large outdoor area with assorted vendors including some very non-Asian vendors (State Farm) and marginally Asian (Acura, Honda).  I thought there would be more cute Asian merchandise, crafts, etc. to buy, but there didn't seem to be much in this regard (unless we missed it).  They had a lot of booths with kid-oriented things, and inside there were some cultural displays and a small stage for cultural performances.  

There was a very large outdoor food court of sorts with a whole variety of food and beverages.  We tried two of the egg rolls from a specialty egg roll company (I forget the name).  They were $5 each and mostly stuffed with cabbage rather than meat.  Not terrible but not worth $5.  The Vietnamese iced coffee from a different vendor was also pretty good, but very overpriced for $5 as well for about a Starbucks grande size.

They had a large outdoor stage with continuous performances, but it was just too hot and humid to sit and watch them.  

Overall not a bad experience but far from amazing; maybe they could plan it about a month earlier, though, before the weather gets so hot and humid."
What a fun time! Lots of different foods, desserts and drinks. Plenty of activities going on, shows, live performances, and little shops. Thank God there's plenty of shade available, because it gets hot standing in a line of 30 people waiting to order food. I only gave it 4 stars because parking is a complete joke (just try to get there earlier and pay $5 to park in a lot. It's not worth it driving around for 30 minutes looking for a spot. You're not in the safest area, either.) AND because they need to space everything out. There was thousands of people here, and it's just cramped. I don't mind waiting in line, but 20 to 30 minutes for food is crappy when 1.) it's hot and the sun is beating on you (no shade by food carts) and 2.) since every single food line is 30 people deep, lines start intertwining and people start getting confused. A few times, you could barely move because there's so many people in the food area. All in all, this is a fun place, though. The people are friendly and the food was delicious.   Definitely try the coconut sticky rice, halo-halo, stuffed chicken wings, bubble tea, sesame rolls with munk fish and the red chicken.

"First thing is parking. It is always bad and very unorganized near the festival plus always taken up so most likely you'll be walking a little from your car and even more when you get to the festival but I'm usually getting dropped off anyways lol Kids are always welcome but make sure you have a close eye on them or they'll be gone in the crowd and be careful of the annoying preteens that horse play. : / I usually come on Saturday during early morning or late day since more stuff happens but I suggest going on Sunday if you wanna be around less people/crowd. FOOD! Big portions for cheap. I usually only get rice since I was a vegetarian at the time but I love the bubble tea and this cool tropical fruity drink lol B) There are lots of performances; like martial arts and dancing mainly. They also usually have facts and info on each Asian country in random areas; I also love when they have all the Asian countries come together and walk around the festival. They also have booths where you can buy things from different Asian countries. Some booths can be pricey so make sure you look at most booths before deciding on what to get in case it's cheaper somewhere else. A henna tattoo is also always a must!

It's always nice to have blanket/chair for the grass, bring groups of friends/family makes it more fun and some water/snacks if you don't wanna buy food."
"The sprawling expanse of vendors selling food on a stick and various kinds of fried things and noodles reminds me of an episode of Bizarre Foods. This is the kind of event Andrew Zimmern seeks out. 

One tip: don't pay for parking. We almost did but then found we could park at Wolfe Parke (http://foursquare.com/venue/1552709) for free and take the shuttle over to Franklin Park, also free. At the place where we would've paid to park, we would have walked a lot farther than we did to the free shuttle bus. So don't get trapped in the parking scam. 

There was food from every country you can think of on the Asian continent. I tried some delicious pork on a stick at the Phillipines booth. I went back to find out what it was called and get another and found it was simply barbecue pork. But it didn't taste like any barbecue sauce I've had. It was sweet and savory at the same time. The pork was tender and just the right balance of fat and meat. It was cooked over a fire and had that nice smokey taste. It was delicious. 

I went to a Chinese booth and tried bamboo rice and pan fried bun. The rice was sticky and mushy, almost gelatinous and sweet. It was wrapped in a leaf and tied with a string. There was meat and mushrooms in the center of the rice. It was a little bland. The pork bun was like an egg roll in a doughy sticky bun. Not bad. 

The Lao booth was bad. All the meat was dry, tough and cold. The beef jerky was as chewy as leather. My teeth could hardly handle it. 

Green tea lemonade at the Tea Zone (I think it was called) was delicious. They have a tea shop on Bethel near Microcenter. I may check them out and review them someday. 

The best part was the fried bananas. It was at a booth up near the Tea Zone, I'm not sure what country it was. The banana turns yellow and mushy, like pie filling. It's inside a sweet breading, crunchy on some edges. It's like a fried banana pie. It's awesome and one of the cheapest things at the festival. Three for two dollars. There was also fried taro but it tasted like a dried up turnip. 

Most of all, we went to the festival for the food. I love fairs and festivals. I don't usually go to the entertainment at these things but I thought my little boy might want to check it out. I heard some pretty, new age sounding music at one point and what sounded like Native American (but couldn't have been) chanting and drums before that. The music was quite pleasant. When we finally went to the amphitheater, there were Indian dancers on stage. Their music is usually very irritating but with the bass on the big speakers, it wasn't half bad. My son liked it. Most of the crowd was up dancing and he got up with them and did his own thing. I caught a cute video of it. (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T5d5oVwRe34) 

So, all in all it was a fun day out. It was tolerable even in the almost 90 degree heat. There were lots of vendors selling trinkets and jewelry. Some of them very nice. Most of it was standard fair/festival junk. 

One major complaint I did have was finding anything. There weren't maps around, and the program I happened to accidentally find had a very confusing map in it. When I finally found a sign, the arrow looked like it'd been placed by a one eyed drunken dislexic guy who didn't know where anything was. The arrow pointed in an odd direction. We went there for one thing, and we were parched and needed drink badly. We walked around that place for the better part of an hour and never saw a single food or drink booth. We went around in circles before we finally found the food court. A little more careful planning and better marking would make it a better experience. 

I would also add that Franklin Park, not pretty. It's made out to be a beautiful botannical garden. It's just rolling hills of grass and cement walkways. Not impressed.
