"Prices are very good here, with many dishes under $10. That makes it very affordable. I hope it can stay this way.

With so many Malaysian food restaurants around in the lower mainland, it is really nice to see a Singapore hawker food restaurant. While there are similarities between the two cuisines, there are some subtle differences. 

We ordered 4 items to try:
Sayur lodeh bee hoon - this is pretty nice, with a lemak gravy.

Prawn noodles soup - the broth can be better but it is still a decent bowl

Vegetable fritters - reminds me of Singapore and the hawker stall. Not that commonly found there now. Not bad.

Prata (or roti canai) - it is ok, sometimes I rather buy the frozen version (Singapore brand) from T&T and heat it up myself. Until I see or find the real prata made on site with the flipping and squishing of the dough, I think this dish is usually way overpriced (it is priced ok here) in many similar restaurants here.

I will still come back here to try the other items."
Hurray Great value! Better than McDee more nutritious and way tastier too! I love spicy food and this place reminds me of street food vendors in Indonesia. I love this place for their food not decor but its the taste that counts, right? Anyways for possibly the best value in this city Hawker's Delight. Don't forget to get the vegetable fritters tasty appy.
"***TAKEOUT EXPERIENCE***

Easter weekend, Saturday 2pm. Order for our takeout was placed at 2:09pm. We got our takeout at 2:19pm. Ordered the Mee goreng ($7.25), Fried Kuey Teow ($8.60), and Mee pok ($8.60). We love all of them and each dish is cheap enough for us to be super full and happy. The ingredients are not bad for the price and the portion is good. 
We usually order take out since a) we can't finish it and doggy box costs $0.25 extra, and b) we want to take it home to enjoy it with a good beer. 
The only thing sucks about takeout is we don't really want to take soup dishes to go. So we don't want to try the laksa unless we are eating in. We will try that someday, but for now - fried noodles with a microbrew are our thing."
"This is what eating the vegetable fritters and curry chicken rice feels like. Please don't deprive yourself of this moment. It costs less than $10 :)

https://youtu.be/Vo_GMMLULXw"
Good, basic place to get a quick, cheap bite to eat. I had the Mee Goreng which is fried noodles with tofu, green onion and potato. I didn't get it spicy and I think they ended up making it a bit bland for me. But it was only $5 so I don't expect too much. I definitely want to try some more things.
This place is small but always packed with people because it is so delish!!!! My favourite is the curry chicken noodle, ask them to change it to thin noodle, just change it up and you will know the difference. Highly recommended!!
"BADASS cheapeats here. 

Come any day except Monday (closed, alas), and get your eat on for less than $10.  Curry puffs, laksa, hainan chicken... it's ALL good.  takeout orders typically require 20min wait times.  Space for eating in is limited, but doable (if you're only 2 or 3).  

SOO good."
"Take it from the Singaporean when I say it's pretty darn authentic. The bf ordered Hainanese chicken rice and it was solid. Chicken meat, tender and moist; chili could be spicier but no complaints since it was the proper kind of chicken rice chili i.e. watery tangy garlic chili. For me it was a toss up between tofu goreng and gado-gado, I decided on the latter. Not the best I've had, I prefer the peanut sauce thick and chock full of peanuts but got a diluted version instead. Perhaps the first option would have been better.

In any case, I know hawker food when I see hawker food. No doubt I'll be back to give their mee goreng, laksa or fried bee hoon a shot. Until the foodie strikes again..."
This place is right around the corner from my house and I eat here often. It's fast, super cheap and yummy. I usually get the Mee Siam (with peanut gravy)... it's delicious! It's enough for two meals but I will eat it in one sitting if no one stops me.
I enjoy this HITW but there No way in Hell it's a deli-who makes this crap up?
"The food at hawker's delight is simply amazing. For the price you're paying it's definitely worth trying everything on their menu. So far i've tried their Mee Rebus, Kuay Teow and their Laksa, and they all are superb.

The Mee Rebus was exactly like the one i had in Malaysia. Sauce was almost to perfection, and the Kuay Teow wok fried perfectly. The wait was short for the food, and the staff was friendly. You'd order up front and they'd bring the dishes over to you.

If only i lived close by this would be my new fast food joint."
"Hawkers Delight offers delicious and super cheap Malaysian food with super size me portions. 

A very casual, small setting. Not a lot of seating, but I usually do take out, so it isn't much of a problem. 

My favourite dish is the Nasi Goreng, that stuff is delicious."
"""Skip the canned and bottled drinks. Just go straight to the counter and order a dish. Heck for $5, order two.""

For the price of a value meal, you get a nutritional dish that makes you swear you once were a Singaporean and Malaysian altogether in a previous life and their menu is the comfort food prepared for you when you were a child. Remember?

Yummy, spicy, sweet concoctions from Laksa noodles in coconut curry soup to the covert-looking Hainanese Chicken that's flavourful down to the tasty and fragrant white rice.

It can be a squeeze in there bumping chairs around as you go to the counter to refill your own tea and water. Cash only. It's a hole in the wall for goodness sake. All is forgiven."
If you want a hole in the wall type of restaurant, look no further than Hawkers Delight. Their food is very well priced and extremely delicious. Don't expect the best service, but do expect a filling and excellent meal. This is a great place to get takeout as they are super fast! I always come back to Hawkers when I'm in the area just because it's the type of food that makes you feel good.
Quick and delicious noodles. The portion was huge and I took home leftovers. The server was friendly and helpful.
Probably one of the more authentic singaporean-malaysian food I've eaten. The portion was great, definitely good for sharing. The price is very worth it too. All in all, reminded me of home
"I can't believe 2 of us just ate like kings for $12. I don't think I've had this good and cheap of a meal since traveling in Asia. 

The selection was plenty: mee and nasi gorengs, laksas, veggie fritters, tofu puffs and so many other varieties, I had to hold myself back from spending all of the $20 in my pocket because with nothing (?) over $5.95, I could have easily ordered for 4 people and not felt guilty (mmmm - that would have meant leftovers). Thanks yelpers for all of the dish suggestions - with this many choices on the menu your guidance was a necessity. Sure, the quality is lower than some sit down places around town (Kam's and Banana Leaf come to mind) but at these prices, it's just impossible to pass up!

The set up works well for the tight space: order, grab a drink, grab your cutlery, bowls and tea and then pull up a seat. You can even go ahead and move the tables around if your group is larger."
"One of our favourite lunches.

This place is amazing especially if you are trying to have a vegetarian meal. Lots of options. 

Everything is delicious and cheap. Most meals are about $5 (including tax)."
Always satisfying, love the authentic street-food vendor feel of the place - its what I imagine all genuine south Asian restaurants to be like. Food is fresh and hot out of the tiny kitchen - service is quick, portions are huge, flavor is totally bang on. I always get the noodle options since I'm a noodle poodle but the rice dishes look good too! Hawkers is a great place to grab a hearty meal and just chill with friends or your newspaper. Great local ethnic representation!
"Prawn noodle soup - I rate it a 4.5
Soooo delicious and so much rich prawn flavour. Almost reminds me of the prawn noodle soup in Singapore"
Cheap and easy lunch on the go. Arriving at the restaurant, ordering and finding a seat made wine feel for a moment that I was back in Asia. We had the laksa (prawn and curry noodle soup) and the cha Kwak deow (fried rice noodles). Cha Kwak Deow had enough heart from the wok but the chicken was a little bit dry. The laksa was nice but lacked the richness and depth of flavour compared to traditional laksa however it was still very tasty. And for the price I have no complaints there.
"Going to keep this one short given the many reviews. If you know what to order, your experience at Hawkers Delight can be either amazing or simply mediocre.

I'll save you the trouble.

1. Char Kway Teow - This wonderful dish isn't shown in any of the photos on the walls but it's one of the best dishes here. I would recommend making it spicy for the extra authentic kick to your tastebuds.

2. Mee Goreng - Another fried noodle dish, but the Malaysian version. Very good as well.

For $5-6 a dish, you can't go wrong at Hawkers Delight."
This is like better chinese take-out. I know it's Malaysian/Singaporean, but I'd choose it over Chinese take-out any day. I've only ever tried the Nasi Goreng, Mee Goreng and Fried Kuey Tow; and I personally thought they were all spiced, cooked to perfection.
"This place is delicious and cheap!

I walked in one day knowing nothing about the food and the lady at the register helped me out by asking me questions to narrow down what I like and what I should try. We ended up on a dish, which I forget the name of, that's noodles (big and flat) with chicken and prawns. It was exactly what I was craving! 

I've been back a few times and like to get their veggie fritters - can't beat 2 for $1. I noticed a new thing recently, which the older lady working there told me they don't make much, called Murruku. She couldn't describe it to me (she said they were like chips), but I bought it anyways, it was only $2 after all. They looked like tentacles but were made of rice and an Indian flour then I'm assuming deep fried so they were crunchy. They were a bit spicy but I really enjoyed them.

It's a small place that takes cash only but definitely worth trying."
Hawkers Delight is not the best Malaysian food you'll find in Vancouver, but you can't beat the price. The most expensive dishes on the menu are $5.25. My favourite is probably the Mee Goreng. Unfortunately, they don't served Roti. It's cash only and if you can't finish your meal and want to take it home they'll charge you .25 for a box. Seating is crowded, but you don't come for the ambiance, you come for the generous portions of tasty, inexpensive food. I can never figure out when they are open (it's pretty hit and miss) so it's best to call ahead.
"When choosing a neighborhood moving back into Vancouver, the location of Hawkers actually factored in...

On one of the best blocks of Main St. Hawkers offers $5 meals that will blow your mind. It is always busy, and for a reason, it is fast food for those that don't want burgers.

Laksa, and curry dishes are great but I like the dried pork best, and just spicy enough to clear my sinuses when I have a cold.

Just writing this I've determined that I'm going there for dinner. If you go tonight, I'm the guy wearing a black Star Wars shirt. Seating is rarely a problem but sometimes you have to wait if you go with more than 2."
Finally found a place serves he authentic Singaporean food. Get my fix here every week. Wished I found it sooner. Singapore food court in one tiny restaurant
"It's been a few years since I've been back and they are still good as always. A true hole in the wall with picture menu boards. Come down for some true Southeast Asian food at affordable prices. Now that the weather is getting colder, their spicy curries and warm bowls of soup noodles will surely satisfy your cravings. 

24/30 of 30 Days of Yelp"
"I already wrote a Quick Tip, but Hawker's Delight deserves a full review....

Maybe there is better Chicken Rice somewhere out there in Vancouver. Maybe your girlfriend thinks the mee goreng is too spicy. Maybe the lines are long and the tables tight. 

But dear fellow Yelpers, None of that matters...

You see, this is the **ONLY** restaurant in ALL of North America that will make you a PROPER bowl of Mee Siam or Lontong. And they both are glorious. 

That's because the (very friendly) uncle you see standing at the wok is actually from Boon Lay. His right arm is probably larger than the left, as it should be, a testament years of stirring his char kway teow and hokien mee - both of which are beautiful, but are over-shadowed by the mere presence of the mee siam.

Whenever we visit Vancouver we eat here. Sometimes several times a trip. (OK, yes it's true... sometimes several times a day.)

It truly is as close to the Makan Sutra incredible culinary experience of Singapore that you are going to find in North America. ...and all that for just 4 bucks. 

It doesn't get any better than this."
"Huge portions of mouth-watering Singaporean & Malay food for the price of a venti Starbucks coffee. What more can you ask for? Well perhaps one more thing....I wish they would install AC (or even a ceiling fan) because it was sweltering in that tiny restaurant. But hey, the heat only adds to the authenticity of the experience. 

Suggestion: Don't go during peak meal hours as there are only about 20 seats in the restaurant. Also, it's cash only. 

To Try: Lontong for $4.75 plus tax. It consists of compressed rice cubes cooked in banana leaves, soaked in creamy coconut curry sauce with vermicelli, cabbage, tofu, egg, and a bit chili oil.

Lovin' this place and I will definitely be back...but perhaps on a cooler day."
"I came back here just for Hainanese Chicken Rice, but thought of trying something new so I got Prawn Noodle($7.50). Like other noodle dishes here the portion was big, had plentiful of toppings like fish cake, prawn, pork slices and some veggies. It also had something crispy bits on top. It was flavorful, tasty and delicious. However it's kind of spicy and has little bit of jalapeno peppers in it.

This dish didn't catch my attention at first and it was better than I thought. On my next visit I'm not sure whether to try Mee Siam or just get usual Laksa or Hainanese Chicken Rice."
"that whole stretch of main street from just north of broadway to just south of king ed is chock full of innumerable delicious looking eateries.  and yet i will often forego trying a new spot to go visit an old favourite for a dirt cheap, spicy, coconutty, piping hot, brothy trip to flavour country.  

highlights:

-malaysian/singaporean cuisine (laksas, noodle soups, rich curries with rice, hainanese chicken)
-most dishes are in the $4;50 to $6 range, only the lamb curry exceeds that range
-large portions, speedy service
-the broths carry enough heat to breathe the life back into you on a shitty vancouver day
-tons of veggie/vegan options
-photos and descriptions on the wall to help you pick
-a far less greasy alternative to places like banana leaf; broths are thin and well flavoured but not dripping in oil
 
yesterday i opted for the mee siam, which is described as ""thin rice noodles served in sweet and sour and spicy peanut gravy garnished with tofu puff, egg, tofu, chives and bean sprout"".  this was topped with a pile of reduced carmelized onions.  so good.  

my advice: get the fried veggie fritter.  it's $1.12 for two and they come with this gingery rice vinegar dipping sauce that's got a great zing to it."
"Reading previous reviews it appears that they've upped their prices a little bit this year.  Most dishes are $6.80 and the lamb curry is $10.95.  

That being said, their portions are humongous and the veggie fritters are now 2 for $1.00.  

I had the Char Kuey Teow (mild) and it was so flavourful, greasy, and satisfying that I ate the entire plate even though my stomach was pleading that it was very full.

My fiance had the lamb curry and the lamb chunks were very plentiful as well as tender.  

Add an order of veggie fritters and we were more than stuffed.  

Will be back to try the laksa and Hainanese chicken rice that everyone else has been raving about!"
"This is a hole in the wall that you have to try. The food is great and very cheap but still  fast and high quality 

In asia Hawkers means open-air complexes in Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong  housing many stalls that sell a variety of inexpensive food. These are places with good cheap fast food but and Hawkers Delight on Main lives up to the traditional Hawkers in Asia. 

Each dish is under 10 bucks and the portions are huge and you have to try the Hainanese Chicken Rice

This place take you back to the stalls in Singapore and Malaysia and well worth the trip

This is a small place and a cozy little place on Main street to find good cheap fodo that is high quality"
"One of my highschool girlfriends took me here on a date once, it was rad. Hawkers is an underground Vancouver staple. If you know Vancouver you'll know about this place. There aren' too many places where quantity meets quality AND for the right price -- Hawkers is one of them.

If you're into Malaysian, you best go out of your way a little to get some of chow at Hawkers. End of story."
"This is a great spot to eat in or take out Singaporean fast food. So good for a cheap price.

I had the Mee Pok, which is wide flat noodles, with pork slices, minced pork, a couple of prawns, yu choy and bean sprouts as well as a few jalapeño. I asked for the dish without the fish cakes.  It was really satisfying.

Mind you, I was quite hungry when I ate the dish, but I found it hard to stop eating. It hit the spot. It's not fancy fare, so don't expect too many specialties on your plate. I could have handled more of a hot or chili sauce on mine. 

They serve big portions for decent prices. The Mee Pok was $8.49. This type of food would also go really well with the Singaporean beer, Singha.

I'll definitely return to try the laksa! They also have several vegetarian dishes to sample."
"Good:
Large portions. 
Nice staff.
Good prices. 

Bad:
There aren't too many seats.
Not open late. 
Check if the dish you are ordering is vegetarian or not so you aren't surprised. 

Highly recommended!"
Singaporean Hawker center style food. Nasi Gongren, Nasi Lemak, Mee Goreng and Laksa are all very good.
You gotta try their Laksa and Malaysian Fried Noodle.  My all time favorite!
"Neighborhood food just the way we like it... good taste, good portion, good price and simply good.  There is a lot of things on this menu which I need to go back and try.  But if you want a quick meal or a little something to go with the fritters on display then let me suggest the spicy nasi goreng.  

I will be back soon because it is in my neighborhood and I can't think of a reason not to."
Honest to god, one of the best little eateries on Main Street, and that's saying a lot. This place doesn't need a flashy storefront or advertising to win people over; the food speaks for itself, and this place has secured a loyal following from many in the neighbourhood. Granted, the space is tiny; getting a table is like winning the lottery, and waiting for your food to go is a nightmare of pressing up against the wall by the soda fridge and swerving around kitchen staff. But you will forgive all of this when you take a bite of their spicy (or mild, if you like) heaven. Meat-eaters and vegetarians alike will find something to love here. Personally, I go for the mee goreng or nasi goreng; when I ate meat, the lamb curry was my go-to. Now. Let's get to the pricing. As you can tell from the one dollar sign in the info area of this page, the food is inexpensive. But I don't think you quite understand yet. You can get a dish of food that will easily feed minimum two people for between $7 and $8. I am not kidding. You really get your money's worth at Hawkers. One catch here is that it is cash only, but it's still worth running across the street to the atm.
"This is one of those places that you hope never goes away! 

It's a small spot on the king edward and main strip but  i have to say if you are looking for value and a full stomach - this has to be one of the best places in the city.

My favourite thing to order is their chicken curry.  It's not too spicy and comes with a couple pieces of chicken and potatoes in a delicious Malaysian curry broth.  Just over 5 bucks with tax. Beat that one!

If you are a vegetarian - FEAR NOT!!!  Just as good value and a bloated stomach in the end from all the food you'll be getting. None of that tofu!!! Try the laksa!! Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.....

Couple problems. It's a small kitchen and a minimal seating for diners. It can take up to 20 minutes but be patient it's worth the wait for the price you pay for all the food you get.

Plus, I love supporting the little guys."
Very traditional Singapore Malaysian place~ food quality was not as good as expected but it's still above average :p picky tongue I got! If you miss Malay food~ come here hehe

There is hot tea for self service so help urself . As we reached there around 8:30 so it was almost done. Glad there was water. 
Tip- dont expect a big shop as its a tiny place n few seatings
Clean washrooms n self service"

"I had high expectation for this place after reading all the good reviews and craved hainanese chicken rice on my trip to Vancouver. The place got crowded quick after we found immediate seats and line started to form while others were forced to share tables with fellow patrons. Great sense of community and love all around. On top of that the cashier was blunt and  has ""our great food trumps all"" attitude. All good signs. However the chicken rice didn't live up to my expectation. Rice was too garlicky, chicken was bland. The ""okay"" char kwe tiau saved the day though. I'm glad we ordered that extra dish. All of a sudden the attitude, the crowd, the line, the good reviews didn't make sense. The great price did. We also got mee pok to go and that was disastrous. We then walked over to Mui Garden to get our hainanese chicken rice fix and it's better."
"On the prowl for a tasty noodle meal? Have you splurged during the past few days, and are now therefore on a budget? If you've answered ""yes"" to these questions, sounds as though you need to pay a visit to Hawker's Delight. 

For a fiver, you will receive a heaping portion of the consistently delicious dishes such as Mee Goreng (noodles, sauce, veggies, and tofu, with spicy option) and for $1.25 more, grab two veggie fritters. The deli is equipped with a self-serve water cooler, beside which there napkins and chopsticks to arm yourself for the attack on your lunch/dinner. The counter by the front offers great seats from which to look out onto Main St. action through a large open window. 

Hawkers is a such a gem, very modest in size and appearance. The price and taste of the food is worth returning for, again and again."
"After several failed attempts (one time, the place was closed for summer holiday;  another time was a Sunday), we finally got a chance to try the fares at Hawkers Delight on Main St.  We arrived early (11:50am or so) as we expected the place to fill up quick for Friday lunch rush.

Our group of 3 was 2nd to order - Dried Kuey Teow;  Laksa;  Curry chicken noodle & 3 Tofu puffs.  By getting there early, we had our choice of tables, so helped ourselves to tea, dishes and utensils as we waited for our food.

Food was brought to our table in fairly quick succession, and we noticed that the place had filled up quickly.  (Spacing between tables is very tight, esp. as it was raining and everyone had jackets, umbrellas, etc.)  But once we got our food, we focused on our feast.  The serving size of the Curry Noodle and Laksa was generous, but we were surprised by the somewhat smaller size of the fried Kuey Teow.  Granted, the prices are very reasonable. The food was very good;  not the best Singaporean/Malaysian food I've had, but definitely good!  

The line up continued to build as we ate our lunch quickly, with many people actually waiting around for their food as take-out (crowding the restaurant).  This is not a place to hang out at due to its small size so as soon as we were done, headed back out into the rain, glad to have finally tried this place.

Next time, we'll order take-out in advance, and pick up to eat in the comfort of home.  Important note:  if memory serves, this place is CASH ONLY!"
"This place is probably better than most for Singaporean/Malaysian fare at this value but it's still a far cry from the real thing. Was here probably a year or two ago and remember being wowed by the laksa. This time around, it was just ok. Creamy but, not particularly flavorful or spicy. When asked for sambal belachan, the kitchen staff didn't know what it was. 

I've not seen soto ayam on the menu outside of home much and so, just had to order it. It tasted like bak kut ten and had fish cake and bak choy!

The mee goreng was barely spicy when I had asked for spicy but it had some flavor.

Portions were generous for the price so come hungry and if you're not picky, it should make for a fine meal. We were here on a Saturday night, late, and the place was relatively empty."
"I missed a good bowl of Laksa and that made me want to go to Hawkers. I went here last Friday for Laksa ($8.60), and the size seemed little smaller than before.

Even though staff was busy making other food, my food came out fast. It was full of flavours along with smoothness of coconut milk. It's nice they have 2 water coolers in the restaurant. One by the entrance and another one by the counter. 

Also I personally like their Laksa better than Cafe Dlite Express in Aberdeen mall."
"Came here for lunch with a party of two it's a very small restaurant with a lot of awards the atmosphere however leaves a lot to be desired as does the service their not rude however no smiles or hospitality to make you feel welcome 

After looking at the menu they were a lot of things I wanted to try so I ordered a lot thinking I can always take the left overs home so the two of us ordered four spring rolls four tofu puffs four veg fritters two roti canais and one chicken curry but we subbed the regular rice for chicken flavored rice the spring rolls were good and pretty similar to a spring roll you get elsewhere the tofu puffs were interesting cubed fried tofu stuffed with peanut sauce and cucumbers but beware these are really hot in the middle the roti canais was our favorite flaky crisp roti with a flavorful curry to dip the vegetable fritters were similar to a Indian pakora but topped with a slightly sweet vinaigrette really good but not hot and fresh from the fryer I also really enjoyed the chicken curry I believe it was the same curry as served with the roti however a much larger portion with two pieces of dark meat chicken and potatoes the chicken flavored rice was a perfect compliment fluffy rice with great flavor that I believe is cooked in broth instead of water (I could be wrong)

Overall I loved the food and as a bonus it's also very reasonably priced however there is a downside they did one of my pet peeves in a restaurant where they make you pack your own food to go (however with their price point and quality maybe you can over look that) also as I mentioned the atmosphere and service (or lack there of) leaves a lot to be desired for these reasons I wouldn't recommend it for date night or even a place to go if your looking to spend some time while enjoying your evening however in spite of all this I still gave it four stars due to the food and for a quick delicious meal I will return"
"Hawkers may be the best value for money in the city of Vancouver. It's mostly a take out place, but also has a nice casual seating area. Few veggie options but they are decent enough and a very generous size for the money. 

Best not to go at key times, such as lunch or just before dinner, as you will have to wait since this place is very popular."
"Absolutely authentic. Not quite as good as the food in Singapore, but I still licked my plate clean. Mmmmm!

When you are in Singapore or Malaysia, the hawker stands often only specialize in one dish. These guys do a great job of giving variety, but I think the variety keeps them from perfecting individual dishes. Nevertheless - 4 stars; ""I'm a fan"". Makes me wish I was back in Malaysia!"
"after visiting vandusen park my wife and I looked for a nearby place to eat

great food to dollar value here,  and the food quality is fairly good too (3.5).  They curry chicken or lamb on rice are my fav's.
"A hawker is a place in Singapore and Malaysia where one can have inexpensive food; it is a food stand which serves complete meals. I have never been in Southeast Asia, so I apologize if I am not accurate enough. However, that region is known for flavourful and delicious cuisine.

I read about this place in Yelp as a good inexpensive place. It was Friday afternoon and the place was a little packed with customers, and the size of the locale is not very big. After waiting about 7 mins in line, I ordered chicken curry and spring rolls. There was no Satay that day, however.

My order took between 10 and 15 minutes to arrive, which is just a little slow for a 'hawker deli'. It was very well worth the wait because I was rewarded with chicken curry cooked with real coconut milk and with the right balance of spiciness. The rice was served right: not sloppy or soggy. The serving size was good for 5 CAD and 0.75 CAD per spring roll. The spring rolls I might say may rank among the best I had in my life and they were vegetarian. All gushed down with a can of 1.25 CAD lychee pop.

As far as I can tell, this is the place with the best food/value ratio I had since I came to Vancouver. No other place has granted me so much culinary delight with less than 10 CAD tax included! 

Will definitively come back. The only drawback of this place is that it took me a while to choose which dish to order. Everything looked so good.

BTW, they finished remodelling on Sept 8, so the photos may not be 100% up to date."
"We heard great things about Hawker's Delight so we finally stopped by. The restaurant is very small and we were lucky to find a seat. We ordered the laksa and the mee pok dried noodles. The laksa was delicious, the noodles were nice and bouncy and the meat was tender. The broth didn't feel heavy but we didn't find it spicy enough. The mee pok was quite good, a good medley of noodles, meat, and vegetables; but we will probably try something different next time.

Hawker's Delight is one of those hole in the wall restaurants that provide great food. Most people order for take out as mentioned before there is limited seating. The prices are good considering the portion size of the meals. We would recommend!"
"Nasi goreng and veggie fritters are two of my favourite things in Vancouver.  And the price is amazing.  I would recommend takeout, the room is pretty cramped.
I miss the pork stays they used to have on the menu."
"Hawkers is one of those places that I have been meaning to try forever.

"All these food from Hawker Delight reminded me about the food that I had in Singapore. The food brought me a lot of memories. The food tasted good but not quite the same. Most of the food are greasy. The hainan chicken with rice had so much rice but there was not a lot of chicken, so the dish did not look proportional. 

The restaurant is very small and there are many chairs and tables as well as counter stools. My graceful companion and I ordered the food at the cashier and grabbed a table with a number. A server brought food to our table. Due to the limited space, we did not really enjoy the environment. The food was just cheap or okay. Indeed they lacked quality unfortunately. 

I went to their bathroom. It was kind of dirty and I didn't want to go back there. My recommendation is to order take out and eat the food at home or somewhere else. You may feel more comfortable."
"We wanted fast, cheap and tasty eats and Hawkers delivered. This place is the epitome  of a no frills hole in the wall. 

We ordered 3 dishes, all in the $5.00 each range. The mee goreng was ordered spicy and was served as such. We were pleased that it was far less oily than we anticipated. 

The chicken curry noodle, loaded with chicken, was delicious although in hindsight we do prefer it with the rice option.

My husband took the first bite of the laksa, said that it tasted ""off"" and pushed the bowl away. Given the fact that he just spent 2 weeks on business in Singapore eating street food daily, one would think that I would defer to his judgment and just let it go. Nope, I dug right into the bowl and unfortunately his initial assessment was correct, one of the components was bad with a capital B. If I felt like playing chicken with my GI tract I would have investigated further to identify the culprit but decided not to risk it.

Despite one bad dish this place still warrants a 3.5 - 4. Hawkers is what it is and for the price of a gourmet coffee, one can get enough decent, somewhat nutritious food to keep you going for a meal or two, an anomaly in Vancouver."
Been to Hawkers Delight a few times and it's always a great quick place to grab some Singapore dishes! The restaurant is smaller with only 4 to 5 tables where each can seat a maximum of 4 people tightly. Once you arrive you order your dishes first at the cashier and find your own seat. Drink and utensils is also self serve to give you a bit of that hawker vibe! The food here is always flavorful! A few of the favourites are the meegoren, the sayor lodeh bee hoon and roti!
best value for your money. good portions, tasty and dirt cheap!!!
We went on a Saturday night... the place is extremely small and was packed ...too many tables and chairs... way too many people... So if you don't like sitting on top of other people and crab walking sideways through a restaurant, then this place is not for you.... Food was decent however.... Portions were much larger than I expected considering they charge so little... We had the vegetarian curried vegetables on rice and it was good !!!  ... Though tasted more like chilli than curry. There were leftovers ! You need to pay 25 cents for a takeout container, but it seemed reasonable...  The bathroom was less than pleasant however.  It was small, dirty and right off the kitchen near the alley.... If I could have avoided using it ... I would have.  Still I feel it deserved 3-4 stars.
Tried prwan noodle, Mee goreng, laksa. Didn't know they all had noodles. Mee goreng was good and prwan noodle was quite spicy and laksa was not as fishy or deep taste enough. Been to Malaysia before but dishes here lack the zingy and deep flavors that I tasted in Malaysia.  But price value was really good as most are under 10 dollars. May be back to try others.
"This hole in the wall serves up some hawker style food reminiscent of the food from Singapore and Malaysia. The selections are simple with favorites like Char Kuey Teow, Mee Goreng, and Chicken Rice but things like Mee Rebus and Mee Siam are decidedly Singaporean dishes which many people would enjoy.

I had the chicken rice and it wasn't bad but the chicken were bonesless, much to my disappointment. The prices for most items are about $5-6 so you can't beat that for a quick lunch or dinner. I would definitely come back to try the rest."
Great find for fast,cash-only, cheap eats kind of place in Vancouver. Mom & Pop feel, casual atmosphere with authentic Indonesian/Singaporian cuisine. The curry lamb was tasty; tender and flavorful beef, enough to share. The veggie spring rolls weren't anything to rave about nor was the mee goreng which left me craving for something else. Disappointed to see that they no longer offer a staple dish... beef satay. Also didn't see any roti, it just isn't on the menu nor are Singaporean noodles. My rating would sit at 3.5.
"This is a small shop located on Main Street that specializes in Malyasian food. They are a small casual eatery with a limited number of seating; you order at the front counter and they bring you your food once it's ready. During my visit, I had their Roti Prata, Chicken Curry Noodle, and Fried Kuey Teow. All of the food was very good; I was especially blown away by their Roti Prata. Their prices are very reasonable, especially given that their portions are quite generous.

Roti Prata ($2.75):
5/5
This is served with a small side of curry for dipping. The bread itself was seriously just fantastic: warm, soft and flaky. The curry also had a great fragrance of coconut as well as a slightly sweet flavour that paired great with the bread.

Chicken Curry Noodle ($9.05):
4/5
This contained noodles in a curry broth with potatoes and chicken. The chicken itself wasn't really curried however, but was rather like Hainese chicken that was added to the noodles. It was tasty however, and was tender, juicy and well-seasoned. The noodles had a nice bouncy texture and the broth was very flavourful with just a slight bit of heat. It was quite a good portion for $9.05, and filling.

Fried Kuey Teow ($9.05):
4/5
This consisted of broad rice noodles stir fried with egg, bean sprout, prawns, fish cake, shredded chicken and green vegetable. You can have it spicy or non-spicy; I had the spicy version and found it to have just a slight kick without being overly hot. I really enjoyed the texture of the noodles, which were chewy and bouncy. There were only a few prawns, but a good amount of fish cakes. The portion size was not enormous, but more than generous for just $9.05.

Summary:
Food: 4/5
Price: 5/5
Service: N/A
OveralL: 4.5/5
Recommendations: Roti Prata, Chicken Curry Noodle, Fried Kuey Teow"

"I noticed the restaurant a couple of months ago when we were antiquing on Main Street.  With so many good reviews on Yelp, we finally went there tonight.
 
You definitely can't beat the prices and authenticity for Southeast Asian noodles at Hawkers Delight.  Everything on the menu is $5 or less.  There is only one dried noodle bowl at $5.25.  There are about 15 items on the menu ranging from fried noodle dishes, noodle bowls with soup, noodles dish with sauces, to Hainanese Chicken Rice.

Hainanese Chicken Rice is my all time favourite Singaporean plate but I ordered it almost every time I visited a Singaporean restaurant so  I tried something else tonight.  I had Mee Rebus and Allen ordered Mee Siam.  Mine was thick egg noodles with a hard boiled egg with tofu, scallions in a sightly spicy thick sauce.  Allen's was rice noodles with a hard boiled egg, scallions, some dried vegetables unknown to us with a limey sauce.  The sauces were thick but not overpowering.  Although I prefer Chinese or Japanese when it comes to noodles with soup, our dinner was delicious.  I will definitely return to try the Hainanese Chicken Rice."
For the price and portions, amazing.  I just call ahead 10 min to avoid the wait and being cramped in the busy place.  I don't think I have ever see this place quiet.  Curry lamb , so good. Yum!
"Hawkers- I love thee. One of the cheaper spots of Main Street. Equal amount of vegetarian options to meat/fish options. They often sell out of their veggie curry, so if you have your heart set on it, go at lunch! My favorite is the mee goreng, or nasi goreng. 

Portion size is huge. Cash only. Closed Sundays."
"A taste of Singapore in Vancouver.

You can find many Singaporean dishes here and at very reasonable prices. The food falls a little short of how the authentic dishes would taste in Singapore but who can complain when you're so far away from home. 

I had the Mee Rebus and spring rolls and they were tasty. Mee Goreng seems to be fairly popular (overheard many people ordering) but I did not get a chance to try that! Definitely would recommend anyone missing some Singaporean food to visit this place!"

"The boyfriend hates this place. What can I say, it's small, dingy, offers funny ethnic food with menus barely written in English. For a white dude, this is most definitely not acceptable.

Me, being Asian and used to the Chinese street food, really quite enjoyed the place. I came here on my friend's recommendation for a lunch date (she's also a Yelp Elite :D). I must say, given the look of this place and the initial shock, the food was delicious.

The small, cramped space is not for everyone. However, if you can get past that and are looking for somewhat of a food adventure, I would give this place a try. The portions are big and the price is cheap. 

Cash only is a deterrence for me but I can see me eating here again. Especially for when I'm too broke to eat anywhere else."
"I've been coming here for the past couple of years.  Food is fairly good. Don't expect much service as you have to head to the front to order and they'll bring the food to you.  It's a small place so any more than 4 people and you'll have to sometimes wait for a table to clear (esp during rush hours).

Price is reasonable and ranges between $6.25 and about $6.80. There is the lamb dish that is more expensive at $10.90 but it's not worth the price.

I usually have the Hainanese chicken rice. The rice is pretty good but the chicken (boneless) is not as authentic as real Hainanese chicken. The curry chicken in noodle is also another favorite of mine.  Portions are a decent size and should fill most stomachs up.

Overall a small inexpensive no frills kinda place. Great if you want to grab something fast to eat!"
"This is one of those places that seems to be mentioned when talking about this type of food, and amazingly enough I have never heard of this joint. Borderline 3.5, but maybe cause I was an unlucky one, and for the food I ordered, most of it was bland. I definitely will give this place a try again, as there is variety, and the price, you cannot beat this place on the strip, as you get probably the most 'bang for your buck' in terms of quantity to the dollar.

If you want your ""hole-in-the-wall"" restaurant, well Hawkers definately fits the bill and definition. This place is tiny, a little run down, and tacky in color, which is great, and probably goes with the name and the prices, as what would you expect? The menu, is all over the wall, in pictures, and a brief description in the menu, with a price to go along side. I really do not think I saw anything near the $10 mark on my visit. I've eaten in Singapore many times. Food quality is consistent and authentic. Prices are reasonable, though it has crept up over the years with little change to the room. One of the ladies at the register is very welcoming and friendly. Generally not a long wait for food. Though it can get busy quickly and then, it naturally takes a little longer. Had their Chicken Curry Noodle this time. Yet another favourite of mine.  Cash only.
"Probably my favourite place in the neighbourhood for a reliably tasty, economical meal.  The nasi goreng (pretty much the cheapest meal on the menu, at about $6) is enough for a moderately-to-severely hungry human being. I'm not vegetarian, but the nasi goreng probably meets most vegetarian's standards, although there is likely Naam Plaa / fish sauce, stirred in, and possibly eggs.  
 My fave thing to do is:  order the Nasi Goreng (or sometimes, the lamb curry with rice -- also a reliably delicious dish) to go;  then stop by East-West Grocery store which is right next door, pick up some extra tofu & veggies (broccoli, asparagus, bok choy, you-name-it)  make a stir-fry with some raw peanut or olive oil, garlic, onions, ginger, the veggies you just got for like 3 bucks, then throw in the one serving of Nasi Goreng (the dish, as they make it, has a bit more salt/flavour than necessary for that amount of food/rice, so if you dilute it with a pile of veggies, it's ideal).  
  You end up with a meal that isn't too salty, has easily enough flavour, and there's enough food there to feed 3 or 4 people (for about 10 bucks!)
 ps. the take-home method isn't for any of you wanting to ""eat - out"", obviously.  But if you want to eat right there, I'd still say anything on their menu is pretty recommendable, but if you're only medium-hungry, you should probably share one meal between 2 people, otherwise you'll end up asking for a ""to-go"" box.
   I agree with a couple previous posts that,  the ambience isn't always great, but if you look at this place as a ""Ma&Pa-Operated Ethnic-Fast-Food Joint"", it's pretty much unbeatable."
This place is hidden on main, and food is cheap and edible. Mee goring wasn't bad just not spicy enough, I don't blame them I got the typical white person spicy.

"For the price, the food was pretty decent. I got the Laksa as it was one of the most recommended items on Yelp reviews. It wasn't the best but it was still pretty good. "As a Raccoon, street food is in my blood. So this has been one of my favourite hole in the wall establishments in Vancouver for over a decade. This place really brings back memories of old school Asian hawkers food court.

*Note: Cash Only, Order Take Out if you hate cramped seating Don't expect those free smiles, lovely services, and cute staff bringing you drinks and you'd be fine. There are pricier alternatives for that :)

Hakwers Delight offers some of the South East Asian comfort food at great value and large portion. Some of my favourite dishes include the Hainanese Chicken Rice and Stir-Fry Kuey Teow (thick rice noodles). Their wok-fried items on most days for producing that ""wok flavour"" --which translates to the faint ""grilly/smokey"" taste that you're suppose to get when you cook with a hot wok. 

The only down side is that I really love very pungent spices and not just hot. So I feel that their laksa has fallen a bit short on that spice spectrum, since the soup base tends to be more on the coconut milky side.

Between price you pay, the area you're in, and the stuff you get, this is a steal, so I gave it 4 stars.

Good for dining solo."
"This is my favourite go-to neighbourhood restaurant. Aesthetically, it's a hole in the wall, but the food is delicious and cheap. Two can easily stuff their faces for less than 10 dollars. 

I come here so often it's almost embarrassing. The staff are friendly but must secretly think ""don't you ever buy groceries? Try fruit once in a while.""

My favourite is mee goreng and nasi goreng but the vegetable curry with rice runs a close second. The vegetable fritters are also delicious, albeit greasy and never hot."

"Absolutely the best cheap eats on Main St. I get the dried bee hoon, noodles with pork, crispy garlic and fish cake, for around $6. Also good is the beef stew.

This place gets very busy but it's worth the wait to sit down and munch. Shuts down for a month each summer while the owners are on vacation. Yes, it's a bit of a dive but try it anyways."
This little hole in the wall comes pretty close to an authentic Singapore hawker stall experience.  Yes, I've havd better laksa and mee goreng, but this place is just so honest and cheap, it's hard to find anything negative to say about it.  The laksa has egg, tofu, chicken thigh meat, shrimp, and a healthy dollop of sambal.   It has a thicker gravy style and uses a white pasta kind of noodle instead of the yellow alkaline variety.  Pretty damn good.  Every time I'm in the area, I always make a point of stopping in for a snack.  Char Kway Teow is pretty good too.  If you've been to the food courts in Singapore and Malaysia, you'll feel right at home, and at this price, you can't go wrong!
"If you like oily and affordable food, you've come to the right place.

This place is a small hole-in-the-wall style restaurant that is self-seating and self-serve. You order and pay at the front, get a number, and take a seat. Then, they either bring you your food or call your number when your dishes are ready. The restaurant is very bare-bones and small, where you grab your own cutlery and glasses of water. After eating, you can put your dishes away in the collection bin, or let them clear the tables.

The menu is very easy to read, posted on the walls, with lots of pictures and visible prices. That day, we were craving roti, so we got two of those that came with curry, as well as mee goreng and vegetable spring rolls. It was a carb heavy, meat-free meal that day. Oh man, did I regret the choices. Not only was each dish oily and greasy, but also so heavy in the stomach.

First, we got the vegetable spring rolls. These were crispy, but the bottom of the plate pooled with its oil. I think they need to rest their fried items on a rack first before plating so the oil does not collect and continue to soak in the food. I could almost not believe how much oil there was - I thought it was possibly the vegetable juices - but no, it was definitely oil.

Then came the mee goreng. The flavour was there, with a spicy kick, and it was quite tasty, but again, this was cooked with a ton of oil. The roti was flaky and crispy, and again, on the oily side (which is expected). The weird thing is, they had no knives in the self-serve cutlery section, so I asked the lady at the front for one. She said they did not have any. That's odd, but whatever, we were still able to easily portion the roti with a fork and spoon. There could have been more curry sauce given for the 2 rotis, but I liked this sauce a lot.

I have also had their laksa before. It's decent - not the largest portion, but big enough for me. The soup is flavourful, although I've had better. Prices are decent enough, so I would get this again.

After that carb heavy meal, I felt so gross. I didn't even eat that much - I could feel the heaviness - but it was still sitting in my stomach like a rock. I had that feeling you get after you eat McDonald's, and we all know that is not a great feeling.

I would really recommend getting only one to two fried foods as an accompaniment to your meal, as I would next time. I do think the flavours are there, and the value can't be beat, as all of this cost about $15 bucks. It would not be my top go-to choice for Malaysian, but I would not be opposed to going if I felt like having a cheap and quick meal."
"When you're limited in time and budget...and you're hungry, as in ""I need to eat NOW or there will be consequences..."", this is the place to go.

The moment you part with your $5, you can hear the cook in the back clanging his cooking implement on a giant wok.  Not that I've seen the giant wok, but the sounds suggest mad, wild cooking.

Often, within less than 5 minutes--  we have...our faves: nasi goreng (they put potatoes in the rice- how cool is that, lol=), mee goreng, and my partner's favourite, lamb curry (comes with a good helping of rice).  The lamb has recently gone up in price to about $10.  Perhaps it has something to do with people sitting there, slurping it up, and groaning ""I can't believe this is only $5!!!""

As for seating, this is as casual as casual goes and there should be a picture of it in the dictionary under 'hole in the wall'.  A lot of 'take outs' get 'taken out' in the half hour it takes for us to finish our meal.

For no nonsense, hot, and mostly good food, this is the place to be.  Not a fan of the laksa here...but you can't go too wrong with mee goreng.  It's very much like the streetside, hop off the bus and hope to find food type place that will only disappoint if you expect too much."
Pretty good
"Typical street side food of Singapore. Taste of food is unique and different than usual Thai or Vietnamese food. However the place is too small to accommodate more than 12 people. I would assume it's a hard to find, been there for many years ""rat hole"" location. They accept Canadian dollars cash only - that's a problem. The lady (senior citizen) taking orders does not smile, welcome you or have any good feeling about your visit. Absolutely grumpy. 

So I would rate this place as - 
4 Star for food taste and quantity
4 Star for prices
2 Star for cleanliness 
1 Star for customer service 

On an average of all these above points I'm granting them 3 Stars overall. They need to work hard to gain customer loyalty by improving customer friendliness & restaurant's cleanliness."
Finally got to eat here after bookmarking it for a couple months -- was closed for a holiday last time I tried. Came with a friend on a Saturday at 6pm, which was perfect for getting a table in the very small restaurant. We liked the no-frills pay-first system -- getting our own utensils and water and all. My main complaint is the lack of meat... my Sayur Lodeh was very vegetarian. Taste was good, albeit more spicy than expected. It was an adventure pick -- I would probably go for the more classic Laksa next time. We also ordered a side of stuffed tofu puffs, which I give a 5/5 and highly recommend.
Tasty, cheap, hearty food. Good options of both spicy and non-spicy Malay/Singaporean dishes. Service is pretty quick, would recommend this place to just about anyone.
You go here for a cheap quick lunch, if you expect anything more you will be disappointed. The dishes we had were tasty (we ordered the Laksa and something else), very filling, and cheap, but you find your own seat, clean up after yourself. Do not go here if you want a lazy lunch with a large group, it is noisy, the kitchen opens up to the seating area and there are only a handful of tables. But hey, the food is good and cheap, sometimes that's all you want.
Good stuff. Great value, huge portions. This little hole in the wall is fantastic when you're hungry and don't want to pay too much... There is a 20% chance you'll be using the facilities shortly after so maybe avoid it if you have a date later.
Good ol' Singaporean and Malaysian home cooking! Hawkers serves up tasty dishes that are delicious and cheap! My favorite is the Lamb Curry($6.75) with big, juicy pieces of lamb and stewed veggies. If they are out of lamb, the Beef Curry is just as good! The Mee Goreng and Nasi Goreng($4.75 each) are deliciously spicy as they should be. I've had better Satay elsewhere, but at $0.75 per skewer(min. 5) they're a steal. The Veggie Fritters($1.05 for 2) are a definite must! I usually get them to go, so I can heat them up at home(much BETTER warmed up)! Although I get them less often, the Stuffed Tofu and Mee Siam are good too, but at these prices you could try a few different items and still have change in your pocket, not to mention tasty leftovers!
"I hit Hawkers one very rainy Friday evening, after my flite into YVR was delayed and I ""lost"" my car in the long term parking.

 When i arrived I was drenched, cold, headachy, and feeling pissed off. I needed food and fast. A steaming bowl of Laksa and two veggie fritters quickly arrived which I slurped down while pretending I was in an extra in Blade Runner watching people scurrying by in the downpour.  All those wonderful characteristics of Malaysian street food, hot, steaming, spicy, coconutty and lots of other magic flavours that work so well together had me feeling way better in no time."
"Good value for money. Cheap food, nasi goreng is great and the hainanese chicken rice was a lot better than much of what you can get in Vancouver. Somebody else pointed out that the normally bland rice part of it was great too. Pleasantly but not excessively flavoured with black pepper, garlic and ginger. 

Customer service though, what customer service? It doesn't exist here. I was greeted with a scowl and a ""what do you want"". No pleases, thank you's or smiles. It doesn't take much. When I picked up my order I smiled and told the lady to have a nice day, she scowled and looked away in response like I offended her. Just like the mother country. For that reason alone, I would much rather go somewhere else. 

In short. The food is pretty good, the service is nonexistent. You get what you pay for."
Very busy, simple place, understandably so, the food is very cheap but very tasty. I ordered the Chicken Curry rice and my friend got Hainanese Chicken. Quantity was brilliant and the chicken curry rice, I'm told by my friend who's Malaysian, is authentic, meanwhile the Hainanese Chicken was good but could be better. Nevertheless, for the price you pay, this place is unbeatable. Vancouver needs more places like this.

I thought that it was incredible how they were using utensils that looked identical to the ones I remember seeing at the Hawker stations in Singapore. Definitely gave me a nostalgic feeling of when I studied abroad there 6 years ago.

It's a little hole in the wall in an easily accessible location and has limited seating, although I suspect take out makes up a lot of their business. They're closed on Sundays."

"Hawkers.  This place is tiny - like, hole in the wall, tiny.  It's uncomfortable in the summer and if you're seated you're likely going to feel people staring at your food while they are waiting to get a seat or place their order.  You quickly enjoy your food, scarf it down and then move on.  Don't bother trying to get cozy - it ain't gonna happen.

It's inexpensive and damn tasty.  I'm a big fan of the veggie fritters, the nasi goreng and the laksa.  For under 6 bux, you can order your lunch and have enough left overs for dinner.  They are closed at certain hours of the day and I think on Mondays so it's good to check out their hours of operation if you're making a special trip out to their joint."
"More than satisfied with our meal!! Went in and was overwhelmed by the place. It was packed on a Thursday night 7:30pm to be exact. People in line.. people standing up waiting for their take outs. I'm not very familiar with Malaysian food, so I ordered Hainanese Chicken to be on the safe side. My fiancé ended up getting the same and so we initially ordered that with 1 order of veg fritters and 2 orders of roti. To my surprise, only paid a little less than $20. I was like ""Dinner for two for just 20 bucks?!?! cool!""

Luckily, there were a couple who got up and we had a table to dine on.  we have the fritters on hand by then, The fiancé took first bite on the fritters, and I can still remember how his face brighten up! Like eyes were saying ""WOW""... And yeap, after that bite he surely got up from his seat and ordered more. He ended up eating 3 of those. 1 for me. I guess you get 2 pieces for $1.25. It is like a little smaller than the size of my fist.

Roti was served next, served with a curry-tasting dip. It was really addictive! It has a crunch on the outside and just thick/thin enough to have a little feel of bite as it is soft in the inside. Dip it in the sauce then it becomes so sooo good. Should've took some home so I can munch on it while writing this. Writing about it makes me drool for it!

Hainanese chicken was awesome too! Came with a huge serving of rice, probably just ate the quarter of it. The chicken taste perfect to me, not so satisfied with their sauce for the chicken though. I was expecting more soy based. I'm not sure what it was but I think it's chili sauce. They do have soy sauce in a bottle for condiments- which I saw a little too late, I was already working on half of my chicken, saw it from other table, that, I enjoyed with the chili sauce. 

I would definitely go back and try some other dish! We were constantly looking at other people's orders whole in there. And just talking about what to try the next time we go here. Really, really enjoyed! 

Cash Only
Small Space
Kind of: Self-Served"

"Good spot for cheap and fast take out, but from all the 4 and 5 star reviews I was expecting a little better in terms of food quality.  Don't get me wrong, it's definitely good value for the money, but I wouldn't go out of the way to eat here again.

It is good and has a good variety of food. Its a good quick stop for lunch. I'm always looking for a food adventure and I was pleasantly surprised by a dish called  Mee Rubus. It's a little more savory and the broth is slightly thick which I found very interesting and delicious. It can get a little loud in here and it seems it's always congested. "The name alone drew us in, as well as the reviews that say Hawkers Delght is a ""dingy hole in the wall."" Ummm have you met us? We love that! 

We walked in on a Saturday afternoon for lunch, and it was super busy. Luckily we grabbed the last available table. The menu is posted on the wall and reading the options brought back so many amazing memories from Malaysia and Singapore, the latter being my favorite food destination in the world so far. To name a few, there was Nasi goreng, bee hoon, mee goreng, and of course the national dish of S'pore: Hainanese chicken rice. The prices are also amazing...$5.90 or less for nearly everything except the curry lamb, which was a few dollars extra. The portion sizes are huge and great for sharing.

 I ordered the Hainanese chicken rice, my hubby ordered nasi goreng (vegetarian spicy fied rice), and we got some veg fritters as an appetizer. The veg fritters were huge and served with a tangy sauce. The chicken rice was also quite large and every piece of chicken was silky smooth and boneless! The Mt Rainier sized mound of rice was infused perfectly with ginger and chicken fat. It was all served with a side of spicy and tangy minced ginger sauce. I kid you not, people....it was the BOMB!!! I was in a happy chicken rice stupor afterwards. 

P.S. Cash only!"
"Let me start with: I AM MALAYSIAN. And with that said, my judgment will still be a fair one. 

Aside from the nice, low prices, I do not see any reason for frequent visits to this place. It was my first time there with some friends who have been to this little food shack. It sure looked authentic when I first got there. I ordered at the counter like everybody else, and realised the family behind the counter was Singaporean. 

If you're not Malaysian, you won't know that Singaporeans cannot cook our food. They make a right mess of it, the same way they just did right here. I'm sorry to say, but this was very much a Hawker's Un-Delight to me. I was dissatisfied with the cooking and absolutely horrified that they should dare promote themselves for their ""Malaysian"" food. I think it only fair that it just says ""Singaporean"" cuisine on their window. But, as there is NO SUCH THING as Singaporean cuisine, they might as well borrow some of our dishes; however please do not say it is ""Malaysian"" because Singaporeans will never learn to cook the way Malaysians do. 

It is almost impossible to find real Malaysian food in this country, which brings me to my original point of fairness. I want to be fair to them and say they're doing all right as they still manage to keep a throng of regulars. 

Overall, I would say: try it once to see if you like it., and if you do... oh boy... wait till you taste REAL Malaysian food!"
"Hawkers Delight Vancouver is a hole in the wall Malaysian restaurant on Main Street. Barely 200 sqft, this dated kitchen serves up authentic Singaporean, authentic Malaysian cuisine in Vancouver. Popular dishes include Nasi Goreng, Laksa Noodles, Hainanese Chicken Rice, Roti, etc. The prices are dirty cheap around $5 to $6 with generous portions. Seats are not very comfortable and on a hot summer's day, you are better off ordering take out. If you are looking for more comfortable seating arrangements than Penang Delight Cafe would be your better bet.

Dried Noodle | Mee Pok Been Hoon: Served on a bed of warm dry egg noodles, bean sprouts, veggies, and minced pork.

Laksa: A slight sweet and not very spicy version of Laksa curry noodles. Flavors seems toned down compared to Bo Laksa King on Hastings. Served with tofu puffs, hard boil egg, and minced pork in coconut curry broth.

Roti Canai: This roti was flat and starchy. I didn't really like this Malaysian pastry pancake much. I think the best roti canai in Vancouver is at Bo Laksa King or Penang Delight. The dipping sauce here was water thin and didn't have the rich flavors of coconut cream, cloves or star anise."
I popped in here for a quick bite to eat and was not disappointed. It was busy and hard to find a seat but people moved in and out pretty quickly. I had the mee goreng with medium spice and found the heat was perfect for me. I would definitely come back and it seems the perfect place for take out. (Just make sure you have cash)

Only thing I didn't like is that the place was small but that's not going to deter me from coming back to eat their delicious food. Also make sure to bring cash!

Edit: I would like to say the laksa and kway teow was delicious. That is all."

Tastes better than the food I've eaten at actual Hawker stalls in Singapore. Easily my new favorite place to grab a bite in Vancouver.

"As far as I can tell from local Vancouverites, Hawkers is an institution, and not for nothing. After finally trying it out I'm willing to say I definitely want to come back!

I went for the Fried Kuey Teow, and made sure to ask for spicy - and guess what, it was reasonably spicy! No skimping on the capsaicin here, like a lot of other places do. For a cool $10 I got a heaping, delicious pile of veggies, noodles, and meat, and quite quickly to boot.

It's not often you find a meal that really warms the heart and makes you feel just full enough. And the folks working here are really nice too. What's not to love?"

"I've went to Singapore before so to find out that this was Singaporean food, I was even more intrigued by this place.   I realized that the name Hawkers Delight actually is derived from the Hawker centres found throughout Singapore (something I learned when I traveled there).   Hawker centres are places in the city that have many various good eateries situated in one place for a very affordable price.  The same was found here at Hawkers Delight.   It's a nice small place and when you walk in you can see the menu displayed above with pictures of the delicious food.  I wanted to try them all.   

Anyway, I ordered the lamb curry served with rice.   My friends ordered mee goreng (noodle dish) and laksa (soup).   Our food was brought to us and I was really satisfied with what was presented to me.   The portions on each of our orders was perfect.  I had the lamb curry in one dish and the portion of rice on another.   The lamb and the sauce it was in was rich and I poured that shit all over my rice and it was amazing.  The taste was delicious and reminded me of my visit to Singapore.   I will definitely come back here to try the other dishes."
"This place is know for their cheap price and large portions.  Not the best Malay food I ever had but still pretty good.  The place is pretty run down and need a bit of reno.  I would give it another star if the food was spicier and tastier.  I tried their Laksa but it was too sweet for my liking.  I also tried their Char Kuey Teow.  I thought it was soup noodle but was more like mee goreng like.  I didn't like the porky base sauce as I got this dish thinking it would be vegetarian.  Vege fritta was ok - bit greasy but ok.

I tried few of their other dishes that I can't remeber the name but nothing really stood out as outstanding.  Still, a pretty good place to grab a quick and cheap bite."
"I couldn't stop thinking about laksa one day and looked it up on Google to find many people raving about this place, so off I dragged my boyfriend to try this place.

It is a small restaurant with as many tables it could possibly fit with enough room to squeeze through. Before entering we noticed all the awards and Yelp stickers on the glass door!

There was a bit of a wait for a table, but by the time we had ordered a space cleared up for us to settle into (our backup was some space on the counter on the side). Here you order first at the window and they give you a number.

We ordered the chicken curry noodles, laksa (see above), and a side order of roti. Each of the dishes were very flavourful and was a good portion. With three dishes and a drink, the total was around $25 making it a very inexpensive meal for the tasty goodness you get. I can't speak to the authenticity, but it was really great food. We'll be returning to try their other items - so far eyeing the hainese chicken, mee goreng, and veggie fritters, tee hee."
"Haven't been here in ages.. It's still the same old dirty hole-in-the-wall hawker place with pretty authentic tasting Singaporean and Malaysian food! 

We ordered the Roti Prata to start, and the Fried Kway Teow and Hainanese Chicken Rice as our mains. The Roti Prata was crispy, with a rich buttery taste. The curry dip it came with was flavourful, albeit a tad over-salty. The Fried Kway Teow (my absolute fave dish to order at any Singaporean / Malaysian place) was quite delicious! Wok-fried to order in their big open kitchen, it tasted just like the same dish you would get straight from a hawker centre in Singapore. Both the chicken & the rice in the Hainanese Chicken Rice dish had just the right hit of flavour. The only thing missing was an accompanying bowl of chicken rice soup to wash it down with! 

The place is small and can get pretty warm even with a ceiling fan. Water/hot tea is available,  alongside self-serve utensils. Decent portion sizes and relatively low prices make for good value. With authentic-tasting food and a truly hawker-like experience, it's worth stopping in for a bite if you're in the area."
