"We managed to order lunch during the weekend rush and get a couple seats by the window without having to wait too long. You order, pay in cash and get a number. The kitchen staff drop off food at wherever you are seated.

We ordered a few items: hainanese chicken, mee goreng and roti prata. Food arrived in reasonable time. The chicken and rice was okay. I have had better chicken and more aromatic rice elsewhere. The value is there at under $10 for the meal. The roti was good - flaky and oily goodness. The curry dipping sauce was very coconut based and was good. 

Decent cheap eats if you are in the area. The portion size is good for the price. Cash only and parking can be challenging at times in the area."
"***Warning: Do not come here if you are a critic whose liking of the food is based mostly on the restaurant's choice of interior decor***

Ok, you have been warned. Now let's get to the important part of this review: The food.

Having heard about this place and being a fan of cheap, authentic and good food, I decided to try it out for dinner. Not only that, I brought one of my Singaporean friends with me to try it out so that I would have all aspects of my review covered.

We tried the Laksa, Mee Goreng and a tofu dish with peanut sauce (I forget the name of it). My Singaporean friend gives all of them a stamp of approval in terms of authenticity. Being a noodle fanatic, the Laksa was delicious! The ingredients used were all fresh, and the coconut curry broth was spicy, tasty and aromatic. Move over Banana Leaf -- if you want good Laksa for your buck, come to Hawker's instead. The Mee Goreng was full of spice and flavour -- slightly on the oilier side, but I was too busy enjoying the taste of it to care. As for the tofu dish with the peanut sauce, I caution you to share it -- either you have to love tofu to eat it for your meal, or you should find people to share it with, because the peanut sauce deceivingly covers a majority of the tofu squares.

The place definitely is small and has the hawker's feel to it. There is an order window where you order and pay, and they will bring the food to you when it is ready. With the Asian-style coloured cafeteria eating utensils, plates and bowls, it really takes me back to the good ol' days in Asia where food was good and cheap -- just like it is here at Hawkers."
"Food: 3.5/5 - we ordered the tofu goreng, Hainanese chicken and rice, laksa, nasi goreng, and roti. The hainanese chicken was my favorite. Large portion and flavorful rice that will make you want to chow it down fast. The laksa also was also tasty. The tofu gorgeng wasn't anything special but servings size was large. The nasi goreng was spicier then expected for a mild and would maybe get it less spicy to appreciate the flavor a little more.


Service: 2/5 - practically no service, you order, grab your own cutlery and water, sit down and wait for your food. Don't expect anything more than that.

Ambiance: 3/5 (this depends) - it's a hole in the wall with Asian street-food vibes. It's not the fanciest and cleanest place. But it does give it an authentic feel or experience. The place is small can feel a little cramped

Value: 4/5 - the food was good with decent sized portions. For less than $15, you'll have your fill. 

Overall, I doubt I'll come back to this place unless I lived in the area and was walking around and needed something to eat. 

Tip: it's cash only"
Very tasty food, reminded me of being back in Malaysia. The hainanese chicken rice was a little out of proportion for rice:chicken but overall really good. Will definitely go back!
"Classic hole in the wall excellence, complete with cash only, self serve water, and delicious food. I will 100% return to this place every time I visit Vancouver. It's as close as I can get without actually going to Singapore. From a Singaporean's perspective, here's what to get:

Kway Teow (5/5): This is a classic singaporean/malaysian dish, that is not to be missed. It's kind of like pad see ew, but with a more savory flavor rather than sweet. One of my favorites.

Laksa (5/5): Must get. This is a coconut based seafood noodle soup. It's a bit spicy but as someone who really hates spice, I will deal with it for this dish. 

Bak Kut Teh (5/5): This pork herbal soup will heal your soul and fight off diseases you didn't know you had. Super peppery and flavorful. Give this lesser known soup a try!

Mee Pok (4/5): This noodle dish isn't as flavorful as the other dishes.

Hainan chicken rice (3/5): Not enough flavor and fragrance."
"Hole-in-the-wall, Malaysian/Singaporean, Cash Only, Cheap

Your to go Malaysian/Singaporean place that is meant for ""to-go"". Also, a great hole in the wall! After coming back from Malaysia and Singapore, it does the hawkers' places great justice.

First, this place is tiny! Unless you are lucky to find a spot by the window or come outside of peak hours, you have better bets taking this home. But if you are one of the few lucky ones who snag a seat, do order a good variety. Great portion size and immense flavor! I will warn you that many things on the menu is quite spicy. Family owned and staff are very sweet. Do know they are swamped 100% of peak hours so don't take offence when they are not as attentive then. 

Second, here are a few items to try: steaming Laksa (great for a cold day), Char kway teow, gato gato, Mee Goreng. Fritters! They are sold next to the cashier, buy a few to snack on while you wait!

Third, don't come during rush hours."
"* Almost like the hawkers in Singapore *

With the heat yesterday sitting in the small dining area it *almost* reminded me of being at an outdoor hawker food court in Singapore.  Ok.  Scratch that.  It wasn't even close to hot enough.  We are such wimps in Vancouver with heat - complaining when it hits 25 degrees!  

(Although I do confess that when in Singapore I frequently will happily visit the indoor ones too!)

I'm not sure how I never put up a review for Hawkers before.  But after visiting yesterday I realized I should as it is a long time favourite for me.  

My favourite dish here is the lontong.  The rice is prepared inside of a banana leaf and compressed into nice little rice cakes.  These are covered with a mild coconut curry filled with all sorts of goodies like fried tofu, cabbage, carrots, a hard boiled egg, fried onion paste, a hint of chili oil, and a slight hint of belachan (shrimp paste).  

It makes for a very filling meal for an incredibly reasonable $4.75.

Also tried out one of the vegetable fritters they had just freshly prepared and had sitting on the counter.  This was a massive fritter filled with all sorts of different veggies.  It was served at room temperature but wasn't the slightest bit greasy.  After ordering it they gave a quick spoonful of a vinegar based sweet sauce that soaked into the fritter.  Delicious snack for $1.05.

They make a very nice laksa as well - but I hadn't been in a while so I had to order the lontong!

I agree with Claudia L completely - Hawkers definitely kicks Noodle Box's butt!"
"This is where to get the real authentic Singaporean food(- spiciness) . I lived in Singapore for over 5+ years so I can guarantee that this is the real Singaporean food.
I came here with my friends and shared mee goreng, lamb curry, laksa, roti, chicken curry and chicken rice......the food is really good. Great portion, great food, cheap(in Vancouver standard)  and very authentic. 

My favorite is Laksa. The laksa is really close to the best laksa I had in Singapore. It was so good to the extent that I even finished drinking the soup... If it was spicier, it will be even more authentic but I think most people including me will not be able to tolerate the Singaporean spice level...."
"Super affordable Malaysian cuisine on the heart of Mount Pleasant! I've wanted to try this place for a while but I never have cash on me (they are cash only). Today I stumbled upon Hawkers again so my boyfriend and I decided to try the food here. I ordered Laksa ($9.55) and he ordered Mee Rubus ($8.55). To be honest I'm not too familiar with the cuisine and I've only had Laksa twice (both in Vancouver) so I may not be the best judge, but our out of three times I've had it this place was my least favourite. The flavour was a bit lacking and there weren't enough toppings VS noodles. Noodles were also rice noodles or wheat noodles and not egg noodles. However, for the price I would say it's a bargain as their service was super fast too. 

I'm someone who looks for taste before price so I would give Hawker's a 3 based on the Laksa that I've tried but I'll have to come back and try more things from here."
"Because it's Covid time,  we could take out only. Drove 15 minutes to here for our first time visit after seeing a lot of good review here. Finding a parking was not easy - we had to park the car four blocks away on Saturday 1pm. 

Ordered Laksa and Veggie Fritters and I think they are pretty much so so. My husband ordered Mee Goreng and said it's not too bad. 

I think I won't drive all the way here again unless I am happen to be around."
"Great spot to fulfil the craving for fast, cheap, and delicious Singaporean food. I'll be returning. 

[Dishes]
Laksa - really tasty, not overly spicy, and surprisingly sweet compared to other laksa that I've had. Would recommend.

Hainanese Chicken rice - the rice was cooked to perfection, you'll taste the chickeny goodness with every bite. The chicken was good too, but the rice is the standout.

[Atmosphere]
Things are bustling. Make sure to scope out a table quick, or you could be left standing with a tray of food and nowhere to eat it. The service is quick and efficient, and won't appreciate anything that slows down the stream of food from the kitchen. 

If you've got a big group, this place probably isn't for you. I'd say four max to sit comfortably. 

[Value]
Pretty good value. Paid $10 each for the laksa and the chicken rice."
"Simple yet delicious. The chicken rice, mee rebus and mee goreng was good. Very authentic. They only take cash! There's an ATM around the corner. 
I'm glad we stopped by on the way to Vancouver. Boleh!"
"Guys, trust me the Laksa here is AMAZING!!!

I find myself coming back here again and again for a quick meal, for take out, and to just enjoy in this small shop! I constantly crave their laksa, nowhere else makes it like them!!"
Good selection with great prices. Had the nasi goreng which was great flavour and a wonderful size. Couldn't finish it all. Ordered the spicy version but still needed to add hot sauce. Next time I'd get it to go as the eat in area is small and cramped so you can't help but be bumped into by other diners.
Price alert!  The menus photographed have old pricing.  Add about 1.5 to each item for the updated price.  The food here is tasty and much like the hawker style in South East Asia.  Try their char Kuay Teow - it is pretty authentic.
This place is love. It's pretty much your definition of a hole-in-the-wall family run restaurant with cheap prices, a menu on the wall, and serve yourself utensils kinda place. I came here after hiking with my boyfriend and he loved the place so much, by the time we left I could tell he wanted to give the small Asian lady behind the counter a hug. We will definitely be coming back to this place to try more items on the menu, but really, you can't go wrong with anything! The fried rice is greasy, chewy, and has the perfect amount of kick to it. The laksa is creamy yet soupy and oh-so-comforting on a cold evening. I could go on and on about the food here, but it really speaks for itself!
"Tasty, delicious meals at reasonable prices! There aren't a lot of tables but they have 2 different counter seating spots. You won't go wrong with anything on the menu plus get the vegetable fritters!
Tip: prepare to pay $0.25 for every container you need for your leftovers."
"Came here after hearing many recommendations and having it on my to try list for years and we were not disappointed with the food or the prices! Very small place with not a huge menu but the people that work there are really nice and the food is authentic! 

We got the hainanese chicken rice, which was really flavourful, a large portion and had a good amount of chicken as well! I tried out the mee pok with minced pork sauce, some protein (shrimp, pork and fish cake) and lots of noodles, for the first time and although it looked really heavy, but since the portion was so large, when you mixed everything in, it wasnt overly salty or oily! I really liked the noodle they used too! 
Next we got the fried kwey teow which was rice noodles wok fried with egg, fish cake, chicken and shrimp. They were quite generous with the amount of size of this dish and it was dang tasty too! My family also loved the laksa which was the perfect blend of spicy and coconut. The noodles were the rice noodles (thick) which I don't love but I believe you can choose to change the noodle if requested. I liked that they also gave a good amount of chicken and prawn on top as well. We topped off the meal with their vegetable fritters which were a GREAT price for some huge sized fried vegetable balls! 

Overall, Hawkers Delight has it all! Food that is really yummy, large portions for the price and friendly service. Some dishes are a little oilier but thats expected for Malaysian food and they dont have many ""appies"" but their large dishes are so well priced, you could just order another ;)"
"Came here for quick lunch with my brothers. Small little hole in the wall place with delicious Malaysian comfort food and so cheap!!!

It's the kind of place that makes you feel like you're in Singapore or Malaysia (was also very hot this day).

Their fried veggie fritters were so tasty. I didn't expect much out of them but I was pleasantly surprised. We got chicken rice and char kuey teow, classic dishes I always order. I'm not picky with food but I have to say they were one of the best dishes I've ever had, maybe because of the great prices and portions, but it was so worth it. I've never been to Malaysia or Singapore but it really made me feel like I was there because the flavors are so authentic!

Will find my way back to this gem soon!"
"I was here a few nights ago with my boyfriend to do takeout this time. It was a lot different. We were here for the Fried Keuy Teow and Mee Goreng. They were $8.60 and $7.25 per dish. Really good value because they actually put the take out food in a plastic container that is microwave safe. I think it's a pretty good bargain but the downfall is we chose non-spicy and it really tasted bland. The wait for take out was a good 10-15 mins for those two dishes and we got Roti. I have to say all of these were really oily and heavy on MSG. I ate half of what I expected to eat because there was so much MSG and oil. The roti can be better but ya.... 

Overall, it's a good bargain for what you get just it was kinda bland for me. Do get the spicy and if you can't eat spicy you can maybe try mild spicy."
"I seriously love this place. I love the feel of this little joint - it totally reminds me of Chinese street food cafeteria style dining, and they keep true to the feeling with the prices and the flavour. 

All the notes are right: cash only, be quick with your meal, serve your own water and get your own cutlery and napkins. Other notes; not open on Mondays, and they're about to close out for a month on vacation (Aug 15 - Sept 15 2013 I think). 

The laksa is delicious - the portions for the price are mind-boggling, and their Hainanese Chicken + Rice is so fantastic. We wanted to order a bunch of other dishes, but we seriously couldn't fit enough in our little tummies. 

Come hungry and come ready for some greasy food. Leverage the pictures above the ordering area if you need. Keep an eye on table diners as they leave, it seems you need to do a bit of hovering if its crowded, since tables don't seem to be handed out first-come-first-serve (we had a table or two swooped out from under us until we finally held our stance and secured seats).

I love this place. I would come here all the time if I could. If you've never been, it's time to visit one of the go-to eateries in this beautiful city! What are you waiting for?!"
Good food for a great price. A change of pace and an interesting menu.. A friend introduced me to it years ago and I keep coming back when I am in the neigbourhood  Stop in and try it you just might like it !!!!
"After hearing some hype about this place, I decided to check out it.  Walking down Main St., I thought I had the wrong address as the place looks like a run down western cafe.  However, the strangely alluring busy hole-in-the-wall with large picture menus and low prices beckoned and I had the feeling that I found something special.

Coming at lunch time, the tiny cafeteria was busy (capacity being about 15 people).  Packed with patrons all shuffling pass each other down the narrow aisleways flanked by small tables, my friend and I were snapped out of our picture menu gawking and our indecisiveness as someone had to elbow past us to get a tea refill.

As mentioned in other reviews, most of the dishes are about $4-$5 and they offer tons of vegetarian options with the various rice/noodle plates.  For about $20, we got a lot of food:
- 6 x satay skewers ($0.75 each)
- nasi goreng (fried rice) - veggie
- mee goreng (fried noodle) - veggie
- lamb curry with rice ($6.75 - most expensive thing on the menu)

Place your order, pay the cashier, grab your utensils and tea, try to snipe a seat, and wipe off the curry remnants from the last diner off the table - and you don't notice any waiting time before they bring your dishes to you.

The portions are perfectly-sized - large and filling (perfect for a cheap lunch) but not so huge that you feel like a glutton (although you definitely are indulging) if you order two dishes.  Feel like a small-time baller for $10.

The nasi goreng was good and I preferred it over the mee goreng (felt like it was missing a spicy kick - maybe I'm too used to the 'Mi Goreng' instant noodles I get from T&T).  But the highlight was the lamb curry with rice.  Not as spicy as its threatening red appearance would lead you to believe but the curry was flavourful and the lamb chunks were so tender and moist - over rice, this was some sensational comfort food.

After an amazing meal (especially considering the value) our plates and neon-coloured bowls were quickly bussed away.  Being as busy as the place was and seeing others hunting for seats, I felt uncomfortable loitering and sipping tea and quickly slinked my way to the exit trying not to bump into someone enjoying their food.

Not a place for a sit-down meal, but as the name suggests, it's a place to get your good grub on, quickly and cheaply like the hawker centres in Asia.  Take-out is a good option; charging ~$0.25 per take out container - which I thought I was strange considering they save on bussing and dishwashing - shrug.

Overall, I was pretty happy to find this gem of a hole-in-the-wall and will be back to try the Hainanese chicken rice and laksa.  I think the game of human Tetris you play when you come inside the cramped interior is part of the appeal - after all, it feels like you fought for your food.  If I worked/lived nearby, I would be a regular here - just please don't elbow me in the head when I'm eating."
"Just wonderful. Everything about this place reminds me of hawker food back home. The sweltering heat in the summer, the rude service, the smell that lingers in your clothes, the cheap prices and of course, the amazing food. Definitely the most authentic Singaporean/Malaysian food outside of either country. 

Order the char kway teow or the mee goreng."
As some have noted, this is the quintessential hole in the wall. But it's a fantastic spot for authentic Singaporean hawker style food.  The area for eating is miniscule and diners will sit armpit to elbow with their neighbors, so it's an authentic experience!  We tried the laksa and the Hainan chicken rice, both signature dishes for this type of restaurant.  While the Hainan chicken was decent, the laksa was outstanding and I would travel across town to have this again.  The prices are ridiculously cheap but all of the money is spent on the food, not the décor.  A top find.
This is a tiny hole in the wall eatery that is delicious. I have only tried the laksa but it never disappoints - whenever I'm over in the area I make an effort to visit. It's small size means it's advisable to get there shortly after it opens to get a seat if you are a group. As I've only dined there solo I've never had a problem getting a space. Cash only, but it's really good value for money.
This place is a dive, hole in the wall, etc etc and it's amazing. Best place for cheap Malaysian/Singapore food. I often go for the meegoreng. It's one of the better ones in the city. Yes, it's greasy but what asian fried noodle dish isn't? You'll certainly be paying at least 50% more at the other full service restaurants. Hawkers Delight is an ode to eating in Southeast Asia. Packed full of people, questionable cleanliness, and delicious food made on the spot. Perfect. The only thing it's missing is the cheap plastic chairs and metal tables that you often find in those parts of the world.
Have lived in the Main Street area for 10 years and finally found the time to eat at Hawkers. Wow was I surprised at this hole in the wall. I had the vegetarian curry which came out in less then 10 mins and was delicious. I had more then enough for lunch and the leftovers were perfect for dinner. Will definitely be back.
"prob one of the best kept well known secrets of Mount Pleasant.  Malaysian Street style food, nasi goreng to die for or curry beef on rice.  veggie options throughout also, the deep fried veggie fritters are soooo good.  

price average $4-$6 a plate....satay $1.50 with 5 as a minimum order.

usually only takes about 5-10 mins to be served your food, and maybe 15 mins wait for takeout.

good feel, good hood.....great food, better price"
As a student, i woud highly recommand this place. As a Malayaian, i would strongly suggest you to try prawn mee and char kway teow. You get both the value and the authenticity.
This is the best Singaporean food you can find in the whole of Canada. The portion and price is reasonable that hit the spot!
Hawker's Delight brings you well priced authentic Malaysian food. I really enjoyed their Mee Goreng, Char Kuey Teow and Laksa. They also have really good roti canai. The place is very small and has limited seating and has a more of a server yourself concept. Food comes fast and you will leave feeling full without dropping a lot of $$.
"This place is very small but homey. Walk in and the aroma hits you along with the sounds of the kitchen and fellow dine in guests. I also adore the folk music they got going on in the background. It's very tight squeeze to walk around but if you're a solo traveler like me, I recommend sitting at the window to people watch. 

The food comes out really fast too. Not even a minute after I sat down, it was delivered to me. 

I'm so glad I came here because there is zero malaysian food in San Diego :( I have a soft spot for Malaysian food since it reminds me a lot of Vietnamese. 

I ordered the Laksa and if you're Vietnamese, this tastes like the coconut version of Bun Rieu. Its so good and cheap too."
We decided to drop in here after seeing the line-ups at some of the more trendy places in the neighborhood. It was pretty busy inside, but people get in and out quickly. We ordered Mee Rebus and Vegetable Curry with rice. Both dishes were rich, flavorful and hearty with a good amount of spice. Lots of options on the menu so definitely need to come back here to try other things. If you're looking for ambiance, go elsewhere. The food is definitely on point.
Been here multiple times, always satisfied. I am a Penang borned Singaporean, so i am really particular about my Malaysian-Singaporean food, and this  place gets it. Fav are char kway teow and Laksa. And the price is so reasonable too!
"Hawkers is a definite go-to spot. It's very vegetarian friendly, though those who enjoy meat will also be very pleased. Did I mention that it's cheap? Oh....right. Well, it's very cheap. 
It's often crowded and a bit chaotic, don't assume that because you ordered together your food will arrive simultaneously. It's kind of part of the experience though. That feeling of jealousy as your friend begins only adds to the delight when you get your big plate of piping hot delicious food.
That's about it, it's very good and very cheap. It's so down to earth that you occasionally have to flag down the food runner and convince her you ordered that dish she's carrying, but that's kind of fun too."
A little gem tucked away on Main, that's very true of Hawker's Delight! Specializing in Singaporean and Malaysian cuisine, their laksa is one to none in town. Rich coconut broth with just the perfect amount of chili oil, and add a dash of savoury fish paste will bring you to Singapore and back  ! It's a rare find in Vancouver. We also had Hainanese chicken with rice, although you may find better options elsewhere as the chicken is a tad chewy and they only serve the spicy sauce (no ginger and green onion dipping sauce). Not a bad place and looking forward to trying their Char Kway Teu next time!
Cheap eat, and full of quantity. If you're starving and want a quick burst of south East Asian flavours, this is the place to go. The veggie fritters and nasi goreng are some of my go-tos but other dishes are also delicious and reasonably priced. If you're ever in the area, you should stop by and try it. Perfect for a night when you are hungry and can't decide what to eat.
"This area is filled with restaurants and eateries but luck was on my side and I found parking right outside! We came after the rush around 7:15pm on a Friday night so we got a good size table by the wall. It's definitely hole in the wall type of place where you grab your own utensils and tea/water. The plastic cups for hot tea isn't really ideal so mainly used to clean the utensils.

We ordered some of the classics. Fried kuey teow, hainanese chicken, roti prata and bak kut teh with noodles. The kuey teow we asked for mild heat and I guess they couldn't do it because there was no heat at all. It was quite bland but you can still taste the 'wok air' (frying with a wok that gives off a different taste). 

The hainanese chicken was boneless and pretty tender; mostly dark meat and dressed with some sauce already. The rice is seasoned well also so the sauce on the side was not really necessary. I could definitely see myself eating just this again. 

I have had bak kut teh elsewhere and this one is not nearly as peppery as it should or could be. The spareribs had no taste at all because it all went into the broth?? I am really glad we chose the round rice noodles instead of rice to go with it. 
Finally the roti, when it came, I wasn't impressed. It was very flat on the plate like a green onion pancake. When I broke it up with a fork, then I could see it had some layers too it. The curry sauce is very runny and had some heat. I am glad I tried it but it's not the best in town. 

I would come back for takeout orders. The atmosphere is authentic to how you would eat it in Malaysia, I suppose? Definitely not a fan of all those fans."
Hawker's Delight is the closest restaurant to authentic Singaporean food that I've gone to, and you'll absolutely love how good (and spicy, and inexpensive) it is! I had the laksa (rice noodles in a spicy curry soup, coconut milk, tofu puffs, fish cakes, egg, chicken, prawns, and sprouts), roti prata (kind of like a pancake that's crispy on the outside, non-GF) served with curry sauce, and fried Kuey Teow (one of my favourites! Spicy rice noodles with egg, bean sprouts, prawns, fish cakes, and green onions). You HAVE to try this place. It's not very clean and it's a little cramped, but that's how a lot of hawker stalls are like when I visit Singapore, so maybe I'm used to it. Amazing authentic food though!
The Veggie Fritters were surreal - order at least two. Also tried the Laksa and loved it. We did very little talking during the meal, eating with a ravenous efficiency and speed that might have done us damage. You will sweat like hot yoga.
"Tasty cheap eats. Worth it. 
An institution on main st.
Expect to spend $10 per person."
"I've been coming to Hawkers for well over a decade when the prices were insanely cheap and the menu was photos of a dish stuck on the wall. Every time I come back (which is often) its always heart warming to see the same familiar faces in the kitchen. 

For me this restaurant is a mixture of nostalgia and just amazing consistent food. Its a very small restaurant so be prepared to get cozy with a neighbour and its also self service so you grab your own cutlery & tea/water in the front. 

Hands down my favourite dishes are:

- Dried Bee Hon (5/5) 
Thin rice noodles tossed with the most delicious sweet/savoury meat sauce with bok choy bean sprouts and pickled chilis (p.s ask for extra pickled chilis they give the dish a great tangy/spicy zip) 

-  Mee Goreng (5/5) 
I always get mine spicy, overall this dish is just so comforting. The balance of the chewy egg noodles with a mixture of stir fried tomato, potato, onion and veggies is perfect.

- Hainanese Chicken Rice (4/5) 
If you are use to the Hainan China style of chicken rice than this will be completely different. But regardless this is still delicious, the chicken is succulent (and the bones are cut out which I pleasantly enjoy). The rice texture is like broken rice and flavour wise is a little more on the subtle side. *Tip there will be a bottle of a type of soy sauce on each table, USE IT on this dish it brings that extra uumpph!"
"Came by on a Saturday afternoon to this very popular Singapore/Malaysian establishment.  It is small with limited seating but we were lucky and secured a table.  We ordered the chicken curry (with rice), fried noodles and roti with curry..all for $20.  The noodles and chicken curry were okay...fairly typical Malaysian.   The roti & dipping curry combo was the highlight of the meal...if we went back, that is all I would order.  They also have complimentary hot tea.

Great food value for the price and it was a positive food experience...happy to go back just for the roti & curry."
This hole in the wall Malaysian joint is a must try when in the Main st. neighborhood. Serving authentic Malaysian / Singaporean hawker dishes, this place is everything but frills - if you're a fan of  'wok hei' from traditional Asian cuisine (aka the rich flavors from stir frying), this is the place to go. I had the chance to try multiple items off their menu over several visits, items that I find myself reordering is the Spicy Prawn Noodle, the Fried Kuey Teow, the Mee Goreng and the Vegetable Fritter (!!!) - highly recommend the vegetable fritters!
"One of the best things I love about traveling is street food. Stepping into this place makes you feel like you're in one of those food stalls in Asia (minus the higher probability of diarrhea).

They didn't have satay available the day I went. I opted to try their veggie fritters as they were on the counter, boy were those tasty! 2 for only like $1 and change, packed with flavour.

I ordered up the Laksa and it was only $5 something! It was the best I've ever had. I'm pretty sure they put chicken meat in it along with shrimp, egg, and a kick of spiciness. Definitely made me sweat with the heat. I also got a veggie spring roll which was pretty decent with some kind of black sauce.

Props to the chef who you'll hear banging away non-stop on the wok, and the super friendly lady who takes your order.

Definitely a repeat-worthy place."
Ordered the Thai Style Chicken and Nasi Lame.  Pretty authentic Malay food.  Not too spicy which is great.  I love spicy food but not to the point that it singes everything to a point where you can no longer taste your food.  Amazing value and quality.  This merits another visit for sure.
"My review may be a bit biased since I order only one thing lol. But since coming back from Asia I've been turned off by laksa because it just isn't the same here. On my hunt for great laksa I have stumbled upon this little place inside Crystal Mall. I have to say, it is the BEST laksa I've had so far in Vancouver!! 

I believe they have two types of laksas and the one I'm talking about is the Singapore laksa. The laksa comes with tofu, fish balls, some other kinds of meat and two different types of noodles. It's really neat they do that. One is the thin rice noodle? Or vermicelli noodle? And the other is a thicker yellow noodle I have no idea what it is. As much as I like the double noodle combo in the beginning. As I've continued to eat this, I realized that I only want the thin noodle but I keep forgetting to ask them every. Single. Time. 

All in all, come here for their laksa. It's fantastic! And have some xiao long baos from that corner store diagonally across from them while you're at it."
It's really the only place I would crave in the whole food court, and what a wonderful full flavour. Try out various Southeast Asian dishes known from Malaysia and Singapore.
Decent food for a decent price.  Unlike some of the other vendors at this food court, the people here are pretty nice at and generous and the food is actually pretty good.  The other commenter ridiculed the place for their fried food, and we normally try to stay away from fried food...but e noodle soup and stir fried noodles were pretty good.
"Found this little spot by chance and was immediately drawn to it.  The kway teow was AMAZING and very authentic, the kind I'd get in Brunei.  The flavours were great, with some spice to it .

The Laksa was so delicious that my friend, who can't tolerate spicyness, was ALL OVER IT like a fly on poop. He paid for it later, but said it was totally worth it.

Every time I go to Vancouver, this is on my list.  While I sit in my house in Edmonton, I dream of the Laksa at Ipoh Bean Sprout Chicken."
"Not bad for a cheap eat at Crystal Mall. We ordered their Haininese Chicken with Rice for $8 and although there wasn't much chicken, there was A LOT of flavourful rice. The chicken was tender although not very strong in flavour and comes with a soup.

Overall, not the best but definitely not a bad choice."
"I had food from this stall a few times now. The first time I tried the Penang prawn noodles and I was not impressed as it lacked the oomph in the taste of the soup. The laksa gravy which I nicked from my friend was also on the weak side. 

I decided to order other dishes which seemed very popular with diners and they were definitely much better and similar to those you find in Malaysia/Singapore. Thus the 4-star rating.

The char kway teow had the wok hei flavor to it and was a close duplicate (soy sauce tasted a bit different but I could understand that since you could not really get the exact same brands here). Instead of cockles, they sub it with some shellfish or clam which gave the chewy texture. Unfortunately the clam/shellfish was very tasteless. 

The nasi lemak was pretty good, especially the crispy ikan bilis (anchovies) and fried chicken wing (very legit Malaysian/Singaporean home style) and the generous serving of sambal. Simply delicious in Vancouver's context. 

The hor fun (fried kway teow with creamy egg sauce) was the kind you get from the tze char place in Singapore. Wok hei and all. I saw many people ordered this and there is a reason for that. If you are a fan of the Singapore style hor fun at Kurumba in Port Moody, then you will like this better. At least I did. 

I will need to go back to try the Hainanese chicken rice and ipoh chicken rice and ipoh hor fun next. They also have Hakka Pan Mee which is exciting as I love the pan mee in KL, Malaysia. I hope it will be the same.  

Prices are fair as this is located in the food court. The chef and the lady taking order are from Ipoh. Go say hello to them if you are also from that part of the world."
I thought of getting their Ipoh bean sprout chicken but when asked about their most popular dish seafood laksa seems to be the one. So I got an order of that to try. For $8.50, you get a lot of noodles and average laksa broth with not so much seafood toppings. I like that they provide complimentary tea.
"Got the creamy egg hor fun after trying it at their sister restaurant in marpole and must say that although the portion of noodles was quite small, it was expertly stir fried and the creamy egg sauce went perfect. It was a little bit salty and oily but hey, it cost $10 and was from a food court! There were some pieces of shrimp, pork and greens in the sauce and made for a tasty combination.

Overall, quite a delicious dish from a ""chicken"" place!"
"Malaysian street food.  Beautiful.

Parking is available in the Crystal Mall lot.

As with all the other places in the food court, this place is really just a counter with a bunch of signs taped to the wall.  Staff took my order, and the food came maybe 10 minutes later.

The shredded pork laksa I had (can't remember the name) was tasty.  The shredded BBQ pork was a bit on the fatty side, requiring me to spit out chunks of fat.  The soup was quite good.  Noodles were half decent, though they tasted like they came from one of the Asian supermarket stalls nearby.  The garnish was a bunch of leaves and half a baby lime.

Wouldn't mind coming back here again for sure, to try their signature Ipoh bean sprout chicken"
"This place is located in the 2nd floor food court.

Seating was a little challenging as it was a little busy.

Food was quite OK for food court standards.
We had the chicken rice, nasi lemak and fried kwey teow as can be seen by my pics.

I have had better SG and Malaysian food elsewhere though..."
In a city where food court and food truck meals are now around $15, it's nice to have a food court like Crystal Mall where you can find some authentic hidden gems for around $7.  Mind  you I've tried some places in this food court that wasn't all that great. And not being able to speak/read any of the Asian languages, it can be an adventure picking a spot to try.  This time around I tried Ipoh.  Scanning through the pictures on the wall, I picked out the claypot short rice noodle soup with ground pork.  It also had a gooey egg on top and I'm a sucker for a gooey egg on top of anything.  What came out of the kitchen was a bubbling, sizzling clay pot with the egg freshly cracked on top and still cooking.  By the time I made the slow, careful walk to my table, the dish had cooled down to a slow simmer and the egg perfectly cooked and ready to be gooed all over the place.  The menu said this was a soup but it was more like a really thick stew. I bought an order of white rice on the side to eat it with.  It was delicious, flavorful, nice texture and everything you could want on a cold day.  I'm only giving this place a 4 star because I haven't tried anything else on the menu to be sure it's a 5 star.  Although at this point I'm not sure that I'd try anything else on the menu with how much I loved this clay pot dish.
"I've been here for twice already and the food was impressive in my opinion. Their Chicken and Laksa Combo ($9.50) was big and filling. Laksa didn't have much toppings, however noodles and soup were tasty. Chicken was rather lukewarm; however the portion and taste were great. I think the whole combo would be TOO big for one person. I didn't have to go all the way to Hawkers Delight for Laksa ,and Ipoh is definetely closer distance from my home.

I also tried Malaysian wings($5.99) earlier for dinner. Chicken wings were fresh and crispy. My only gripe was staff gave me few napkins after ordering wings. I mean you get all messy and greasy after eating and why giving so less? Anyways I totally recommend Ipoh for some Laksa and the rest of the food. Char Kway Teow looked quite yummy and I want to try it next time."
"We always get the flat rice noodle with shrimp and egg sauce.  Delicious! The pickled jalapeños that come with it are yummy. 

Too many things in the good court, when we'd go we buy things from at least 3/4 vendors, and this is the dish we get from here.  

I've tried the vermicelli laksa before and it's ok. Nothing I would crave again. 

Get these noodles !!!"
I ordered nasi lemak and it was presented exactly like the average nasi lemak u can find in Malaysia. I feel like the sambal is not spicy at all.. There's no kick to it but they probably dilute it to cater for the locals here. But, they have better sambal at the condiment section which is delicious. Overall, it's a decent nasi lemak. I gave it 4 stars because it's still better than most Malaysian restaurants I been in BC.
"I went to this place today to try out my first Malaysian meal after reading comments on Yelp. I got chicken and noodles laska soup ($9.75). I got my food about 5 minutes after placing the order. It came with 2 parts, 1 noodles bowl and 1 deep fried chicken portion. 
The noodles bowl have: Noodles, bean sprouts, green onion, and 2 pieces of deep fried tofu, so not many toppings: The noodles was quite nice, but later on I was full and It was kinda rich so I had to leave some unfinished. 
The chicken is seasoned with salt then deep fried. It was very nice. 
Overall, I could not finish the meal (I was hungry when I ordered). The dish was good. Will I ever come back again? Hardly. Because the price compared to the meal was a bit too filling since I didn't finish it.  (I am a student)"
"If you are looking for good Singaporean/Malaysian food, this is definitely a place to try! 

The taste is pretty authentic, portions are generous filled with ingredients (especially compared to a couple of other local Singaporean restaurants I've been to..) and price is affordable! 

The menu is filled with so many different options! My faves so far are:

*Ipoh Hor Fun: flat rice noodles served in a delicious eggy soupy base. Just from the picture, it's easy to see that it's filled with so many ingredients like prawn, fish cake, veggies and pork. If you like a little bit of spice, it also comes with cut green chilli which goes really well with this dish.

*Char Keoy Teow: definitely a signature Singapore dish done right! Yummy, and sprinkled with numerous prawns and Chinese sausages

I've also tried the Penang Prawn Mee today, which I also enjoyed! It comes with a mix of yellow noodle and vermicelli which is a combo I really like. The soup was decent, but a little bit on the oily side. It doesn't quite hit my list of faves, but is something I would consider ordering again :)"
"It's easy to pass by this Malaysian/Singaporean place as it doesn't look like much. That would be a mistake though if you enjoy this type of cuisine.  This is one of those places where you shouldn't judge the quality of the food by how a place looks.

If you're like me, trying to decide between the myriads of different eateries in the Crystal Mall food fair can be a challenge.  One time I decided to give Ipoh a try. That was all it took to make me a repeat customer.  So far I've tried their laksa, prawn mee (noodles in soup), kueh teow (fried flat rice noodles) in creamy egg sauce, nasi lemak, fried chicken wings, and roti and have never been disappointed.  Overall, the food is fresh, tasty and authentic."
"The Ipoh Chicken dish is great!
The chicken was tender, juicy and flavourful, without being overly seasoned. The flavours were very delicate, and went very well mixed together with the bean sprouts and cilantro. The rice was on the harder size, to ensure that it wouldn't get soggy from the sauce. The sauce on the bottom of the rice was a sweet soy sauce, that paired well mixed with the other components of the dish. The cucumbers on the side were a nice touch, and added a refreshing textural component to the meal. 
I was pleasantly surprised by the soup that the meal came with. It wasn't watered down, and tasted as if it had been brewed for hours. I couldn't quite pinpoint what it was, but it tasted delicious!"
"This is one of my favourite places for laksa. I've had the laksa here many many times and I still love it. Full of flavour, perfect spice, and they always give a generous amount of toppings.

I've had both the Chicken laksa and the seafood laksa and they are both equally good. I like that they use both the yellow noodle and the vermicelli noodle. Most other places just have the one kind."
"NOTE: Cafe D'Lite is cash only! They take U.S. currency, but they don't take the conversion into account. 

Aberdeen Centre has got to have the most to die for Asian food court I've ever encountered in my entire life. Heard about how amazing the Haianese chinese on rice here was in Vancouver at Cafe D'Lite and had to make my way to try their other dishes! 

Came here for the Haianese chicken but was so tempted by how amazing the Singaporean chicken laksa and beef curry looked, so we ended up getting those. The Singaporean laksa made my taste buds dance!! It was SO, SO delicious, and it was extremely filling. I'm a huge fan of curry, so anything with curry and coconut milk, I'm ALL over. They used 2 different types of noodles for the laksa, one thicker and one that was similar to vermicelli. It added different textures to the dish and made it very unique and tasty. The chicken was well-cooked and tender, and the soup was a great consistency as well. 

If you're in Vancouver looking for Singaporean/Malaysian food or just a plethora of choices, definitely check out Aberdeen Centre's food court on the 3rd floor. MINDBLOWINGLY GOOD!"
"This place has the best Hainanese chicken in town! So reasonable with side of rice and soup!

Typical Asian service in food court, don't expect a smile."
"Ever since I moved into the hood, Hawkers' has become that dont-feel-like-cooking (who-are-we-kidding-I-can't-cook) alternative to greasy pizza/mac and cheese sort of laziness.

Sure it's a hole in the wall. Sure the menus are printed out on paper and taped up haphazardly. Sure sometimes I can't really decipher what kind of meat i'm eating... Call me crazy but I find the whole stack of broken crock pots in the hallway, dingy plastic cups and order, eat & get the hell out sort of atmosphere almost charming... 

Now I do admit, I haven't been too adventurous at this little greasy spoon. In fact, after snooping Ellen L's review of the fried goodness that is the Kuey Teow (which, god love me, I still can't pronounce properly) I haven't strayed much further. It's hot, spicy, plentiful and occasionally I recognize shrimp - and for a whopping $5.30 for a meal the size of my head, i'm not expecting fine dining. At that price, i'm looking for eat-in-my-pjs and hang out with a movie sort of lazy comfort food and Hawkers delivers.

I usually grab a veggie fritter or two to munch on the walk home. It comes with a fancy little to-go sauce but I haven't yet mastered the walk and dip so I can't clue you in to its merits.

Not a place to bring the folks but if you're looking for a fast dinner (and in my case, also a second day breakfast) - Hawkers is a decently-good/totally satisfying call.

As many a Yelper before has mentioned - it's cash only so hit the bank across the street before you venture in!"
"=== 1. VERDICT/VALUE
Some tastes of Singapore come to Main Street in Vancouver at a reasonable price - and that's a good thing!

=== 2. FOOD
If you've eaten Hainanese chicken at a ""hawka centa"" in Singapore, you'll know how naturally (or unnaturally?) addicting it can be - seemingly healthy (not fried) chicken that's boneless and tastes amazingly good on its own or with rice.  So it's with high expectations that we ventured to try out Hawkers Delight Deli...

Hainanese Chicken Rice ($10.99): a chicken leg on rice with cucumbers and a tomato slice.  HDD gets points for offering boneless chicken (some places in town do bone-in instead), a decent flavour for the chicken, and the tomato is a nice touch I suppose (not commonly offered).  But it loses points for coarse chopping (tomato is a thick slice, cucumbers are big chunks that are harder to eat vs. everyone else offering thin, easy-to-eat slices) and rice that's flavoured but hard - sitting in the rice cooker too long perhaps?  Only the sweet chili sauce is offered; the sweet soy sauce typically included is not offered by HDD.

The extra leg of Hainanese chicken can be ordered for $6.65 and it's identical, sans rice and some cucumber.

=== 3. SERVICE & ENVIRONMENT
During COVID, there is not a place to dine-in, though it looks like bar-style seating was available at one point in time.  Those with wheelchairs or baby strollers have plenty of space.  The dim, hole-in-the-wall feel allows you to order essentially at a window inside and head out to enjoy your bounty.  Service was fine for quick and efficient takeout, but they accept only cash.  Parking is a challenge with Main Street typically busy at the meters out front and only one spot in the back, so be prepared to walk some ways to get here!"
I've been meaning to try this place out for years with their large vegetarian selection, but they appear to have somewhat unstable hours. Having visited Singapore and fallen in love with the food there, I was excited to try Hawker food in Vancouver -- does it live up? Well, it's not really what I experienced in Singapore, but the food is delicious. Everything we ordered was super flavourful, pleasantly spicy, and balanced well. The Mee Goreng was probably the highlight for us, but it was all excellent. Everything was ready for pick-up in 15 minutes. Cash only, so be prepared. Highly recommended
Great food, great prices, and friendly staff. I've been here once before for dine in (pre-covid) and again for take out. Both times I was very satisfied with my meals. This time around, I ordered mee pok with the broad wheat noodles. It had a minced pork sauce that needed to be mixed with the noodles. As well, it had fish cakes, thin slices of pork, prawns, and some vegetables. It was quite tasty. I asked for it spicy and it came with some pickled jalapenos...making it a bit too spicy, but it was still good. I liked the thick noodles and the sauce was not too salty. Overall, it was a satisfying dish and very affordable.
"Hawkers have been my go to place for comfort food at fantastic prices. Been coming to their little gem for many, many years. Sometimes it's a miss but many times it's a hit. You come for the food and eat & go. The place it tiny. Glad they are open during this time for take out. 

Had Mee Goreng (choice of spicy or non-spicy): fried wheat noodles with egg, bean sprout, onion, tomatoes, tofu, diced potatoes and yu choy. 

Lamb Curry Rice: steamed rice with small chunks of lamb and vegetables curry. This is probably their signature dish and the one I order the most. A little but not screaming hot spicy.  

Both dishes were delicious and the portions were generous. After 2 servings each there was still leftover for tomorrow. Dinner total for two was $25 not including tax and tip."
Awesome and very inexpensive hole in the wall, but cash only.   This is during COVID so take out only but hey given the limitations this place is the bomb.  The Laksa flavors were out of this world.  Soto Ayam is a really good gem, it's like rice paste, hard to describe, like really thick rice noodles with choy sum, fish cake, flavoring.  Mee goreng is decent.  I love the tofu stuffed with peanut sauce and veggies.  The curry chicken is not bad too.  Would definitely go back. The only problem is they forgot a hainanese chicken but I called them and they said they would give me one free next time.
"Take out heaven @ Hawker's Delight. I think there are 17 options for you. Pictures left right and centre with variations with different types of noodles to choose from for certain dishes. If you haven't been here, even their relative small selection can drive you bonkers. 

Plates that get taken out starts to make your mouth water and you wonder if you should order that instead. I asked the lady in the front what was popular and she told me the Mee Goreng.. which I believe that it is a stir fry saucy noodle essentially.. another thing was the thick dry noodle bowl (COMBO 5a), which is similar to the dry noodles at Phnom Pehn.... I couldn't help it I was sold looking at the variety of items on the dish  - pork sauce, veggies, fish cake, bean sprouts etc etc.
I convinced my lady Cyndi to get the Laksa as she wanted curry.

I was sooooo happy with my selection.. this dish was soooo greasy, saucy, and savoury. With each bite, I was piling the meat sauce on top to make sure I get the most of everything. The thick noodles were awesome texture and the toppings seemed endless. Unfortunately, Cyndi didn't like her Laksa too much - she thought it was too spicy, although I thought it was very rich flavours. For a super hot day, I couldn't take the curry but i would still recommend it because I thought it was great.

I think each dish was $5.25.... You can easily share if you were not super hungry... but this was too good. I want my own portion to myself.. not matter how un-hungry I am!"
Uber Eats. I got chicken curry noodle. Portion is on the smaller side. Taste was ok. Roti was good. Typical size.
"I spent a summer in Singapore a few years ago, and my mouth still drools at the memory of the food I discovered at hawker centres across the city (country? I never know which word to use when). I've tried the Singaporean staples at restaurants in Seattle, and while the food has been pretty decent the price point has been proof that this is a westernised version of the food. 

Then I came here. Everything is under $10, spicy, flavourful, and just how it should be. The decor is minima and the place is always packed to the brim. Again, how it should be. The roti-prata is soft, flaky, and delicious. Both the mee goreng and laksa are pretty good too. My boyfriend (also very familiar with Singaporean food) was quite disappointed with the chicken curry because the curry powder used in it wasn't great. But stick with the rest of the menu and you'll have a blast."
This has got to easily be the best gem in town for Malaysian cuisine. small, petite store tucked away on Main and King Edward Ave. Prices are very reasonable. and portions are generous. Only issue is that when it gets busy. it is very difficult to get a table. During off hours though, lots of space to sit down and enjoy your meal. Recommended absolutely. Food comes quickly and is very delicious! Any local who is looking for Malay food has got to come and try this place. Any visitor to town has definitely got to try this place out for sure.
"This update is really just to add my collection of pictures from Ipoh Bean Sprout Chicken in Crystal Mall. Now I haven't been to Crystal Mall since pre-covid so I'm not 100% which stalls are still opened.. but I'm hoping this one still is, as it is one of my favourites.

As you can see from my pictures, I've had their Chicken Laksa numerous times (each picture is a separate visit). I love noodle lifting their laksa as they give a generous amount of noodles, and a mix of the yellow noodle and vermicelli noodle. I know a lot of different laksa spots that don't have that combination, and only one kind of noodle.

I absolutely love the broth. And as mentioned in my previous review, it's the perfect amount of flavour and spiciness. And there is a good portion of quality chicken. May be awhile before I go back to Crystal Mall, but certainly give them a try if you're there!"
"The Crystall Mall Food Court in Burnaby is full of food stands serving primarily Chinese cuisine. What I like about this food court is that you can find different regional Chinese fare here and the prices are very reasonable.

Ipoh Bean Sprout Chicken is the Malaysian food stand at the food court. After a filling breakfast at a HK cafe, I was looking for a lighter meal and thought Malaysian Chinese fare would be a good option. Meal prices at this stand were good. It seemed like many items were under $8. I decided to give the Ipoh fried hor fun ($7.25) a try.

Since this is a food court, you will need to find a open table which can be a challenge. It is best to bring someone with you when visiting the the food court here to stake a table while the other person orders and waits for the food.

After my meal was ready, I grabbed it and found a table. Upon opening the box, plenty of steam poured out telling me that the noodles were fresh off the wok. Hor fun is a rice noodle dish that is essentially like Chinese chow funn. I haven't had Ipoh fried hor fun before, but it seemed like the difference from the Chinese version is the use of shrimp.

The hor fun was good. I noticed the addition of pork in this dish. Not sure if this is traditional, but it is nice to have a second source of protein. The shrimp were not as fresh as in Malaysia, but fine given the low price point of the dish. As for the rice noodles, I thought they were my favorite thing in this dish. The noodles were fresh and the ""wok hee"" comes through.

There are so many good places at Crystal Mall Food Court that it can be difficult to choose. But if you are looking for a filling meal that is not too heavy, I would recommend the hor fun at this stand."
This place is a hidden jam. The Singaporean restaurant is small but very clean and tidy. Service was pretty friendly and efficient. But most importantly the food was so good! The HA fried rice was flavorful and the charred pork chop was so juicy. As for the Hainanese chicken rice, I think it's the rice that sets it apart from the competition. I recommend both dishes. Apparently their laksa is one of their signature dishes too but I'm not a laksa person. However my wife thinks their laksa is amongst the top 1-2 she's had in Vancouver.
"This restaurant used to be Queen's Cafe but is now taken over by the Singaporean restaurant chain Eighteen Chefs. However the name of the restaurant now seems to be Queen's Cafe by Eighteen Chefs. Anyways it is on the corner of Kingsway and Salisbury.

There is an interesting variety of dishes with interesting names such as Heart Attack Rice. I don't know if it is on soft opening as it has only opened very recently.

We had three items: Salty Egg Yolk Fries (!), Chicken Skewer with Truffle Udon (!) and Heart Attack Rice with Tenderloin (!). All three dishes were delicious and there are many other dishes I want to try.

I will say that there was quite a wait for the food (close to 45 minutes) but we talked to one of the staff who said they were still hiring staff. I hope that part improves."
"Pretty nice food and comfortable environment.
Even though my dessert came very late but still good food."
"Saw this on Yelp and wanted to try, the original Queen's Cafe is now by Eighteen Chefs, as Eighteen Chefs a Singaporean franchise, I think they may have some connection, anyhow, my curiosity brought me here!

The menu, as I agree with some fellow Yelpers, is pretty limited as it tries to cater to different tastes but at the same time do not offer too many choices if you are wanting to have a more Singapore flavoured dinner. I am hoping that they will expand their choices as time goes ( such as Char Kway Teow, Sambal Eggplant, Spicy Kangkong etc. )

On our first try, we decided to have one dish representing Singapore and one Hong Kong!

Singapore Laksa : 5/5 
The soup is perfectly spiced and very well balanced, you can taste the fried dried shrimp with chilli in the stock, the richness of coconut milk and other spices came together harmoniously, even thought it looks deadly spicy, in fact you can find yourself enjoying the soup to the last drop and not overpowered by the spice.

Baked Pork Chop in Tomato Sauce with Fried Rice : 4/5
The Chef here take special care in the preparation of the pork chop to make sure it has proper marination, you can taste a hint of garlic in the chop, the crust is still crispy when it came out piping hot from the oven, one thing in my own opinion, the tomato sauce can be a bit more tangy to give the dish a kick!  Otherwise, this is as good as it gets, even from a Hong Kong standard!

Service is very friendly and efficient, with partial re-opening, the spacings of the tables are still very wide apart, utensils are presented to you in individual baskets for extra hygienic concerns.  Our server Jacky, is super nice in making sure our meals are alright and also showed us their Special lunch menu, each selection comes with a soup and a drink.

For sure, I will be back to try out other dishes, humm, maybe Curry Beef next time?"
"Quite good.  There's few good options for singaporean food in this area, so this is a welcome addition.  Lots of spacing between tables as per covid guidelines.  Understaffed and so a lot of running around by the available staff.  This might be a family-run business, even though I understand that Eighteen Chefs is a franchise. 

They aim to put some theatrical drama in the food, with the hanging metal BBQ grill and striploin on a cutting board presentation.  

Prices are reasonable for the quantity and quality.  The interesting comparison is between Shiok and here, where Shiok tends to have lower prices but much smaller portion sizes.  

Small quibbles:

We were a bit surprised that the Hainan Chicken rice had bones in it.  Basically, it's a chopped chicken leg.  Usually, Hainan chicken rice in singapore style is boneless.  

Laksa was decent, but it didn't have two types of noodles, but only the thicker rice noodle.

The curry and roti was excellent.  Must order more roti next time.

The advertised combo (laksa + kaya toast) on the poster and A-board is only available 3-5pm."
"This restaurant offers fusion Singaporean food. The menu was a bit deceiving for starters. The nasi lemak only included one protein (chicken, fish or pork), but the photo shows two items. I would have expected two protein choices until the server clarified that it was only one choice. 

We tried a number of items. The laksa had an aromatic spicy curry broth. Mild spicy was actually Asian level spicy. There was a good variety of toppings. I prefer the wheat and vermicelli noodle mix, but this version only had vermicelli noodles. The salted egg yolk fries were a tad too salty. It was good that the dip was on the side. The fries were over seasoned to pair with the egg yolk dip. If the chef lightened the salt on the fries, it would be better balanced. Egg yolk dip was good and tasted as expected for those familiar with the flavour. The HA fried rice with striploin and spring chicken was good. The beef was a bit over cooked for medium. It arrived well done and I can overlook this because this is not a steak house. The chicken was moist. The fried rice tasted like soy sauce rice.

Service was very good. Our water glasses were never empty. There is free parking behind the restaurant or metered street parking. Credit card payment accepted which is always great."
"Came here after they renovated.   Apparently it is new ownership but has same name.  It is now a Singaporean style food, before it was Cantonese style. 

I ordered the skewer beef with truffle rice.  It was really good.  The beef was tender and lots of flavor.  They hang the skewer up so that its drippings fall onto the dish below.  The truffle rice was good as the truffle oil gives it a nice hint of flavor to the fried rice.  I would order it again.   My girlfriend ordered the curry chicken with roti.  The curry was spicy and rich.  We were about to order more roti to go with the curry or even thought of getting a bowl of rice as there was ample amount of curry sauce.

Super friendly and amazing service at a pretty convenient area. Walkable to street parking, bus stops, and Edmonds skytrain station. Clean restaurant and restrooms. Simple design and decorations but spacious. A few different options for food and drinks but no alcohol beverages at the moment. Although, they are getting their alcohol license soon. Food is delicious and the portion is just right. Reasonable prices and you can either take out or eat in. Walk ins are welcome but reservation is allowed too. Have to call a day before to preorder the crabs since they go to the market the morning before that so they are fresh. Good quality and amazing time each visits. Highly recommend!!
Very clean restaurant which makes me feel safe to venture out during Covid. Delivery also available but glad I got a chance to dine in! Being from Singapore, I felt their roti prata texture was on point and neatly cut into shareable pieces. Curry was super tasty though on the sweeter side to appeal to fusion palette. Would also highly recommend their chicken skewer and truffle rice - delicious with great umami flavour! It is on the saltier side so you can request it with less salt if u prefer. We loved the mee siam - just add them to add more lime so it has more of that tanginess! We also had the luxury of ordering the salted egg yolk pasta with huge generous serving of prawns and fish roe! Such a huge portion we couldn't finish (but we were distracted gulping down the roti prata sauce). The salted egg yolk flavours as that's super hard to find in Vancouver and this one is so reasonably priced. Laksa portions and noodles were so huge we could barely finish - included hefty portion of noodles and authentic fried tofu though felt the soup base needed more coconut, spice and dry shrimp. I haven't tried their hainanese chicken yet but can recommend all the above heartily. Excellent homely and respectful service and widely distanced environment to safely catch up with friends after months apart!. Would highly recommend you give this family local business a try as prices are reasonable for service, unique flavours and portions!

"The corner of Kingsway and Salisbury in Burnaby seems like the perpetual Bermuda Triangle for restaurants... it never seems like any restaurant can make a go of it in this location.

Previously Queen's Cafe, and after many lengthy delays, the latest restaurant to grace this property opened up calling themselves Queen's Cafe by Eighteen Chefs (Eighteen Chefs being a popular Signaporean chain). I visited in early December when I tried their Hainanese Chicken Rice ($16.80) which comes with bone-in chicken, soup, and rice. While the soup was quite bland, the rice was moist and flavourful (although a bit too salty due to the soy sauce). I also found there wasn't much meat as it was mainly bones.

On my next visit, I decided to try their Chicken Skewer with Truffle Udon Noodles ($11.80). They told me it takes about 15 minutes to prepare because it's all made fresh. To be honest, this was surprising good... although it was a bit difficult to eat given the way it was presented. The chicken had a good char on it but the meat was still tender. Meanwhile, the noodles were tender and toothsome with a good chew. The only bad thing I have to say about this dish is that it was a bit too oily and, again, too salty.

By my third visit, I began to notice that the service seems a bit awkward... that's not to say that the server wasn't friendly... it's just that her whole demeanor and presence was just a bit off. Anyhoo, I ordered the Mee Siam ($12.80) and found it to be quite spicy. The bowl of rice vermicelli comes with tofu puffs, 2 shrimp, and an egg. Seriously... this dish is not for the faint of heart as you'll feel the heat from the full-bodied soup.

The last dish that I tried here was the HA Fried Rice with Spring Chicken ($15.80) which comes with garlic chili sauce - I think ""HA"" is supposed to stand for ""Heart Attack"". The chicken had nice crispy skin, which I think was the best part. Oddly enough, I found the fried rice (which seemed more like sticky rice) was kind of weak and plain.

Overall, I found the menu to be fairly limited but some items (such as the chicken skewer with truffle udon noodles) were pretty good. Still, prices seem a little bit high for the quality."
"I can't answer if this is authentic Singaporean or if it's famous chain by Eighteen Chefs, but their business card does mention Eighteen Chefs corporation. Anyways, this was my first visit after a new ownership and the decor has definitely changed into a better appearance.

I love both Singaporean food and HK Cafe food so dining at Queen's Cafe was a great decision, and also gave me some difficulty choosing what to eat. We ordered Laksa ($12.80) and Beef Bolognese Rice ($14.80) it came out fresh in hearty portion. 

If you can handle any spicy food (Thai or any Korean food) Laksa is good and it was spicy. Fish sauce smelled too strong when my Laksa came out. My nose felt runny and I was sweat non stop when the heat kicked in. Loved the sweet coconut milk along with curry, lemongrass and other spices. I sipped so much soup off the bowl. Noodles were damn good. Probably same type of noodle when I order BunBoHue in Viet restaurants.

Beef Bolognese Rice was quite yummy too. It was beefy cheesy making my mouth water. Tasty even with rice instead of Pasta. Social distancing rules are followed and staff was wearing mask.

You won't regret as QC is quite impressive. 50 cents charge is applied for a take out orders I believe. Weekday lunch specials and combo meal deals sounded decent. Their Laksa might be TOO spicy for some folks. QC, you deserve 5 stars from me."
"This location has changed restaurants several time and the latest is worth a try. It's clean, spacious and bright.

Came with a couple of friends and wanted to everything but not advisable. Singaporean food to me is too good to only have one dish to yourself so I made sure I tried what my friends ordered as well. 

In order the laksa with seafood and it's really tough to beat Laksa King, however this one was very close. The soup..first taste was rich and super intense flavour (yeah a bit dramatic, but true), was so good. Noodles are not the normal style egg noodles, but spaghetti type rice noodles, was good as well, not overcooked. This also had a whole egg, bean sprouts, tofu puffs, shrimp and more..can't remember as I think I just ingested it so quickly.

Curry chicken with roti. The curry was also rich and flavour intense, the chicken was cooked nicely and I couldn't stop spooning it up like soup. It was very good. The roti was nicely fried, but the dish was missing rice so we order a side of rice and it made that dish complete. 

Baked unagi on rice. Probably the least favorite of the three. I'm not a big unagi fan to start with, the flavor was good but the rice was hard.

Salted yolk fries: fries were deep fried nicely..reminded me of frozen McCains..nothing wrong with that..but when dipped into the salted yolk...that added something I've never tasted before, very different and it is an acquired taste..I would order it again. 

The service was good, it wasn't too busy so great for us. Price is reasonable and great for a family dinner. 

I am naturally nosy and look around at other people's food...everything looked just as good and will be back to try more"
Wanted to try Malaysian from a long time. When we saw this place in Vancouver, we decided to give it a try. Good place with good enough food. Roti kanai, eggplant fries, Assam curry was good and more like a Thai affair.
"Excellent food and service.  The roti canai was amazing!  Also really loved the iced Malay tea with condensed milk-- wow.

I'm coming back!"
"We came back here a few nights later to get only dessert - I was really craving sticky rice with mango.  Their sticky rice is not like what is served in the US.  it was pretty thick and SUPER sticky and chewy.  I enjoyed it, even though it was different from the usual!  

We also ordered the fried banana sundae AND the durian with black rice tapioca (yes, we're fatties).  The durian flavor was not AS pungent as usual, I think bc it came out frozen.  Although next time I think I would pass on the black rice tapioca... it was a little too soupy and the texture of the rice not that appealing to me.  We still ate a majority of it though ;)"

I think I just fell in love with this place."

"I cannot imagine how anyone could not give this place a five star rating, at least based on the food. I found it by chance when I was visiting BC, and I just liked the name. Upon further investigation, I found the menu made me salivate, and once I went inside and tasted their food, I was a goner. It is now the first restaurant I visit when traveling to Vancouver.
I have never been disappointed with anything on the menu. This last visit, my friend had the Rendang Beef Curry, and I had the Halibut, which is not currently on their online menu. My friend said she woke up the next morning fantasizing about the taste of the beef curry in her mouth, tender and savory. Me, I was happy with my halibut, but forced to eat anything on their menu, I would be in heaven.
Apparently there are other locations, and I have only tried this one, but it is a keeper!"
"Been walking up and down Davie Street past this place since moving to the vicinity last Autumn; tonight I stopped to peruse the menu they've posted in the front window and quickly decided to give it a go. I'm glad I did, this place serves terrific food. I started with a mango slush drink made with good quality ripe mango puree and juice and wasn't overly sugary. It came with what at first I thought was a maraschino cherry, but was in fact a cranberry--somebody put some thought into that detail; the tart cranberry was a much better accent to the sweet mango than a cherry would've been. Next I had a satay chicken and pork appetiser. The meats were perfectly cooked and remarkably tender, the cucumber cubes were cool and fresh, and the satay sauce was a nice balance of sweet, piquant, and peanutty. 

The Saturday special prawn dish was tempting, but I went for the lamb shank. I do not order lamb shank carelessly; it was my (late) father's favourite, and so eating lamb shank makes me think of him, and so an indifferently or thoughtlessly prepared one (or just a plain bad one) would be an especially unpleasant experience. This one was fantastic--the meat had been braised in a complex and yummy mix prominently featuring star anise, which complemented and augmented the lamb's flavour. It was lean and fall-off-the-bone tender. Really nicely done! Accompaniments were perfectly-cooked, perfectly-textured rice, just slightly sticky as it should be, and a dark green leafy vegetable, cooked correctly (not overdone), which was probably a relative of spinach. 

I hadn't any room for dessert; the mango slush served that role admirably. 

This is not inexpensive food; it's priced beyond everyday drop-in levels, but for the quality and quantity, the prices are well within the reasonsphere especially for this part of town which tends to be pricy. I have seen and had the displeasure (at other restaurants) of paying much more money for much less enjoyable food. Service at Banana Leaf is friendly, attentive, prompt, and unobtrusive. When I entered the restaurant, it was lit only by table candles. A sign (and the greeter, who was also my waiter) explained that in observance of Earth Hour, the electric lights and the stereo had been switched off. That was fine, and the atmosphere was quite enjoyable. Everyone was having conversation without having to raise voices above the stereo. Not long after I arrove, I guess Earth Hour was over; the lights and stereo were gradually raised. Too much, the latter; the music was loud enough to make it difficult for me to focus on my delicious food. I asked my waiter about it and he promptly and courteously turned it down to a more reasonable background level. So overall no complaint there.

I will definitely be back!"

Service was excellent also
Look forward to returning"
