"I am from Indonesia and I visited malaysia numerous times. So, I knew the food in and out. The food here were hit and miss. Some were really good but some were pretty blah. But since I really really love some of their menu, I am willing to give it 4 stars.

The service
It was a pretty small restaurant. We came here several times and everytime we got different servers. The first two times we got a pretty nice one. The third time we got a pretty rude caucasian girl. But the Asian server and some caucasians were pretty nice in our previous visit. Once you sit, they will take your menu and will recommend food for you. Pretty good

The food
We ordered so many foods that we were so full. I am going to let you know which one worth to try and which one is not:
- Gado-Gado: It was actually from Indonesia and It was not that bad. Kind of like it. 
- Mango Salad: taste plain. Nothing. do not waste your money on this one
- Roti Canai with Rendang Sauce: roti canai was pretty good. the rendang sauce was a bit too watery. It could be thicker. Worth to try if you never before
- Martabak filled with beef rendang and eggplant on the side: the martabak was pretty flavorful but the eggplant was not on the right taste. I would said if you really love martabak and beef, you should give it a try
- Chicken Satay: nothing to rave about, save your money and eat satay at some other restaurants that are better at it
- Malaysian Fried Rice: I would say it's a no no. The color of the food was tempting but the taste were pretty plain. Not impressed at all
- Nasi Lemak (coconut rice): beef rendang and chili came with it were great. The squid were pretty spicy as well. BUT !! the star of this food which is the coconut rice - failed so hard ! It was not good. I have tasted wayyyyyy too many great coconut rice.
- Hainanese chicken rice: YOU HAVE TO ORDER THIS ONE. the chicken were sooooooooooooooooo tender and sooo flavorful. The sauce accompanied the chicken were top notch. The rice smells so good and comes in perfection. Definitely give it a try
- Vegetable in curry broth: Forget about this one. NO curry taste. It's like vegetable in coconut sauce. They could go bold on the curry but they did not
- Singapore Laksa noodle: This one should be removed from the menu as it does not reflect singapore laksa at all. It;'s a big no no and dont try it
- black bean with durian paste: the blackbean was not sweet enough, the coconut sauce was not thick enough and the durian paste was not taste as strong as durian. Failed !!!!
- Mie Goreng Malaysian Style: this one was surprisingly not bad. pretty tasty and like it. You can give it a try
- Mango with sticky rice: arguably the worst mango with sticky rice that i have tried in my entire life. The sticky rice were so miserable. it's like a baseball and taste not good at all
- Kue dadar: my favorite indonesian dessert but they did a pretty bad job here. Not like it at all
- fried banana with vanilla ice cream: this one was pretty decent. the banana was sweet and the crispy part was not bad. Vanilla ice cream or course you cant go wrong with it

The atmosphere
It is good for lunch or dinner. If come with big group, reservation is a must since their restaurant was pretty small. But the decoration inside make you feel like you are in a small asian country having lunch or dinner. Good place to hang out and just chit chat with friend over lunch or dinner

The location
driving will get you into headache since parking will be extremely difficult. but the restaurant is not difficult to find at all !!!

Will I come back? 
YES ! just for the hainanese chicken rice ! Just that... and you can try other menu, but one thing that you should not try is the DESSERTS !!! you will just waste your money. In fact, i should write letter to the owner and ask them to remove the dessert menu since it's a big no no"
Before coming to Vancouver, we'd heard about all the great restaurants. Of all the restaurants we tried, we only went to one twice - Banana Leaf. At this location, we ordered the tofu appetizer. It tasted wonderful, the right combination of crispy shell and creamy soft middle. The stuffing was delicious as well. We both ordered a different seafood dish, Seafood Char Kuey Teow, and a shrimp and vegetable dish which I don't recognize on the menu now. Both were delicious. Oh, and all the cocktails are doubles - Mai Tais especially good. When we wanted a special dinner later in the week, there was no doubt where we would go. See the review for that visit under the Denman St. Location.

"Took SkyTrain to Yaletown station, then walked to the restaurant.

It has an attractive decor & includes a full service bar.  It has been a few years since I dined at their W. Broadway location so my memory of it may have faded a bit.  However, this location seems slightly more upscale.

The menu reflects the Chinese, Indian, & Malay influences on Malaysian cuisine 

We ordered...Fish Panggang in a Banana Leaf, Roti, Sambal Chili Okra & Mixed Vegetables, & rice.  Rice is extra.  The main dishes had fresh ingredients & plenty of spice.

I liked all the food although the fish seemed to have just a bit too much white pepper, & the Sambal a bit too much salt.  The portions were so generous we did not finish & took the leftovers home.  When we re-heated them at home we diluted the dishes with more veggies.  Even more delicious!

Our 2 women waitresses were attractive, friendly, & competent."
"Was here for lunch today. I usually try to make my way here about every two to four weeks when I'm craving South East Asian food that does not begin in Viet or Thai. This location has been here a few years, replacing Kam's Place, a Singaporean restaurant.

Anyway today I had the Pineapple Fried Rice Combo which consisted of Asian salad, pineapple seafood fried rice, satay chicken, and a spring roll for $12.99. Imho it's a great choice when you don't really know what to order. You get a little bit of everything! The highlight was definitely the fried rice. The pineapples and scallops really make your taste buds dance! The last time I ordered the fried rice on its own, it actually came in a pineapple! Easy 4 stars. I'll be back in the near future for sure."
Food was pretty decent. Prices seem generally in line with other Malaysian restaurants. Large groups of 6 or more are charged automatic 15% tip but beware since this is a manual calculation on the bill after it's printed. If they insist on an automatic tip of 15% it's expected that they do the calculation correctly & apply it on the pretax amount. What actually happened was the tip got charged on the food AND the tax. When told a mistake was made on the calculation the waitress brings it to the duty manager who explained it's their policy to calculate the 15% tip in that manner & claimed that no customers in the past have complained about it or brought this to their attn before at any of their locations altho he is not the one who made the policy. After a discussion that went almost 10 min the manager finally agreed to calculate it correctly. I had to be adamant that any restaurant charging a mandatory tip on tax was wrong. It's one thing to be overcharged but having to really press the point their practice was wrong & insisting the math be done correctly ruined a nice dining experience or else this review would have been 4 stars.
"I really like Banana Leaf and their menu. It is full of Malay spices and the culinary influences are out of this world.

The pineapple/seafood fried rice are a nice addition. Make sure you get the vegetable spring rolls. Amazing.

The service here is pretty good. It's not the best in the city, they are moderately attentive.....I can deal with it.

"Short Version: Great food with a strong cultural presence, reasonably good service. Highly recommended, especially if you aren't experienced with Malaysian cuisine.

Long Version: This was one of those places we stopped in while wandering the streets, just because it looked well put together. My wife and I ordered rendang beef and I believe some sort of grilled oyster. The beef was served in the most incredible coconut sauce, and was so flavorful and tender that we were able to savor each piece long enough to definitely get our money's worth.

Service was reasonable, but a bit slower than I would have liked. We ordered some specialty drinks (they were fine, but I don't think any of the beverages are worth getting excited about), and didn't get water. It took a very long time to get that water after we asked for it. After eating we had to wonder if we still had a server, as no one volunteered to bring a check. The food more than made up for it, and I still highly recommend this place- just realize that it isn't somewhere to stop in if you're in a hurry.

As a said note, after getting back home I tried my hand at making my own rendang beef, which will need quite a bit of practice on my part. But I always have a special place for restaurants that can inspire me to try figuring out a new flavor in the kitchen. I hope we have the opportunity to try the other items on their menu someday."

"Banana Leaf on Davie (馬來餐廳的午市特價餐) 
個人推介：午市特價餐供應時間11:30am-3pm

Banana Leaf蕉葉屋在溫哥華的馬來西亞餐廳裡算得上是首屈一指，現今已開有5家分店，到過溫哥華旅遊的馬來華僑，都很難相信溫哥華有如此地道的馬來菜館。向來少做宣傳的店家，生意來源大部分都是靠食客的口碑。其實很多備受大家喜愛的馬來菜色都是源自印尼、泰國、印度、中國和葡萄牙等美食演變而成的fusion菜，例如美味的南洋乾咖哩牛肉(Rendang Beef)是源自印尼的，各種咖喱食物是改良自印度，著名的娘惹菜不就是混合了中國菜的原素嗎？但這亦是馬來菜色吸引大眾味蕾之處！

走進餐廳大門後首先會見到餐廳多年來所獲的飲食獎項，獎牌的數量可不少啊！餐廳採用鮮艷的顏色對比和牆飾，加上陳列著不少各式各樣的民族木雕擺設，充滿著濃厚的東南亞風情，餐廳在裝潢和設計上也算是挖空了心思，好讓顧客能在繁忙的市區中心帶來一點熱帶情調。特別一提是這家位於溫哥華市中心Davie街的分店口碑跟生意都非常好，建議想到這裡去品嚐南洋美食的朋友要提前訂位喔！

Sayur Lemak + Spring Roll Lunch Special $7.99 (3/5分)
椰漿菜(sayur lemak)是一道樸素的馬來風味素菜，味道清甜帶有濃濃的椰漿味，特別下飯

Big Lunch Combo Lunch Special $7.99 (4/5分)
這份午市特價餐包括蔬菜沙律, rending beef, roti canai和黃薑飯，可謂十分抵食"

Banana Leaf is a really good pan-Asian restaurant with over five locations in Vancouver. We ordered the Laska (curry seafood rice noodle) and Hainan Chicken with a side of Hainan Rice (rice mixed with the essence of the Hainan chicken). The Hainan chicken was boneless and served with 3 sauces: ginger & oil, sweet & sour, and hoisen with soya sauce. My favorite with chicken is always the ginger & oil, but the other options provides interesting flavor.  They also have really good happy hour specials for drinks. Happy hour here last till 10 on certain days, which is great! For dessert, we had the durian ice cream. There are 4 other durian flavor desserts here! Durian lovers will get their craving fixed here. The ambiance was cozy and convenience, on top of great service, good food, and affordable prices, hence the 5 stars.
Best happy hour AND late night menu AND daily specials in town. I go here at least once a week!
Food used to be really tasty, this time the food wasn't too fresh, and seemed overcooked
I really enjoy eating here. The service was good and the food, especially the Migoreng was really nice. Little expensive, but not so much.
"Be aware that this place bribes reviewers by offering discount coupons for future meals, so I suggest removing a star right there. We came inside and I felt I was in a sauna.  Not because it was particularly warm, but there was a wet musty wood smell to the place.  This maybe due to being there just after the rainy season-November to May in Vancouver, I'm told-had ended. There were definitely some stern signs about how to deal with a wet umbrella by the door but this restaurant was alone in the musty smell category. 

I ordered the salad wrap, unfortunately without discussing my gluten free status with the server, a handsome and helpful fellow. My companion ordered the Kung Pow chicken and seemed happy enough with it. It was a special for the day we were there. Although salad wraps are usually reliable choices for gluten-free eating, unfortunately the filling for the salad wraps came to the table in an edible wheat based salad bowl. As I've indicated I blame myself for that. If I had spoken to the server first, this could have all been avoided.
So I ate it anyway avoiding the wheat basket as best I could. It was okay. I had a lovely green tea and a tiny smidgen of dessert. They were each $3 and I would come by in late afternoon again just for these two. The dessert was was jelled but creamy and tasty without being cloyingly sweet like so many
Asian desserts are. It had a delicious mango sauce that was full of flavour. And it was gluten-free."
"Food is average, service should be better. As someone who can't tolerate spicy food, the lunch menu had only two opinions without a chili pepper- the hainan chicken and the pineapple rice combo.

The hainan chicken was disappointing. The chicken was overwhelmingly fat and the soup tasted like instant noodle soup. The sauces were good. 

The pineapple rice combo was delicious. I enjoyed the dish. It came with a chicken skewer, pineapple fried rice, calamari, small salad. This is something I would order again. 

In terms of service, I find the servers were rushing our table to leave as soon as we finished eating. I understand that it is lunch hour, but you shouldn't be taking plates away 10 seconds after. And you shouldn't be handing the cheque to our table when we didn't even ask for it yet. If you want to enjoy your food without rush, go before or after the lunch rush."
Can't go wrong with Hainan chicken and rice. I'd recommend in a heartbeat.

I actually enjoyed my meal this time. The place was not very busy but sometimes that's a good thing. I ordered the kung pao chicken alongside some jasmine rice, and my partner got the boneless curry chicken. Both meals were done well and quite tasty. The staff was polite and it's fairly priced for the amount of food you get."

I also ordered the tofu goren , which was much larger than I expected as you can see in the photos it was beautifully presented. The sauce was slightly acidic slightly sweet and with the crushed peanuts on top and fresh vegetables,  really satisfying
David had the dish 10 vegetables 10 spaces that came with rice. This was not a typical curry type, in that it had much more depth and complexity of flavors, which made it very special. You kept trying to determine the spices as they were subtly blended together.

"One of the best meals we had in Vancouver.  Kid-friendly restaurant with baby plates.   Roti canai had a wonderful, sweet chewy aftertaste. 

I got the Hainan Chicken lunch special.  I was a little concerned when I read reviews saying that the Hainan chicken didn't come with rice, but my lunch special had chicken, rice and soup so I was a happy camper. I compare all Hainan Chicken to Savoy's version (LA restaurant) and usually places fall short.  However, Banana Leaf's was comparable, though its strength is not in its chicken or sauces but in the rice, which was incredibly flavorful: sticky with a nice firm density, garlicky, and tasting like chicken broth. Washed down the food with a refreshing calamansi with honey drink - first time having it and enjoyed it. 

My husband loved his Mee Goreng and is now on the hunt for an excellent rendition of Mee Goreng in the LA area.

Only thing was I went to the bathroom before the food arrived, and one of the toilets was really foul, like someone dropped a massive, splashy deuce and was too proud to flush.  Not the restaurant's fault, but it did taint my enjoyment of the food just a tiny bit."

What I tried here was the staple of fried tofu and a spring roll and something called Assam curry vegetable. All of it was good and reminiscent of neighboring countries' cuisine. I don't think anything blew me away but I know I've only scratched the surface. The service was slow and the place was packed. "Iced Calamansi and Honey $5

First and only drink as I've rest of dragon boat competition to finish tomorrow. Very refreshing, lightly sweet, and carbonation have given it more like light drink but my face was very red after finishing it!

The Tarek $4 Malaysian Black Milk Tea - hot or cold available was ordered to go as it was very cold outside, and get me better hydrated after alcoholic beverage. 

Atmosphere was very inviting, clean table and simple decoration with warm color choices. Light was dim and perfect to let me relax after a long fat competing. It was a moment of paradise after being rained on and shivering for nearly 12 hours and surviving off of peanut butter and jelly sandwiches snd protein shakes. 

Oh. My. Gosh. My tongue has tasted so many mingling ginger, spices, and sweetness - I never got tired of each bite! We got the 8 course meal for $25 and so glad we had a chance to taste so many dishes. They were so accommodating for a friend who cannot have gluten, and menu was readily available and modified. 

I was too busy taking note of each dishes, but every protein (sea food, meat, and veggies) were consumed which will fuel me efficiently for tomorrow's final race. My favorite was soft and moist calamari. It's always been too dry and oily for my taste, but this place changed my mind. And the peanut sauce and succulent chicken was eaten in somber silence as we could not talk. It was mutually agreed it was the best thing we've all tasted today.

Every vegetable cooked or raw was fresh, and lightly flavored so I could enjoy the delicate flavors. Fish and meat was little more heavily spiced but it was very tender and juicy. People of every dietary need and cultural background can congregate and leave satisfied, and frankly I would not mind returning here next day before six hour drive back to Portland - because I'll miss this place dearly. It'll be my annual to-go from now on."

"I lived in Singapore for 4 months and I'm half Singaporean, so I'm pretty sure I can say I know what Singaporean food should be like. Banana Leaf isn't authentic Singapore/Malaysian food, but the waiter did mention it was more of a fusion with Thai food.

Even after seeing the reviews, I wasn't ready for Banana Leaf. We dropped in to pick up a quick lunch  bite, and I have to say that we left with a memorable experience. Staff was polite and made some adjustments for us. I had the signature beef over rice, and it was incredible. My wife had the goreng rice with shrimp and it was also awesome. Great start to our Vancouver foodie tour.
Menu is varied, looks great, tastes even better. Portions are fresh, colorful, substantial, not over spiced, over salted, or overpriced. The roti bread is a must. The cod dish was fantastic. Only $12 for lunch and a large portion. Fresh veggies all around and they will sub out the meat if you don't want chicken in a dish. Music is great too. Nice mix of African, ambient, soundtracks, and totally unlike most restaurants where they either play rap or elevator music jazz. My only complaint is I asked for no chicken in my order and they served me the dish with chicken. As a vegetarian it can be distressing to bite into chicken when you don't expect it. Make sure you are very clear to the server that you don't want meat in your dish. This was quickly exchanged for a fresh plate.

"Yes, there is a sign that they offer a future discount for reviews, but if someone didn't like it, I suspect they wouldn't plan to return and, therefore, wouldn't care about a future discount. I don't live in Canada, so here's my unbiased review:
Roti: 5/5 The roti is served hot and nicely flakey. There's a slight sweetness to it, but the dipping sauce really makes it delicious!

Singapore Laksa: 4/5 Nice turmeric coconut milk-based soup with thin rice noodles. If I lived there, I would have saved the broth to make more dishes at home. It is not spicy.

Char Kuey Teow: 4/5 Wide rice noodles with a good ""wok-taste."" This dish does have a spicy kick to it.

"i was so stoked to learn that a banana leaf opened up on davie and burrard! i'm a big fan of the one in kits and it's awesome that there's one downtown now that's not in the west-end (don't get me wrong, the west-end is great, but just way too far, especially when it's raining).

the roti is probably my favourite appy. there's an appetizer tray that was like $16 for two people and it included the roti, calamari, spring rolls, and a papaya salad! great deal, and everything included was delicious.

as for dishes, my personal favourites are the beef rendang and the hainan chicken (with the hainan rice). the pineapple rice is pretty good too (and comes served in a pineapple shell). the mie goreng and nasi goreng aren't really authentic (as i lived in indonesia for nine years and visited malaysia frequently) but they're still alright.

i love their fruity alcoholic drinks too. i had the mango slush with vodka the last time i was there, and i've definitely had a lychee slushy concoction in the past as well.

this location has a nice, casual, and comfortable ambiance. our waiter was also pretty awesome the last time i was here, and i've never really had horrible service at any of the banana leafs."

"About a year ago I fell in love with Malaysian food when some friends and I went to Penang Delight. Rendang blewwwww my mind, and I was constantly craving it from that point on......like seriously it became a bit of a problem and if I didn't have self control I would have gone broke....... 

I'd always been meaning to go to Banana Leaf, just to try it out but Penang Delight was closer to home, and so that was my go-to Malaysian restaurant. As I now live downtown, I decided to give the Davie location a try. 

I had the roti canai to start, something which I love at Penang Delight. Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed with Banana Leaf's version. It just wasn't good at all. On the other hand the green papaya and mango kerabu was so delicious!!!!!!  Though I do keep in mind that at the same price, you can get the same type of salad at Kaya Malay, another Malaysian restaurant. To add to my meal, I obviously had the rendang beef curry, and the singapore laksa. At both Penang Delight and Kaya Malay the rendang isn't quite on the spicy side, however Banana Leaf's was. Since I'm not a fan of spicy food, it was a bit more difficult to actually enjoy, as I was trying to control the heat explosions in my mouth from both the rendang and laksa. Prices at Banana Leaf are also slightly higher than those at Penang Delight and Kaya Malay. 

Overall I wouldn't choose Banana Leaf over the two others I have mentioned, as I feel like I have gotten better value and satisfaction from primarily Penang Delight, and next in line, Kaya Malay. Though I have heard from my Malaysian sources that Hawker's Delight is the real deal- this coming from a Malaysian born friend of mine. Next time I'm craving, I know where I'm going!"

"Visiting Vancouver after a long sea voyage. Not my first time in this town so I was in the mood for exotic, but not typical asian food. Enter Banana Leaf, it was in a great location downtown near my hotel, I walked by about a dozen pretty happening gastropubs and eateries on my way to Banana Leaf but I was drawn by that yelp photo of their Mango & Sticky Rice. We ordered the 8 course pre-fix, only $25 Canadian bucks per person. What a spread!!! Of course I couldn't resist ordering Roti Canai as an appetizer.
1) Asian salad - papaya, pineapple, tomato, mango & spring lettuce (2) Fried Calamari that was so light and crispy, almost like tempura batter (3) asparagus with samba (sweet & spicy sauce) (4) seasoned rice (5) Beef curry (6) curry fish (7) satay chicken with peanut sauce (8) Mango chili tiger prawns and technically the 9th dish...sweetened coconut in a crepe. 
ALL of that for $25pp, unbelievable, and super delish!!

That was a little overkill, but if you are hungry and desire a taste of Maylasian fare that's the way to do it. 

And yes, I got the mango sticky rice to go, and it tasted just as good in my hotel room a few hours later. They also have fresh coconut juice served whole. I felt it was really authentic but I've never been to Malaysia, it was just yummy. I went on a Sunday night and the restaurant was at 80% capacity, no wait though."
"New review: went here for lunch with a few friends. My friends had the lunch specials while I had my favourite. The food was amazing and the service was better than last time! If they keep this up we will keep coming more and I recommend the lunch specials! Good for price and taste!! 


We always go here for dinner and late night food. This time around we were getting really bad service and the server forgot our drinks and never came by to check on us. My friend's food came 30 mins after ours which meant we were finished by the time he started his. Overall the food tasted the same I felt that what I usually order had been reduced in size. 3 stars just for the food."
"They are able to make most vegetarian dishes vegan!!
Eggplant and basil dish is very yummy :) 
Love the neighbourhood this restaurant is in."
Went in for a plate of Nasi Goreng and I was not disappointed. If I lived here I would probably be there weekly.
I would say this is a very good place. I usually give 5 stars or 1 star, so 3 stars is pretty good. I would even come back here. My only comment is that the tumeric rice was oily. But my fish was delish.
"Banana Leaf has been around for years though this is my first visit to this outlet. I usually go to the other outlets. 

I tried the Nasi campur which is an awesome way to try the various dishes. Most of the dishes were on point with some that could be better. 

Roti canai was crispy and fluffy, simply delicious with the curry dip given. 

The chicken satay was ok (not the same as in Malaysia/Singapore) but great with the peanut sauce. I would say the satay was more like what you get in Indonesia. 

What caught me by surprise was the gulai. It was so good. Creamy curry and flavorful. It was not as spicy as what you would get in Asia but the level of heat was perfect for me. 

Spring roll and eggplant fries were also nice. 

The Assam curry and beef rendang were ok. The beef could be more tender though. 

I also tried the pulot hitam (black glutinous rice) which was gorgeous. So good with the coconut cream. 

I will be back when I crave some singapore/Malaysia food."
"Came here about a month ago....

Food:
Gulai Seafood - incredible!  Although there was ample seafood and great flavor, I think the portion size could increase a bit.  Well done, though!

Satay chicken skewer - dried out and not a whole lot of flavor.  I didn't enjoy them as much as I had hoped I would.  Simply overcooked.

Service:
Awkward and strange.  Server was kind but quiet and not engaging.  Definitely made us shift in our seats.

I might return for the Gulai and something else."
We found this place on accident as it was right off a bus line.  We were pleasantly surprised and the food was amazing.  Great ambiance and good service
This was a new cusine for me and I really enjoyed it.  I thought the prices were in line with all the other restaurants we visited in Vancouver.  Really enjoyed the Mango rum drinks too.
Delicious food presented in a dynamic, unique way and in a gorgeous environment. We went for brunch but I'm looking forward to going back for dinner!
"Finally!  Despite living in Vancouver for decades and this restaurant's multiple locations, it took time away from Vancouver and a visit back home for me to have my first experience at Banana Leaf.  What an experience.  They had a great drink special the Wednesday night we went (Mai Tai singles for $4 and doubles for $6 - pretty great for the location we were at). ONE STAR

We ordered the following:

(1) Roti Canai / $7 
Flaky layered bread served with coconut curry sauce ~ one of India's great culinary contributions to Malaysia.

(2) Rendang Beef Curry / $15 
No festive occasion is complete without this rich Malaysian dish, boneless lean beef stewed to melting tenderness in coconut gravy and spices.

(3) Gulai Seafood / $20 
A taste of the ocean: scallop, prawn, fish, mussel, clam, and squid simmered in spicy turmeric coconut sauce made of tamarind, galangal, lemon grass & ginger.

Item (1) was our absolute favourite and I would have been happy with just that.  I find myself craving this appetizer even now back in Houston.

Items (2) and (3) were also delicious, but very spicy.  That turned out to our advantage because when we mentioned it to our waiter, he gave us some ice cream to cool our palettes - on the house!

Item (3) had generous portions of the listed seafood.

There were two of us and we had leftovers!  A great deal for the food, ambiance, service and quality level.  Can't wait to return!

This review is based on my personal experience and all statements made herein reflect my personal opinion only. Your experience may be completely different."

The roti is a must have, yummy warm bread to dip into a curry sauce.  Im still to find a main thats not too spicy for me as im a weakling when it comes to spicy food. The randag beef curry has amazing flavor but i wish there was some yogurt availble to cool it down! We also got calamri and the portion was HUGE !
Great food, excellent service. Both vegetarians and carnivores in our group had lots of great options and we all loved it.  But it seems kinda cheap to charge extra for rice when the entree pretty much demands it.

We ordered the pork ribs and beef skewers (not on happy hour) with a seafood noodle dish. Also ordered an iced coffee and it was great. Strong coffee, very sweet, great portion.

5 dollar pint of 1516 quenched me, while she had a glass of Pino, which was ice cold... so refreshing after a day of solemn financial markets!!

Who cares? I've got my succulent curry! My ice cold beer!  It's Friday evening, and what better place to take my date than BANANA LEAF!"

As for the curry dish, it was good in taste but not much ""Wow"" in my opinion. Overall, the dishes were simple and tasted like home cooking with no much effect in preparation. "More like three and a half stars, but there were some definite highlights.

Went for lunch the other day, and we ordered the Hainan chicken and the big lunch special along with a side of roti canai.

The roti canai was one of the best I've ever had here, and the curry dipping sauce was a perfect balance with great flavour, consistenty, texture and very slight heat.

The lunch special was beef rendang, rice, roti canai and a side salad.  All quite good, the beef was a tad dry, but it was also late in the lunch time slot.  The roti was same as the side, though a smaller portion.  A sizable lunch for a very good price ($8 if i recall correctly).

The Hainan chicken was presented with the three sauces as well as a soup and coconut rice.  It was very good, but I've had better hainanese chicken here.  Good size portion for very reasonable $11.

Decent beer and wine list with reasonable prices, very good service from our water.

Fruit flies were a significant issue, to the point where we had to stop eating to bat away at them and they were all over the food and our wine.  

Our waiter assured us that it was temporary and not usual and they weren't sure what caused the infestation.

I would eat there again - they have a tasting menu for lunch as well as dinner which would allow one to try a wide variety of dishes, but bring your appetite.  I found the lunch servings quite sizable."

"Tried the boneless curry chicken and instead of a side of rice, I went with an entree of rice -pineapple fried rice. "If this review was based on deliciousness of food alone, Banana Leaf would get a five-star rating from me for sure.

But let's start from the beginning. Having thoroughly researched all the restaurants participating in Vancouver's 2017 Dine Out Festival, I had noticed that Banana Leaf had quite the deal: 7 courses for $20 - papaya salad, calamari, chicken satay skewers, beef rendang, caramelized fish fillet, sambal green beans with rice, and panna cotta as dessert. 

Everything was absolutely delicious, and it's such a good deal for the price. My sister and I both ordered the Dine Out special, and the appetizers were served promptly afterwards. Here's where my issue lies. As soon as I bit into my chicken satay skewer, I saw that the inside of the meat was almost completely pink and quite visibly undercooked, borderline raw. So I called our server over and told her that I was concerned about the cook of my chicken. She took my plate and said she would check with the kitchen, but that the pink could just be because it was dark meat. I felt a little affronted at that comment, but she took my plate nonetheless. 

A few minutes later, she came back and apologized and yes indeed, it was undercooked, and said that the kitchen was making a new one. At this point, it would have been nice to see compensation of some sort, so I was a little disappointed with the service. 

Other than the chicken skewer incident, the rest of the food was absolutely delicious. So just based on taste, 5 stars, then minus one for the raw chicken, and minus one for no compensation. Hopefully next time I go back, the food will be just as delicious but a little more cooked through."

"We asked our hotel concierge about a good Asian restaurant in Vancouver and Banana Leaf was recommended among the many, many choices in the area. We were not sure what Malaysian was compared to other regions, but we found familiar items that we were interested in ordering. Nice comfortable ambiance with an upscale feel. Note, I did not see any indication about a ""bribe for a good review"" at this restaurant as others have mentioned but being a serious Yelper I could never consider or approve of such an offer. 

We ordered the Roti and it was delicious with the slightly spicy dipping sauce. If it had come out earlier than our entrees we would have filled up on this. Since prices were a little steep, I selected the special of the evening Kung Pao chicken. It was delicious, packed with peppers, peanuts, perfectly cooked chicken in a sweet and spicy sauce. My husband ordered mango prawns and enjoyed the prawns but felt the mango was not ripe enough. We were surprised that entrees do not come with rice so you have to separate. If we would have realized the size of the rice portion, we would have just ordered one to share. The server suggested the coconut rice for me and this was served in a banana leaf. Interesting but really not that much better than the regular jasmine rice my husband ordered. Overall a little pricey but nice meal."

Better than most Malaysian restaurants I've tried in California because there's very few there. "Oh, how I miss Malaysian food. 

Disclaimer: my parents are from Malaysia, and my relatives who live there make it a point to stuff me as full of food as humanly possible every time I visit.

I got the nasi lemak, my favorite food of all time and the national dish of Malaysia. And let me tell you, it was ON POINT. The sambal was nicely spicy with perfect fishy essence. Ikan bilis and rendang were fantastic; so rich and hearty. The shrimp and fish curry were a nice touch as well, both very good. And the cherry on top was fried calamari rings with a savory sweet sauce! And best of all, the coconut rice had just enough pandan flavor and wasn't too heavy or sticky--perfect! Flavors were authentic. The only gripes I have is that I wish there was a whole hard boiled egg--they only gave half. But I digress. Everywhere else I've tried so far in WA has been lacking in authenticity.

I drove up here from Tacoma, WA just to eat. 
And next time, I'm bringing mom&dad. 5 STARS"
"Gulai seafood pasta from Banana Leaf.
I am so happy my co worker recommended this place to me, it was amazing! 
First off the service was great and the atmosphere was relaxed but kind of romantic and beautiful. I ordered one of their lunch specials, of which there were a lot to choose from, and received a much larger portion than i would have expected. 
The flavour was everything I had hoped it would be! Complex, creamy but refreshing and not at all heavy. There was so much seafood in this and it was all perfectly cooked. 
I also got their Monday drink special which was a Bourbon Smash because I've never had one before.

Overall I would definitely recommend this place to every one especially if you are vegetarian as they had a huge amount of plant based menu items and for the price you can not go wrong!"
"Everything we ordered here was excellent. I love Malaysian food and don't have any near to where I live. "Our last foodie stop before leaving Van City, so I had to get some more Malaysian food in my belly! Banana leaf has several locations quite close to each other, but since we were in the area, we came in to this location. We were the first guests since we came in right after the opening time, so the service was prompt and the food was brought to us very very fast. 
We got some drinks to start off, the Virgin Lychee Mojito was alright, a bit too slushy/icy; the Calamansi Caipirinha was better, enough alcohol and plenty of flavor, very refreshing. 
We got beef rendand, which was great, jsut watch out for whole spices in the sauce; also, hainana chicken, which was ahhhhh-mazng, almost made me cry from happiness with each bite (a quarter chicken order is plenty for one person btw!). 
My only disappointment was roti canai, the bread was a bit too thick and chewy, and the curry was vegetable based and lacked flavor and that delicious greasy factor I've always tasted everywhere else. This is usually my go-to appetizer, but I wouldn't order it here again.
At last, we ordered fried banana with vanilla ice-cream for dessert, and it was faaaaaaabulous! I am not a desert person, but I finished my share of this one. The portion is pretty large two, there are pretty much two whole (?) fried bananas with a scoop of ice-cream. I would totally go back just for that!

Other than food, the ambience is relaxing, the restaurant is clean (including restroom), and they have a full bar to serve you fancy drinks."

The last wine in the pairing was a port and it was the perfect end to the meal. It was my first time eating Malaysian food and we are going to go back again tomorrow!

I was so surprised that all the dishes were big portions. You are getting bang for your buck! I am not vegetarian or vegan but I love veggies and unfortunately the other tasting menu had lots of shellfish dishes and I have a bad allergy but we ordered the lamb curry as well which was remarkable. The food was exceptional! Each food I tasted always surprised me by just how flavourful it is! Every time I took a bite felt like the flavors exploded in my mouth. I especially love love loveeee their roti! On top of the great food, the service was quick and the servers were caring and very entertaining.
First time trying Malaysian food while we were in Vancouver. The banana leaf could be considered a good introduction , especially since they provide a sampling menu that allows allows one to taste their most popular dishes. the food was excellent, the freshness of the ingredients really came through. From what we've sampled at this restaurant, it seems as though malay food incorporates some indian influences , except that the vegetables arent cooked as much, and so they remain crisp and light. Liked the food, good ambience, great service. Give malaysian food a try, you might be pleaantly surprised

"Came by for happy hour on a Friday afternoon, around 4:30, and I'm so glad we did! 

Happy hour is offered everyday 3-6 pm as well as 8:30 pm till close Sunday to Thursday. The hh menu includes both drink and food options.

There's a small outdoor patio in addition to the indoor seating, but we opted for indoors as there was construction going on outside. It wasn't crowded at all, so it was easy to get a table far from the other diners.

For my drink, I went with the daily special cocktail, the mango margarita ($8), and it didn't disappoint. I love that there was actual mango slush in the drink! They have some great drink specials such as half off all bottles of wine on Thursdays, and lychee mojitos on Saturdays. Definitely take advantage of it!

Neither of us were super hungry, so we opted to share the English Bay Sunset Box ($20), which includes calamari, roti canai, Asian salad, and chicken satay.We also ordered wings from their hh menu for $8.

The food was all delicious! The calamari was chewy with a nice crunch on the outside, and the roti canai with the curry dip was so good! The wings weren't spicy at all (thank goodness for my taste buds) and were fried perfectly. My only complaint was that the peanut sauce that accompanied the chicket satay was a little too sweet for my personal tastes. I would've preferred something on the saltier side. Other than that, I was quite happy with the meal!"

"Not my favorite Banana Leaf. But it was passable. 

The service was... interesting. I kept getting ignored and it wasn't even busy, I guess the server had more interesting things to do than serve but ah well. 

The food I did like though. Their curry laksa was very good lots of seafood and ingredients but the strengh or deepness of the broth wasn't that great (I'm a tough critic on this dish because my mother makes the best laksa).

The mee goreng is really nice, once again the portion size was good (it was $13) and the flavors for this dish was spot on. I liked the variety of ingredients, lots of veggies, metas and seafood and made it really nice and well-rounded. 

I tried their Guava Tini, sounds nice but in all honesty it wasn't that great (I'm a bartender so I'm picky). Whenever I go out I usual get something people can't mess up, but was feeling a bit adventurous. The guava was there but it was muddled with other flavors and smells which was a bit off. I would've preferred it only be guava juice and booze. 

Food is really good here, will definitely be back. Not a big fan of the drinks and the service needs some help, although it was probably only that one server, I've never had a bad experience before."
The dosa was really good. And they have a huge menu with tons of yummy food. Would love to go back.

I was pleasantly surprised ( it can be hit and miss with Indian food) and will definitely order from here again. Delivery was fast and portions were great for the price point."

"I heard some up and down reviews for this place, but it sounds like they're slowly on the upclimb because the place was pretty okay when I went last. Might be a bit late for them, since we were the only people in the restaurant the whole time. 

Service was definitely slow (surprising, since you know - only people there). I was all excited when I saw dosas on the menu. I haven't had a dosa in a long long time, and was super happy to order it off the menu. When the lady asked me how spicy I wanted it I said medium. Because right? Medium? That sounds reasonable.

Medium is insanely spicy. Like, REALLY spicy. Like it hurts my lips after three bits. Everything burned. Pretty much everything that we ordered aside from the naan was extrmeely spicy. Even the pakoras were spicy! Good gracious, I couldn't taste a thing after two minutes! I even had food left over to bring back to my husband, who subsequently also burned off his tongue as well.

But the food is good, and if I go back I'll definitely order the mild next time and try not to be a hero. It's seems a decent enough place, but the fact that it's quiet as heck makes me wonder why."
"I have been going to this restaurant for about 13-15 years. During that time it changed ownership.......and food quality changed.  But always there were a few items that were amazing. "Here was my first taste of Vancouver Indian food, and got to discover it from a flyer. Boy, those flyers with photos really work when hungry! Never mind if you have to drive away from downtown, our group, sold on the idea drove and came in an almost empty restaurant, clean cafeteria style with a TV screen playing Bollywood variety shows. Service was attentive and helpful, and we felt actually good about succumbing to the print ad.

It offers South Indian, Halal, and Sri Lankan cuisine at very reasonable prices. However, its main offerings are a large selection of dosa dishes. Our kind waiter spent a good two minutes describing the dosa dishes, only for us to skip it and go with the staples we normally order. The food took awhile to come out, but all dishes came out flavourful, with well-balanced spices. I instantly devoured the roti which I thought was the highlight for me. At that point, I would have given it 4 stars. However, having gone out to a few more Indian restaurants, I deemed it was only my satiated appetite speaking at the time and not a more discerning taste and judgment for the cuisine. In fact, I've had in many instances, a lot better roti elsewhere.

Nevertheless, it was a pleasant and satisfying experience for us, but will move on to try the myriad of other places serving similar cuisine, though I might change my mind if they come up with a tempting promo on their flyer again."
"Excellent service! The moment we stepped in, we were greeted by the friendliest man who seated us promptly and explained all of the specials.

I ordered the Chicken Tandori Tikka (13.95). I found it to be very juicy with the nice grilled flavouring that comes with Tandori Chicken. There was also a good deal of pepper and onion to add extra crunch and some tangy flavouring to the dish. The sauce that came with it kind of reminded me of a more tomatoey and less buttery form of butter chicken sauce.

The roti had a slight crispiness to it and a nice sweetness. The papadum was PERFECT though! It had a strong chick pea taste and a great level of saltiness. Only qualm would be that for the portion size, it's a tad on the small side for the price. Otherwise, was awesome!"

"This spot doesn't look like much from the outside, but the space inside is very clean, intimate and cozy and the food is delicious, totally worth the wait.  They have an extensive menu and everything I've tried so far has been very flavourful.

Sri Lankan food is probably some of the most delicious I've ever tried. After arriving home i was in search for some local sri lankan food and after stumbling upon Noorumahal i was not disappointed. Make sure you try the kohtu roti....its like a sri lankan stiry fry using deliciously cooked strips of roti....just delicious! The string hoppers are also a favorite!
I love a block away from this place and it took me almost a year to try it, doesn't look very appetizing from outside, when I finally try it was a pleasant surprise! Tasty , good price and service . The mild it's already spicy watch for that.

"Strong Indian takeout, and pleasant to eat-in although quiet most times. You can order online or phone, I've tried both and my order is always correct. 

This place specializes in dosas, but I tend to like the curries and I find them to be just as flavourful. I love roti, like really love roti, and theirs holds up well even reheating the next day to go with my leftover curries. 

I discovered the chicken kurma this week, and it was delicious - a little bit less hot than the curry which was a nice alternative to the searing heat if you are looking for a couple of dishes to order. I love the beef curry, good meat quality, great flavour, and nice and thick.
I order medium heat - and that's all I can take, and be warned, your mouth will be searing !
The value is great, about $10 for most dishes and they come with roti, rice and papadums - I usually get two meals out of it if I order an extra side of roti. 

The only downside is their pakoras are sorely lacking, doughy and not flavourful at all (and served with ketchup - really??). Loses a star for this one.

But the rest is great and a regular favourite takeout!"
"Nooru Mahal Restaurant (南印度及巴基斯坦風味餐廳)

Nooru Mahal Restaurant是溫哥華一家經營已有20年以上的南亞餐廳，主要的餐點包括南印度和巴基斯坦兩地美食，而最特別是連新加坡的料理也有供應，相信食肆的老闆曾經居住或在新加坡工作過吧！由於南印度和巴基斯坦兩地食物的調味較北印度辛辣，所以提醒怕吃辣的各位在落單時記住要求「微辣mild」為上。

餐廳的菜單包括南印度、巴基斯坦和新加坡的料理，而主打的招牌菜是印度捲餅，這裡的Dosa選擇非常多，有葷有素。Dosa是一種用米和扁豆麵糊放在熱鐵板上烤捲成的煎餅，跟法式可麗餅crepes的做法很相似，只不過印度版的尺寸大很多，而且中間會加入不同的印度鹹食饀料。Dosa在斯里蘭卡也很普遍，可以當成早餐或晚餐吃，也是街頭美食之一，但以印度南部省份的泰米爾納度（Tamil Nadu）最著名，其他有印度種族的國家，例如馬來西亞和新加坡也有Dosa，但名字則稱為Thosai。

Chicken Mattar Alu Dosa $8.95 (4/5分)
饀料是青豆薯仔咖喱雞，這裡的餡料比別家多，吃起來無餡料的地方捲餅皮很香脆，有餡料的地方給浸泡過比較稔。由於Dosa是即叫即做，每次只能做一份，即使同時落單亦會分先後上桌，我建議大家切勿等齊才吃，先上桌的要即刻起動，否則肯定吃不到香脆的餅皮

Dosa附來的兩種蘸醬中，綠色的帶有薄荷，而我比較喜歡黃色帶有椰蓉的一種。另外隨餐還有一小杯Sambar辣湯，喝起來有點像加辣羅宋湯

Beef Curry $12.95 (4/5分)
每份咖喱餐都附有 rice, roti, papadam 和raita，牛肉份量很多，咖哩十分香濃，可選擇微、中、勁三種辣度。我要了微辣，起初沒有感覺，其後越吃越辣，但對我來說還可以接受。"
Food here is one of the best Indian foods but for the last week no one has been there. When you call, there is answering machine to leave a message but says nothing about them being closed. I walked by the restaurant and its been closed without any notice on the door. Not sure if they are open anymore.
"First, order mild. Even this made my face sweat. If you think you can take it, order medium, but get extra papadums, roti, whatever, to spoon that raita into your mouth. 

Food is tasty. Lamb kurma is sensational and beef curry has better cuts of beef than many Indian places. Not much fatty meat with this place.

If you can find it, pour a glass of Jam Jar (sweet Shiraz). It may be the only wine that doesn't make the spicy lip sting worse."
Fantastic food and service! We've been coming here only a few months and it's a new favourite. Handy that it's close to where we live. I'm surprised it isn't rated higher, I'm going again TONIGHT!

"Solid Indian take out.  

Starving with an empty fridge, I discovered this place on www.just-eat.ca.  Ordered the Vegetarian Samosas, Butter Chicken, and Palak Paneer. I was quoted online that it would be ready to pick up in 25 minutes, but just 10 minutes later I got a call telling me it was ready.  Luckily I was just a 5 minute walk away.  

The first thing I noticed when I picked up the food was the quantity - for $29 the bag was stuffed pretty full.  The meals came with rice AND roti AND poppadoms - so don't make the mistake of ordering those sides separately (I almost did). Samosas were nothing special but nonetheless very good.  Butter chicken was really tasty. Palak paneer was a bit disappointing (pretty sure the spinach was frozen). Regardless, I wouldn't hesitate to order from here again - just skip the spinach next time."
Loved the Vegetarian Eggplant Curry and the Lamb Curry. We also had been searching for authentic string hoppers. You can tell the food is fresh made to order, as it does take more time to make, and the flavors show. Each curry is distinct and I cannot wait to try different one next time. The fresh Sambal is a must!
Ordered their deep fried fish ball which was spicy but super delicious. Also had one of the vegetarian dosas, the one with Peas and Potatoes. I think it's called, Matar Aloo? The crepe came out well seasoned and crispy, and the curry was well balanced between sauce, pea and potato. Overall, it was generous in portion and tasty. Just wish that service was a little faster next time.
"If you're looking for the straight up Indian food you will probably be disappointed in this place because this place serves up Sri Lankan food. I think people do a disservice to this place because they come in wanting the same butter chicken as all the other places on Main/Fraser. 
Highlight: Sri Lankan food is NOT Indian food. Do yourself a favour and try of their Sri Lankan specialties and get it spicy- (I asked for medium because I expected it to be serious- sri-lankan-hot that I was familiar with in Toronto- it's not- or maybe the lady didn't trust me with that kind of heat : p )

The food and service here is good. That being said, They split their menu to much between different regional cuisines and, therefore, I believe the overall quality suffers."
Not bad at all! The chicken wings are yum. The satay and dried noodles were boring, the chicken rice with ginger was delicious.
"This restaurant opened 2 or 3 weeks ago, and it is one of the rare Malaysian restaurants in northern Burnaby. The interior is modern and clean. We were seated quickly, and the first thing I noticed was that the tables are like school desks, which have a platform underneath to put your belongings. This also means your feet have limited range of movement, which was a bit irritating.

We arrived with only 3 other parties in the restaurant and by 6pm, the place was completely full with the early dinner rush of families with little kids. The wait time for our food was around 30 minutes. My thoughts on the food:

1. Roti canai - With Malaysian food, the roti canai is usually what makes me come back to the restaurant. I'm pretty sure the roti are the same kind I buy from Superstore, because of their uniformity and perfect shape. The dipping sauce was above average. I would have preferred a stronger, more flavorful sauce, but it was still good. However, knowing that they are just bought from a store and heated in the restaurant, I will probably pass on this item in the future.

2. Chicken wings - My second favorite dish. The order came with 4 chicken wings, but it included the entire wing with the drum, wing, and wing tip. The wings had a very basic batter on them, and were deep fried. The dip is a lemon/sugar/garlic sauce that has the consistency of water. Other places have a variant of this sauce that is very lemony, or peppery. The dip here leans more towards sugary/garlic flavor. I really liked it over the lemon/peppery versions. I will be ordering this again in the future.

3. Haianese chicken laksa - This was my favorite dish. The portion size was a good value, and it was quite delicious with a mild spice kick. Spice level was moderate....nothing particularly strong or overpowering, and the spice leaves the tongue after 2 minutes or so. It may not suit those who love spice, but given that this area is primarily Italians, it's probably a good idea not to make the spice too strong to appeal to a wider range of customers. Chicken was tender, and the broth was rich. You get a choice of egg noodle or vermicelli.

4. Pineapple fried rice - A fairly basic dish. My 1 year old daughter loved it, which I am thankful for, since dinners are often a battle.

Customer service / friendliness - 4/5
Price / value - 4/5
Food quality - 4/5"
"I've been here a few times since they've open for dinner. I do suggest making reservation if you have more than 4 people as the place isn't big and yet you may need to wait during rush hour of dinner. 

They mee goreng is really good here with lots of flavours. The Haianese chicken sauce was really good but the chicken itself I would say beware of it having bones on some of the pieces. The rice for this is ok and it does come with soup. Their roti is really good cause i can taste the fat they use to pan fry it in. Everything else on the menu is good and at a reasonable price. 

The place is really like a Singaporean/ Malaysian restaurant. The tables and feel of the place is really casual. The owner of the place even has a room in the restaurant for her baby to sleep/play in. It's very homie while a little baby boy may be running around the place. I do warn you all about the tables there. When you sit down make sure you don't hit your shin because the design of the table doesn't allow you to comfortably put your legs under. 

They are lucky that in the area there really isn't much competition. They are also on skip the dish. So, delivery is available for people who choose to eat this at home. But I do have to say it's good to have a good haianese chicken place close to home."

"Went for the first time last night.  Very nice couple running the place. Portions were generous. I have spent many years married to a Malaysian and have been there many times so I jumped at the chance to go to a new place. 

First up roti chanai. The roti was nicely cooked flakey and delicious. The dip coup use some more depth of flavour. Thus tasted like Baba's curry powder.

Second chicken and beef satay. Peanut sauce was decent but not great. The meat was nicely cooked and the chicken had alot of meet on it. The marinade on the beef had more lemon grass so I enjoyed it more.

Curry laksa, hainanese chicken.  The noodles, sprouts and fish bar were good. The soup was too thin and lacked the depth of flavours I crave, no sense of a bouille base with dried prawn flavours.  A lot of chicken, but it was all dark meat so my daughter was disappointed.

Char kway teow.
A Singapore style, less dark sweet dot.  Tasted good but more like char hor fan than char kway teow. I ate it all.

Wishing them good luck in their new venture. 10 % off for the first month."
I've been wanting to try out this new place. The decor is very modern and light. The staff was very welcoming and attentive. We ordered the roti canai, chicken/beef satay, seafood curry and Steamed veggies as an add on item. Everything was tasty though I was disappointed that the steamed veggies ended up being kai lan (not my favorite veggie but it was my fault for not asking what it was going to be before ordering). You don't get a generous amount of seafood (1 mussel, 1 fish ball, shrimp,  potatoes, scallop?) in the curry but I'm not complaining since I'm not a big seafood eater. What we ordered was enough for my gf and me to share lunch. I would like to come back to try the Char Kwee Teow since it's my favorite Malaysian dish. Next time I'll remember to post pics as well.
Newly opened restaurant in the Burnaby heights area that serves some pretty good variety of Malaysian eats.  The dishes there range from laksa, curries, pinapple fried rice, Hainanese chicken, roti canai, satay skewers and more. The portions and prices are pretty good! The Hainanese chicken set was $9.95 and came with the chicken, rice, and soup.  For lunch they also have lunch add ons if you want a little something extra to add to your meal. Taste was relative to many of the main stream Malaysian restaurants. One of my favorite so far is the beef curry. Their curry is more liquidy but is full of flavour and had just the right amount of spiciness - it was perfect with the white rice. I came here a little past lunch hour and the place was relatively quiet but the server was very attentive and friendly. Only thing I would suggest is if you plan to use the yelp check in discount to check the bill again cause even though you check in at the counter and show them they tend to forget to apply it to the bill. Overall, not bad for a Malaysian restaurant in this area!
This little place is full of warm lighting, furniture and a comforting aroma of hainanese chicken. It is a perfect addition to the neighbourhood and Burnaby had been lacking malaysian, Singaporean food. Now I don't need to trek all the way to Richmond for some quality food.
"Didn't enjoy. Not sure if it was the dishes we tired or the cuisine. Although I enjoy Thai and lots of other ""Asian"" cuisines."
"This new family-run Malaysian restaurant is clean, bright and spacious.  There is also plenty of parking around.

As for the food, few dishes were ordered including satay, roti canai, hainanese chicken, mee goreng and deep fried banana & ice cream.  Among the dishes, I enjoyed mee goreng the most because it was fried with enough 'wok hei' (heat).  However, all the sauces need work (eg. Satay peanut sauce, curry for the roti).  The deep fried banana and ice cream is a treat but I wish there's a choice of mango or coconut ice cream.  Nevertheless, as good Malaysian food is hard to come by in the lower mainland, I hope to see improvements the next time I visit."

"Green & Oak is one of the newer Malaysian restaurants in town and situated just east of Boundary Road on Hastings Street. We arrived in mid-April (right before they were set to temporarily close down for some kitchen renovations) for a late lunch/early dinner and were fortunate that they were still offering their special lunch add-on menu (where you can order smaller versions of their appies).

The interior of this restaurant is spacious and there's plenty of light coming in from the large windows.

With the special lunch-time add-on menu, we were able to try a lot of different items: Chicken and Beef Satay ($2.95 for 2 skewers), Chicken Wings ($3.75), Fish Cakes ($3.75), and Roti Canai ($2.95).

We also ordered the Hainanese Chicken Set Meal ($9.95) which comes with minced ginger and a spicy dipping sauce along with chicken rice.

The satay was accompanied with a peanut dipping sauce. I found that the chicken was much better than the beef (which was drier and a bit chewy).

The fish cakes had a paper-thin crisp exterior which encased the plump fish patty but it seemed to lack any fish flavour. Meanwhile, the roti had thin and flaky layers and a curry dipping sauce.

The 2 full chicken wings (tips intact) were crispy and accompanied with a tart dipping sauce. Not on the level of chicken wings that you'd find at Phnom Penh (but few are).

Last up was the Beef Curry ($9.95) which was served with a bowl of rice. The mostly tender chunks of beef and large pieces of potato were swimming in a delicious curry sauce. You definitely need the rice to sop up that curry sauce.

We revisited three months later during National Ice Cream Day and ordered the Milo Godzilla ($5.25) - given how hot it was outside, this was a really good choice. For those of you unfamiliar, Milo is a chocolate malt beverage. This ""Godzilla"" version is iced and topped off with ice cream that's been dusted with undissolved Milo powder.

We again ordered a bunch of items from their lunch add-on menu... the Spring Rolls ($3), Roti ($2.95), and the Chicken Satay ($3.50). Again, these add-on items are perfect for trying out a bunch of different items.

For our mains, we stuck with the Char Kuey Teow ($12.50) and the Hainanese Chicken Set Meal ($10.95).

Overall, the food was rather good. They also have a shelf under the tables where you can put your bags (although I kept hitting my leg against it)."
"Interior is super cute and servers were nice, still new but nice. The food was okay, nothing special. The laksa was not good, as if there was no coconut milk and the flavor was more salty. The veggies in shrimp sauce were yummy! Spring rolls were average, i could probably get the same ones at costco. And the roti was okay, once again nothing special. The drinks we had however were quite yummy! Wouldnt go out of my way for this place,
But the prices are on point so if in the area and craving SEA food id go back."

"Came for a visit, entirely thrilled with a new Hainanese chicken spot...  but have to say, the chicken was good (portions smaller than most) and the rest of the items we tried were a disappointment. Three stars for: decor, chicken and the concept. 
The rice was too soft, like food court quality. The skewers I was not fond of but the house made peanut sauce was tasty, laksa was a miss as well... but most importantly service could definitely be improved. The server cannot come over and start clearing plates when your customer is still eating a bowl of rice, second the server should never bring the bill and stand right there waiting to collect the $. Which I love having chicken yellow rice with Curry. Also their chicken wings are the my favourite side dish. It comes with a lemon dipping sauce which brings out the flavour of the deep fried chicken wings. I will definitely come back for more other dishes especially the pan fried Chow Guey Teow and Mee Goreng !! A Great Malaysian cusinine added to the north Burnaby neighbourhood
"For a new business - this is phenomenal! There's a nice cosy feeling the moment you walk in, and you're greeted with a nice warm wood tone that is consistent across all their furnishing. 

The menu is simple and I was very glad that there wasn't too large of a selection to go through. My dining partner and I settled for the pineapple fried rice and a vegetable and tofu curry. The portions are good and taste delicious as well! However, I found the curry and rice ratio to be disproportionate so I also ordered another bowl of rice. The vegetables in the curry were quite unconventional! Brussel sprouts in a curry are unheard of for me, but I quite enjoyed it!

The service is prompt and while they're not attentive (I don't mind), they were quick to answer you if called for them. You can also definitely tell that Green & Oak is a family-run restaurant, considering when I went there was a small toddler running around and a backroom that seems to be for the toddler to nap in. While I don't mind it (it was too adorable), it may be a con for someone that wouldn't like to hear the occasional footsteps of a toddler."
The foods are great, with great services, and the atmosphere is calm and great (just like went into a forest lol). It's a good place to spend an afternoon in!!!
"Went here this afternoon after finding this place on Yelp. There's not a lot of good Malaysian places around town and especially not a place that's as inviting and cozy as Green & Oak. I think they did really well in making it feel like home - the atmosphere was very calm and relaxing. It wasn't too busy (maybe due to Easter weekend), my friend and I ended up chatting for almost 2 hours and not once did staff attempt to rush us out. In fact, the owner even wiped our table down and told us to enjoy our tea after we had finished our meal. 

The food great! Definitely recommend the chicken wings - they were so good we ordered it twice! Also had the Meegoreng and roti which were both excellent. 

Overall great experience and will definitely be back!"

"New restaurant with 10% off! We came here on a Thursday at 7ish and were seated immediately. There were 5 other tables seated.
Very nice family run restaurant. It sounds like the family speaks Cantonese.

Ambience & decor: simple and cute. It gives off a home vibe. There are approximately 5 - four seaters and 5 - two seaters, and about 6 bar seats.

Customer service: efficient and nice. As we were seated we were immediately asked if we want water, tea or other beverages. We asked for tea to start. They noticed we are sharing a noddle and proactively asked us if we wanted sharing bowls.

Kitchen service: We ordered a Haianese chicken laksa (with the chicken on the side) and Char Kuey Teow at 7:24pm. The CKT is ready at 7:38pm. The laksa is ready at 7:41pm.

Price, portion, taste: the alcoholic beverages are surprisingly reasonably priced. We got a bottle of Sapporo for $4.50. The CKT is too salty, lack the ""wok chi"", and lack the spice and sweetness that we are used to.
The laksa is tasty and large portion. The condiments  such as parsley, etc. are missing. The chicken is meaty, but it tasted more like the Chinese style blanched chicken rather than Haianese Chicken."
Great decor! It was a slow night because of the miserable weather. But I heard there was a new Malaysian restaurant near by so I though i would give it a go. As usual I over order just to try everything. The rice and noodle dishes  flavouring was good. But definitely missing the heat of the wok. The hainanese chicken was very moist and the tom yum soup was well flavoured.  I would skip the laska soup, I had better at aberdeen mall food court. The roti was ok but the sauce was cold, which didn't make any sense. The service was good but then again it wasn't a full house. All in all it was ok the food was ok for the price. The place is well lit and the parking is ok

"Lunch Review

It's great to see that they offer a variety of dishes so sharing with a group is a good way to try a bit of everything, in our case, a family of 7

My in-laws are from Malaysia so I was glad they enjoyed the food at Green and Oak

The Roti was a bit pricey per piece but it wasn't oily like other places I've tried

The Laksa we ordered was with chicken, and vermicelli noodles. The soup was tasty with a good balance of heat, curry, lemongrass and coconut. There were tofu puffs, boiled egg, bean sprouts, fish balls and a lime wedge. Next time, I would ask for cilantro to tie in all the flavors! 

Hainanese chicken with Yellow Chicken Rice
I think this is a must try dish, the chicken was tender, boneless and full of flavor. 

Singapore Style Vermicelli was fried very nicely, it wasn't too oily and it had a good curry 

The Mee Goreng was on the oily side but the noodles were al dente 

The Banana Boat is basically deep fried banana served with ice cream on the side (you get a choice of Vanilla, Strawberry, Chocolate ice cream) It would be nice if they had more exotic ice cream flavors or toppings to go with this dessert. But $4.95 for dessert is pretty good! 

Overall, the service was great, prices are fair, and adding Malaysian cuisine to the neighbor is for sure a good move!

#MustTryHainaneseChickenandRice"
"We tried a fair bit of dishes during lunch. I love that you can add on appetizers at a reduced price during lunch. Sometimes you just want a little bit extra to add to your mains but without having to order the full portion. 

We ordered the laksa, chicken rice and added on the satay and chicken wings. 

Laksa was ok, taste was a bit bland as it lacked the spices (not spicy spices but the spices which gave laksa its taste).

The chicken rice was not too bad, I still did not get how the rice was yellow from the chicken fat (I was told it was from the chicken itself), maybe it was kampong chicken? 

The fried chicken wings were nice but nothing memorable, same for the satay. After so many weeks, I could not really recall the exact taste, so yeah, definitely not a place that would pop into my mind if I am asked to recommend a place for decent Malaysian food. 

Great service though and the place is nice too."
"Almost two years has past since I went when they first opened. Back then it was promising but had a long ways to go as it really felt like just your everyday home cooking. Never really felt the urge to come back as there was always something else to try

Not sure if they have changed owners since but went recently and they've learned a lot and it showed! Busy on an ugly rainy Friday night.

I remember in the past being intrigued cause they offered some different dishes and flavours than the standard Malaysian and they still do with notch up in the execution and presentation. After a couple years I'm sure you learn about getting people through the doors. Glad they are still around!

Food wise was good, a spicy noodle dish stood out for me where it wasn't hot spicy but still a good kick. Quite yummy. I also look for hainanese chicken and it was well prepared and cooked here but was still missing a certain distinctive flavour that might not be possible to achieve easily here depending where you source the chicken from.

Glad I came back, gotta go through their Laksa next time!"
