Wish there're more restaurants in Vancouver that serve Hainanese Chicken!
"BEST. HAINANESE. CHICKEN. IN. VANCOUVER!!!!

I haven't found a place that serves chicken more tender and flavourful (with rice as delicious too!) than this place.

I always get the large hainanese chicken on rice- it's a good portion for a bottomless pit like me and it comes with a delicious bowl of bone soup as well.

Their roti here is also amazing- flaky and tender with a dipping sauce to die for.

Service is meh but who cares when the chicken tastes so good.

Will come back again and again."
Very cool that the store changed the ordering system to self serve. Customer will need to take a picture of the provided barcode, and the phone will pop out and direct you to a link for you to order. I always come here for hainanese chicken and yellow rice! They're are the must orders. My friend liked the beef laksa and said it was authentic and she would come back shin for the laksa.
"Don't go by what the menu depicts: you'll be sorely disappointed. The portion size is hardly the grand array that seduced you. The chicken is tender but under-seasoned; the size of the accompanying chili is fit for a garden gnome and maybe his squirrel companion could get a little awful pawful. The drop of ginger is the size of a coiled inchworm and the same color too. If you want more sauce, you have to pay for it even though you ordered a lot of chicken. Cucumbers are sliced like there is only one green stick to feed the entire evening's clientele, and it ain't Jesus doing the cutting, so prepare for paucity. The service, as many other reviewers have pointed out, is close to non-existent other than ordering and taking your dough at the end. Also, be mindful you can either pay with debit or else cash. I've seen chicken shacks in condemned areas of some of ""America's most dangerous cities"" willing to take credit cards. There's couples swarming around wanting your table (they are vibrating ""get up, get up, get up"") so it's hard to eat without feeling many, many, many pairs of beady eyes trailing your food journey like hungry denizens of an emancipated post-war city. I got a stressful dressful, to say the least. ALSO, these folks are perpetually short-staffed and I've seen that ""sorry, we're short-staffed"" sign for a couple of years now. Must be harder to get an interview there than get tickets for ""Hamilton"" on Broadway...."
"Am I the only one that thinks of slide-whistles and hum 'Groove Is In The Heart' when I see ""D'Lite""?

Anyways - the boneless Hainanese chicken rice is the main attraction here.  The chicken is good. But felt pretty let down by the rice - it was dry and didn't have enough chicken oil flavour for my liking.  Maybe it was a mistake coming here right when they opened first thing is the morning?"
Got to meet the actual Mama Lee and she was very friendly and welcoming, and apparently works there nearly every day. Their noodle dishes were surprisingly good, as was their hainanese chicken. Portions are relatively small for the price however. We needed 3 dishes to feed 2 people for lunch, and could have still eaten some more. It would be nice if they gave a bit more sauce with the order of chicken. Parking is relatively easy to find on the street.
"We're always up to try a good Malaysian restaurant and I've heard some good things about Mamalee located on West Broadway in Kits.

This is a pretty basic Malaysian restaurant (not a very huge menu) and the interior is quite utilitarian. Still... we're here for the food. We wound up ordering the Hainanese Chicken (regular size) with a side of soup as well as Roti Canai and a Milo Dinosaur. A cold Milo Dinosuar really is refreshing on a hot day. The simple soup was so aromatic when it arrived at the table.

First up is the Hainanese Chicken, served cold, with a side of rice. The poached chicken was quite good and we managed to finish this rather easily. While it comes with a bit of dipping sauce, I would have liked if it had more ginger and scallion dipping sauce (you have to pay extra for more).

The Roti Canai was a bit disappointing... not sure what was really going on here. It seemed quite shredded up and the outside seemed to be overcooked and not the least bit fluffy on the inside.

We also wound up ordering the Chee Cheong Fun with Fish Balls. This actually turned out to be a pretty good dish and I enjoyed the tender rice rolls but I thought the sauce was a bit too runny as it was difficult to coat the rice rolls with it.

Overall impressions... a very minimalistic Malaysian eatery with some hits and misses. In either case, don't order the roti canai unless you like it overly dry and shredded."
We ordered lunch for our branch this week, and one oF the advisors recommended we order from here. We ordered seafood laksa soup, chicken laksa soup, and a beef dish. Food was excellent, everyone enjoyed food - soup had perfect amount of spice! Service was excellent - very friendly - needless to say we will order from here again!
"My 200th review - woohoo! 

My friends come here sometimes but I've never come with them...until now!

Luckily I showed up a bit early (fearing the lines) and snagged a table. The menu is rather small compared to larger Malaysian restaurants but that's ok considering the size of the place. 

I got the large hainanese chicken on rice and it was pretty tasty but not the best I've had. There's two other places I prefer (but those come with some bones left, so if you can't pick 'em...they're not the best places to eat for you). My friend had warned me that the portion size would be smaller because they did meticulously debone everything...but I'd rather pay the same for more and occasionally spit a bone out. The rice was good but not as good as other places. 

Overall I'd say I'm pretty disappointed. I've heard such great things and seen the lines and never had a chance to try it. Now that I've been here...I don't think I'd come back unless I was in the area. I think maybe the reason it's so popular is because it's the only Malaysian place nearby with the exception of Banana Leaf."
"I got the regular hainanese chicken for $12.50 and it was just okay. I honestly felt like I got more chicken skin than chicken meat. And the flavor was lacking a bit. There's only street parking for those wanting to come here as an FYI."
"Mamalee is offering COVID friendly takeout right now- you can order ahead online and choose your pickup time! Sooo convenient :) My order was ready when I got there for the time I set it for.

I was ordering for myself on the weekend and I got the following:
-Regular Hainanese chicken + rice $13.50- I thought this was a little pricey for what you get (the portion size was smaller than I hoped for, no leftovers for me). The chicken is super well done and the sauces that come with it were on point! I wasn't too fond of the rice- I was hoping for more flavor from it. Comes with some slices of cucumber as well.
-Roti Canai $8 (also a little pricey imo) - comes with dipping sauce. This was INCREDIBLE! Loved how flaky and buttery the roti was and the dipping sauce really topped this off perfectly. The BEST ROTI dipping combo I've had so far and I cannot wait to come back and get this again!!

Food was overall great but I was not too impressed with the pricing. But for how much I enjoyed the roti, I wouldn't mind paying $8 just to get it again xD"

"I came here on a hot day (when we were having the heat wave), hoping for some good food and AC.

One of the customers asked for water to which the person responded and got them water. He asked us after and when we asked him, ""is water $1 each?"" he scoffed and said loudly ""why would you pay for water?"" I found this pretty rude and sort of humiliating. I figured afterwards they probably meant bottled water but when you aren't served water until way after your food comes and there's a sign that says $1 water, it's pretty misleading. 

Now, on to the real review. Food.
We got tofu goreng. It was pretty sweet and not bad. Nice to try a bite or two but I don't think I would order again.

"Mom and pop style shop with Mom and Pop style food.  Straight up awsome home made comfort food that I'm familiar with.

Food: Fried chicken and rice 2 ways. Crispy flavorful chicken fluffy rice. Thai papaya salad with sweet, sour, savory with a backend bite from fresh garlic mixed in.  Large Tom kha with chicken enough for 8 adults. 3 orders of Rotti because it was that good. Dough slightly crispy on the outside and chewy with a curry dipping sauce. Last but not least a noodle dish  similar to chow main with a Malaysian flair. All the food was surprisingly well prepared, hot and quick to make it to the table.

For a two person mom and pop shop and a full house, food was fast and service was friendly. If you like the Malaysian/Thai/Indo-Chinese type food this is your go to place in Surrey, BC, CANADA."

"I was here yesterday for a lunch with my sister, and dining here was the best decision ever. Thanks Yelp for finding this hidden gem of Guildford.

So first we ordered Chicken Satay ($7), Tom Yum soup(with chicken $9.5), Mee Mamak (with beef $10.25) and Teh Tarik ($2.95) , and service was bit slow at first because there was only wife and hubby together (I think they were Malaysians). We even saw some dishes and waste that wasn't finished cleaning. 

I was very much blown away from Tom Yum soup at the beginning and it really felt like eating home cooked Thai food. It wasn't like fake ones from the food court. Chicken Satay was fresh. I loved the nutty and sweet flavour of chicken satay. Mee Mamak was good too, however the chicken in the noodle was quite dry and rubbery. Everything else about the dish was great.

Teh Tarik was really good. It tasted like home made milk tea that was sweet and milky. Good thing ,I didn't order along with Thai Iced Tea as the two drinks would taste similar. I highly recommend this place for those who likes Thai\ Malay cuisine. I personally think MD is better than Tropika and Banana Leaf. 

They do have wifi under #Telus, the only downside I found was small narrow washrooms. Owners were helpful and friendly."

"Came here as I read the good reviews, the place is small 6-7 tables. Clean place, ordered our food right away, and came before 20-30 minutes. Don't expect the service will be top, but ohh well it's cold and snowing heavy outside so might as well enjoy the food!

"I dined here on a Sunday at 7:30pm. We made reservations, but that was totally unnecessary since the restaurant was empty. Decor here is pretty minimal. There are 5 tables inside, which seats a total of 20 people. A server asked us if we wanted tea or water, so we asked for tea not knowing it isn't free. We didn't even get a refill on it either. Bummer. 

We ordered: 
- Roti Canai: 3/5. It wasn't too thick and it was pretty fluffy. Dipping was a bit oily.
- Mee goreng: 4/5. You get a pretty good amount for the price. We got it with beef but you have a choice to get it with chicken or prawns too. I thought it  tasted pretty good, but my sister found it to be too salty.
- Laksa: 3.5/5. Comes with two types of noodles. I found this to be too heavy and not enough noodles. Three of us were struggling to finish this bowl because it got sickening really quickly. Nice how you get one whole egg though. 
- The server also recommended us to get this appetizer that was on special... Not sure what it's called but it's like a spring roll with potatoes, mozzarella, chicken and something else inside. 4 for $5. It tasted like chicken pot pie. Pretty good. 
- Thai Iced Tea: 1/5. Don't get it. It was too sweet and didn't even taste like Thai iced tea... also got charged more than what was stated in the menu. 

While we were seated, a lady walked in and sat at the table in front of us, facing me. She kept staring at us and laughing hysterically... it made things really uncomfortable and we wanted to get out of there ASAP. She seems like a regular since the employees were joking around with her while she was ordering. On top of this starer, the people working here were speaking incredibly loud and obnoxiously. There is no music playing in the restaurant to mask the noise either. It made our dining experience very unpleasant. 

The ladies here were not attentive at all. I had to walk up to them to remind them about my Thai Iced tea. I also had to walk up to ask for a togo box and the bill. I'm sure if I needed to use the debit machine, I would have had to walk up to them as well.

We decided that we will not be returning as eating here is not fun."
"One word : Teleportation. This restaurant serves bona fide Malaysian Thai cuisine without actually having to take a 20 hour flight to South East Asia.

"This place is definitely a gem.
Finally came here yesterday after being recommended by a few friends.
We ordered Roti Canai, Three Tastes Fish, Chicken Apple, Nasi Goreng Kampong and Char Kwe Tiau. 
And all of them are just so good.
The fish isn't as spicy as how it looks and has that refreshing sour twist to it.
The Chicken apple is better than what I was expected. It is perfectly cooked and the skin is really crispy. Not to mention that the apple sauce is really good. It's is sweet but also a bit tangy.
Nasi Goreng Kampong is quite spicy, in my opinion, but really authentic and delicious.
Chat Kwe Tiau would be the only moderate dish we had on our table yesterday. It's good, but not great.
The winner for me would be the Fish and the Roti Canai. The Canai is very crispy on the outside yet still manage to be chewy at the same time. The curry that come with it tastes a bit spicy--which I like. We ordered our 2nd plate after tasting it. It is really that good.
The only cons for me would be that the food takes quite some time for them to be prepared. However, considering the food, I think it definitely worth the wait.
So yeah, definitely coming back here again! :)"
"Hands down the best restaurant serving Malaysian food in Vancouver so far. 

The location is a bit far if you are not anywhere near Surrey (this is near Guildford area), but after my first bite of the mee goreng, I decided I will make the trek out in future. It is so worth the trip. 

We ordered the tom yum soup with prawns (very similar to what you get to Thailand or in the Singapore/Malaysia region), mee goreng (it is so good!), lamb nasi briyani (equally tasty) and kampung fried rice with chicken (very yummy). We also ordered sambal which cost $1, and it was super spicy. All the dishes were delicious and would not be out of place at any coffee shop in Singapore. The taste was that authentic. 

Service was a bit slow as they were understaffed but they were very friendly and warm. Do not go in a big group as the space is limited. Probably could seat 16 customers or so.

I will want to go back again to try the crispy fried chicken and the three tastes fish which is also highly recommended."

"Despite the entire restaurant staff being down with the flu, leaving the one owner lady to wait tables, cook, clean, and cashier simultaneously all by herself, my experience at Mek's Delight was an astoundingly positive and tasty one.

Almost everything on the well-photographed little menu looked delicious, but I decided to focus this visit on some mainstays: the roti canai and the laksa.

The roti canai were utterly indulgent: savoury and flaky and a tiny bit chewy in all the right ways, and the curry dipping sauce was just as ""awesome"" as the menu claimed it was.

The laksa was also very good. My first couple of bites of vegetables and noodles seemed a little weak, but as the rich chili-coconut broth soaked into everything over the next couple of minutes, that was quickly remedied. Like a good wine, it needed to ""breathe"" for a minute for all the flavours to blend a little. Slurping up big spicy spoonfuls of that broth later, I wasn't sure if I was going to be able to quit even though my already-full belly was telling me to stop.

I can't wait to go back to try other things.

Things to know: 
- There's no street parking, but there's a free parking lot in the rear of the building, and you can enter through the back or walk around.
- The place is very small, with only 5 four-top tables. Bring your date or your three closest friends, but leave the big groups at home. Carryout might be a good option if you're feeding more than four.
- Everything is made to order and may take a little bit especially if several people arrived at once. That's the price to pay for a fresh family-made meal.
- They have some Thai dishes on the menu, but I'd agree with other reviewers' suggestion to stick to the Malaysian dishes, especially on a first visit. A neighbouring table's tom kha soup looked just okay."
An honest to goodness mom and pop Malay and Thai place. The food was delicious, the owners were very friendly and the prices were excellent. The Roti Canai, chicken satay, Tom ka Hai and nasi Lemak was excellent. The three taste fried tilapia was out of this world. Highly recommended! Place is small and service is a bit slow, but everything was made fresh and came out piping hot.
"I have a love-hate relationship with this place. I LOOOOVE their food but their service isn't the best. It's a small restaurant run by a couple, the husband is the server and his wife is the cook, and they aren't the friendliest people out there.

However, their food is SOOOO good in my opinion. We've tried almost everything on their menu, and so far none of them disappoints except for their Beef Rendang, which is not on par with their other dishes. Their Spicy Chicken is out of the world. It's so unique and flavorful, I've never had chicken in that way ever before. Their Fried Chicken&Fries is really good too, it's more flavorful than your normal fried chicken.

I've been trying to restrain myself from coming back due to the bad service, but I can't help but crave their food. All in all, I'll recommend this place to you foodies out there that don't mind bad service as long as the food is really good."

"During my years living in downtown Vancouver, I'd often get my fix of Malaysian food at one of the BL locations...whichever was closest, or at the other ""Malaysian"" restaurant, which during my recent visit, I noticed is now closed down. Then, upon yelp'ing for BL's location, I noticed this ""new"" location on Robson....thought I'd go check it out.

We came a little before 6pm and noticed that the place was already pretty busy. We were greeted by one of the servers who told us it was going to be a 5-10 minute wait.....oh cool!.....at least it wasn't an hour wait! Shortly after, we were seated, handed the menu, and our server came by to welcome us and take our drink orders.....very nice and friendly young lady.

So, my father enjoys good Malaysian food, but is often not too happy with what you get overseas, when comparing it to the real thing back in Malaysia. However, he and I were, overall, quite happy with the food here. We ordered the more typical Malaysian dishes, just because we had a craving for them, and for us to test out the quality of these common dishes. We went ahead and ordered the Roti Canai (flat bread), Chicken Satay, Gado Gado (salad), Boneless Curry Chicken, Singapore Laksa (curry vermicelli noodles), and the Pisang Goreng (fried banana fritters) with Vanilla Ice Cream.

First off, the roti canai was probably the best I have ever eaten in the US/Canada, and is the closest to the authentic roti canai you get back in Malaysia.....thick, puffy, and tastes yummy. The boiled veggies in the gado gado should have been drained better as the water diluted the peanut sauce and diminished the taste quite a bit. The chicken satay was very nice and tender, but had very weak flavor.....a bit bland....the peanut sauce that came with it helped somewhat, but the satay itself typically has much more flavor on its own. The Singapore laksa was good.....yummy. But, it was the pisang goreng, that's my father's favorite dessert....which he will often eat on a daily basis from any good Thai or Malaysian restaurant that carries it.....that he commented was ""very good.""

Yea, some hits and some misses with this place, but overall, we were quite happy with the quality of the food. Service was fine for us despite how crowded and busy the place was. Will definitely come back here again when I'm back in town."
"On our first day visiting Vancouver, a local friend recommended Banana Leaf as a lunch option for us.  We are still talking about how amazing that lunch was.  The perfectly balanced flavors and fresh ingredients were exactly what we had been craving.  

We ordered the peppercorn oysters, roti canai, lettuce wraps and the papaya and seafood soup.  Maybe it was because it was chilly outside but that soup was phenomenal.  Just the perfect amount of spice.  All of our other items were amazing as well; all perfectly cooked without being greasy at all.  

If there weren't so many other restaurants to try during our stay, we would have definitely returned!"
"Like most people have identified, this Banana Leaf does not really live up to the name of the other locations. It's almost incomprehensible that they can charge as much as they do for; lets face it...glorified fried rice. 

My friend and I shared a pineapple fried rice a few skewers and two beers. Everything was over priced and way too oily and there was little to no meat. Why be so el cheapo with the meat? Do yo really think people won't notice if you smother everything in very salty sauce?

If you are in the neighborhood, I recommend going to the donair place next door for a better meal."

I love it. Good quality of food. The taste is absolutely remind me of real Asian food in Asia. Will come back
Great service, nice location. They have really reasonable lunch specials but I was with a group of 6 and we opted to order a bunch of items to share. Food is so delicious. From what we order I would get again: mango kerabo(mango, cucumber, carrot salad so refreshing, need it to cut the richness of the meal), eggplant fries(light and a great share plate), roti canai, tiger prawns in mango chilli basil(this is something new I tried and I was crazy about it), nasi goreng, mee goreng, char kuey teow (my fav out of the noodle dishes). We also ordered the rendang beef, and then raised lamb shank which were both quite nice but I would skip them next time and try something else. We finished it off with the pisang goreng which is the deep fried banana, sooo delicious. Make sure you ask for mango ice cream with it instead of the vanilla it originally comes with. It's finished with caramel drizzle and toasted nuts. Didn't last on the table for more than a minute. With a bottle of wine, a beer, 4 specialty drinks, 9 dishes and 2 desserts it came to $210 for 6 people! So reasonable! Definitely coming back. Only downer was they were out of the mango slush to make half of the drinks which I was annoyed about so I was limited on the beverages. Especially when I had my heart set on having a mango drink. Ahh well...
I love the food in all location! Very diverse menu and a lot of drinks selections 5/5 stars. These restaurants are meant for sharing, so if you're planning to be with friends and/or family. This is a great place for that!

Fresh fried rice mixed with with ripe, juicy pineapple chunks and a medley of fresh shrimp, baby scallops, and chicken. Then the whole thing is served in a hollowed out pineapple half. "This was our first time at this location, and we were not disappointed. The Banana Leaf is one of my must-do's every time in Vancouver. Ever since my first bite of their caramelized cod, I've been a fan.

This location was less cramped than their Denman location, which was a nice change. As always, the food was wonderful. My son had the lamb-a new try for our family. He is a fan of lamb in general and reported that while this dish didn't taste like ""traditional"" lamb, it was ""really good."" 

A couple of helpful notes: with the wide varieties of spicy food in this city, sometimes it's hard to judge heat levels. The ""regular"" at The Banana Leaf, however, isn't so hot that you'll need a glass of milk and Tums. My kids can eat their food without having to have it made mild. However, the restaurant will make things mild if needed."
"Cosy restaurant.  Immediate seating at 5:30 Sunday night.  Service:  very attentive.

Extensive menu with many tasting options for 2.

I ordered the vegetarian delight for my main which consisted of coconut vegetable curry, rice and one vegetable spring roll. The spring roll was good but a tad greasy. "I am totally jazzed about a Malaysian restaurant chain.  I love the flavors and think they could really catch on if more people were exposed to them.  Banana Leaf does this in a classy way, putting the art and artifacts of the culture around you and does it at reasonable prices.

So why three stars?  Although our group of 5 had 4 different dishes, only one of them was a standout.  The rest were bland and uninteresting (including the camphur plate and the lettuce roll with chicken).  The star dish was the Singapore Laksa - a coconut curry soup with rice noodles and seafood.  This was great - rich, creamy, flavorful and filling."
"There were 2 locations of this local chain within walking distance of our hotel and we chose this one. We sat on the patio and, after reviewing the menu, decided to order the 9-course tasting menu.  Our first course was mango kerabu, an interesting looking, though particularly flavorfull, salad of shredded carrots, green mangos, chili's and shallots in lime juice/fish sauce dressing.  Next came roti canai, satay chicken and cumin mussels.  We had several dishes on this trip that included mussels, but this one was voted #1. 

Shortly after the appetizers, our four entrees arrived:  rendang beef curry, sambal green beans, caramelized ginger sablefish and gulai tiger prawns and scallops. Our shared dessert was pisang goreng (deep fried banana) with ice cream. Every dish was very good with the only exceptions being the rendang beef curry (tough) and rice (dry).  Pacing throughout the meal was very good as was the service"
I might have found a new Asian cuisine that I love. I had no idea Malaysian food would be so delectable! Every single dish was so distinct and aromatic!
We ordered some of the roti canai (paratha and curry) to start. We also ordered the eggplant fries (5 stars!), tofu goreng (could have passed), It was deliciously crispy and creamy. For the entree we ordered a vegetarian tofu based curry. It is obvious they get their ingredients fresh.
Food was pretty good overall.  Was here during late night happy hour and its a pretty good deal compared to other places in the area.  Malysian milk tea was good and interesting.  My own comment is not to get the win tasting pairing.  They seem to have no idea how that works and they just push out all the courses and bring you the wine only when you ask for it.
If you're going here you have to get the 11 course meal! It's a bit pricier then the rest of the menu but definitely worth it! All meals came pretty quickly and tasted true to authentic Malaysian plates. They also had a very delicious sangria cocktail.

Satisfying, but a little underwhelming. Disclaimer: I am in no way an expert on Malaysian dining. Living in Portland, I have access to phenomenal Thai and Vietnamese food, but Malaysian is something our city has yet to embrace. So my first time was in Sydney ... and it was a revelation. I was very excited to get another fix while staying in Vancouver, but the food here couldn't quite live up to that magical first time. The sampler appetizer was a nice array, all the same (we couldn't put our finger on it, but something about the calamari breading was really addictive), and the Mee Goreng had a nice enough flavor, though texturally, it was kind of a slop. Small but nice selection of local brews was a pleasant surprise, and service was friendly.

Chinese takeout. 3 small tables inside so be aware of that. This my first time here and got curry chicken for lunch. It is delicious. A lot of onions so if that isn't your thing be sure to ask for new none or less. Unlike most Chinese fast food, you will be so happy to see that it is clean inside and so is the bathroom. Also the people are very very friendly. I wish I would have known about this place for years since I drive by and work close but never would have stopped based on what it looks like outside. Don't let that fool you, the plaza is finishing up renovations so I hope this helps their business. I will be back to try all of the other dishes!
I was in town for a few days,  staying in Altamonte  Springs,  and I had an urge for really good Chinese food.  I yelped and came across this little gem... So glad I went despite the nasty traffic. The owners are super nice and super friendly!   The prices are very reasonable and the food is amazing!  The beef with oyster sauce and chicken in black bean sauce dishes were delicious and the chicken chow fun (which I was told was really good that day) was so good I couldn't stop eating it!  Add in the yummy egg roll and this meal really hit the spot.  Highly recommended!
"I just tried China Moon take out....OMG..I was a chef and have spent time learning how to cook Asian food.  I learned that sesame chicken should be made with thigh meat, first braised and then deep fried and tossed with a light vinegar and sweet sauce.  I haven't had sesame chicken this good since the NY china town chef showed me how to make it..until now.  

We also got Beef Chow Mien.  It reminded me of the  chow mien we used to get at a a hole in wall restaurant in Boulder, CO back in the 60's.  The cook there was straight from China and had a way with a wok.  

So much flavor.  This place isn't fancy, it is in a strip mall and I recommend taking it home, but wow, it is so much better than a local staple Longwood restaurant Chinese/sushi  that used to be great, but has gone downhill in the past 8-10 months.

Please try this hometown restaurant and support local business.  These folks are great I highly recommend you give them a shot Longwood...so that they are able to stick around!

Oh..and the prices are great!"
Best quick Chinese food I've had in the Orlando area since I've lived here! I order from there a few times a month. I always try different menu items and have not been disappointed yet! The owners are extremely friendly and accommodating. Give them a try!
Best Chinese around, everything tastes fresh and the inside is very clean. Really nice people. Don't go anywhere else, this is the place.
This is a hidden treasure..  The location is lonely beside a beverage store but nothing else.  It gets dark there at night.  Find your way into a very clean 3-4 table dining area.  The food is really good, tasty and seasoned very well.. I am a visitor to the area and love finding these places :). I'll be back.
"Sometimes you just need to find a good Chinese takeout place and until recently, I had been searching for one.  I've found places where they may have one or two tasty items, but at China Moon everything is tasty!

I came across this little gem over the Christmas holiday thanks you ""Yelpers"" out there.  I was searching for something near my home in Winter Springs and saw that this place had 4.5 stars.  I had initially started out thinking pizza but hey, Chinese is good to so en route to Luna's the hubs and I made the switch. 

The restaurant is tiny.  I mean that literally.  It's tucked into a strip mall next to a package/convenience store and as mentioned it's not well lit outside.  I was expecting the inside to be similar to all other take out places I've been with the sad Formica tables and vinyl chair showing wear but man was I wrong! The inside is bright...lots of light and painted a warm
gray/green.  The floor is new and unscuffed and the baseboards and door trims are bright white. There are some abstract works of art on the walls and it's clear that the owners take pride in their establishment. 

As for the owners this is a true family run establishment. Being that we were there during the holiday, the daughters were working the front while mom and dad prepared the food.  They took or orders and joked around not only with us, but with each other.  The highlight was when one sister patted the head of the other and said ""Good job Annie...I knew you could do it""!  We later found out that ""Annie"" was the older of the two girls.  It may sound odd, but for a moment it felt like I was part of their family!

As if cleanliness and family aren't already enough, the food is...well, the food is amazing. The dinner combos are a great deal.  Large in portions of the entree plus an eggroll and soup.  We had the General Tso's Chicken, Five Flavor Chicken, Mongolian Beef and Kung Pao Chicken.  The dinner's come with pork fried rice but I asked for a substitution of white rice with the Gen Tso's and they were very accommodating.  I had also ordered some steamed vegetable dumplings.  They were out of those and the owner came over to apologize and offered me another appie for the same price.  I asked if she had the pork dumplings, which she did, so I took those instead. Everything was perfect.  The eggrolls were crisp and not greasy, the fried rice was smokey and filled with roast pork, the green onions in the Mongolian Beef were still crispy tender, the sauces were not too sweet or too salty...it was simply lovely.  
Since our initial visit we have been back trying the egg drop soup, wonton soup and Mooshu Chicken.

The prices may be a tiny bit more (if at all) than other places and they don't do the ""Spend $30 get a Quart of free soup"" that I've seen other placed do but for a family of 4 it seemed average to me at $40. And the quality is well worth the cost. 

If you are in the Longwood area near Ronald Reagan Blvd, or even if you aren't, you should definitely make a stop by Chin Moon!

Pros:
- Food is amazing and they have a few extra menu items you don't often see such as Mooshu, Chop Suey, Chow Mein and Mei Fun.
- Owners are great! They talk with you while they cook your food and keep you updated as to how much longer you have.
- Pristine clean!!! 

Cons:
- Tiny inside...8 seats only so it's really meant to grab and go (which means you have to wait to eat the amazing food!)"
"This small, immaculate restaurant is easy to miss tucked in a small strip mall on a busy, mostly industrial road. Don't pass this restaurant by, though! You will be glad you stopped for food here!  

I judge my Chinese restaurants by the quality of their dumplings. China Moon did not disappoint!  They had both steamed & fried pork dumplings.  Their filling was flavorful, the wrappers the perfect thickness--thick enough to hold together but not so thick to be doughy and overpower the filling. We also ordered the seafood soup for 2.  The portion was enough for 4, and contained a plethora of fresh seafood and veggies.  The broth was light and flavorful, and you could actually taste the food, unlike other soups I have had that are so overly salted or seasoned that you don't taste anything else.  We also had the Ma Po Tofu, (requested without hot peppers) which was delicious, flavorful, in a nice brown sauce that again, didn't overpower the tofu.  The portions are generous, and the prices are very reasonable.

We will definitely be going back often and trying other items on the menu.  (We have already preordered a large quantity of dumplings for a party coming up in a couple weeks)!"

My boyfriend and I are regulars and always struggle to decide between trying something new and getting our favorites (including the bourbon chicken!!). The amount of food you get is enough to feed a small army! It's fantastic. The owners are just so nice and friendly. Truly a joyful experience!
"Oooh, this Banana Leaf is so much better than the one in Los Angeles! The location is very spacious, comfortable, and decorated in a way that gives it a nice Southeastern vibe.

We came here as a large group, so we were able to share a couple things. We got the fried calamari and roti pratas to share. Each person ordered a version of curry or fried rice, all which were good. I ordered the Singaporean Laksa (as always). 

The broth was rich with coconut milk, which I like a lot. Apparently authentic laksa doesn't is more seafoody and less coconutty - but I prefer the more Westernized version. There were a LOT of noodles in my dish, which made less room for soup. Sad :( 

The nasi goreng was more tomato-y than usual. Not sure if it's supposed to taste like that, but my friends liked it so I guess that's good!

I personally loved the roti and calamari. The roti had a nice hint of sweetness to it - not too powerful, but just a hint, so that you'd want more. The calamari was very umami and did not taste oily or fried, even though it was.

I'd love to come back! The menu was very extensive, which is always exciting.

Yelp 100 Challenge 2017 (32/100)"
"Gotta write a review for one of my favourite restaurants in Vancouver! If you want Banana Leaf, this location is the best. 
Service is great and they remember all my preferences.
Seafood dishes are great, but my absolute favourite is the roti canai. Fluffy, perfectly crispy with that magical dipping sauce. I keep the sauce to mix with entrees because it is that good. They used to have this chicken and gado gado with rice, but it is not longer on the menu but the kitchen does make exceptions. I love the peanuts on the chicken skewers! 

Groups also have the option of a tasting menu.

I like to come for lunch because there is quite a large price jump when you come eat dinner. Surprisingly it usually isn't too packed on the weekend. 

They have a patio for those summer days."
"A friend and I went here for the first time recently on one of our weekly lunches. The decor is a little kitsch, but there was plenty or space and it was cosy. We arrived for a late lunch.

They were very accommodating in doing a vegetarian adaptation of a laksa - so we both had that. We also ordered a wonderful salad as a side - the papaya one - it was fresh and crunchy and tasty. We also had a starter - I think it was spring rolls - these were tasty, but nothing outstanding.

The laksa was fresh and the noodles were good, but I would have liked a bit more veggies and tofu - I love that big bowl of goodness feeling. The soup was a little too spicy for me in a few places - I had a coughing fit twice - and that is unusual for me - I each spicy Asian food regularly.

We also had a few cocktails to go with lunch. The one I had was great, but my friend had the lychee mojito. She didn't like it and even this week when we had lunch somewhere else, she mentioned again how much she didn't like it and that it had a strange lingering after taste. She reminded me to mention it in my review!

Overall, this was a nice lunch option, but nothing special. We also felt hurried to finish up - they gave us the nudge twice."
"This is by far my favorite Malaysian restaurant in Vancouver, or anywhere for that matter. The restaurant is full of bright colours, with kites dangling from the ceiling and the wait staff dressed in semi-traditional outfits, which are just as colourful as the walls here.

It was pretty clean when I went, I'm not sure if this was before or after the public health hubbub. Things seemed pretty normal, even impressive, to me.

My favorite dish is the fried rice served in a pineapple half. How often is it that you can eat your food out of a pineapple? The satay -- chicken, beef, or pork -- is all good, smothered in delicious peanut sauce that will have you craving more. 

Even my Malaysian boyfriend admitted this place wasn't too bad for fusion cuisine, and said it was way better than places like Tropika. And he's picky when it comes to restaurants! The food isn't as spicy as it probably would be in Malaysia, but then again, this isn't exactly Malaysia and not everybody has tastebuds that can withstand the powers of chili!"

"I went here hoping to be reminded of flavors and things I had in Singapore.  That might of have set my expectations too high.  So take that in to consideration if you are trying to interpret my review, but I know others in similar hunger for laksa or chicken rice so it might be more useful for them.  

I didn't even try the chicken rice, mainly because there was no mention of the different chili sauces that accompany it.  That was what made this dish for me, the different sauces and one of the major ones not mentioned on the menu, I wasn't going to order it.  

Instead we tried four things, the roti, the lettuce wraps (I know, not traditional but sounded good), the laksa and Char Kuey Teow.  The roti were a bit odd, they had a hint of sweetness that threw me off.  They were light and had the right bit of crispness, but the flavour seemed odd to me.  Maybe a regional variation?  But the curry that came with it was just sad.  More like a brown gravy dipping sauce and no real aromatic spices or flavor.  The lettuce wraps were good.  The chicken version had a nice flavor and actually I put some of the filling on my roti which was actually pretty good.  The Char Kuey Teow was pretty decent but was missing something, maybe a hint of dark soy or a pinch of salt, it was close to what I remember, just needed some cockles!  but I know those are something you aren't going to find around here.  

The Laksa was just odd.  Not spicy at all.  But I didn't get any of the flavor from shrimp paste and it almost tasted like they finished it with cream.  And the noodles were still a bit stiff.  We kept trying to decided if we should send it back because the noodles were so underdone, but sitting a bit let them finish cooking in the laksa.  I know this can be tricky, but how long has this place been here?  Also, servers kept trying to take our plates while we were still eating off them.  As I write this I'm not sure if I shouldn't change this to a two star review.  The decent Char Kuey Teow is what is saving them."
"The Banana Leaf came highly recommended so we knew we were in for a treat.
Just to clarify we are food freaks (1 x lactose intolerant and 1 x vegetarian) so sometimes eating out for us and having a choice can be a little challenging.  We went through the menu with our server just to confirm what had shrimp and fish sauce so that we made the correct choices.  Our server knew the menu so well and made some fantastic recommendations.  
The shredded mango salad is a phenomenal salad.  The flavours are sublime.  Just a shame it had fish sauce in it so my husband couldn't enjoy it as well.  The lamb shank was heavenly - the meat fell off the bone and the sauce/gravy was a perfect complement.  Again such subtle and well matched flavours.  The tofu starter with sweet chilli was fantastic and would have been an awesome lunch dish.  
The service was excellent and the bill not too steep considering we'd both had starters, entrees and shared a bottle of Mission Hill.  
The only weird thing about the Banana Leaf was the music in the background - hardcore dance/trance!  It was such a bizarre choice of music for this restaurant and didn't really want to make us hand around for dessert."
"So we were walking aimlessly one summer evening on Broadway, on a holiday, and most restaurants from Cambie onwards was closed, or looked kind of empty.

We stumbled upon Banana Leaf which looked bustling (we had already heard some pretty good reviews from our friends).  We were seated pretty quickly and I started off with a Tiger beer.

We started off with the Steamed Mussels in Ginger & Cumin Coconut Sauce.  The sauce was amazing... almost... too amazing.  In fact, it's almost unfair how amazing this dish is.

We then moved onto the Seafood & Chicken Fried Rice in Pineapple Boat  and the Eggplant in Dried Shrimp with Basil.  I highly recommend both of these. 

The rice dish was flavorful with a garden of different seafood and pineapple.  And the eggplant dish worked really well with the rice.. the rice soaks up the sauce from the eggplant... and I'm pretty sure if you combine the two, you get Captain Planet and the Planeteers.

The price is fair and  I look forward to eating there again."
Came here with a friend from out of town, we ordered the appetizer selection (all delicious except I would skip the calamari next time, it wasn't great), their delicious veg & tofu yellow curry which has tons of tofu & vegetables in it, and the sambal prawns with a side of rice. SOOO goood!! Service was attentive, the server had no issue with us switching our appetizers at the last minute and graciously accommodated our fickleness.
Just did a lunch a Banana Leaf ... it was still fine, but not quite as good as before ... even the roti was not as I-just-can't-help-myself tasty as usual ... please, Banana Leafers, let it just have been a bad day.  You're still my favorite sit-down lunch near VGH.
I highly recommend the 7 course $25 dinner. Great presentation, great portions, great taste. Get er dun!

"Growing up in Malaysia, we couldn't pass up the opportunity to eat here. We ordered beef rendang, gado gado salad (this salad is actually of Indonesian origins) and 'sambal okra, brinjal, green beans and shrimps' (all in one dish).

The beef cubes/chunks were nicely marinated, and the rendang sauce was more curry in texture (in Malaysia, the rendang sauce is much thicker, as one needs to cook it several hours). Despite this, the rendang curry was just as flavorful. I use the curry label to describe the constituency, rather than the flavor. The bowl was spooned clean. The kaffir lime leaves added to the flavor.

Gado gado salad has steamed bean sprouts, slices of hard boiled eggs, green beans and small chunks of potatoes. Peanut sauce is poured over all these. The key is peanut sauce. This was done just right, and it help pull the salad altogether.

The last dish must be a chef's special creation, as this was the first time we ate a mix of these three vegetables. It was a hit for us. The shrimps in this dish provided some nice meaty texture, though we enjoyed the vegetables by themselves in the sambal sauce just as much.

I do not pass on any Malaysian dessert with gula melaka (coconut sugar). Unfortunately, there wasn't that much gula melaka in the two desserts we chose, which is a shame.

I chose the sticky rice with mango. What makes or breaks this dessert (besides the gula melaka sauce) is the sweetness of the mango slices. That was the case last night, as the mango slices were a bit tart.

My wife had the kuih dadar, which is flour wrapping with shredded coconut stuffings, soaked with his melaka. This was much better. There were 4 rolls, so, one could share that dessert!

We enjoyed our meal and would come back again when we are back in Vancouver BC."
"I think a lot more foods would taste better presented in half a pineapple.
The front of the dining area has a giant safe.  What's in the safe?  Magic Treasure?  Servers who refuse to sing happy birthday to diners?  Diners who refuse to pay their bill?  Yelpers want to know."
"My friends called me out for a dinner since they didn't have plans this evening and Banana Leaf was the call for the night. I arrived first to get us the walk-in space, welcomed by an extremely small waiting area (considering how popular they are, bad move). The music was quite loud and I could barely hear myself let alone my friends. We were seated and weren't given any (audible) introduction to our server prior which kind of irked me. We each ordered a dish and shared appetizers with each other which went pretty smoothly. 

The food took a little bit to come out (understandably, full house) however, my main issue was the order that the food came out in. We first received one of our entrees followed by one of our appetizers. About 5 minutes after, the three entrees came with another 5 before  getting the 2nd appetizer. First, most restaurants bring appetizers out before any entrees for the sake of being an ""appetizer"". Secondly, our friend didn't want to eat without the rest of us getting our entrees and I can only presume his food lost its heat after such a wait. None of the servers had followed up to tell us that there was going to be a wait for the other appetizers or entrees which was extremely disappointing.

To the food. I shared the calamari with my friend and had the Singapore Laksa. The calamari was well flavored and the sauce accompanying had a good tang to it. The laksa however had various points of disappointment. I first noticed how lacking the toppings were. There were literally 2 pieces of chicken, squid, and egg in my bowl. In particular, the egg sections were EXTREMELY small and had no yolk (what a joke!). Nevertheless, I was disappointed with their advertisement of toppings. The flavor of the soup was decent and had an odd ""eggy"" texture , and the noodles were strangely textured, presuming starchy noodles, doesn't have that degree of softness that i'm used to)

All in all, the food was mediocre at best and service was under that. I would only go again under ""mandatory"" conditions."
"We had dinner twice in this restaurant during our recent visit to Vancouver. The restaurant seems to be popular amongst locals as it was full both times we visited. However, the wait time was short and the host was very efficient.

Food is really good and portions are generous, meant to be shared. Service is great considering they were busy but still served our fairly big group of 8 within a decent amount of time.

My personal recommendation will be to get the Nasi Goring rice, Rendang beef curry and Roti Canai. Any combination of these three items were delicious. They have a lamb shank item on the menu which also should get an honourable mention."
Pretty good food and fast service. Everything I ordered was packed with flavor. The portions were kind of small especially for the price of some of the dishes. the dishes are meant to be shared, so if you are dining with a larger party of 8 for example, then it would be wise to order 2 of a couple dishes.
"I really had a one of a kind experience here! 

First of all, the interior design. It was very authentic, the colours of the walls, the art hung on the walls, the plants and the music - all combined into a perfect ethnic blend. The waitresses all wore traditional aprons, too. 

I strongly recommend that you do get rice. The dishes only come with meat/veggies, but you need rice for it to make sense. We ordered the appetizer sampler to share and it was great - although there were 3 people sharing a 2-people sampler, we made it work. I also recommend getting the fresh coconut drink that they bring in an actual coconut. It really helps to drink it when the food gets a little too spicy. The Malaysian bone-in chicken was great(very tender), and so was the kung pow one, the prawn dish was incredible also. I kept saying that it was like having a party in my mouth - so much flavour, it was almost shocking! The taste was almost edgy and I loved it. The fact that I don't usually succumb to spicy food might have contributed to that.

All in all, I had a great evening. When I decide to have Malaysian food again, I know it's gonna be this place that I'll come back to.

Also, we came about 1 hour before closing. They mentioned that we need to order asap, but at the same time we didn't feel rushed at all. The waiter came only when we were ready and when it was time to close, no one was urging us to finish sooner."
"I have not dined at Banana Leaf for years and I ended up here during a group dinner. We tried the 9 course menu for $30. The menu was a nice mix of Malaysian food. Although not the most authentic tasting, the food was good for what it was and for the price.  

My favourite was the roti canai and chicken skewers. I love the fluffy bread dipped in curry. I think the curry sauce could be more flavourful and aromatic. Chicken skewers and peanut sauce can never go wrong.

The service was really good. I am not sure if it was because gratuity was already built in. Our server was very good at refilling drinks, checking up on us regularly and clearing plates.

The ambiance is nice and inviting. There is plenty of seating and the restaurant can accommodate large groups."
The service was kind and attentive. I enjoyed the rendang and sambal green beans. The price was reasonable. I will be back.
"Some definite hits and misses in a sanitized Malaysian restaurant environment.

Ugh, both were cloyingly sweet and we plead temporary insanity for even thinking that we would enjoy them. 

We started with their appetizer plate for 2 which was somewhat disappointing. It was comprised of a salad, calamari, chicken satays, roti canai and spring rolls. For the price, the portions we received were minuscule. I looked enviously upon neighboring tables which had ordered the individual appetizers for a fraction of the price and received far larger portions.

For mains we ordered The Sambal Chili Pawns, the Malaysian bone-in Curry Chicken and the Seafood Char Kuey Teow Noodles. All of the dishes were well balanced with regard to spice and flavour and were thoroughly enjoyed. One major misstep was the steamed rice that accompanied it, the rice was mushy! Seriously,a restaurant that prepares an Asian cuisine that can't cook rice?

Our server, other than having lousy taste in cocktails, was pleasant and attentive. This restaurant might be the ideal place to go with our less adventurous friends that we can't convince to go to some of the hole in the walls that we frequent."

"I've been to Banana Leaf's other locations around the city and this is just as good.  Located on Robson but further down towards the seawall or Denman. "I've been to this location a few times and haven't been disappointed yet. Overall their food is solid, decor is nice, and the staff friendly and helpful. 

On my last visit, I brought some out of town guests for lunch here. We decided to all try the Big Lunch Sampler from their prix fixe menu.  They served up the food on big plates to share the food. The nice thing is that they don't force you to pay $17 for each person in the party. You just tell them how many portions you like (minimum six portions). So if you have young kids who don't eat much you don't have pay for them. 

When the first few dishes started to come out I was a bit worried as the portions looked small. However, as more and more food came out my worries were alleviated. "I've been to all three downtown Banana Leaf locations and always enjoyed it. Went here most recently on a Sunday just after lunch and the place was cool, well-ventilated and shady, and not very busy. Service was quick and friendly, too!

And as always, there were some pretty good deals. I had a $15 lunch platter with a lot of variety, and everything from the salad to the calamari rings to the kung pao chicken was flavourful and nicely prepared. I also had a cocktail called a Malaysian Jungle Bird that tasted pretty good, though cocktails are always on the expensive side, even here.

The dessert was a surprise - I've had their coconut pana cotta before and thought it was just okay, but this time it was really excellent. Maybe they've changed the recipe? Either way it was creamier and had more flavour, came topped with yummy fruit bits, and the syrup blended in nicely with the rest.

This Banana Leaf and the others are a great place to grab something casual and fun to eat, and this location might be the nicest both in terms of atmosphere and traffic. I always like going here!"

"We had a very enjoyable dinner here on a Friday night, although we showed up at 7:30pm on a Friday night with no prior reservation, they were able to fit us in a nice table upstairs. There was a bit of a crowd as the night went on by the time we left at ~9pm. 

Food is pretty good, flavourful and a bit heavy as expected for Malaysian/Singaporean food. We ordered:

- appetizer sampler $18 (fruit and veggie salad (heavy sauce), 2 fried eggrolls, 2 fried squid rings, 2 chicken satay skewers, 3 pieces of Roti bread... best part is the 3 part sauce: peanut, satay soy, and the one for the Roti.. ?)
- Assam curry with seafood (a little bit of scallops, prawn, eggplant, bell pepper, some other veggies)
- Nasi goreng (seafood fried rice)
- Singapore Laksa (coconut based rice noodle dish)
- lamb shank -- the meat is so tender it's falling off the bone, I think they made this as it's ordered so it took a while to come out of the kitchen and was the last dish served. 

Overall, the deal was delicious, again, generous portions for our party of 4, and the bill came out to a reasonable ~$100 total (tax + tip included), as I would expect for a nice sit down restaurant on Robson street. 

Next time, I will try the ""Banana Leaf"" branch on Davie street, that one is definitely smaller in scale and not as fancy in deco though."
"Came after a long hike to have a few beers and some food. Service was a little slow and it took about 15m to get 5 of us seated at 3pm, even though the place wasnt very busy. "Here is another lunch review. 

They are still having lunch specials for $6.95 now (notice the $1.00 increase from last time), and the items are still pretty much the same. A laksa and a rice dish. 

I will refrain from saying too much about the food as my feedback has not changed since my last visit. I asked for extra broth again as I can never have enough. What I would really like to comment on this time is the disappointing service I received today. 

Generally, I do not care for much service. I expect you to know your menu, answer my questions, take my order and bring me my food. Wait... Is it too much to ask that a waiter/waitress knows the cuisine? 

Here's my story: 
When I ordered the Singapore Laksa lunch special, I said I'd like to change the rice noodle to the yellow noodle. She looks at me blankly. So, I said it again. This time I referred to it as mee, which is the proper term for it. She continues to stare blankly. My last attempt was to call it egg noodle. She started to frown as though I had been a hand full just then. She snorts: ""...so, just the egg noodle?""

Then, we got into the extra broth confusion. I said: ""and with extra broth, please."" She gives me the SAME BLANK STARE and so my husband chimes in explaining that the broth gets soaked up by the noodle, yadaa yadaa, and may we please just get a little more broth with the noodles. ""OK"", she snorted again. 

**Slight addition to this review: my bowl of laksa came with the chopsticks stabbed in it. Aside from it being a disaster-spill waiting to happen, that is also how you serve food to dead people in some cultures. Thanks, waiter/waitress.

We Malaysians pride ourselves for the most friendly and efficient service. Our cooks back home are always versatile and will make any food you order to your liking, even if it means changing almost everything about it. Of course we do not expect this sort of treatment here, but we can at least uphold the quality of service. Please, teach your waiters and waitresses a lot more about our cuisine. Otherwise, you cannot pass yourselves off as an ""authentic"" Malaysian restaurant. 

It is one thing to be an unfriendly waiter/waitress. It is entirely another to be an obnoxious and arrogant one. You are not fooling anyone."
"Wow. Just wow. Rating is on food alone.

J and I rented bikes and biked around Stanley Park and the city of Vancouver for about 2 and a half hours. We were STARVING by the time we finished biking. And the closest and most delicious sounding place to get some grub? Banana Leaf. ohhhh mmmmyyyy goooodnesss. 

Roti Canai. Sambal Green Beans with beef added. Ipoh Char Hor Fun. 2 orders of Jasmine Rice. Done. Killed it. Freaking delicious.

"First time dining at a Banana Leaf, and first time trying Malaysian food. I had the Char Kuey Teow, which I found to be very similar to the Thai dish Pad See-Ew. I love the latter, so I quite liked the former as well. My father had the Pineapple Seafood Fried Rice, which was both mild and complex in flavor. I think we both would have liked a little more oomph from the rice, but we agreed that it was very tasty anyway.

My dish was a good portion for the price ($15). My father's rice was, in my opinion, just a little expensive for what it was ($17). HOWEVER, we ordered from the Buy One Take One Home menu, which meant that we each got to take home another entire serving of both our meals. Which made our food extremely inexpensive for what we got. TWO full meals each, for $15 and $17 respectively? Wow!

(Note: Our Pineapple Seafood Rice didn't come with a big chunk of pineapple, the way it seems to when you order it off the regular menu - which is a shame, since I think that bit of extra presentation makes a HUGE difference in how the dish is perceived.) 

Overall, I wouldn't say I was utterly blown away by the food here, but I definitely enjoyed it. Their BOGO dinner deal is pretty fabulous value for your money, and I'd definitely like to go back and try more items from the menu.

I just wish their upstairs area was open more of the time. I'd really like to eat up there, but it always seems to be closed off whenever I go by."

Food:

Veggie springrolls: Four to an order, came out piping hot with a zippy sauce. They were a bit greasy though, but I really liked the sauce.

"It's a shame that I can't like this place more. I caved -- FINALLY! -- and popped in for lunch. Since they were having a customer appreciation special, I decided to go with that. Lunch for $5.95! 

The Laksa for lunch special, although stated as ""Singaporean"", shares the same curry with the Malaysian Laksa on their menu (I'm almost certain). The main difference: noodle. Singapore Laksa - rice noodle; Malaysian Laksa: egg noodle.

I ordered the Singapore Laksa on lunch special, changed the noodle and practically made it a Malaysian Laksa, for the price of the lunch special. The curry came a little short in quantity. Please, you can't serve a true blooded Malaysian a half bowl of curry and call it a meal. Naturally, I asked for more curry. Oh boy, did I get more curry! They brought me a big bowl of curry, and probably went snickering back into the kitchen. Snicker no more, I finished it. The verdict: NOT BAD AT ALL! I expected worse! It was nicely spiced, coconut creamed, and just generally quite flavorful. It gives me hope for a 4-star review next time around! 

The service was OK. I don't need much of that around here. The girls were very friendly. 

The prices are steep. But my trick around that is to be smart when you order! Only order what is worth the price. I know it's easier said than done, but try!

Let's do this again, Banana Leaf!"
"This place was pretty good.  We tried a few different items from their menu and everything was flavored pretty well.  I've been to many Malaysian restaurants and I can't say this was the best...the flavors just weren't as strong as I've had in other spots.  

I will say that they do have fun and creative cocktails and the service was excellent and friendly."

"Mmmmm. I loved Banana Leaf when it was on Denman (and that's still my favorite location, though I haven't been in ages), and then it opened up this location...right across the street from my apartment. 
I'm doomed to spend all my money on Assam Curry Tofu and on Singapore Laksa (which PS: is on special for 6.95 Mon-Thurs until 3pm, whaaaat). I get a young coconut for dessert, which freshens my curry breath before I step outside, and ensures that my food-baby belly is hydrated. 
I'm vegetarian, and there are some good options on the menu; ask your server though... things like the Sambal Green Beans are a silly thing to get vegetarian because the sambal is what makes it special, and that's got shrimp paste in it, so they'll just make it with soy sauce and garlic, which you could do at home. Get something you CAN'T make, like the veggie lettuce wrap (whose default is pretty spicy, heads up!)

Staff are friendly and make a point of remembering regulars :) Some days, I have to make sure I walk on the other side of the street so I don't find myself going in for dinner just to say hi."
A Singapore/Malay oasis in the North America. It's a large establishment with penty of seating outside and inside. Caters well to large groups and allows for reservation. It was pretty packed on the weekend evening that we had walked in but we were able to secure a place soon enough. We had chicken curry, banana leaf fish and of course, roti canai. The food was on the spicier side but very authentic and delicious! High recommended and totally worth the trip to Vancouver for us Seattleites.
"This is a classic need a half star situation. I would give them a 2.5, just verging onto a 3 star. FYI I would give the Broadway location a 4 star.

This will be my third time eating at this location since they opened and they are yet to live up to their Banana Leaf name in service and food. 

I am confused on the service, I feel like zombies have taken over the staff here, they move exceptionally slow in a dazed fog. On none of my trips have there been more than 1 or 2 other tables but trying to get seated seemed so surprising to the staff. Months later they still seem startled when someone walks in. One time we stood there for 5 minutes while the waitress sat on the ground and wrote out the specials of the day on the blackboard. 

Food is good albeit not consistent. The roti canai seemed a very small portion compared to the Broadway location and the curry sauce runny. The lettuce wrap filling was yummy but the lettuce leaves though big and fresh were drippy with water, we had to dry them on our napkins! My Char Kuey Teow was just how I liked, perfect blend of flavour,  but I ordered Chinese sausage with it and they forgot completely. Satay is always good, a staple on my order roster. I also normally order the chicken curry and sambal green beans which are superb.

Honestly, I can't remember much about the location, being summer I have eaten on the patio twice and just inside the door the last time. I remember high ceilings, traditional decor and a little more fancy than the other locations. 

Prices are fair, they have gone up over the years and it's not a cheap Asian meal. You are looking at least $50 for 2 people with appetizers and main, no alcohol. Lunch specials are approximately $15-18 and a broad selection to choose from.

Ah- the kalamansi soda is fabulous. I used to have this daily when I was in the Philippines. Kalamansis are like sweeter limes.

"Bottom Line:  Mediocre service contrasted by bold, uneven dishes.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is one of the last meals I ate with my brother in law, known as 'Gerald ""Lutz911"" L.' on yelp.  He passed away last night in a motorcycle accident.  He really enjoyed yelping, so I decided to write this review...

Gerald and I often coordinated our family visits by consulting yelp for where to take the family to dinner.  We were in Vancouver BC to bring my daughter to college -a big extended family affair - and after striking out at our top yelp picks Kingyo, Guu and Ramen Santouka  for our party of 8 (so many Vancouver restaurants are soooo small!) - we landed at another yelp pick, Banana Leaf.

It should be noted that this Banana Leaf is the lowest scoring of all the branches in the chain.  This is important, because the food here was good, but uneven...service lame.  I would surmise you probably wouldn't have these issues at other Banana Leaf restaurants and get a 4 or 5 star experience instead.

The average price for even vegetable dishes was a little high in my opinion - about $14.  Things like the eggplant in oyster sauce with basil were so delicious as to be worth it; a complex dish that had me dissecting each bite so I could imitate it at home, it had basil, fresh ginger playing against dried shrimp and soy sauce...and I suspect some XO sauce.  Very satisfying.

Unfortunately, the lamb curry - an iconic dish in Malaysian cuisine - lacked punch.  It had barely any curry sauce, no spice to it (a hallmark of this dish), and I suspect I know why sauce was lacking:  the lamb had been braised to the point of burning.  You know that taste you get when some meat burns and that smoke permeates the dish?  Yeah...that taste.  Not worth $18 by any stretch.

Gerald loved the Mee Goreng and the Mussels in Cumin and Ginger sauce that he chose.  He was always good at picking out strengths on a menu.  The mussels in particular would well worth the $8, quite a deal for about 8 to 10 plump, perfectly cooked mussels in a creamy, pungent sauce worthy of spooning on rice.

The service was lacking.  Inattentive on refilling water, not pulling dirty plates.  They were obviously in a hurry to get off work (we came near closing)...but, honestly, I can't think about it now....because I won't eat with Gerald again and now it seems so small..."
"We had a supper for four, on saturday evening, outside in the patio. 
The waitress was very friendly and effective. For an ultimative experience they should exchange the polluted and damaged disgusting tablecloth.
All the meals were served together and hot. My curry was of rich flavor and my sons meal were the best prawns ever, he told me. All the meals were of  original taste and recommendable. This day we had the bettler  choice sitting in the patio, behause airconditioning was temporarilly out order."
"Finding ourselves in the West End, which is a rare occasion, we had intended on visiting a particular restaurant on Robson Street but, after seeing the long lineup queuing outside, we headed over to nearby Banana Leaf instead.

Banana Leaf is a popular Malaysian eatery with a number of outlets around town. We started out our Sunday morning feast with a Virgin Lychee Mojito ($5) and Curry Spiced Oysters ($12). I've had this slushy drink before in the past but felt like the one served here was a bit lacking in flavour. The deep-fried oysters, however, were on point with a delicately light coating.

One of the things that Banana Leaf is known for is their set meals which lets you try a bunch of different items. When we saw the picture of their Malaysian Brunch ($17), we knew we were going to order it. Served in a cast iron pan, you get everything you need for a perfect meal... tender rendang beef, roti canai with a curry dipping sauce, eggplant fries, krupuk (deep-fried crackers/chips), sayur lemak (vegetable curry), and turmeric rice topped with a fried egg.

We also wound up ordering the Chicken Satay ($8) with a well-balanced peanut-based dipping sauce.

Overall, I'm actually quite pleased that we wound up here instead of our originally planned destination."

"All I can say  is ""thank you Jesus."" Are you kidding me? Is it possible that someone within 100 miles of Orlando actually makes pork fried rice that isn't yellow and loaded up with carrots.  Is it really true that someone within a 100 miles of Orlando makes pork fried rice where you can actually see pieces of pork?  Is it really true that someone within 100 miles actually makes roast pork fried rice that is moist and not greasy? Hallelujah, my 11 year wait is over.  I am euphoric and have been here 4 times since I discovered this place while sipping quality suds at Hourglass Brewery. In fact I walk across the street and eat it over at Hourglass.  The dumplings, all though not packed with meat and slightly blandm are solid and rank high for the area.  The beef is beef.  I repeat, the beef tastes like beef.  Their five flavors sauce is wonderful, off the charts good. They are also are one of the few that know how to make fresh quality chow fun;  it has wonderful flavor.  The vegetables are always fresh if that is your thing.  Keep in mind I am a tough customer so my 4 star rating means go get you some. So why not five stars?  1)  The wonton soup does not have any pork or greens.  Up north and in Chinatowns in NY, Boston and SF you would never see wanton soup served like this, but Central Floridians sadly only get baroness.  Dumping a wanton into plain broth is not wanton soup.  2)  The Jumbo shrimp are not Jumbo. 3) The roast pork fried rice while giving you more than anyone else in the area still has a too high of peas to pork ratio; a little more pork is warranted.I have no problem paying a little more for more pork.  4) no fried noodles and duck sauce given with takeout order.  I will have to see if they have them.  5)  no minced pork in the Shrimp with Lobster Sauce.  Without minced pork, it is simply not Shrimp With Lobster Sauce. The owners are a super nice couple and the place is clean and doesn't have that old over smoked bad oil smell you get when you walk into a bad Chinese restaurant.  The prices are more than reasonable and they offer the smaller size on most dishes.  I implore you to eat here.  This is a welcome and long awaited addition to the area."
