I have refused to eat Chinese food since I returned from a vacation in Beijing and Shanghai several years ago. My husband, knowing my stance on this cuisine, used my love of hot & sour soup to lure me back in, bringing home a steaming hot bowl and egg roll for lunch since I couldn't step away from my work. All I can say is: BEST DANG HOT & SOUR SOUP I'VE EVER HAD! It's so rich and spicy (per our request), with heaps of shrooms and tofu and other yummy veggies. I think this may have convinced me to give Chinese food another try...BUT ONLY AT CHINA MOON!
"I will never order from another Chinese restaurant ever again! They don't deliver, which is sort of a bummer but the Yelp reviews were so good I decided it might be worth the drive. And oh my gosh it so was. We got the sesame chicken dinner combo with wonton soup, a small beef and broccoli, and the crab rangoons. Everything was so delicious. We were able to feed myself, my husband, our daughter, and my father for about twenty bucks--  an incredible deal. The beef was really tender and the veggies were perfectly cooked. The egg rolls and rangoons weren't greasy at all, even though they were fried. I don't think I've ever eaten a more delicious egg roll in my whole life. The wonton soup and the accompanying fried wonton noodle things (I don't know what they're called) were perfect. Seriously, perfect. The places we usually order from over cook their fried noodles- or give us stale ones- but these were light and airy and delicious. The wonton was delicious and had a generous amount of pork inside. I usually just drink the broth from the wonton soup and skip the wonton itself because it's always gross. But I wish I could've eaten a gallon of this!

The restaurant itself was really small but meticulously clean and the owners were so sweet and helpful and seemed actually excited to see me. I never get that from restaurants anymore. I will forever be a China Moon customer!"
I absolutely love the food here.  It doesn't have that cheap feel like most of the other chinese carry out spots around here.  The ones where you get the bright yellow rice instead of real fried rice.  The owners are the nicest people.  They always remember me and are in great spirits even after working there all day.  Try the sa char beef.  I highly recommend it.
Tonight I ordered the sesame chicken w steamed rice and the sweet and sour chicken. Hands down the best sesame chicken I've ever had. It was so fresh and flavorful. My son loved the sweet and sour chicken. The customer service here is also very good. They always have a smile and warm welcome. I will be visiting this place more often. It is also very, very clean. It's more of a take out place than dine in but worth it.
I'm a huge Asian foodie and let me tell you ... THIS IS THE BEST CHINESE FOOD IVE EVER HAD !!!  The food is super fresh!!! I'm so happy I found this please. The owners are very friendly and the place is extremely clean! I recommend anyone to try this place ;)
I have never seen such a clean Chinese food take out spot. Maybe I'm just use to the NY Chinese food always being questionable, don't get me wrong it's delicious but you are always wondering if it's really chicken they are serving you. This place was so clean and the food was so fresh it blew my mind! Everything we had was delicious and the owner was so sweet. It's definitely where I will be getting my Chinese food from.
Excellent Chinese food and great dinner specials! It may be a tiny restaurant but the couple who cook the food and all in the restaurant have big hearts and cook excellent food.  The wonton and egg drop soups were wonderful, The eggrolls hot and crispy, and both the Mongolian beef and the general Tso's chicken were excellent. We will be back again and highly recommend China Moon.
This was our first time with takeout from here. This is probably the best Chinese takeout that I have had anywhere in Central Florida. Everything tastes fresh and the woman who took the order on the phone and rang me up was extremely nice. The Egg rolls tasted extremely fresh. The wonton soup and egg drop soup were good. We will order from here again!
Great food and very friendly owners. They always remember us. We have been ordering take away from them for over a year. Never an incorrect order and never any quality problems with the food. Just a great hometown restaurant.
"Being born and raised in NYC, I grew up on take out so I know what true authentic NYC-Style Chinese food is.  Sadly, most places outside of the Big Apple claim to be authentic but rarely are. This is NOT the case with China Moon! It's as authentic as it gets. There is only one other place I've been outside of NYC that gets is right (located in St. Cloud).  China Moon was a cute and tiny place. It was clean and inviting. The staff was absolutely terrific, so nice and friendly. The food was shockingly good and it's hands-down our new go-to Chinese spot. 
We ordered the lunch specials which were very inexpensive and even came with a drink!  We ordered the Chicken and mixed vegetables with pork fried rice and also the sesame chicken along with an egg roll. Everything was fresh, tasty, and finally satisfied our craving for authentic NYC style Chinese food. I must also add that the egg roll was really good and that's coming from someone who has never been a big fan of egg rolls.  We will see you soon our China Moon!"
"This place is legit, I am not saying the best Chinese food I've had, but very well seasoned and with pretty good ingredients. ""Everything is made to order"" is their logo, implying that they cook everything when ordered. This motto is used as an apology to the time it takes to make the food, which is a bit longer than any other Chinese restaurant around town. 

The ingredients are pretty good, the crunchy stuff is really crunchy, the veggies are also a bit fresher and crunchier than other restaurants, the fried rice is pretty good, and I specially like the lo-mein because it is not sour, since some places add rice vinegar to lo-mein. Not here.

The place is small, three tables, they have drinks for lunch specials, and a bathroom. Not a lot of traffic, but a steady flow. I like it, I would go back."
Best Chinese food I've had in awhile what are the general tso chicken with fried rice wonton soup n a pork egg roll everything was delicious when I went to pick up my meal I was greeted by a very nice lady I'm assuming was the owner I had asked for hot oil and she even put it in a separate little baggie inside my bag so it doesn't spell very thoughtful people reasonably priced and absolutely amazing this is my new favorite Chinese food place in the area will be back here many times in the future
Food is great and the service is so nice and sweet! I will always get my food here when I am in the area. They are open late too which is always very convenient!

The owner/server/cashier/chef was friendly, easygoing, and seemed to cooked from the heart. His food was delicious, plentifully portioned, and well priced. He cooked all of it in under 15 minutes.

Highly recommended... We will be back!

I decided to try this place because of all the positive reviews on here. Honestly, I don't understand the 5 star reviews. The chicken and beef were both rubbery and weird tasting. I could immediately tell it was bad quality meat. My boyfriend still ate it, but he agreed it was a strange consistency. The veggies and noodles were ok but nothing to write home about. When picking up the take out, the owner was very nice. However, The quality of the food needs to be improved. Next time I am in the mood for Chinese, I will be trying somewhere different.
"I'd like to give China Moon, 3.5 stars but that's not an option and I cannot round up on this one...It's not a bad option for Chinese takeout. It's a small step up from most strip-mall options, as they make everything from scratch, every time an order is placed. They don't even keep a put of soup in the back - it's made fresh each time.

The hot and sour soup is the best I've found nearby. The prices are low and the portions plentiful. Twice now I've gotten the curry chicken and both times the onion to chick ratio was WAY off. Like, there was an entire onion and maybe 3oz of chicken. No bueno. 

It's the best option on my side of town so I will definitely be back!"

China Moon is hands down the best Chinese food we've had in orlando. The owners are awesome and they obviously care a lot both about their customers and their food. Their krab rangoons, orange chicken, egg drop soup, wonton soup, Buddha's delight, fried rice- anything we've ever gotten from there has yet to disappoint. Their orange chicken especially has a great thick & mild glaze to it that sets it apart from any I've tried in the past. When in there last time, we asked what these guys do on their day off and they spend their days off prepping- you can tell their food is made with dedication & care & from the taste and consistency, it is obviously never frozen. Our first choice for Chinese in the orlando area is always China moon.

"This place was pretty damn delicious. We tried a whole medley of stuff - the eggplant, Singapore crab, seafood fried rice. Everything was excellent. The crab was outstanding - succulent, generous (though I would have appreciated being told the market price was about twice the cost of a regular entree before ordering). The hot and sour soup was both, and an interesting change-up from the usual formulation of the dish.

Service was also good - a bit slow with the water, but on the other hand they were not in a rush to kick us out even though we were the last in the place one night.

Decor is pleasant, tables are spaced well (a pet peeve of mine) so you can have a group and not feel too cramped, or that you're on top of the next diners.

We walked in late-ish on a Monday night and stay right down, but I'd guess that weekends are pretty busy judging by the fact that there were plenty of diners there when we arrived (not a traditionally big eat-out night)."

"Food 7/10
Service 7/10
Value 7/10
Atmosphere 7/10

Entrance 

We had been to this restaurant a few times before. This time was unexpected. We were out to study but since we were hungry, we decided to have a early dinner at 5pm and study afterwards. The restaurant was well decorated with tropical plants and cultural artifacts that reminded me of South East Asia. We were quickly seated and brought water.

Food

The food was good as always. However, I am only speaking from a perspective of someone who has never tried Malaysian cuisine in Malaysia. What I have been eating may not be considered authentic by other Malaysians but to my taste buds the food was good. One thing I have tried before was the Singapore Laksa in Singapore. Comparing what I had in Singapore to what I was served here brought up many differences. The Laksa served here in Banana Leaf was alot more creamy than the one I have tried in Singapore. The taste difference is dramatic because the deep Laksa taste is hidden in the Banana Leaf Restaurant. In my opinion the Laksa in Singapore tasted alot better but I can see some people liking the Banana Leaf Laksa more because it is less of an adventure. As for all the other foods I have no idea how authentic they are but Banana Leaf claims to cook authentic food. I doubt that though.

Overall

The food was good, service was good, the atmosphere was good. I go back every now and then. It's alot better than the Boat House in English Bay... Trust me."

"I went here with some friends after showing one of them around this neighborhood (she just moved a month ago). On a Friday night, a party of 3 still had to wait for about 20-30 minutes without a reservation, and this is the largest of their branches. 

It kind of figures given that the food is really good and fairly reasonable. Banana Leaf is a Malaysian-Singaporean restaurant - the decor is kind of chintzy with a lot of blue, green and red going on (and this isn't a store trying to sell computer monitors, I swear!) as well as TVs showing sports (which makes this feel like a gym was set up in your mom's living room during the 1970s), but the service is always polite and the drinks flow freely. I started out with a fresh coconut, which is a young coconut with the coconut water, while my friends each had some BC reds (a Burrowing Owl merlot and Petales D'Osoyoos, indicating a good repertoire of wines). 

Then came the appetizer, which was murtabak. Murtabak is a roti that was stuffed with meat, eggs and bean sprouts, among other things. They're kind of like the Singaporean equivalent of panini but the bread is much flakier (think of a naan meets filo pastry), there's no cheese and it's okay to have air in the middle, and it comes with a curry sauce like roti canai (a light curry sauce that seems to have a beef-ish base). Very good! A good introduction for three people.

We then proceeded to split three entrees - tiger prawns with peppercorns (which was spicy and a bit salty, which reminded me of the deep-fried shrimp with chili peppers that's popular in many Chinese restaurants), curry chicken with vegetables (which was quite Singaporean in style as it was a very turmeric-ijnspired yellow that was a bit watery, indicating less of an impact of coconut milk), and Singapore laksa (a seafood noodle soup that you really should order if you like anything with coconut milk, fish, or seafood... it's just a hearty bowl of spice and marine flavor that happens to be my favorite dish. The laksa quality is going downhill, though - no limes, few bean sprouts, and the sambal laksa is getting grained out in the broth. 

However, the restaurant is still excellent. The coconut's $5, a glass of those wines was $12 (but they have cheaper ones to offer), murtabak is $8, shrimp were $17, curry $15, and laksa $13. We took some of the food home as leftovers and I knwo for a fact that a bowl of laksa can feed one for dinner quite easily. 

A yummy Friday night!"
Although my experience with Malaysian cuisine is somewhat limited, my experience at the Banana Leaf restaurant in Kitsilano was fantastic!  After ordering a pitcher of brew, my friend and I settled in for tender, flavourful lamb skewers with an amazing spicy peanut sauce along with sambal chili fried okra, eggplant and green beans that brought veggies to a whole new level and the amazing 'abundance of seafood in assam curry sauce', with fresh clams, mussels, prawns, scallops, squid and fish simmering in a pungent, spicy broth, a welcome respite on a blustery day.  The service was friendly and attentive and the everything for the 2 of us came in under 70 dollars.  I will absolutely be back when a craving for Malaysian kicks in!
"Highly recommend this restaurant over the one near Broadway and Oak. This restaurant has much better ambiance and more spacious. Aside from the good food, there's patio seating outside. And cushy booths near the back of the restaurant.

If you're going with a party of 6, I'd suggest that you ask for a booth, but just not the last one near the kitchen (a bit too noisy).

Hope this helps anyone who is considering booking this place for a party/gathering."

"I love, love Malaysian food. I find it is so exotic and delectable. One of may favourite places is the Kits location of Banana Leaf.

One of the advantages of a big group is getting to try as many dishes as possible. We dined out large on all the fine Malaysian offerings. I love roti, the simple break/wrap/tortia like side.

All the dishes were great, espicially the seafood ones. I enjoyed the tasty sauces from the lamb, shreeded beef, fish, and mussels. Everything was splendidly delicious and filling.

The deep-fired salted prawns was probably my favourite dish. It was so delicious and crunchy. We did a number there with so many different dishes trying the gambit of what they had to offer.

I love the boat like bowls that are easy to serve. All the interesting, meaty sauces are great for rice and dipping. Deep-friend banana with ice cream is always an enjoyable desert. It hits the spot just right.

It was one of the more delicious, satisfying meals in a long time. You cannot go wrong with the Malaysian cuisine at Banana Leaf. However, it can get pricey."
This was my first time here and i loved it. The service wasn't the best at first but they did resolve it well and were very nice. The food was delicious without question. I definitely recommend coming here.
Delicious Malaysian food - everything melts in your mouth and zaps your taste-buds with incredible flavours. But don't expect much in the way of service. The staff here are simply 'doing their job' and somewhat reluctantly at that.
This is my favourite SE Asian restaurant in town. Love the fried eggplants, pineapple rice, mussels and  curried seafood of any kind. I bring my visitors from the US here and have never failed to impress them.
We've been vacationing in Vancouver for a week now, and already we've made three visits to Banana Leaf. Every time we've had nothing but great good, but by now we'd learned to pace ourselves so we're not bursting at the seams when we leave. This time we ordered the Nonya's chicken lettuce wraps, Alaskan Black Cod (which we've had on all three occasions), and the Seafood and Chicken Fried Rice. We also shared a young coconut drink between three of us. The cocunut drink had a great, refreshing flavour, and we were so occupied with digging for and eating the meat of the coconut that we didn't even think about what we'd ordered until it arrived. Again, the Black Cod failed to disappoint. The ginger and garlic sauce tasted delicious  and the fish was cooked perfectly. Today was our first time ordering the lettuce wraps, and it will not be our last. If you're a fan of lettuce wraps, you will fall in love with these. Lastly, my favourite dish would have to be the Seafood and Chicken Fried Rice. It was served in a cute pineapple boat and consisted of fried rice, shrimp, scallops, squid, chicken, egg, corn, raisins, and sunflower seeds. Some of the tastiest fried rice I've had. The bill ended up being around $60 for three of us, but it was well worth it.  I'd definitely say Banana Leaf is worth a try.

"Wow I think I just found the best Malaysian cuisine in Vancouver..  I really enjoyed the whole experience here.  

The restaurant name ""Banana Leaf"" caught my attention and I was feeling famished so when I unhesitatingly entered the restaurant I definitely got more than I asked for.  From the outside it looks like an everyday casual restaurant but you'd be amazed by how many awards they have won. (check pic!)   and the colorful interior design is superb.  The waitors wear these ethnic aprons and of course not to mention the people love us on Yelp in the front :p  The waitor greeted us very warmly and every single staff was so accommodating and really made sure we were enjoying every minute of our dining experience.  

I was rather overwhelmed by the abundant menu choices so we ordered the 9 course dinner ($28/person)  I especially enjoyed the green beans, seafood curry and curry mussels!  They were all cooked to absolute perfection.  The satay with dipping sauces were heavenly as well.  Just be aware, that the 9 course dinner is really filling so you might have to to take some home because you cannot go home without eating dessert.

Last but not least the Fried banana with ice cream was scrumptious and a good way to end dinner.  Presentation was great as well.  I would not say this is fine dining but definitely not so casual either, somewhere in between is right.  

Needless to say for the comment card I ticked Excellent for pretty much every criteria.  Next time will bring my friends here...you should too!

Hope you enjoy the pictures of the delicious 9 course dinner I've uploaded!"

One of my all-time favorite restaurants in Vancouver.  The roti canai is fantastic (though I would ask for extra dal as the amount they give you is a little on the light side), the satays are the best I've had, and their sambal green beans, sambal prawns, and especially the fried rice served in a pineapple are outstanding.  Nice decor and good service as well, highly recommend it.
"Wow, really great experience, and great value for dine out Vancouver. Firstly, they have a dine out menu option, and for under $20 each (before drinks and tax) we were quite full.
I was really surprised by how strong the flavors and textures were across the dishes. We had fish curry (fish cooked perfectly), beef (also perfectly cooked, meat came apart effortlessly), Naan, and deep fried bananas. The drinks were good too, the ginger martini had a huge amount of ginger flavour which I love.

Overall it felt like we were dining in a restaurant that would have a much higher price point- of course, since it was the dine out menu special it was cheaper than usual. But even compared to regular banana leaf prices! 

This was not my first time dining at banana leaf - all the other times have been good, but this one really stood out.
Friendly service too!"
"We visited Banana Leaf in hopes of it curing our hangover from partying the night before, and while it did definitely take the hangover away, we ate so much food that we left feeling sick and bloated-- it's a good sign though! 

What we tried: 

Roti Canai - This was what we were looking forward to the most! Soft and buttery insides, but also crispy on the outside with a satisfying flakiness to it, this was the perfect appetizer. A bit sweeter than I typically prefer it, but the roti definitely lived up to the expectations. We ate it down in minutes, but I wished I had saved some for the beef rendang curry that came later. For $8 though a few more pieces of roti would've been nice!
Rating: 5/5

Beef Rendang - As a Sri Lankan it definitely tasted like home, nice and spicy with the Malaysian flavours really exploding here. The best part was the tender juicy beef that just fell apart with the touch of a spoon. We had this with a side of rice and was a delicious addition to our meal. It was just too much curry so I would recommend sharing it with more than 2 hungry people!
Rating: 4

Nasi Goreng - Having eaten Nasi Goreng growing up, I was expecting a lot out of this dish and it was definitely a reminder of my parent's kitchen. A bit more tomatoey than I'm used to, and a bit sweet as well, next time I order it I would probably ask for more shrimp chili paste. It was highly addictive and I kept going back for more. The pickled cabbage on the side was a nice touch, especially when in need of a palate cleanser. A decent amount of protein and shrimp in there as well. As per the tradition, a fried egg on top served on a banana leaf would complete this popular dish in my opinion. 
Rating 4/5

See you soon, Banana Leaf!"
"I really love this place- even thoguht they always seem to laugh a little when I order ""very spicy""... The food is consitenly very good and sometimes great- keeps us coming back for more. The full dinners are a slamming deal- two people could easily get two meals out of em! 5 stars for the very consistent food at very reasonable prices"

Our favourites that we always order are Singapore chili crab, laksa and char kuey teow. You might want to reserve your crab when you book your table, just so they have enough. "The first trip to the restaurant was pretty good. I had Nasi Goreng which I chose for further nostalgic reasons - my mother (or at least her cook) used to make the BEST nasi goreng. If you don't know what it is, it's basically Malaysian/Indonesian fried rice with beef, shrimp, egg, tomato, onion & green bean. I may have been slightly unfair by ordering this dish, since my standard was set by the authentic cooking of my Indonesian maid. I ended up finding the rice 'okay'... slightly boring and lacking of the true taste of Indonesia. My significant other ordered the Rendang Beef Curry, boneless lean beef stewed to melting tenderness in coconut gravy and spices - a dish which I found 'okay' as well. The meat was decent, the spices again a bit lacking. I don't know how else to describe the experience other than 'OKAY'.

"Where to take my most well-traveled friend who has a family-style eating preference for dinner when she comes to visit? Why, Banana Leaf of course.

South Asian dishes with a Malaysian bent, the food here is consistently and mouthwateringly delicious. If food with a little kick is your kind of thing, then your taste buds will not be deprived here. Complex without overwhelming, the flavours are perfectly balanced in every dish I've ordered. And order I have: Assam curry scallops, dungeness crab in kum hoeing sauce, Alaskan black cod in ginger sauce, braised lamb shank in cumin and star anise, sambal fried okra, nasi goring -- the list goes on and on. 

An ideal place to bring friends from out of town, the energetic vibe at Banana Leaf is the perfect partner for the unofficial family-style that the dishes lend themselves to. All in all, a super satisfying evening out."

"First time checking out the Kits location, not too busy when we arrived around 12:30pm today, so we were able to take our time enjoying our food. We were the last ones to leave before their lunch operations closed (at 2:30) to re-open again at 5pm. Overall, the ambiance was very relaxing.

We ordered mainly from their lunch special menu - Roti Canai, Singapore Laksa, Satay Chicken and Gado-Gado with Rice, and Tiger Prawns with Gulai Sauce. And for dessert Mango Sticky Rice and Coconut Crepes. All this for two people - le'ts just say we were pretty satisfied by the end of lunch. =)

If it's your first time trying Malaysian food, I would recommend the Roti Canai (so fluffy! and with the curry sauce that it comes with...yum!) and Satay Chicken and Gado-Gado with Rice (unless you're allergic to peanuts, then don't get this since it comes with a peanut dressing). The Singapore Laksa is a noodle dish that comes in a coconut soup base - tasty, but I think it was a little bit too rich for my personal preference. The Tiger Prawns I give were a 3.5/5 - good, but I think my attention was too focused on the Roti and Satay chicken. =P

Now on to desserts. Between the Coconut Crepes (which are green, fyi) and the Mango Stick Rice, both of which are veryyy good, I'd have to say my vote is for the Coconut Crepes - these are served nice and warm with the stuffed shreddings inside giving it a nice texture. Give it a try!"
"My friend and I just stumbled upon this restaurant by chance. We were driving through the area looking for something to eat and this area caught our eye. Street parking was surprisingly easy for a Friday night. 

There were a couple parties ahead of us, but not too long of a wait for 2 people. We ordered steamed mussels in Cumin & Ginger sauce. It was delicious! They were pretty generous with the number of mussels. The sauce flavor really simmered into the mussels.

We also ordered Seafood Char Kuey Teow. It wasn't too spicy, enough to give the dish a small kick. The last item we ordered was the Sambal Green Bean (gotta eat them veggies!) and they were sauteed just right, enough crunch but cooked with a hint of spice.

The service was fast and friendly. The atmosphere is good for having conversation, you can actually hear each other!"

"""Dont order the prawns,"" those were the first words I said when I walked in the door to my bf. The smell was subtle but I knew that smell, its bad prawns. Its hard to mistake when you've smelled it before. Anyways, regardless of my slight apprehension we sat down and were instantly man-handled by our server... ok not literally but the guy was not all that impressive. Two or three times my bf tried to hail him from our table for more water, or a dessert menu, or our check and he either blatantly ignored us or just didn't care that much. 

The food wasn't bad, it was wednesday and it was obvious they were scraping the bottom of the bucket of their curry. It had been microwaved, you could tell by the texture I didn't fault them for it since the flavour was definitely there and tasty. The mussels were quite good, full of spice and wonderfull flavours, but only 1 piece of bread. Hm. Now I don't know about you but the sauce that mussels come in is just as good as teh mussels. So we ordered extra rice to pour it on and were happy with that.

Prices were ok. The coconut milk steamed rice was tasty and went perfectly with our choices, $2 for about a cup of rice... and mind you no rice comes with curry so you have to order it. The mussels and curry itself wasn't bad either, we didn't get drinks and our bill came to about $37. So we were fed, happy and walking around kitsilano quickly thereafter.

Not bad for a quick bite."
Yay for eating in Vancouver! You can see the good nutrition on the fresh faces of this city's residents.. people all look like they've just come out of a Tide commercial or something.. vibrant.. and the reason in my humble opinion is constant access to organic and locally sourced foods. This restaurant is no exception. Right on Broadway and easy access, plus open on Sundays which little is in that more business oriented part of the city, this spot bustles. The decor as mentioned is bright and inviting, the lunch specials are CHEAP and the repas all fresh and easy to customize. I love the Malaysian flavors, nice curries and plenty of egg and fish.. If you're in the area, I wouldn't miss this spot, but then again you're in Vancouver so almost anywhere you duck in, you'll find enticing local eats that keep the engine on high-functioning.

"Recently had their curry laksa here for lunch. It was quite good, the soup is nicely flavoured with coconut milk, turmeric and other spices. The bean sprouts was not cooked which is perfect because by the time I start eating my soup, it was somewhat crunchy and slightly cooked. There were some boneless chicken bits along with half an egg. They used vermicelli although generally a type of yellow noodle (skinnier than Shanghai noodle) is also used.

The level of spiciness was mild to medium and the overall flavour was decent. It wasn't overly salty."
"We finally got to try one of the Banana Leaf restaurants, and we weren't disappointed. The rating is mainly for the food.

This location is bright, with tall ceilings, and not overly noisy. I was glad there wasn't any music blaring. The Banana Leaf is clean, with just enough atmosphere and decorations to give it some Malay flavour.

The food and mixed drinks were delicious. Each dish was well spiced and flavourful, without using too much oil. The portions were also generous, and this place is a good value at lunch time. The mixed drinks were all well received, too, and I enjoyed my lychee mojito. 

Service was prompt, and the food made it to our table rather quickly, even on a fairly busy lunch rush. 

The only downsides are a. many dishes contain shrimp and/or  seafood, so people with allergies might have issues and b. the servers, while providing quick service, seemed impersonal and bored. 

I'll look forward to trying a Banana Leaf lunch again."

"Came in and noticed it was quite busy. We were placed in the room area which was significantly quieter than the rest of the restaurant (hurray!). There was only one server handling the entire room which made it difficult to get help etc, but he tried his best. He was always prompt in asking if we needed a refill, if the food was ok etc. 

- The asian fruit salad was delicious! I liked it way more than their regular papaya salad. I'd happily order this every time.

- The nasi goreng had the flavor but the eggs were burnt on it (actual black on it).

- The boneless chicken curry was DELICIOUS! Never ordered it before but I really liked it. It was a tad too spicy for my liking but I'll ask them to tone it down next time. I usually hate okra but I liked it in this dish. My partner, on the other hand, didn't like this dish. She ate the nasi goreng mostly.

The biggest disappointment was the hot and sour soup. The chef seemed to have no quality control tonight (as noted above with the burnt egg) because the soup was goopy. The thickener wasn't thoroughly mixed in and the soup was just blobs the size of my spoon. I had to send it back because I had no intention of choking down blobs of thickener (or whatever it was). 

We weren't wowed by our dinner. I usually look forward to my meals here but this time I left disappointed by the quality. I don't think I'll be back for some time."

"Came here on a Wednesday night for a dinner with family. 

Atmosphere: The interior space was decorated really nicely. Seating was spacious (we were seated in booths) and tables were wide enough to accommodate a fair amount of plates. The furnishing and decoration was also well chosen. However, it was pretty dim in there; the lack of lighting made it pretty hard to A) take photos and B) read the menu.

Service: Service was honestly a disappointment. Our water was only refilled when we were about to pay our bill, and when our waiter was taking our order, he didn't say anything, just wrote down our orders and left without a word. When servers dropped our food off at the table, they would quietly announce the name of the dish and leave straight after. No hospitality here, unfortunately.

Food: Now, the food was the star of the night. Must-try's at Banana Leaf are the roti canai (perfectly buttery but still flaky), the skewers (we had the beef and chicken skewers -- delicious!), the sambal green beans (addicting), the pineapple fried rice (I need this recipe), the chicken wings (crispy and flavorful!) and the turmeric cauliflower rice (I could NOT stop eating this). Every dish was delicious and full of flavour.

Overall, I would come back here, but only for the food. Service was lacking and the atmosphere was okay."

"//OVERALL THOUGHTS//
Being born & raised in Malaysia, I think I have a good idea of what real Malaysian food is. I've eaten at Banana leaf a couple of occasions now and my final verdict is that it's a good place to sample some Malaysian foods... everything is tasty, but don't expect a great amount of authenticity since a lot of the flavours have been Westernized. 

//THE FOOD//
Nasi lemak - didn't have any sambal sauce. shrimp was the best, peanuts was meh (it should be roasted for extra flavour), and the calamari was alright. The banana leaf it was on wasn't fresh thus it had no fragrance to it. 

Singaporean laksa - too much coconut milk, too thick/creamy, spiciness was on point, but the fish cake, chicken & shrimp was below mediocre. The chicken and shrimp weren't flavourful and the fish cake was limp and felt like it was made of a lot of fillers. It had all the ingredients of a laksa, was yummy for the most part, but it just wasn't totally right! 

Roti - sweeter than what I'm used to but I'm into it ! 
Satay - the chicken satay was not bad ! The peanut sauce is also sweeter than what it should be, but it was still yummy to eat! 

Beef rendang- only 3 pieces of meat and not enough sauce to eat with the amount of rice and roti it came with. Not impressed."
"I've eaten here a few times - and it's always been amazing. The food is always great, the atmosphere is cool - kind of feels like you're in a jungle, and the servers are attentive.

"Haven't had Malaysian food in awhile, so this place filled my craving!! 

PAPAYA SALAD - I always love ordering papaya salad. The way Banana Leaf makes it is refreshing and great way to cleanse your palate. 

CALAMARI - Great appetizer. Instead of tartar sauce, however, it is server with another brown sauce... not quite sure the name, but it was great! (Not BBQ sauce) 

PINEAPPLE FRIED RICE - not going to lie, I was a bit disappointed. It weren't as flavourful and amazing as I remember them to be... sort of on the bland side. 

MEE GORENG - it's a bit spicy! Very filling. I would order again! 

EGGPLANT FRIES - My favourite dish of the meal! Deep fried eggplant, making each bite quite light and juicy - compared to heavy potatoes. Even my dinner mates who HATE eggplant loved it!! Comes with Thai sweet chilli sauce drizzled over the top.

Would recommend coming for happy hour! From 8:30-close, they have a deal where if you order Mee Goreng/pineapple rice, and other dishes, you get ""Buy One, take home for free""! This is great if you need an extra dish to pack for lunch the next day. In other words, you get 2 dishes for the price of ~$15!!! Such a steal."

"A solid choice for Malaysian grub.

We visited late one vending for dinner and although the place was jamming, we were seated almost immediately. Place was neatly decorated with lots of live plants and hints of Asian flare.

"It had been a few years since I was last at a Banana Leaf and so happy that they still have tasting menus...yes that is plural as one can choose from a 6 course up to a 10 course.  These are great options for those that wish to sample many dishes.  It was a birthday dinner so we opted for the 10 course tasting menu as it included lobster tail.  The room is large with plenty of natural light and the service was quite good. 

Now for the food.  The presentation and taste of each dish was outstanding...so many different flavours in each dish.  We started with a light mango salad followed with chicken satay and the roti canai...a perfect start to a  meal.  This was followed in quick succession with cumin mussels, scallops in a curry broth, and lobster tails with chilli & garlic.  The next three dishes were the caramelized ginger sablefish (black cod), green beans and eggplant in a sambal sauce and the classic rendang beef.  Rice was served in a banana leaf.  We eventually made our way through all the food and dessert was served, pisang goreng (deep fried bananas with ice cream).

I thought it was good value at $38 per person given the variety of dishes served which included so much seafood.  The flavours of each dish are so unique, but have to say the lobster tail and sablefish were outstanding and worth a return visit.

With the great service and excellent food, it was a very positive food experience and happy to recommend Banana Leaf."

"Banana Leaf Kits is one of my go to places.

Sitting right below the kind of price that I think one would normally pay for food of this quality, the Banana Leaf delivers both the tastiness and eating experience that keeps me bringing guests here. 

I think more than the other locations (Denman is ok but not a fan of the others), the Kits branch is the best eatery in that area and I find myself there frequently.  

Aside from really good food for decent prices something else sticks out to me: the exact kind of service I like.  Noone interrupts my conversation, but i feel they are always aware of when we need something.  I can't say that for any other place in the city.

I've had nothing I did not like here, but I think the value is in the 2 person set menu.  the breads and the green beans (of all things) stick out as memorable."
